HEADLINE: New U.N. Index Measures Nations' Quality of Life

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 20

 BODY:
The average Brazilian earns $4,718 a year, or slightly more than the $4,542 earned by the average Costa Rican. But who is really better off when the average Costa Rican lives longer, is better educated and enjoys cleaner water and better sanitation than a Brazilian?
The United Nations gives a clear answer. Its latest Human Development Index gives Costa Rica a score of .852 out of a possible 1.000, while Brazil gets only .730. 
 The index, published in a report this week by the United Nations Human Development Program, assigns Costa Rica a higher score because it has been more successful than Brazil at translating national wealth into higher living standards for its citizens, mainly by distributing it more evenly and spending it on projects that benefit more people.
Since 1990, Mahbub ul-Haq, an economist and former Pakistani Finance Minister who now works for the program, has been striving though the annual human development reports to remind the world that the real goal of development is not building impressive factories, dams and highways but insuring that individuals lead fuller lives and enjoy more choices.
The introduction of new industries often improves the living standards of people who work in them. But economic growth does not automatically translate into higher living standards, as many of the estimated one billion people in the world living below the poverty level know.
 
Index of Happiness
 Dr. Haq's Human Development Index can be viewed as a measure of human happiness based on life expectancy, educational standards and individual purchasing power. It shows what countries are doing to meet their people's basic needs: keeping them healthy, raising educational standards and helping them earn the income needed to make choices.
Among industrialized countries, Japan scores 0.983 and replaces Canada as the leading nation because of a surge in personal disposable income. Canada is rated second, followed by Norway, Switzerland and Sweden.
The United States lands in sixth place with 0.976, but the report observes a broad gap between the living standards of white Americans and those of other races.
Some developing countries, like Barbados and Uruguay, score higher than more-industrialized nations like Hungary, Bulgaria, Portugal and Poland. At the very bottom of the human development index are the poorest African countries, among them Somalia, Gambia, Mali, Guinea and Sierra Leone, where only a very few enjoy what wealth there is.
 
Income vs. Development
 This year's report shows no automatic link between a country's per-capita gross national product and its level of human development. Chile, China, Columbia, Costa Rica, Madagascar, Tanzania and Uruguay, for example, rank far higher in human development than they do in per capita income, suggesting that they are doing a good job "translating their income into the lives of their people."
But citizens of Algeria, Gabon, Saudi Arabia, South Africa and the United Arab Emirates lead less satisfactory lives than their countries' per capita income suggests they should, indicating that their wealth is concentrated in the hands of a few or is being misspent.
The report also indicates that no country treats its women as well as its men, although such inequities are not figured into the human development index itself. When the ratings are adjusted for disparities between the sexes, some countries fall sharply. Japan drops from first to 17th place and Canada from second to 11th, because women in those countries, like women in most nations, have fewer job opportunities and lower earnings than men.
In the developing world, the greatest disparities between men and women are in jobs, health care, nutrition and education.
Levels of human development can vary from state to state or from region to region within one country. In India, for example, the score for the state of Uttar Pradesh is one-third lower than the national average. The rating for the Mexican state of Oaxaca is 20 percent below the national average.
 
'Trickle Down' Economics
 The notion that global development efforts should be more closely tailored to the needs of individual human beings did not originate with the United Nations Development Program, whose chief mission is promoting the transfer of technology to developing countries.
As far back as 1973, Robert McNamara, who was then president of the World Bank, argued against the concept that the fruits of industrial growth would automatically "trickle down" to the poorest sectors of society. At an annual meeting of the bank in Nairobi, he asserted that help must be funneled directly to the 800 million people across the globe who were estimated then to be living in absolute poverty. "They do not contribute to economic growth, nor do they benefit from it," he said.
In its 1990 World Development Report, the World Bank urged nations to assign a higher priority to health care and education for the poor so that impoverished citizens could capitalize on their own ability to work.
Dr. Haq's work has not been free of controversy. Earlier human development reports contained a "freedom index" ranking countries by the personal liberties of their citizens. Such ratings were strongly protested by developing countries, which were concerned that future aid would be linked to democratic reforms.
 
Benefitting Ordinary People
 Seizing on the collapse of Communism and an increase in the number of countries holding multiparty elections, the Human Development Report argues for a new strategy aimed at insuring that economic development benefits ordinary people, and not just governments and power elites.
"People today have an urge -- an impatient urge -- to participate in the events and processes that shape their lives," the report says. Properly harnessed, this urge can become "a source of tremendous vitality and innovation."
In a foreword to the report, the program's administrator, William Draper, argues that "many of today's struggles are more than struggles for access to political power."
"They are struggles for access to the ordinary opportunities of life -- land, water, work, living space and basic social services," he writes.
The report calls for a "people-centered world order" based on new principles. Security should be redefined as security for people rather than for states, and achieved through development instead of arms, the document suggests. Global military spending has declined by $240 billion since 1987, two million soldiers have been demobilized and defense industries are expected to reduce their work forces by one quarter by 1998.
 
Retooling Defense Budgets
 Such savings should be channeled into human development projects, the report says, including the retraining of those workers and the conversion of military industry.
The report also calls for more investment in education, deregulation of business and aid to small enterprises to reverse a trend in which economies keep expanding without creating new jobs.
Governments should promote efficiency in markets as a way of raising individual living standards, the report said, and power should be decentralized, especially in the developing world.
While a quarter or more of total government spending is in the hands of city or regional authorities in the most developed countries, the figure is 10 percent or less in the third world.
Western development aid should be overhauled so that it no longer reflects cold war priorities, the report says. Rather than funneling half of all direct assistance to Israel, Egypt, Turkey, the Philippines and El Salvador, for example, the United States should spread its aid more widely and put a new emphasis on advancing human development in the poorest countries, the document suggests.
Human Development Report, 1993 can be ordered from Oxford University Press, 2001 Evans Road, Cary, N.C., 27513. The price is $17.95 per copy.

HEADLINE: DIPLOMATS ARRIVE IN HAITI FOR TALKS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 22

 BODY:
In a push to finalize an agreement on deploying an international police force in Haiti, envoys of the Clinton Administration and the United Nations arrived here today for talks with the country's military leaders.
For two weeks, diplomats have described the planned deployment of about 500 foreign police officers in Haiti as a crucial final element to reaching a negotiated settlement to this country's political crisis, which began with a violent coup against the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in September 1991. 
The drive to deploy the police force, led by the United Nations mediator for Haiti, Dante Caputo, and President Clinton's special adviser on Haitian affairs, Lawrence A. Pezzullo, has been repeatedly delayed, however, by negotiations with Father Aristide, many of whose supporters are opposed to any armed international presence in Haiti.
Diplomats also had to counter strong opposition by many of the exiled President's foes here in Haiti, who have campaigned against the deployment with strongly nationalist slogans recalling a 19-year American occupation earlier this century.
In an open letter to Father Aristide, his former planning minister, Renaud Bernadin, warned this week that the police force was offered by an American hand bathed in "the blood of the people," and was a poisoned pill aimed at giving President Aristide "the image of a national sell-out."
At the same time, a sworn opponent of Father Aristide, Marc Bazin, the country's de facto prime minister, denounced the planned deployment as part of a campaign by industrialized countries to subjugate Haiti rather than to restore democracy.
In face of this opposition, diplomats involved in seeking Father Aristide's return have warned of the high costs of rejecting the police deployment, which is intended to help end a climate of widespread violence, restore the Haitian police and set the stage for the formation of a new government that would lead to Father Aristide's return.
For Father Aristide, who diplomats say accepted the deployment only after repeatedly pushing for clarifications over its role, the implicit penalty of rejection would have been having Haiti shift from being a subject of high-priority international diplomacy to a country whose problems would soon be perceived as intractable and relatively minor in comparison with other world crises.
 
Haiti Faces New Sanctions
 For Haiti's military leaders and the civilian government they installed, however, diplomats say, the price of rejection of the plan would be harsh new economic sanctions, and the possibility of losing amnesty protections offered by President Aristide as part of the settlement.
For the Clinton Administration, which has committed itself to providing police and other personnel as well as large amounts of foreign aid under the United Nations-led effort, the cost of any failure could be high, particularly after repeated statements of confidence from Secretary of State Warren Christopher and others in Washington in recent weeks.
Even while diplomats have sought to reassure people here that the international police presence is not an armed intervention in disguise, as some have contended, there have been increasingly clear warnings of strong punitive actions should the deployment be rejected.
"There are limits to the patience of the new Administration and they are making it clear they will have to be respected here," said one diplomat who is close to the negotiations. "If not, they have made it clear that they are willing to impose some real pain."
Despite increasingly clear warnings, many Haitians have revealed a hard shell of skepticism about the international community's ability or willingness to impose a solution on a bitterly divided nation of stark class differences and weak institutions.
"Whether they want it to succeed or not, nobody here will take this thing seriously until it actually happens," said one former Government official. "There is a feeling that we have seen all of this before, from the good cop-bad cop diplomacy to the shuttle missions."

HEADLINE: Balance-Beam Politics: Giuliani's Second Try

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Time warp alert: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, was standing (looking like a G-man in a tidy dark suit), beneath a subway trestle late one night last week while several police officers swung their nightsticks, shuffled their shiny shoes and shouted over the roar of a passing train: "Heyya. Rudy. Anything for you! Yeah." and "Rudy! Hey! I gotta get your autograph for my kid!"
Mr. Giuliani, his wire-framed glasses glinting in the yellow pool of a street light, nodded warmly but continued an intense out-of-earshot discussion with a pallid assistant district attorney wearing a scruffy suit and (no kidding) a dark fedora.
 
A Thoroughly Modern Campaign
 New York. New York. Visuals from the 1930's notwithstanding, the scene beneath the train tracks was part of a thoroughly modern moment in a thoroughly modern mayoral campaign. 
 Behind the candidate, the Council of the Jewish Organizations of Borough Park was letting out, spilling hundreds of Hasidic men in drab suits and dark hats into the cool spring air while their wives -- who were segregated behind a screen during the meal and the address by Mr. Giuliani -- gathered up their skirts and pocketbooks and said their fond goodbyes.
Hours earlier, Mr. Giuliani had met with some of the city's most powerful Jewish business and religious leaders at a dinner in midtown.
And the next morning he would stand on the steps of City Hall -- on Mayor David N. Dinkins's doorstep, if you will -- to clasp hands with a dozen or so black Republicans and welcome their support. At other times last week the candidate ate kimchi and listened to a Korean tenor sing Italian opera, and did a "flying drop by," in the words of his communications director, Richard Bryers, at an event held by the Hispanic Federation.
"This is not an election about race," any staff member of the Giuliani campaign will tell you. It is, they say, a thoroughly modern campaign about bringing the city together.
But in New York, that does mean it's about race, and ethnicity, and cultural differences and even who marches with whom in city parades.
 
Lost by 2 Percentage Points
 Rudolph William Giuliani lost his bid for Mayor by two percentage points in 1989. The former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who had gone after such financial luminaries as Ivan Boesky, had turned down an offer from the Reagan Administration to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, and had sidestepped an approach to head the F.B.I., the jut-jawed tough guy whose record was described in New York magazine in 1987 as "probably unmatched in the distinguished history of the office," lost to the man he now hopes to unseat.
He now says he was ready to govern then, to balance a $30 billion budget and put together a team that could handle any crisis. But he was not ready, he conceded, for the quirky realities of campaigning in a city of more than seven million, for the pounding debates, the complexities and the balancing acts that every good New York City campaign entails.
"I didn't even really start running last time until August," Mr. Giuliani said on Thursday while driving from Brooklyn to Manhattan and one last late-night meeting with his political strategist, David Garth. Last time, he said, he did not make up his mind to run until some time in late March or early April. It took him another four or five months to get his team in place. This time, he said, he knew he would run on the evening of his narrow defeat, Nov. 7, 1989.
 
Already Running Hard
 So Memorial Day has not even come and gone yet, and Rudy Giuliani is already running hard. He quit his private law practice. He opened a second suite of offices at his campaign headquarters at 355 Lexington Avenue. He has a paid staff of 20 and scores of volunteers. He has more than $3 million in the bank, compared with the $200,000 he had raised by this time four years ago. He has issues advisers and ethnic advisers and media advisers and more. He even has hangers-on. Curtis Sliwa, the controversial head of the controversial Guardian Angels, follows in the candidate's wake, wearing his trademark windbreaker and red beret.
So oiled is this machine that Mr. Giuliani has even ordered posters aimed at Hispanic voters that are identical to those printed in English (RUDY!), with but one subtle yet significant change, the inverted exclamation point that appears in Spanish: RUDY!
At a midweek lunch in Manhattan, two of Mr. Giuliani's staff members complained about a headline in The New York Times that emphasized the results of a poll that showed a deep divide in voting preferences among black and white New Yorkers. They reiterated the campaign's basic point, that this is not a race about race and said that to depict it as such is needlessly inflammatory.
But moments later Mr. Bryers pointed to a chart printed alongside the poll results. It showed 48 percent of black Protestants backing Andrew Stein over Mr. Giuliani, whom the poll showed with 24 percent of that population's vote. "We can work with that," said Mr. Bryers, presumably indicating that if Mr. Stein were not to run, those were voters who could move to the Giuliani column.
The conversation turned to the difficulty some voters have with Mr. Giuliani's name, which spelled phonetically would be something like: JOO-lee-ah-nee. Kenneth Frydman, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary (who pronounces his name FREED-man), placed a notebook on the table. "We'd really rather have the pronouncer spelled like this," he said, then scribbled: "JEWLIANI."
In a city filled with neighborhoods, clubs and social groups that often define themselves by race, religion and ethnicity it is, perhaps, impossible to run a campaign in which the theme of race is absent.
Yet Mr. Giuliani tries. At business luncheons and fund-raising dinners he walks gingerly around the topic -- even when asked direct questions about it. His news releases speak of a "multiparty fusion movement" that proposes to be blind to partisan politics and issues of race, ethnicity and anything else that goes beyond the simple question of whether a candidate has enough of a moral compass to lead.
 
Three Basic Facts
 At stop after stop he tells his listeners that it does not matter if they are white or black, gay or straight. He says, instead, that New Yorkers' rights are basic rights built on three basic facts. "What matters," he said Thursday night at a fund-raiser in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, "is that we are human, that we are Americans and that we are New Yorkers. That is where we get our basic rights."
But first, a man in the front row had made the whole hall ring with laughter when, after the candidate ticked off the special-interest groups that he said wanted special treatment (blacks, gays, Jews, Hispanics, Pakistanis and on and on), the man yelled out: "Hey! Rudy! I'm Arab! You left us out!"
The candidate missed a beat and his already pale face went to a lighter shade of pale beneath his plastered-down dark hair, then he laughed, too, and shrugged as though to say, "See what I mean?"
It is a serious business, though, this business of not alienating anyone in a city in which no one likes to feel left out. Mr. Dinkins promised to bring everyone into an urban "mosaic" in which each group would have a place of its own honor.
That message still resonates. And it is one that Mr. Giuliani has adopted, using it now against its originator, subtly alluding to the racial and ethnic strife that has occasionally flared in Mr. Dinkins's tenure.
Since the mayor is black, the touchiness over the issue extends to the doors of Gracie Mansion, making it a delicate matter to raise without threat of a backfire. Mr. Giuliani's staffers grouse that when the Republican candidate attacked Mr. Dinkins for being bad at math, the Dinkins campaign responded that the comment was a barely veiled racial slur. The Giuliani staff vehemently denies that the remark had any such overtones and fires back that the Dinkins administration was intentionally quick on the draw.
 
Trying to Out-Dinkins Dinkins
 So Mr. Giuliani must try to out-Dinkins Mr. Dinkins. He made a step toward that goal Friday with his announcement that Susan D. Alter, a Democratic councilwoman from Brooklyn, had joined his ticket to run for City Council President.
Since Ms. Alter and her husband, Gilbert Klaperman, an influential rabbi from Long Island, were among the first prominent Jewish political figures to back Mr. Dinkins in 1989, the departure had to have hit particularly hard. "It was a beautiful hope," Ms. Alter said of Mr. Dinkins's promises of 1989. But now, she said, she places that hope with Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Giuliani has reached out, too, to Herman Badillo, a Democrat, whom he hopes to back as Comptroller. Mr. Badillo, however, is taking his time with that decision. Political fusion may work in news releases, but he is leery of burning his party bridges.
It is difficult, with all these pressures, to keep the voters' eyes on issues. It is also difficult to frame them for an audience that includes some of the most powerful and well-educated voters in the country.
At a luncheon Thursday, Mr. Giuliani spoke at length, and in detail, about the city's economic situation, its crime problems and the city schools. As the main speaker at a meeting of the Citizens Budget Commission at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, he faced an audience of stockbrokers, business leaders, economists and financiers.
Outlining a plan to reduce the city government's size, he made comparisons with the budget of 10 years ago and said the city needed to trim its personnel by 3 to 5 percent "across the board" through attrition in government jobs. "New York City has to get control of its expenditures," he said, then ticked off several examples of how to do so.
 
A Demanding Audience
 The speech was both smooth and professional. But his audience was hard. Several men chatted about Mr. Giuliani's performance and his proposals as they left. They were not kind.
"You don't freeze across the board," said a man wearing a perfectly tailored pin-striped suit and a pair of tortoise shell glasses. "You have to target your freezes. At least we have learned that."
Mr. Giuliani, meanwhile, has learned how difficult it is to run for the top job in a city that includes voters who get their night's sleep on hot-air grates as well as the men and women who run some of the largest corporations in the world.
"Last time, I think I didn't really appreciate how hard it is," Mr. Giuliani said reflectively. "It's New York. It's a tough city."
He has learned, though, to start early and play tough. So from one stop to the next, from Hasidic neighborhoods to Hispanic festivals, black churches to Fifth Avenue cocktail parties with the city's WASP elite, he spreads his message and his name. As he quipped recently, "I'm like the movie trailer: 'Coming soon to your neighborhood -- maybe next week.' "
He has not formally announced his candidacy. That will come in time. Meanwhile, he is working on his slate, repeating his warnings that education is about "reading, writing, arithmetic and computer training," and reminding any New Yorker who will listen that this election is not about race. Really.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Need to Remain Steadfast Is Stressed at Fordham
commencement yesterday on its Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. The university conferred 1,449 bachelor's degrees, 1,524 master's degrees, 131 doctorates and 429 J.D. degrees.
Separate diploma ceremonies for the individual schools followed and will continue through tomorrow evening with ceremonies for the School of Law and the Graduate School of Social Service at Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall.

 BODY:
 Peter Steinfels, who writes about religion for The New York Times, addressed the assembly on the importance of historically religious institutions to the social structure and the institutions' mandate to avoid their secularization.
"The dividing line in Catholic higher education today is between those institutions determined to face these questions and those who prefer to avoid them, proceeding with a calculated ambiguity or by simple default," he said.
Mr. Steinfels received an honorary doctor of letters degree, as did Margaret O'Brien Steinfels, editor in chief of Commonweal magazine and wife of Mr. Steinfels, and Robert V. Remini, a professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago.
The other honorary degree recipients were Msgr. Myles M. Bourke, pastor emeritus of Corpus Christi Church in Manhattan, who received an honorary doctor of humane letters; Bert W. M. Twaalfhoven, a 1952 graduate of the Fordham College of Business Administration and president and founder of N. V. Indivers in Amsterdam, who received an honorary doctor of laws, and Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, who received an honorary doctor of fine arts.
 
Marist College
 Marist College honored 760 bachelor's and 139 master's degree recipients yesterday at its 47th commencement.
An honorary doctor of humane letters was awarded to Orin Lehman, the New York State Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, who announced his resignation from that post last Tuesday. Gene E. Likens, the director of the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, N.Y., and vice president of the New York Botanical Garden, was awarded an honorary doctor of science degree.
The actor James Earl Jones delivered the commencement address and received an honorary doctor of fine arts degree.
 
University of Texas at Austin
 Robert M. Berdal, president of the University of Texas at Austin, delivered the main address yesterday at the university's 110th commencement. He became the university's 25th president last month. He conferred degrees on 5,800 undergraduate, graduate and professional students at the ceremony held on the terrace in front of the Main Building.
 
Southern Methodist
 Marian Wright Edelman, founder and president of the Children's Defense Fund, spoke to 2,450 undergraduate, graduate and professional students yesterday at Southern Methodist University's 78th commencement.
"On the eve of a new century and millennium, a new civil war is raging at home as the dangerous triplets of racial intolerance , economic insecurity and violence spread across America," she said in a speech at Moody Coliseum on the Dallas campus. "Unless confronted forthrightly, they will stain our social fabric indelibly, fray our national bonds, and undermine our ideals, domestic safety and future." She was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree.
Others receiving honorary degrees were: Michael Stewart Brown and Joseph Leonard Goldstein, Nobel-Prize winning molecular geneticists, and Kenneth Prewitt, senior vice-president of the Rockefeller Foundation.

HEADLINE: How a Tax Change Could Help Small Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding Amar Bhide's article (Viewpoints, May 9), I agree with Government's inability to help small business. My experience shows how Government hurts but suggests how it could also help.
Back in, I think, 1981, the I.R.S. rules for paying estimated corporate taxes were changed to require acceleration of the prepayment of those estimated taxes. Formerly the rule for prepayment was something like "at least 80 percent of the next year's estimate, but no greater than you paid in the preceding year." It meant that a fast-track company with a low income base could defer its payments. This change was all part of a process to accelerate the payment of taxes. However, the change siphoned funds from all fast-track companies. 
 Consider an emerging company with zero or low income in one year and rapid growth the next. Under the changed rule, my own company (tripling in sales each year) had to prepay more than $1 million of taxes each year -- a direct reduction of the working capital we needed to expand the business.
Restoration of this procedure might well be one of the few things that Government could do to help emerging companies.
 
DONALD S. HUTCHINSON
Sudbury, Mass., May 10

HEADLINE: Does Bond Buying Really Show Confidence?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Like President Clinton, Floyd Norris is incorrect on two counts when he reads the willingness to buy long-term bonds as "no better indication of confidence of a society in its industrial and financial system" (Market Watch, May 9). Two headlines in The New York Times that day -- "Confidence in Clinton Is Slipping Among Many Business Leaders" and "Three Decades of Dwindling Hope for Prosperity -- Monthly Surveys Mask a Deep Gloom" -- challenge his assessment. 
 Witness, good news on the economy, output or job creation causes bond market downturns and pulls down the equity markets because of fears of rising interest rates. In the 1980's, analysts and commentators began using the phrase "Good news is bad and bad news is good" to describe causes for market moves.
Mr. Norris implies that investors in long-term bonds hold them to maturity, hence their economic value. But surely the days of wealthy individuals and funds investing in 30-year bonds and "clipping coupons" are long gone. Today's underwriters typically re-engineer such bonds, stripping their principal and interest features, repackage them and/or use the bonds as trading vehicles.
Economists will quibble. But as your other headlines indicate and various Government surveys report, investor and consumer confidence on Wall Street and Main Street is worrisomely negative on the ability of companies to expand earnings and create jobs.
 
ERNEST NOUNOU
New York, May 10

HEADLINE: U.S. and Europe Have Different Balkan Aims

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"While Europe Stalls . . . " (editorial, May 12) states that it is a "mystery" why the governments of Western Europe are unwilling to take any action to assist the United States in the Bosnian crisis. I do not believe there is any mystery; the governments of Western Europe simply do not share a common interest with the Unites States in resolving this crisis.
The crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina is a result of the disintegration of Yugoslavia. Without a central Yugoslav government to mediate disputes among Serbs, Croats and Muslims, civil war became virtually inevitable. This was particularly true in Bosnia, where more than half the population is composed of Serbs and Croats, but Muslims control the government. 
 Much of the blame for the collapse of Yugoslavia lies with the governments of Western Europe, principally Germany. The European Community, led by Germany, rushed headlong to accord recognition to the breakaway republics of Slovenia and Croatia without any consideration to the bloody civil war that was the inevitable consequence of the breakup of Yugoslavia. It should not come as any mystery that the governments of Western Europe are now unwilling to remedy the disaster for which they are, in large measure, responsible.
What was the interest of the European Community in helping foster the disintegration of Yugoslavia? I believe it was simple economic self-interest. "East Europe's Low Wages Luring Manufacturers From West Europe"(front page, May 11), about the vast investments Western European manufacturers are making throughout Eastern Europe. Since the collapse of Yugoslavia, Slovenia and Croatia have followed in the paths of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic as economic colonies of Western European (principally German) financial interests.
The only long-term solution to the Bosnia crisis is to re-establish a stable national government in Yugoslavia, and that is precisely what the European Community has no desire to see. Thus, Western Europe is content to do nothing or allow the United States alone to become militarily embroiled in the Bosnian civil war.
This does not mean the United States should give up efforts to end the Bosnian tragedy. However, our efforts should not focus narrowly on opposition to the Bosnian Serbs; the Bosnian Croats have demonstrated that Bosnian Serbs have no monopoly on the practice of "ethnic cleansing." Rather, our objective should be re-establishment of a stable, legitimate Yugoslav government recognized by all parties, capable of restoring law and order to the region.
Our ally in this should not be the European Community, but Russia. It is the one country in the world that has the power, influence and credibility to overcome the influence and fears of extreme Serbian nationalists, thereby bringing about a lasting solution to the Yugoslavia conflict.
The crisis in Bosnia and the conduct of the European Community in resisting efforts to resolve it may be the harbinger of a new era in America's relationship with Europe. With the end of the cold war, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has become largely irrelevant. The principal concern for the United States is no longer Soviet military expansion, but economic competition. In this new global context, the expansion of Western European -- once again, principally German -- economic influence through Eastern Europe is cause for concern for the United States.
It may be time not merely for peaceful coexistence with Russia, but even outright alliance. Such an alliance would provide a valuable counterweight to expanding German economic influence in Eastern Europe and would enable the United States and Russia to accelerate the dismantling of the bloated military establishments largely responsible for sapping the economies of both.
The Bosnian crisis gives President Clinton an opportunity to consider a radical redirection of American foreign policy in the post-cold war era. It may also allow Mr. Clinton to solve the conundrum of having to deal with international crises while still remembering that "It's the economy, stupid."
 
STUART E. ABRAMS
New York, May 13, 1993

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 631 words

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Feeding Pigeons
 
Question: I live in a co-op on the Upper East Side in Manhattan. An elderly woman who rents in the building on the 18th floor throws a bag of bird seed from her window each morning; it lands on the roof of a five-story building. Each morning, pigeons swarm in the area awaiting their next meal. This is disturbing, since the birds leave their droppings on my window. I believe that this is also a health violation. 
 I contacted the management office. The woman was spoken to and a letter was sent to her. However, she continues her daily feeding. Management now says it is my responsibility.
I am sure that there is a law about throwing things out of your window. I would also think it would include feeding pigeons.
I would like to know what further actions can be taken to stop this woman. I also would appreciate it if you could inform me if is it my responsibility to act. . . . M. Landau, Manhattan
 
Answer: According to Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer, the building's property lease and house rules do not apply to nonpurchasing tenants if their apartments are rent-controlled or rent-stabilized.
Accordingly, he said, the building's ability to act in this case is severely limited.
Mr. Weinstein suggested that you might, however, be able to get the appropriate New York City department to take enforcement action against the violations of New York City law. In this case, the appropriate department would be the Department of Health. To complain, call (212) 442-1999.
"Technically, it is against the law," said Steven Matthews, a spokesman for the Department of Health. "It's considered to be creating a public health violation because it constitutes littering and creates the potential for attracting vermin."
 
Surcharges for Pets
 
Question: I live as a renting tenant in a stabilized apartment in a nonevict co-op building. Recently, the board sent everyone a letter regarding a pet policy that would require everyone to register their pets and would assess each pet owner a surcharge of $100 per dog to establish a special dog fund.
In addition, the letter set forth fines starting at $150 and increasing in increments of $50 for any dirtying around the perimeter of the building. Furthermore, the letter restricts our access to one entrance and exit of the building.
Is there any recourse available for senior citizens living in the building who would be forced to give up their pets?
More importantly, is this legal? . . . Victor E. Gramigna, Manhattan
 
Answer: No, it is not legal. According to Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the state Department of Housing and Community Renewal in Albany, such surcharges and fee structures can be imposed on the co-op owners but not on the renters living in rent-regulated apartments.
"The tenants are either entitled to have pets, or they are not and that's stated in their lease," he said. "There can be no additional charges."
He added that if a dog were a nuisance, the only recourse for aggrieved residents would be to seek an eviction of the tenant who owned the animal.
 
Setting a Price Floor
 
Question: Recently, the board in my co-op rejected a buyer because they felt that the selling price of the apartment was too low. Assuming the buyer met all other criteria, wouldn't this be considered illegal interference between buyer and seller? . . . H. Troy, Manhattan
 
Answer: Maybe. According to Bruce D. Friedberg, a Manhattan lawyer, a board has to state why the buyer was rejected, and a rejection because the offer was too low cannot occur unless the board has amended its by-laws and set a minimum price on shares.
"Generally," he added, "they can only reject a buyer on financial or credit-type issues and residence issues, not a minimum price."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A response to a question in the Q & A column on May 23 about a co-op board's rejection of a potential buyer without explanation referred incorrectly to the board's obligations. A board is not obliged to give a reason for rejection.

HEADLINE: Hope and Violence as Cambodian Election Begins

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sunday, May 23

 BODY:
After decades of oppression that have brought genocidal terror, wrenching poverty and a civil war, the future of Cambodia may finally be decided by the millions who have suffered quietly for so long and who are being invited today to vote.
As the voting began at 8 A.M., there were no reports of violence, although United Nations peacekeepers held to their prediction of attacks by the Khmer Rouge, the Maoist rebels who have threatened to sabotage the six-day election. United Nations military observers said there was fighting Saturday night between the rebels and Government soldiers in some areas of the northern countryside. 
 Here in the capital, voters turned out by the tens of thousands in an early morning drizzle for the chance to vote -- for most of Cambodia's 4.7 million registered voters, the first chance in their lives to pick their own government. Cambodians say it is a sign of good fortune when it rains on an important day.
Soy Sina, a retired tailor, lined up an hour and a half before the voting booths opened.
"I came early because I want peace to come very fast to Cambodia," she said, clutching the laminated United Nations voting card that displayed her photograph and signature. "I did not think it would be dangerous to vote because I knew the United Nations would protect us." Several feet away, a peacekeeping soldier from Ghana paced nervously, his hands tight around an M-16 rifle.
The threat that some voters would face violence was underscored on Saturday when two Chinese soldiers with the United Nations force were killed in an early morning raid in central Cambodia. The United Nations blamed the Khmer Rouge for the attack.
Elsewhere on the eve of the voting, at least one man died when the offices of an opposition political party were attacked with grenades in the central province of Kratie, and United Nations electoral officials renewed their warning that polling stations might become the targets of Khmer Rouge rockets.
"I want to vote," said Srei On, a 28-year-old farmer. "Everybody in my family wants to vote, even though we will be afraid." With her husband, Mrs. Srei On tries to grow rice and mangos on a plot of scrubby land in the central province of Kompong Cham, where the Khmer Rouge have stationed thousands of fighters and where the two Chinese peacekeepers were killed.
Twenty political parties are on the ballot to pick a 120-member national assembly, which will be charged with writing a new constitution. But the election is expected to come down to a contest between the governing Cambodian People's Party and the royalist opposition party founded by the nation's former monarch, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.
If the governing party is victorious, it is likely to intensify its military campaign against the Khmer Rouge.
Prince Sihanouk, who at 70 is without doubt the most beloved figure in Cambodia, claims neutrality in the elections and has turned over leadership of the royalist party to his eldest son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, 49. The party is known as Funcinpec, the French acronym for the National Front for an Independent, Neutral, Peaceful and Cooperative Cambodia.
If the party wins the election, Prince Ranariddh is expected to ask his father to form a coalition government that might include the Khmer Rouge -- despite the movement's murderous past. When the Khmer Rouge controlled the Government from 1975 to 1979, more than one million Cambodians died from starvation, disease and execution as the Khmer Rouge tried to force Cambodia back to an agrarian "Year Zero."
 
Prince Sihanouk Returns
 At the urging of the United Nations, Prince Sihanouk returned home on Saturday from Beijing, where he maintains a home and where he is said to have been receiving medical treatment for several weeks.
"I am very happy to be with my people," he said on his arrival at Phnom Penh's international airport. "Really, they need me. I am very happy to be with them to support the electoral process, to support the new democracy."
United Nations peacekeepers say that while they predict violence during the six-day election that begins today, they still expect to be able to set up polling stations in at least 80 percent of the country. Most Cambodians live in the southern half of the country, which has been comparatively peaceful. The vote count is supposed to be completed by the end of next week.
"We have the minimum acceptable conditions for free and fair elections -- not the maximum, far from it," said Yasushi Akashi, the head of the 22,000-member, $2 billion peacekeeping force in Cambodia, on which the United Nations has staked its prestige. It is the biggest peacekeeping operation in United Nations history.
"But we can feel there is a deep and widespread aspiration among the Cambodian people for peace," Mr. Akashi said in a meeting on Saturday with reporters. "Cambodians must now try to become masters of their own country."
United Nations officials say that if the election is free and fair -- and if Cambodia's political parties live up to their promise to accept the results -- the nation's new masters will be the voters who, despite Khmer Rouge threats of violence, turn out to cast ballots this week.
 
Most Have Never Voted Before
 Most of the registered voters, indeed most of Cambodia's eight million people, are small farmers whose belongings rarely include much beyond a small patch of land, a house of sticks and palm leaves and perhaps a cow and a few chickens. They are among the poorest people on earth.
Most have never voted before, and until the United Nations arrived here as part of a 1991 peace treaty, they were largely unfamiliar with multiparty democracy or secret balloting. Most Cambodians are illiterate, so the logos of Cambodia's 20 political parties will be printed on the ballot.
The outcome is likely to come down to whether Cambodian voters accept the idea tht they enjoy a free choice -- an elusive concept among people whose survival has often depended on their absolute obedience to authority.
The village of Malua in the central province of Kompong Speu, about 40 miles southwest of Phnom Penh, is a sad collection of several dozen palm-leaf huts, the leaves cracked and faded from the unrelenting sun.
There, the villagers say without hesitation that they will vote for the Cambodian People's Party, the party of Prime Minister Hun Sen. It is difficult to know whether they are telling the truth or whether they feel that it is simply too dangerous to acknowledge that they support someone else.
The Cambodian People's Party has conducted a large-scale campaign of intimidation, often gathering voters together in small groups in the countryside to warn them that their ballots will not be secret and that they face retaliation if they vote against the governing party. In some provinces the party has been linked to the slayings of opposition leaders.
 
'They Saved Us'
 "Of course we will vote for the Cambodian People's Party," said Noy Hou, 38, who struggles to raise corn in the dry red soil of the village, and whose one-room home is decorated with a small calendar with photographs of Prime Minister Hun Sen and the party chairman, Chea Sim. "The People's Party is our party -- they saved us from the Khmer Rouge."
Her husband, Sat Seun, 40, leaning back on a frayed bamboo mat, said he believed the governing party's assertion that the royalists were in a secret alliance with the Khmer Rouge and would help return the Khmer Rouge to power in Cambodia. "I think Funcinpec and the Khmer Rouge are the same thing," he said.
At a Funcinpec office a few miles down the rutted dirt road from Malua, a party organizer, Han Sou Pheap, said that while many Cambodians supported the party, they dared not admit it.
"Only a few people will tell you the truth," said Mr. Han Sou Pheap, who said he had received several visits from armed Government soldiers who had threatened to burn down the office or spray it with gunfire unless he took down photographs of Prince Sihanouk.
Cambodia is a victim of geography, squeezed between two historically voracious, much larger neighbors, Vietnam and Thailand. It was colonized by France in the 19th century, and during World War II, its Vichy French administrators passed over the likeliest candidate for the throne and selected a teen-age prince, Norodom Sihanouk, to be the nation's new King.
 
Coup, Then Communist Victory
 Prince Sihanouk eventually won full independence for Cambodia and ruled the country until 1970, when he was overthrown in a coup led by his Prime Minister, Gen. Lon Nol. Cambodia became a battlefield as the Vietnam War spilled over the border, and in 1975 the Lon Nol Government, like the South Vietnamese Government, fell to Communist forces.
The Communist leader in Cambodia, Pol Pot of the Khmer Rouge, then launched a peasant revolution intended to turn this nation into a giant agricultural commune. He plunged Cambodia into a reign of terror from which its people have not recovered.
In 1979 the Khmer Rouge were overthrown by the Vietnamese Army, and Pol Pot and his forces fled back into the jungle, where they regrouped as insurgents and launched a civil war against the Government installed by Vietnam. That Government remains in power today, now led by Mr. Hun Sen, a Khmer Rouge commander who defected to Vietnam in the 1970's.
Pol Pot remains the supreme leader of the Khmer Rouge and is said to be living in jungle camps in western Cambodia. In 1991 the Khmer Rouge joined in the United Nations-brokered peace treaty for Cambodia but withdrew last year, asserting that thousands of Vietnamese troops remained in Cambodia.
The fear of what the elections may bring was most evident Saturday in the northwestern province of Siem Reap, the scene of almost continuous fighting between the Khmer Rouge and the Cambodian Army since the treaty was signed in October 1991.
 
Violence Feared in Siem Reap
 The rattle of gunfire and the rumble of nighttime shelling have been routine for weeks. United Nations military officials say Siem Reap is one of the provinces most likely to be attacked by Khmer Rouge guerrillas during the voting. Peacekeeping troops assigned to the provincial capital, also called Siem Reap, stationed themselves on Saturday in makeshift bunkers in Buddhist temples, known as wats, which will be used as polling places.
Keng Borin, 28, an unemployed laborer in Siem Reap who is one of nearly 370,000 Cambodian refugees who returned home from border camps in Thailand over the last year under the auspices of the United Nations, wondered again what sort of country he had come home to.
"In Phnom Penh, people think there will be peace after the elections," he said. "In Siem Reap, everyone thinks that after the elections the fighting will begin again."
In the village of Somrong Year, on the outskirts of the city of Siem Reap, Yuit Sinni, 33, said she had abandoned her home in the city earlier this month because of the constant threat of Khmer Rouge attacks. "I do not sleep easily now because I am afraid the Khmer Rouge will come during elections," she said. "I will vote, for Hun Sen because he helped liberate us from Pol Pot and kept Pol Pot away."
In the southern Cambodian province of Kampot, unidentified gunmen ambushed a train on Saturday, killing three people.
But the graceful, tree-lined streets of the Cambodian capital were notably calm on the eve of the elections, though many of the capital's residents still feared violence. Hundreds of Buddhist monks and nuns, some from as far away as the United States, marched down a major thoroughfare, many clutching bundles of incense wrapped in jasmine garlands, while others held signs that read in Khmer, "Please, Peace Come to Cambodia."
Crowds lined the street to welcome the procession.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Monks marching for peace in the streets of Phnom Penh on the eve of six days of elections in Cambodia. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. 1); Sat Seun, a farmer in Phum Mala village in southwest Cambodia, at home with his children. Mr. Seun believes the royalists were in a secret alliance with the Khmer Rouge and would help return the Khmer Rouge to power. "I think Funcinpec and the Khmer Rouge are the same thing," he said. (David Portnoy for The New York Times) (pg. 10)
 
Chronology: "23 Years of Clashes and Terror"
1970: Civilian and military officials overthrow the Government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and turn over power to Prime Minister Lon Nol, an American-backed general. The Cambodian monarchy is abolished.
1975: Communist guerrillas of the Khmer Rouge seize the capital and oust Lon Nol's Government after victories in provincial cities. The Khmer Rouge impose a brutal reorganization of society in which more than a million people will die in three years. Prince Sihanouk, a virtual captive, is declared titular head of state.
1976: Prince Sihanouk resigns and goes to Beijing. The shadowy leader of the Khmer Rouge, Pol Pot, emerges to become Prime Minister.
1978: Vietnamese troops invade in December.
1979: Vietnam installs a new Government in Phnom Penh led by Heng Samrin.
1982: With encouragement from China and the United States, the three Cambodian rebel factions form a government in exile with Prince Sihanouk as president, Khieu Samphan of the Khmer Rouge as vice president and Son Sann of the conservative Khmer People's Liberation Front as prime minister.
1987: Prince Sihanouk withdraws from the coalition and holds talks in France with Hun Sen, now Prime Minister in Phnom Penh. Talks over the next 18 months prove inconclusive.
1988: Under Chinese pressure, Prince Sihanouk returns to lead the rebel coalition.
1989: Vietnam announces that all its troops will leave Cambodia by the end of September.
1990: The United States, Russia, China and other permanent members of the United Nations Security Council draft a peace plan calling for an interim administration made up of the four factions to run the country under United Nations supervision until free elections can be organized. The factions agree in principle to accept the plan, which also calls for mutual disarmament and a United Nations buffer force.
June 1991: The Supreme National Council agrees to an indefinite cease-fire.
October 1991: Cambodia's warring factions and 18 nations sign a peace treaty in Paris, ending the civil war.
November 1991: A mob of Cambodians attacks the nominal leader of the Khmer Rouge, Mr. Samphan, with sticks and fists in a villa in Phnom Penh.
March 1992: The United Nations starts deploying a peacekeeping force of 22,000 soldiers and civilians to oversee the transition to elections.
June 1992: Peacekeepers begin disarming, but the Khmer Rouge refuse to yield weapons.
December 1992: After months of sporadic attacks, the Khmer Rouge begin taking United Nations troops hostage for brief periods. Over the next five months, they kill 10 peacekeepers and wound at least 40.
January 1993: The Khmer Rouge say they will boycott the vote.
April 1993: The Khmer Rouge pull out of the capital and regroup in strongholds. Clashes escalate.
PUB-DATE: May 23, 1993:
; Chart: "The Main Players in Cambodia"
 
Although 20 parties will be on the ballot, the transition leading to Cambodia's elections has been dominated by a handful of politicians and rebel leaders:
 
Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the nation's monarch and titular head of state. He is believed to be ready to form a coalition government if Funcinpec, the party led by his son, is victorious in the election.
 
Prince Norodom Ranariddh of the United Front for an Independent, Peaceful and Cooperative Cambodia, known by the French acronym Funcinpec. The party has called for the creation of a coalition government that could include the Khmer Rouge. Its chief promise is an end to the 14-year civil war.
 
Hun Sen of the Cambodian People's Party, the newly created party of the Vietnamese-installed Government. It has suggested that it would use victory at the polls to destroy the Khmer Rouge once and for all.
 
Khieu Samphan, the nominal leader of the Khmer Rouge rebel movement, which presided over the deaths of more than a million people in a brutal restructuring of society in the 1970's. The Khmer Rouge have withdrawn from the peace process, are boycotting the election and have threatened to sabotage the voting with violence. (pg. 10)

HEADLINE: Clinton Jabs Democratic Critics Of His Budget and Tax Package

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STRATHAM, N.H., May 22

 BODY:
Striking back at Democratic Senators who have challenged his budget and tax package, President Clinton today accused them of protecting wealthy special interests and buckling under to "the big oil lobby."
Mr. Clinton's unusually sharp remarks against members of his own party, made in his weekly radio address, were directed at the centrist Democrats who have bolted from party ranks to try to revise the President's budget and tax package. 
 Two weeks after Mr. Clinton acknowledged that he had allowed other issues to distract him from working on the economy, he strove today to keep the public's attention on his plan for revival. As his foreign policy team announced an international strategy to curb the killing in Bosnia, the President traveled to New Hampshire Technical College here to speak at commencement.
In his radio address on the economy, he did not mention any Senators by name, but his comments appeared directed mostly at Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, a state dominated by the oil industry. Mr. Boren has put forward a plan that would eliminate the energy tax proposed by Mr. Clinton and instead restrict the growth of welfare programs and health benefits to the poor and elderly.
 
'It's Simply Wrong'
 Mr. Boren's efforts have won praise from other centrist Democrats who fear that the "New Democrat" President has come to look like an old-style liberal. [Article, page 20.]
"It's simply wrong for a powerful interest to try and opt out of this program by asking the elderly and the working poor to contribute more so they can contribute less," Mr. Clinton said on the radio. "Making middle America pay more may be business as usual in Washington, but to the rest of the nation it must be unjust, unfair and unacceptable."
Declaring that he would not back down, Mr. Clinton added: "I regret that otherwise good and responsible legislators would even consider this proposal. But I will fight it."
Despite his comments promoting his economic plan, Mr. Clinton was repeatedly reminded of less weighty troubles that have dogged him in the last week -- from the abrupt dismissal of the longtime White House travel office to the expensive haircut he got on board Air Force One in Los Angeles the other day.
The plane carrying the press to the commencement speech -- the first trip out since everyone in the travel office was dismissed -- was stuck on the runway for two hours because of a fuel problem. And a sign displayed outside a shop here proclaimed: "Mr. President, Our Haircuts Cost $12."
And as he left the college, where he made a lower-key appeal for his energy tax, it was clear that not everyone bought Mr. Clinton's pitch that new taxes were vital to his economic plan.
He found himself in a heated exchange with a man who told him: "No more taxes. We're sick of taxes. We're taxed enough."
The President's response suggested he thought the man was a Republican: "You won't listen to the election. After the election, your Administration increased the deficit."
The man shot back: "You're a liar. Why don't you go back to Arkansas. Liar. You're a liar."
Mr. Clinton has rarely used language as pointed as that today against members of his own party. By his sharp tone, he demonstrated how seriously he is taking the Democratic threats to abandon his budget and tax plan -- and signaled his determination to aggressively fight efforts to weaken his proposal. The rival plan has also been endorsed by Ross Perot.
Mr. Clinton defended his plan in milder terms at the two-year, state-supported college, emphasizing the need for an energy tax.
Speaking to the 176 graduates and their friends and families under a tent at the school's 48th commencement, Mr. Clinton recalled the financially strapped people he met in New Hampshire during last year's campaign.
"Every day when I get up in the White House and go to the Oval Office to work," he told the students, "I think about the people I met here and people like them all over America whose quiet courage and determination inspires me to keep fighting to restore the middle class and the fundamental strength and purpose of this country."
The President's decision to step up his attack in his radio address came as Mr. Boren, a moderate who has been an ally on Capitol Hill, made clear that he was not reluctant to take on Mr. Clinton and press him to accept a bipartisan compromise.
 
Formula for 'Destruction'
 "I think that if this President were to get his wish of passing this budget right now, exactly like it is," Mr. Boren told The Washington Post on Friday, "it would be the surest formula for the destruction of the Democratic Party and any chance he has for re-election that I have ever seen."
Other Democrats who have endorsed Mr. Boren's compromise are Senators J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, and Bob Kerrey and J. James Exon, both of Nebraska.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said the President thought it was important to underscore that the Boren proposal would shift a greater tax burden to the elderly and working people. "Boren's plan would shift billions of dollars" from working people to rich people, she said, adding that Mr. Clinton "doesn't think that's fair."
Asked why the President was publicly criticizing influential members of his own party, Ms. Myers said, "That's part of the legislative process."
Taking aim at oil companies, Mr. Clinton asserted in the radio address: "Some of my opponents want to cut Social Security and tax credits to working families with incomes of under $30,000 just to get a tax cut for the rich. The big oil lobby is trying to wiggle out of its contribution to deficit reduction and force senior citizens barely above the poverty line to get lower Social Security benefits."
If his package fails, Mr. Clinton warned, "our new and carefully won credibility will crumble as a nation, and interest rates will start to rise again, squeezing out the investments we need to make to grow new jobs."
Mr. Clinton said he decided to deliver the commencement at this small technical college because during the primaries -- when his fortunes were in grave doubt -- a student there, Greg Fuller, asked him to speak this year as President. "And then he wrote me a letter to confirm the request," he said.
The President used the opportunity to promote technical colleges, saying that with their students who "work and study hard," the schools "are really on the cutting edge -- up and down -- of this economy."
After the speech, Mr. Clinton visited some of his old haunts in New Hampshire, including Vachon Restaurant in Manchester, where he ate a cheeseburger and french fries.

Jeffrey Rafn, Commissioner of Technical Education for the state, after Mr. Clinton's commencement address at the school. (Reuters) (pg. 20)

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Steakhouse in Old Style, in Many Ways

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
STEAKHOUSES are making a comeback. Despite assertions that we are all eating lightly and resisting red meat, the shrines to beef are booming. Witness the recently opened Manhattan Steak House in Cedarhurst.
Diners expecting a big brassy spot complete with gruff waiters will be pleased by the intimate storefront. It soothes with carpeted floors, white tablecloths, creamy walls, subdued landscapes and old-fashioned fixtures with amber lights. Furthermore, the efficient waiters are paragons of amiability. 
 The Manhattan Steak House has more in common with the Big Apple than its name. Its owners, Marinko Glavan and Bruno Peros, worked together at the renowned Sparks Steak House on 46th Street before moving to the Island. They have brought big-city expertise and big-city prices to their new venture.
Long Islanders, lulled by recent recessionary price cutting, may gasp at entrees that begin at $21.50 and go as high as $26.95. Although prices for steak are comparable to those at other steakhouses, there is no inexpensive refuge like chicken, chopped steak or a steak sandwich on the menu.
Still, for diners with deep pockets and traditional tastes, the food is exceptional. A special of glistening, plump, bluepoint oysters on the half shell ($9.50) had veteran oyster eaters proclaiming them the oysters of a lifetime.
Other seafood sparklers were the shrimp cocktail consisting of four firm jumbos surrounding a spirited cocktail sauce, tender baked clams under a sprinkling of crunchy crumbs, tasty shrimp scampi and a special of tiny sweet scallops and crab meat broiled in lemon butter.
The menu's two salads, at $4.50 each, offer a more economical start to the meal. The mixed greens, highlighted with a few tomato wedges and tossed in a lush vinaigrette, were presented on a dinner-size plate.
Equally alluring were the sliced tomatoes and onions. It is not the traditional platter of alternating red and white thick disks paired with a sweet orange dressing, but a mosaic of sliced ruby beauties crowned with rings of red onion. It arrives with the house vinaigrette, or for $1.50 surcharge, a tangy Roquefort dressing sporting chunks of cheese.
Two salad specials also delivered: garlic-strewn roasted red peppers perched atop tomato slices and a plate holding a dozen perfectly cooked asparagus resting on a bed of romaine.
Predictably, steaks are king, and the prime sirloin, with its great beefy flavor and tasty crust, leads the pack. Tops in tenderness are the velvety filet mignon and the melt-in-the-mouth medallions of beef with a Bordelaise sauce rife with sliced mushrooms. The steak fromage with its cheese topping is only for diners with an unstinting love of Roquefort.
All meats were precisely cooked, including a thick center-cut veal chop and three double-rib lamb chops.
Lighter though not smaller was a substantial flaky swordfish steak. Broiled shrimp, six butterflied giants bathed in lemon butter, garlic and thyme, also brought smiles. The lone skimpy entree was a seafood special of four shrimp encircling a small lobster tail. Its price of $26.95 seemed excessive.
A la carte side dishes are not bountiful, either. The hash brown potatoes, spinach and broccoli arrive on saucer-size plates. The green vegetables were perfectly cooked, but underseasoned and boring.
Do not save room for dessert. The cheesecake was dry, and the chocolate mousse cake was commercial. Best one evening was a wedge of ripe Crenshaw melon.
The wine list, like the menu, offers few if any bargains. The 24 table-wine selections average $30 a bottle. The red-blooded 1988 Robert Mondavi cabernet sauvignon ($29) is perfection with steak, and a spirited 1991 Cakebread sauvignon blanc ($24), one of Napa's best white wines, marries well with seafood.
 Manhattan Steak House
Very Good
531 Central Avenue, one block north of the railroad station, Cedarhurst. 374-6768.

HEADLINE: Airport Takes Steps To Pacify Quaker Group

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
IN the aftermath of an episode nearly two months ago in which the management of the Westchester County Airport, apparently following a safety directive from the Federal Aviation Administration, clear-cut 10 acres of forest that had previously protected the Society of Friends Meetinghouse in Purchase from the sights and sounds of runway traffic, a meeting was held May 15 at the house to discuss possible landscaping solutions and inform Quakers and residents about future airport plans.
"There is no other issue that is more sensitive than the proposed modernization of this airport," said County Legislator Joseph M. Delfino, a Republican from White Plains. "We're going to have monthly meetings with the Transportation Department so that people can know in advance what will happen at the airport. People need to remember that no one is out to hurt anyone. It's not our intent to disrupt people's lives with the modernization of the airport." 
 He added: "We've got to be sensitive to people and achieve a compromise between running an airport for the economy of Westchester and how to minimize the impact on people. The airport will never go away, and it's a concern of all of us."
As part of an effort to mend fences -- literally and figuratively -- with the members of the Purchase Society of Friends, three officials met with about 35 Quakers and their neighbors at the Meetinghouse. The three were Joel Russell, the Westchester County Airport manager; DaniloMena, the acting commissioner of transportation, and Mr. Delfino.
 
Future Accountability
 Although armed with architectural drawings and artists' renderings of the proposed changes to the airport, the transportation representatives were given a polite but skeptical reception. Explanations were often drowned out by the roar of jets taking off and landing nearby, and many questions concerned environmental- impact issues and governmental accountability.
There are so many levels of government that something will go through the cracks, said Edith Read, an environmentalist for whom the Edith Read Nature Sanctuary in Rye was named. "It's important to have one person involved who is able to stop something going wrong. The public should be involved from the very beginning."
In response to a question about future accountability, Mr. Mena said: "In all honesty, we did not communicate with you soon enough and we feel badly about that. The engineers had come out and surveyed. This was not done arbitrarily, although it may seem to you that way. Every tree that was cut down was done under a permit. Representatives of New York City and New York State were there. Right now I think you're angry and annoyed and I don't blame you."
Mr. Mena added: "Our biggest mistake was that we did not consult with you earlier. Unfortunately, this particular action needed to be done. But there will be no expansion of the airport. We're limited to 692 acres."
 
A Landscaping Plan
 Since Quaker worship depends on a silent, contemplative atmosphere that has increasingly been disrupted by the sounds of airplanes flying overhead on Sunday mornings, a primary concern at the meeting was attaining a remedy that would restore some of the former tranquillity.
"This is an unusually quiet morning," said Jon Berry of Irvington. "It does seem like a lot more planes have been coming over our meeting on Sunday morning, and I worry about the life of the meeting if we can't hear people talk." Joel Russell, however, said a verbal request to change flight patterns for Sunday morning was made to the Federal Aviation Administration about two weeks ago.
An immediate priority for county government and the Quakers is coming up with a landscape design that will offer a barrier to the sights and sounds of the airport. "Our planning department is working feverishly to come up with a landscaping plan," said Mr. Delfino. "We want to do what's right. I want you to feel comfortable that we will do everything humanly possible to restore serenity and tranquillity to this house. I have a personal commitment to this house. We want to have a plan completed in four weeks, but nothing will be done and nothing will be touched until the Friends have their impact."
He added: "I will be on this every week; we're going to try to over-deliver. The planning department has put things aside to do this landscaping plan. We don't have open bank books to transfer 60-foot oaks from Florida, but we'll do everything possible. I would like to believe that if we do put a barrier up and if it is properly shrubbed, that the beauty of the area will be considerably improved. The county has a commitment to satisfying the immediate neighbors and Friends of the house."
 
'I'm Cautious About This'
 Some of those at the meeting were reassured by Mr. Delfino's promises. "I think we'll get our landscaping and our sound barriers," said Deborah Wood, a clerk of the Meeting. "I feel that the county legislators are acting in good faith in working to ameliorate the immediate situation and help prevent future situations."
But others were unconvinced by such assurances. "They say, 'Trust us,' " said Cathy Billone, whose house is next door to the Society of Friends Meetinghouse. "But when I went to planning meetings, they said they weren't going to cut down trees. Five weeks ago, I lived next to an airport and didn't know it because those trees were a buffer. Now I have five cracks in my kitchen floor from the impact of the noise. They're saying that they made a mistake, but their credibility is really shaky."
Added Quaker Fred Feucht, a resident of Pleasantville: "I'm cautious about this. We've been burned and I don't feel a great sense of trust, particularly with the Department of Transportation and airport management."
Similar skepticism was voiced by Marge Schlitt of Hastings-on-Hudson, a member of the Purchase meeting. "The county legislators are aware and sensitive," said Ms. Schlitt. "I'm not yet convinced that the airport administration is as sensitive or aware as they should be."
And for Quaker Dede Carlsten, the proceedings left her with guarded hope for the future. "Maybe they thought that we were buried under the gravestones," Mrs. Carlsten said. "Being a pacifist doesn't mean that we don't fight for what is right."

HEADLINE: The Boomers' Babies

BYLINE: By Andrew Leonard; Andrew Leonard is a staff writer for The San Francisco Bay Guardian, a weekly newspaper.

 BODY:

13TH GEN
Abort, Retry, Ignore, Fail?
By Neil Howe and Bill Strauss with Ian Williams.
Illustrated by R. J. Matson. 229 pp. New York:
Vintage Books. Paper, $10. 
 REVILED as apathetic, cynical and just plain dumb by both its elders and itself, the generation born between 1961 and 1981 has, understandably enough, an inferiority complex bordering on the pathological. But guess what? It's not their fault. So write the baby boomers Neil Howe and Bill Strauss in "13th Gen."
After all, how can you blame a generation weaned on Vietnam, Watergate, stagflation, oil embargoes, disco and Reaganomics for being just a trifle un inspired? Consider the statistics presented in "13th Gen": child poverty, employment, wages, home ownership, arrest records -- in every category, this generation, the 13th since the American Revolution, is doing worse than the generation that came before. Indeed, for the first time since the Civil War, the authors of "13th Gen" keep reminding us, young people are unlikely to surpass the affluence of their parents.
"13th Gen" seems to be intended as a nonfiction version of such twentysomething texts as the film "Slacker" and the novel "Generation X." Striking a self-consciously post-modern tone, the authors -- Mr. Howe is an economist and historian, Mr. Strauss is the director of a political satire troupe called Capitol Steps -- make their case by interpolating into their main text lots of charts and graphs, margin-ensconced tidbits, cartoons by The New York Observer's R. J. Matson, and even an intermittent dialogue with Ian Williams, a genuine member of the "13th gen" and a computer hacker, who surfs into the text from cyberspace.
But instead of coming across as an exciting hard-copy version of MTV designed to seduce the minuscule attention spans of suburbia's mall-hopping "13ers," this book's compendium of run-amok generalizations has all the flair and provocativeness of a social studies textbook. The authors have managed to capture the contrived glibness of post-modernism while missing just about all of its essential irony.
Actually, "13th Gen" isn't so much a book about this generation at all as a diatribe against the generation responsible for the breakdown of contemporary America into what the authors regard as a fragmented, polarized, chaotic society. All those parents who got divorced, encouraged "open" schooling and neglected their children while indulging themselves are the real villains.
Mr. Howe and Mr. Strauss make sense when they decry previous generations for standing by and watching, and often cheering, as their leaders plunged the nation into a morass of "mounting budget deficits, unfunded benefit liabilities, dwindling savings rates, lackluster R & D, crumbling highways and deepening foreign import penetration." And they rightly point out that given those realities, it is unsurprising that 13ers feel powerless and resentful. But as the authors relentlessly attack the iniquitous "child-abusive culture" of the 1960's and 70's and exult in heaping insult after insult on their own generation -- they caricature baby boomers as countercultural, long-haired, sex-obsessed hedonists -- their real agenda begins to surface.
That agenda becomes clear in part of their wish list for how the 13th generation may influence the future: "13ers will reverse the frenzied and centrifugal cultural directions of their younger years. . . . They will clean up entertainment, de-diversify the culture, reinvent core symbols of national unity, reaffirm rituals of family and neighborhood bonding, and re-erect barriers to cushion communities from unwanted upheaval."
Sounds like some people are feeling just a mite threatened by the churning wake of what Douglas Coupland, the author of "Generation X," labeled "an accelerated culture." De-diversify the culture? Tell that to the women, immigrants, members of minority groups, lesbians, gay men and others whose laborious struggles were in part responsible for all that "unwanted upheaval." Technology keeps on chugging, the world keeps on shrinking, tensions keep on building and deceleration looks a long way off. It's awfully hard to see how a generation whose iconic symbols include punk skateboarders, tattooed and nose-ringed bike messengers and rebellious computer hackers is going to start slowing it all down.
