HEADLINE: G.O.P. Rivals Face Apathy, Then Florio

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 23

 BODY:
After nearly six months of campaigning by Cary Edwards, James L. Wallwork and Christine Todd Whitman, the primary race for the Republican gubernatorial nomination has entered its final three weeks with a rush of radio and television advertisements, a stream of barbed exchanges and scant evidence that any of it has stirred the public's interest.
It may be nearing the end of a frustrating political season for Mr. Edwards and Mr. Wallwork, who began their campaigns trying to overtake a huge lead in the polls by Mrs. Whitman but still trail her by double digits with just over two weeks before the June 8 primary. 
 Gov. Jim Florio is running unopposed for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.
Staff members in Mr. Wallwork's and Mr. Edwards's campaigns have spoken privately in recent weeks about their frustrations and their candidates' frustrations over the inability to get their messages across and to cut into Mrs. Whitman's lead.
 
Theoretically, It Could Be a Race
 Adding to their concerns, Governor Florio has focused his attacks solely on Mrs. Whitman, making it clear that he expects to face her in November. These days, Mr. Florio never raises the names of Mr. Edwards or Mr. Wallwork.
Polling shows that there are enough undecided Republican voters to make the primary race a contest theoretically. And it is over the attention and votes of those people that the three major candidates for the Republican nomination are now fighting in the final weeks of the campaign.
Diane Walker, 45, a bookkeeper from Dunellen, is among that bloc of undecided Republican voters. Readily acknowledging that she had not followed the primary campaigns, she said she had not made up her mind about which Republican candidate, if any, she would vote for on June 8.
"I guess I feel it doesn't make that much difference at this point, unfortunately," Ms. Walker said last week.
Ordinarily, gubernatorial campaigns, even those for the primary, would attract more widespread public attention. But competing against such headline-grabbing events as the bombing of the World Trade Center and the heated debate over repeal of New Jersey's ban on semiautomatic weapons, this year's primary campaigns never caught the public's fancy, politicians and other experts say.
Mrs. Whitman has had much to do with setting the pace of the primary race, which she entered as the favorite on the strength of her near defeat of Senator Bill Bradley in 1990. Her campaign three years ago against Mr. Bradley, a Democrat, gave her the name recognition and political organization to become the acknowledged favorite in the race for the Republican gubernatorial nomination.
And she has protected the lead by avoiding the media and, as much as possible, any venue that would place her alongside Mr. Edwards or Mr. Wallwork. In fact just about the only time she has appeared with the others has been at debates that were widely broadcast in the state.
"There is nobody in recent New Jersey political history who has had the advantage that she has had in the long lead time," said Neil Upmeyer, president of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues, a public policy organization based in Princeton. "She essentially won the Republican primary on General Election Day in 1990 when she almost beat Bill Bradley. She has been the presumed winner of the gubernatorial primary as long ago as that and it has been up to her opponents to dispel that image."
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a two-term Republican who was Mr. Florio's predecessor, says Republican voters have not been excited by much of what they have heard in the primary: clashes over the hiring of illegal immigrants by Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Edwards, embarrassing blunders like Mrs. Whitman's failing to vote in her local public school board election (the election ended in a tie and the school budget was defeated) and increasingly bitter attacks on each other.
"These are not the kinds of things that get people's juices going in a Republican election," said Mr. Kean. "I think the campaigns are too negative. I think what the public wants is a confrontation on the issues and that is not what they are getting."
Mr. Kean added that Mr. Florio, despite his lack of a primary opponent, still managed to distract attention from the Republicans.
"The early focus seemed to be totally on Florio and whether he could be re-elected," Mr. Kean said. "Instead of people focusing on the Republican primary, the story was: Has this Phoenix named Jim Florio been reborn politically or is it just a mirage? That made it more difficult for the Republicans to get their message out."
With time running out, television and radio ads are the only means left for Mr. Wallwork and Mr. Edwards to close the double-digit lead that Mrs. Whitman has enjoyed in a variety of polls since the official start of the primary season in January. And they have used those ads to pummel Mrs. Whitman over her wealth, her lack of experience in elected office and her campaign blunders.
The bumpy road to the nomination, coming after decades of electoral disappointments, has state Republican leaders fretting privately.
In the last 35 years, New Jersey voters have elected only three Republicans to statewide office: United States Senator Clifford P. Case, who served four terms between 1955 and 1979; Gov. William T. Cahill, who served one term from 1970 to 1974 but lost his re-election bid when he was defeated in a primary, and Mr. Kean, who left office in 1990 after two terms as perhaps the most popular governor in the state's history.
"Florio is the weakest Democratic gubernatorial candidate in a long time," said a senior official with the Republican State Committee, who insisted on anonymity. "But I hope that whoever our nominee is realizes that this guy is a tough fighter and has plenty of money. Only a fool ignores this guy as a campaigner."
Last week, the Republican Party began a $250,000 radio and television campaign attacking Mr. Florio's record $2.8 billion tax increase as well as the state's 9.1 percent unemployment rate.
Mr. Kean, who defeated Mr. Florio in the 1981 gubernatorial race by 1,797 votes out of nearly three million votes cast, also issued a warning about Mr. Florio's potential strength.
"Jim Florio is a tough guy and he won't always come after you above the belt," he said. "You have to be tough and you have to be ready if our candidate is going to be successful."

HEADLINE: Creditors Chip Away at Aga Khan's Legend

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 23

 BODY:
With his thoroughbred horses and luxury resort in Sardinia, with friends like Giovanni Agnelli of Fiat and his appetite for the best yachts, the Aga Khan has long been a symbol of wealth. In Italy, the country where he has concentrated much of his business, "ricco come l'Aga Khan" -- "rich as the Aga Khan" -- is an expression frequently heard.
But in a striking illustration of the severity of the recession afflicting Europeans and the fracturing of Italy's close-knit business establishment, even the Aga Khan has come unstuck. Creditor banks moved on Friday to seize the assets of his publicly traded Italian holding company after it missed a payment on its increasing debt. 
 For the Aga Khan, 57 -- the 49th hereditary leader of the world's 15 million Ismaili Muslims, followers of a branch of Shiite Islam, and a figure regarded by the faithful as a direct descendant of the prophet Mohammed -- the banks' decision amounted to an extraordinary public humiliation.
He is a man with the discreet air that old money bestows, his personal wealth estimated at $1.4 billion. Just five years ago, his investments in the Costa Smeralda resort in Sardinia and in the Ciga hotel chain were being widely hailed as extremely shrewd.
"The Aga Khan has made a series of bad business decisions in recent years, plying investment into luxury hotels at a time when fewer and fewer people had the money to stay in them," said Isidoro Albertini, a veteran broker at the Milan Stock Exchange, where trading in the Aga Khan's companies was suspended on Friday. "And now he is paying the price."
The Aga Khan has made no comment on his troubles. He was unreachable today at his headquarters in Aiglemont, near Paris.
This Harvard-educated man has been unaccustomed to business setbacks. Dividing his time mainly between his French base, Italy and Switzerland, he has devoted much of his energy to improving the lot of the Ismailis, who are scattered through Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
Shunning the glittering life of his father, Aly Khan, known to many in the West as Rita Hayworth third husband, the Aga Khan has combined the management of many orphanages, schools and hospitals in Asia and Africa with the quiet development of his business interests. Private enterprise, he has often said, is the best model for development in the third world.
A truly international man -- born in Switzerland, raised partly in Kenya, educated in America -- his undoing in Italy is thus a great surprise. It amounts to a cautionary tale in the vicissitudes of doing business in Europe at a time when recession has proved longer and far more severe than economists had predicted.
His misfortunes also underscore the particular difficulties of Italy, where the lira has lost more than 40 percent of its value against the dollar in the last nine months amid severe political and economic disruption.
Even a year ago, there was little doubt that that the Aga Khan's problems would have been quietly resolved among the clubby Italian business elite. The Aga Khan's family had been legendary in Italy for years. But now, his close friend Mr. Agnelli has his own problems with corruption investigations at Fiat, and the discreet habit of mutual assistance that has characterized the upper echelons of Italian business has given way to a messy scramble to survive.
 
Italian Ventures
 In 1962, he first embarked on a major investment that led to the development of the then-deserted rocky northeast coast of Sardinia into the luxury resort that became known as the Costa Smeralda.
The resort was successful, earning the reputation of a millionaire's playground, and was followed by the acquisition of a Sardinian airline. But it was in the midst of the 1980's boom that the Aga Khan made his major Italian investment, buying the Ciga hotel chain.
Ciga is a special name in Italy, associated with luxury in much the same way as Tiffany's is in New York. Its jewels include the Danieli Hotel in Venice and the Grand in Rome.
Determined to build on this very special franchise, the Aga Khan embarked on an ambitious international expansion program, acquiring hotels like the Palace in Madrid. The company, which had 22 hotels when the Aga Khan bought it in 1985, now has 36 in six countries.
With the expansion, though, came increased debt. An ill-timed decision to invest heavily in existing Italian hotels at the time of the 1990 World Cup soccer tournament, plowing over $80 million into two Milan establishments alone, exacerbated the debt problem. By this year, Ciga's debts had soared to $680 million, about double its annual revenue.
At the same time, demand plunged amid the recession. Where business travelers had been willing to spend $300 or more a night for a hotel room, some now balked. An overvalued lira made a difficult situation worse, as many potential tourists decided over 1990-1992 that Italy had simply become too expensive.
Ciga, which had been profitable in the 80's, plunged into the red, losing $67 million in 1991, the last year for which figures are available. Trouble also emerged in Sardinia, where a project to develop a big new resort area was blocked when planning approval was withdrawn amid environmental objections.
 
Response Is Cautious
 The Aga Khan responded cautiously. He declined to put any of his own fortune into an attempt to shore up the businesses, seeking instead to sell all or part of the hotel chain. As pressure increased from creditor banks, negotiations began last year with a private Italian property and leisure group, Situr.
These talks appeared to have led to a sale, but Situr balked at the last minute, citing unspecified irregularities in Ciga's accounts. Ciga denied the allegations, but it was not the first time that the company's dealings had been questioned. During the 80's the Aga Khan sold personal assets to Ciga for $136 million in a deal that was widely questioned.
With no other prospective buyers emerging, and the cost of servicing Ciga's foreign-currency debt spiraling after a sharp devaluation of the lira last year, the banks' nervousness increased.
This culminated in the move on Friday by IMI Bank A.G. of Germany to seize the assets of Fimpar S.p.A., the Aga Khan's holding company that controls Ciga. IMI leads a consortium of 16 banks that has lent $100 million to Fimpar. It says Fimpar has failed to pay interest on the loan.
While a spokesman for Fimpar, Claudio Miorelli, sought to play down the bank's decision by saying that it was no more than a precautionary move while negotiations continued on a debt settlement, it was clear that the Aga Khan's fortunes in Italy have come full circle. He is now in a situation in which he may be obliged to sell his hotel assets in a depressed market or face bankruptcy.
The Aga Khan almost certainly remains, in his own right, a rich man. But the air of unrufflable wealth and patrician calm that surrounded him has been destroyed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Aga Khan, whose personal fortune is estimated at $1.4 billion, is also a Muslim hereditary leader. (Associated Press) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
News vs. Intelligence: Business Week Aims to Make the Distinction in its New Campaign

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
MARKETERS of name-brand products are not the only ones seeking to build business by convincing the consumer that they are "adding value" to what they sell.
Business Week magazine, in a campaign that begins today, will assert to potential advertisers and readers that it goes "beyond news," all the way to providing "intelligence." 
 "The news is the raw material, and the intelligence is what you make of it," Cara Erickson, vice president and director of marketing at Business Week, said during an interview last week. "We're saying that news happens, but intelligence is created."
In pursuing that strategy, Business Week, a McGraw-Hill publication, joins an ever-lengthening list of consumer-product marketers that are striving to assure customers that the products they purvey are more than mere commodities. The efforts come in response to shoppers' growing love for lower-priced brands that they perceive to be at parity with premium-priced counterparts in quality and performance.
"News is like a commodity item," said Ted Chin, president and creative director at Ted Chin & Company in New York, which was awarded the Business Week account in December. "We enhance the news; we give it perspective, analysis."
"In packaged goods, we call it a consumer benefit," he added.
The benefit implicit in the campaign is that the "intelligence" found in Business Week is better than the "news" found in rival magazines. To dramatize that distinction, the campaign's print advertisements, television commercials, transit posters and telephone kiosk signs portray Business Week as, in the words of one print ad, the business publication that "goes beyond traditional news to provide timely, in-depth, action-oriented intelligence."
The campaign also plays shrewdly upon the fear of failure that is endemic to a sluggish, thuggish business climate. "Japan's economic giants are meeting to shore up their economy and you missed that plane to Tokyo," one television spot says. "There is, however, an alternative way to get on board."
In a second spot, an announcer says: "In a glaring faux pas, the White House neglects to include you in a sit-down on health care." Then, above a rendition of "Hail to the Chief" by an unseen saxophonist, the announcer continues: "We apologize on their behalf. And offer up an equally informative invitation."
In a crowded business-publication field, the campaign seeks to create "the big idea" that was absent from the magazine's previous advertising, Ms. Erickson said. Mr. Chin's agency was named to handle the Business Week account a month after Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss in New York, which had handled it for four years, resigned, citing "creative differences."
For about a year, the Margeotes campaign for Business Week had carried the theme "Profit by It." Ms. Erickson called that phrase limiting -- unable to address readers as well as advertisers.
Business Week plans to spend from $2 million to $2.5 million on the Chin campaign, a budget that Ms. Erickson characterized as "bigger than in the past." The initial print advertisement, based on the White House television commercial, appears today on the back page of the Business Day section of The New York Times.
The television spots will start running the week of June 21 during local breaks on stations in Chicago, New York and San Francisco; they will appear during programs like "Northern Exposure" on CBS and "Seinfeld" on NBC. Ms. Erickson described those shows as "the programming the media kids make plans to watch," referring to the young media buyers and planners at agencies.
Ms. Erickson said Business Week executives had not determined whether the "Beyond News. Intelligence" theme would be integrated into the magazine's circulation promotion campaign. That series of one- and two-minute television commercials, which invite viewers to call a toll-free telephone number to order Business Week subscriptions, is created in-house rather than by Mr. Chin's agency.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Some Investors Enjoy Yields in Double Digits

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Despite the rush by states, cities and communities to refinance old higher-interest-rate debt, there are still a few high-interest-rate bonds out there that are clearly keeping some holders very happy in this new era of lower interest rates.
In some instances the investors who bought bonds in the 1980's with coupons of 10 to 15 percent are going to continue to be pleased because the bond issuers are having trouble refinancing them. In other cases, the bonds may be refinanced soon but the issuers have taken longer to act than they could have, so the bondholders have had a few more years of high interest rates than they might have. 
 Maggie Ashby, of the corporate trust department of the Peoples Bank and Trust Company in Indianapolis, is the bearer of good news to the holders of $1.4 million of bonds sold in 1983 to build the 60-bed Hillcrest Estates nursing home in Liberty, Ind. The bank is the trustee for the 15 percent, 30-year tax-exempt bonds, which could have been called or redeemed in April of 1990.
That 15 percent is equivalent to a taxable yield of 21.7 percent at the current top tax rate of 31 percent and of 24.8 percent at the top tax rate of 39.6 percent President Clinton has proposed. That is three times the yield on the current 30-year Treasury bond.
 
Looking for Refinancing
 "We get calls all the time from bondholders wanting to know if they are going to be called," Ms. Ashby said. "And all the bondholders are very happy it has not been called."
"We are looking for refinancing now but I am not sure I can get it," Robert Rynard, the owner of the nursing home, said in an interview. "Nursing home refinancing is not easy and no one knows what is going to happen to Medicaid, and half of the patients are on Medicaid."
This was an allusion to the uncertainty about the health-care industry while the Clinton Administration develops its health-care program.
But there are not many nuggets left and as investment banks comb the lists of such high-interest-rate bonds looking for new refinancing business to underwrite and from whom to collect fees, more are disappearing.
 
$5 Billion Double-Digit Bonds
 According to the Bond Buyer, the municipal bond industry's newspaper, there are about $5 billion of bonds, based on the original issue value, out there paying double-digit interest rates that are eligible to be called or refunded. A call date, usually 10 years after the initial issue, allows the issuer to pay off the bond early if interest rates decline. The Bond Buyer estimates there are about $500 million of such issues in New York, including the state, the city and other issuers.
The $5 billion, while a big number, compares with $120.5 billion of new issues sold just last year to pay off higher-interest-rate debt and a total of existing municipal bonds of over $1 trillion.
The $13 million in bonds sold to finance the parking garage connected to the Gallery shopping mall in Philadelphia are also still paying 15 percent. But this nugget seems about to disappear, although the interest rate has been paid longer than could be expected.
The 25-year bonds, issued in 1982, could have been called and paid off in February 1992. But a new financing package was too difficult to put together because of the downgrading of Philadelphia's credit rating to junk, which is below investment grade.
 
New Bonds Sold
 In addition, Federal limits on tax-exempt issues established in the late 80's prevented the advanced refunding of this high-interest-rate issue. This has been done in many other instances by selling new bonds ahead of the call date and paying off the old bonds by establishing an escrow fund filled with Treasury securities bought with the proceeds from new, lower-interest-rate bonds.
David Seltzer, a senior vice president at Lehman Brothers in Philadelphia, said the firm expected to lead a refinancing of the Gallery garage issue in the next several months. And he said the 15 percent interest rate, which should be cut to near 7 percent, would give them the chance to achieve some of the largest refinancing savings ever.
In New York, one of the larger issues still paying a double-digit coupon -- 11.5 percent -- was sold in 1981 through the New York State Dormitory Authority for the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. These bonds, due in 2009, were callable in July 1991, which means the bondholders have had about two years of grace. A spokeswoman for the hospital said last week that a refinancing was being worked on now.
But another $6 million issue, also sold through the Dormitory Authority, for a hospital project in Binghamton, is expected to continue paying 11.75 percent interest until the bonds, sold in July 1982, mature in September 2010. David Kuam, an assistant director of financial analysis at the Dormitory Authority, said the small size of the issue made it too small to refinance. "When you tack on the new issue costs, it gets too expensive," he said.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
A Flock of 'What Ifs?' Comes Home to Roost

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
In the multicultural American theater, A. R. Gurney may be the last playwright who writes full time about that quaint old bird, the New England WASP. Maybe it's an unfashionable calling, but Mr. Gurney's view of his terrain is so objective that his plays often fill in the missing pieces of the fractured American social puzzle. When you meet the economically rarefied yet often emotionally disadvantaged characters in Gurney plays like "Love Letters" and "The Cocktail Hour," you remember just why the rest of the country has spent 25 or so years fleeing in the opposite direction.
Austin, the Boston banker at the center of "Later Life," Mr. Gurney's enjoyable new 80-minute comedy at Playwrights Horizons, is one of the playwright's saddest creations. (Or half-creations. In the Playbill, Mr. Gurney acknowledges a debt to Henry James, whose tale "The Beast in the Jungle" seems the play's point of departure.) A smart and genial preppie in late middle age, Austin rather resembles the President he voted for in the last election. He's likable and polite, and he puts in his time at the office, but what exactly is he doing with his life? His children grown, his marriage ended by divorce, he is an empty suit longing to breathe free. 
 "Later Life" tells what happens when Austin (Charles Kimbrough) is unexpectedly thrown together at a cocktail party with Ruth (Maureen Anderman), a woman he met as a serviceman one night in Capri 30-odd years ago. Still young, single and "relatively free and clear," the pair almost spent the night together. But Austin was seized by the premonition that "something terrible was going to happen" to him in later life and dismissed Ruth with a kiss rather than risk ensnaring her in his cloudy future.
Now later life is accelerating, and the plot question of Mr. Gurney's play is whether Austin and Ruth will seize the second chance for happiness they have been handed. But that question cannot be answered until they resolve the question that hangs over the decades separating their brief encounters: did something terrible ever happen to Austin? Apparently not. He has gone on to what he considers a lucky life, notwithstanding his divorce and his current need for Prozac. Ruth, by contrast, lost a child to leukemia and is now trying to flee her fourth marriage, to an abusive gambler in Las Vegas. It's almost as if she had been given the terrible future Austin once imagined for himself.
Or so it might seem. The drama in Mr. Gurney's plays can never take place on the surface because it is the very nature of his characters that their surface remains impeccably civilized while all hell breaks loose underneath. It is also typical of Mr. Gurney's writing that he strips down his reticent WASP's to the sound of laughter, not sentimental strings. "Later Life" is no exception, offering more than a few lines worthy of New Yorker cartoon captions.
Many of the funniest passages belong to Anthony Heald and Carole Shelley, two of our best comic actors, who are here given the delightful task of playing all the revelers who wander onto the high-rise terrace where Ruth and Austin are trying to have their quiet tete-a-tete. Although some of their roles are one-joke stereotypes that reveal the limits of Mr. Gurney's range -- a Route 128 computer nerd, an acerbic lesbian, a Jewish earth mother -- the performers' own range seems limitless. They are priceless as a transplanted Southern couple on a cultural self-improvement kick and as an elderly couple engaged in a take-no-prisoners war over their retirement plans. And they are also unexpectedly moving as two old friends who preside over the party: a Harvard professor's widow who is the hostess, and a prematurely retired Brandeis professor who has channeled all sorts of disturbing rage into his doomed effort to quit smoking.
True to form, Mr. Gurney sometimes uses the various interlopers to spell out his themes, a tic that mars most of his plays. There are far too many lines reminding the audience that a literal and figurative twilight (and autumn) is at hand, that vulgar Southern and Western new money has overtaken Eastern old money, and that it is now or never if Austin is to follow the example of many of the party guests and break out of his Brahmin rut. This congenital refusal to let the audience discover his plays' characters and themes for itself is in part what often reduces Mr. Gurney's Jamesian and Cheeveresque esthetic designs to facile boulevard comedy.
But Mr. Gurney's boulevard comedy is of a high order, at times achieving the luster of Philip Barry and S. N. Behrman even in this circumscribed one-act piece. "Later Life" has been directed in the appropriately elegant, old-school Broadway style by Don Scardino on a starry romantic set by Ben Edwards. Not the least of Mr. Scardino's accomplishments is to recruit his two lead players, both of whom seem to have been absent from the New York stage almost as long as their characters have been separated.
Ms. Anderman's throaty voice and reserved smile help make Ruth a mysterious, alluring heroine whom the audience roots for and yet, like the frustrated Austin, feels it can never really know. Mr. Kimbrough, who has spent the last five years spoofing a television anchor on the sitcom "Murphy Brown," brings to "Later Life" a deeper, darker incarnation of the stuffy men he played in the Stephen Sondheim musicals "Company" and "Sunday in the Park With George."
His Austin really is a Jamesian figure, desperate to break out of his genteel cage but constitutionally unequipped to do so. Even when he raises his voice in passion -- "If that's love, I know nothing about it," he says to Ruth about her husband's brutality -- he could be disputing a meal charge at a men's club. Mr. Kimbrough's well-meaning yet hopelessly limited Austin is so human and elegiac an embodiment of the anachronistic American ruling class that he may even earn the sympathy of audiences who lowered the curtain on George Bush.

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
John Scanlon, the longtime public relations executive, is changing his base of operations. Mr. Scanlon, 58, will join the Abernathy/MacGregor Group Inc., a financial and crisis communications agency in New York, as a partner, effective June 1. At that time, the agency will become Abernathy/MacGregor/Scanlon. 
 Mr. Scanlon, whose clients have included CBS, G.D. Searle, the Nynex Corporation, along with Corazon C. Aquino, and Ivana Trump, had been based at the Sawyer/Miller Group in New York before that public relations firm merged earlier this year with Robinson, Lake, Lerer & Montgomery. HEADLINE: Rehabilitating Empire Blue Cross

 BODY:
The board of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, asleep as the company's financial fortunes plummeted, has finally taken a corrective step by firing Albert Cardone, its chief executive. Mr. Cardone's imperious demeanor and lavish corporate life style annoyed Albany legislators and enraged customers hit with double-digit premium hikes. Following a spate of embarrassing revelations, the board admitted that Mr. Cardone had to go to allow Empire to repair its reputation.
Dismissing Mr. Cardone won't by itself solve Empire's glaring problems: huge losses, poor customer service, and actual and threatened lawsuits with large corporate clients. Empire needs an overhaul, not a mere shuffling of the names atop the corporate tote board. 
 Empire, the largest nonprofit health insurer in the nation, covers more than eight million New Yorkers. The state requires Empire to insure any applicant and charge a community rate unrelated to the applicant's medical condition. (Commercial insurers, by contrast, offer discounts to lure healthy customers -- a practice known as cherry picking.) In return, the Legislature grants Empire tax-free status and substantial discounts on rates it pays for hospital services. Nevertheless, Empire racked up losses of about $250 million the last two years.
Empire says the cherry picking has left it with unhealthy, expensive-to-cover enrollees. It also blames the recession that's hit the insurance industry. An independent audit ordered by the State Legislature agreed that economic forces were the primary reasons for Empire's poor showing.
But they weren't the only reasons. Empire's community-rated clients account for only about 15 percent of its business; it has also lost huge amounts on large corporate clients, who are not charged community rates, and on its health maintenance organization. Some of its best corporate clients have left because of poor service.
The audit report charged that Empire's management is autocratic, hierarchical and "slow to react to the pace of change . . . neither organized nor managed to become a market leader in innovation or quality improvement." And a recent series in The Times exposed a pattern of managerial miscues, including dubious sweetheart contracts with corporate insiders.
Since the audit report, A.T.&T., a major client, accused Empire of fraudulently failing to pass along discounts it received on hospital bills; indeed, for the type of contract it had with A.T.&T., Empire may have taken advantage of discounts for which it was not eligible. And two weeks ago The Times reported that the Federal Government was threatening to cancel Empire's contract for processing Medicare claims because of poor performance.
The report and subsequent revelations jarred the board. After extensive interviews, an investigating committee unearthed low morale and complaints about Mr. Cardone's brusque, autocratic style. Mr. Cardone didn't cause most of Empire's problems. But without the trust of the public, state legislators or subordinates, he was clearly not the leader to rehabilitate the company. The board finally got the message.

HEADLINE: Spend $2,500, Save $10

BYLINE: By Al Gore; Al Gore, the Vice President, speaks today to Federal employees involved in performance reviews of Government work. This article is adapted from his remarks.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As Congress considers President Clinton's economic plan, the focus is on reducing the deficit, spending less and increasing investments that create jobs. But there's another deficit we're addressing as well, the trust deficit: a widespread belief Government simply can't be trusted to spend tax dollars wisely. To eliminate that credibility gap, we're working to develop a new customer-service contract with the American people that has a simple goal. We want to make the Government work better and cost less.
Since President Clinton asked me to lead the National Performance Review -- a six-month comprehensive study of every Government agency -- I've heard from thousands of Federal workers and private citizens. 
 Consider what the Federal Marshals Service of the Justice Department faced when it wanted to get the lawns mowed at houses it seized in drug cases. I heard about it from an employee of the Marshals Service in Atlanta. The department resells the houses and uses the money to finance the war on drugs. But to sell a house, you've got to keep it presentable and that means mowing the lawn. In Atlanta, they thought they'd hire a teen-ager for about $10 a lawn. But procurement regulations dictated that they had to do it competitively -- and, of course, kids don't write bid proposals. So they had to negotiate a contract with a large firm to mow all the lawns in the Atlanta region -- for $40 a lawn.
Another Federal employee came to me with a contraption called a steam trap that's used to take dirt and oil out of steam lines. It costs about $100. When it goes bad, it leaks about $50 worth of steam a week. A Federal engineer wanted to replace some leaky ones. The problem was, the central procurement office had been directed to buy in quantity to save money. So the office saved up all its requests for traps for a solid year. It bought every $100 steam trap for $90 and saved $10. While it waited, each leaky trap cost the taxpayers 50 weeks of steam. That came to $2,500 -- $2,500 to save $10.
An Interior Department employee told me how she used the frequent-flyer miles she earned on Government travel to get a free ticket for a Government trip. But the trip required that she stay over for a Saturday night. She did, staying with friends instead of incurring hotel costs. But when she returned the department refused to pay the extra per diem -- $38 -- even though she had saved it $331 by giving up her Saturday in exchange for a free ticket.
In 1989, an administrator of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration admitted to The Wall Street Journal that his agency did not even monitor the results of the $2 billion it spent each year.
A Department of Transportation employee told me about a telephone device for the deaf that the agency purchased for her use. She could have bought it retail for $300. The department paid $600.
These stories demonstrate that Government has a lot of good people trapped in bad systems.
We need to move from an industrial-age Government to an information-age Government. We are working to change the very culture of our Government. We want a Government that measures performance and puts its customers first. We want to inject competition within Government and make Government more market-oriented. We want to empower communities to solve their own problems, give workers the power to make their own decisions and then hold them accountable for the results.
This fall, the National Performance Review will produce a report with specific suggestions for steps we can take immediately and for longer-term action to bring about real change. It's time we created a Government that can move on issues as small as a steam trap and as large as our future.

HEADLINE: Free-Trade Treaty May Widen Traffic In Drugs, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER with TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Cocaine smugglers working with Colombian drug cartels are starting to set up factories, warehouses and trucking companies in Mexico to exploit the flood of cross-border commerce expected under the North American Free Trade Agreement, United States intelligence and law-enforcement officials say.
The Mexican smugglers are buying and setting up the companies "as fronts for drug trafficking," said a report written by an intelligence officer at the United States Embassy in Mexico City. The phenomenon was confirmed by a senior United States official who oversees enforcement of anti-drug laws and who spoke on condition that he not be identified by name. 
 The cocaine traffickers "intend to maximize their legitimate business enterprises within the auspices of the new U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement," the report said. The report was released under the Freedom of Information Act to the National Security Archive, a private research group in Washington that seeks to declassify Government documents.
 
Taking Advantage of Exemption
 The document said traffickers had also started to buy manufacturing and assembly plants known as maquiladoras as fronts for drug shipments, the senior United States official said.
Under a program established in 1965, the maquiladoras have special tariff exemptions, and the goods they produce move in and out of the United States with minimal inspection.
"A lot of intelligence demonstrates the drug traffickers' ties to maquiladoras," the United States official said. "They are investing in these plants for shipments to the United States."
United States investigators said that they first noted the phenomenon 16 months ago and that the problem was growing; Mexican officials, who first heard of it six weeks ago from their United States counterparts, said they knew of only a few such cases.
The intelligence report, intended mainly as a warning, did not specify how widespread the problem was or which companies the smugglers were investing in. Law enforcement officials on both sides of the border said they did not know the scope of the threat.
"The free-trade agreement makes the United States more accessible and convenient for traffickers," said a United States official involved in fighting drug traffickers. "It gives these people better opportunities to smuggle drugs."
The trade agreement, which was signed in December by President Bush, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, awaits approval by Congress and by the legislatures of Mexico and Canada. Over the next 15 years, it would gradually eliminate tariffs on goods traded among the three nations and eventually allow Mexican truckers to drive their rigs anywhere in the United States and Canada.
A trade expert and two former United States trade negotiators said that while United States and Mexican officials had foreseen the possibility that drug traffickers would take advantage of the trade pact, the problem was not raised during the negotiations. In fact, the pact does not address law enforcement issues related to trade.
 
Why It Wasn't Talked About
 "This was in the 'too hot to handle' category," said Gary Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics and co-author of a favorable book about the trade pact. "It's a painfully obvious problem."
The challenges facing customs inspectors are already daunting. Mexican smugglers working with the Medellin and Cali drug cartels in Colombia already ship 50 percent to 70 percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States, hauling roughly 200 tons a year over the border and pocketing billions of dollars in profit.
The maquiladoras have grown over the past decade into Mexico's most important source of foreign exchange after oil. More than 2,100 maquiladoras employ half a million workers to make components or finished products from materials that are allowed into Mexico duty-free. The products, from furniture and television sets to auto parts, are shipped back by truck or train, with duty payments only on the value added in Mexico.
 
Drugs Among the Electronics
 A senior Mexican law-enforcement official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said the United States officials' warning could "definitely" be well founded.
He said officials were investigating a report of a cocaine shipment hidden in electronics components, although he had not confirmed that any specific maquiladora was being used to smuggle drugs.
Since Mexico deregulated its trucking industry in 1989, each maquiladora has been allowed to operate its own truck fleet and set up its own trucking company. That alone might make them attractive to smugglers.
"The issue of the maquilas is a new one," the Mexican official said. "There is no hard evidence, but these guys are not stupid, and the path is very clear."
A senior Mexican customs official who, following the policy of the Finance Secretariat, also insisted on anonymity, said maquiladora commerce was treated deferentially on both sides of the border. He said that the United States Customs Service has the right to inspect maquiladora and shipments, but that such checks are rare.
"I think the controls will, naturally, get looser" under the free-trade pact, the Mexican customs official said.
Thus the accord is likely to complicate life for customs supervisors like Bill Lackey, in El Paso.
At Mr. Lackey's post on Friday, a line of tractor-trailers spewing diesel fumes stretched for a quarter of a mile across the Bridge of the Americas into Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, waiting for inspections by the two officials on duty.
About 1,700 trucks cross the bridge over the Rio Grande each day, almost all from maquiladoras making textiles and electronic components. Inspections last as little as five minutes.
 
Conflicting Goals at Border
 "We understand they have to get in and get out," Mr. Lackey said. "That is their living. We respect each other. The people coming across understand our problems and adapt to that."
Customs officials are torn between the goals of stopping contraband and supporting commerce. Today "most trucks that go through customs go through almost unimpeded," said Mike Lane, the deputy customs commissioner at El Paso.
But he said 300 new inspectors and new surveillance gear at the 22 customs posts between the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico would help ferret out the smugglers.
Others familiar with the cocaine trade express doubts.
"The passage of Nafta will clearly put additional strain on customs at the borders," said Assistant United States Attorney Glenn MacTaggart, who prosecuted members of the so-called Juarez cartel, one of the Mexican syndicates cited in the intelligence report.
The Juarez cartel imported the biggest cocaine cache ever seized in the United States, a 21-ton supply found in 1989 in a warehouse near Los Angeles.
"If Nafta provides opportunity for legitimate businesses, it may clearly provide opportunities for illegitimate businessmen," Mr. MacTaggart said. "It's almost common sense."
Under the trade agreement, the export of Mexican products in Mexican trucks would vastly expand. Today, a tractor-trailer truck owned by a Mexican company cannot travel beyond a narrow commercial zone near the border, and trailers are transferred there to American haulers. If the pact is approved, a Mexican trucker will be able to travel to any point in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas by 1997, and anywhere in the United States and Canada by 2001.
Evidence suggests that tractor-trailers are becoming a vehicle of choice for Mexican drug smugglers. One truck that was halted in April 45 miles southeast of San Diego held eight tons of cocaine stuffed into cans of jalapeno peppers. American law-enforcement officials said they believed the cocaine belonged to a businessman who owns one of the biggest trucking companies in Mexico.
The cans of peppers were marked "La Comadre" -- The Godmother.

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: Democrats Drop Donors' Session With President

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
The Democratic Party must have figured it had come up with an an offer no lobbyist could refuse. In invitations faxed and mailed all over the city last week, the party offered a weekend retreat, including a big breakfast with President Clinton, intimate briefings with senior White House officials and a gala dinner party.
The price: $15,000 a couple. Political action committees and deep-pocket corporate contributors were especially welcome. 
 But after discussions with the White House -- already smarting from a bad run of allegations of cronyism and misusing the perquisites of office -- the party canceled the breakfast with the President today after a reporter called to ask about Mr. Clinton's participation.
A party spokeswoman said the breakfast was abandoned to avoid any appearance of impropriety.
Some White House officials said they were not even aware of the party's plan to have the President attend the breakfast until it was brought to their attention.
The fund-raising scheme, which mimics an approach made popular by Republican Administrations, offers potential donors a chance to participate in a weekend of activity that includes a buffet dinner with Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, the breakfast with Mr. Clinton, and several briefings with senior Administration officials. The events are to be capped by a gala at the Washington Convention Center.
"I don't think in any way, shape or form that we are selling access to this President or this Administration at all," said Catherine Moore, the spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee. "We're a political party that has to raise funds. We're doing all we can to increase our small donor base and broaden our donor base across the country."
Ms. Moore said senior officials would still participate because "there's a difference between access and briefings."
Still, invitations to the June fund-raising "retreat" have been raising the eyebrows of lobbyists and prominent Democrats here at a time when the Administration's campaign finance bill is headed for the Senate floor.
The idea of allowing contributors to sidle up to the President and his chief policy makers in less than formal ways is not new. The Bush Administration was criticized for offering special "issues briefings" for a fee.
And Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, while head of the Senate Finance committee, offered 200 Washington lobbyists and directors of political action committees the chance to have breakfast with him once a month if they contributed $10,000 each to his re-election campaign. He later canceled the practice after admitting that it was a "doozy" of a mistake.
But Clinton Administration officials have said they would set a higher moral tone. Mr. Clinton pointedly refused contributions from political action committees during his campaign, and he has frequently spoken of the need for political reform in Washington. The campaign finance overhaul measure now before the Senate has been presented as a drastic change from business-as-usual political fund-raising that will level the playing field for candidates.
Yet Mr. Clinton helped raise more than $3.5 million for his party at a star-studded dinner at Lincoln Center in New York earlier this month. And by specifically soliciting corporate contributions in the invitation to the June retreat, the party is leaving the door open for the kind of unrestricted donations that would be outlawed if the proposed rules are enacted.
"They shouldn't be doing it," said Fred Wertheimer, the president of Common Cause. "It's the same thing the Republicans did with Bush. You're holding up the notion that you're selling access to the President and the Cabinet and officials, depending on how much money you're prepared to give."
Mr. Wertheimer said ommon Cause, the public interest lobby, would push the Senate to amend the campaign finance bill submitted by the President to specifically bar the solicitation of money based on access to Federal officials.
White House officials said they were aware of the President's Dinner, scheduled for June 28, but not about the events surrounding it. The money raised goes to the Democratic Party and its candidates around the country, not just to the President.
 
Loopholes to Evade Limits
 The President's Dinner, used by both parties as a staple of their money-raising activities, has been the target of criticism before. Although individuals can buy a ticket to the dinner for $1,500, many corporations and other groups in the past have bought several tables, using loopholes in the campaign finance law to evade limits.
One common technique is for corporations to solicit contributions from employees, bundle them together and buy blocks of tickets. One of the chairmen of the dinner that Republicans held last year was James R. Elliott, an Illinois businessman who was sued by an employee who charged that he had been forced to buy tickets.
White House officials have said they will continue to abide by the rules as they now stand.
"We are working day and night to change the campaign finance system," one Administration official said. "The President has proposed soft-money reforms that will take literally tens of millions of dollars out of the party's coffers and restrict his own ability to raise money."
One Administration official said, "We're not going to unilaterally disarm by stopping our fund-raising while the Republicans who are blocking reform continue to raise money."
The weekend retreat will begin the night of June 27 with a buffet dinner at the Mayflower, a hotel a few blocks north of the White House that is the headquarters of the event. The invitation promises the attendance of "honored guests such as Mack McLarty or Bob Rubin," the chairman of the President's national economic council.
The participants will attend a briefing at the Old Executive Office Building, where much of the White House staff works. In the afternoon, ticket holders will join other top Administration officials for afternoon sessions at the Mayflower.
Listed as "suggested speakers" for the afternoon are Mr. Rubin; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers; Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director; Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, and Ira C. Magaziner, the manager of the President's Task Force on Health Care Reform, who has emphasized the importance of keeping special interests at an arm's length.

HEADLINE: Clinton Aides Propose Renewal of China's Favored Trade Status

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Top advisers to President Clinton recommended today that he renew China's favorable trade status, Government and human rights officials said this evening. But they said he should require that Beijing improve its human rights record before any further annual renewals are granted.
The President did not immediately endorse the recommendation but told his aides to brief Congress on Tuesday. 
 The effort by the White House is an attempt to make good on promises that Mr. Clinton made in the Presidential campaign, when he repeatedly accused the Bush Administration of failing to use trade as a lever to force China to improve its rights record.
 
Tariffs Would Rise Sharply
 The President could have canceled China's favorable trade status, but since taking office he has come under pressure from those who say continuing trade with China is the best way to improve conditions there and from business executives who quail at the thought of losing such a vast market.
If China lost its "most favored nation" trade status, tariffs on Chinese goods imported into the United States would rise from an average of 8 percent to about 40 percent.
Mr. Clinton can change course if members of Congress object to the plan, which would impose conditions by executive order rather than by law.
The plan would require substantial progress by Beijing on human rights issues, like a full accounting of the whereabouts of political prisoners. But it would not link renewals to progress on any single issue.
The most delicate issue currently arises in Tibet, where a demonstration today against Chinese rule became rowdy, leading the police to break up the rally with tear gas. [Page A3.]
The memorandum also says China must curb the spread of missile and nuclear-weapons technology and provide more access to its markets.
China agreed last year to limit its exports of ballistic missile technology, to protect foreign copyrights and trademarks and to lower tariffs on a broad range of goods.
The recommendation from Mr. Clinton's advisers suggests a softening of his final position in the Presidential campaign, which in turn was less stringent than his original stand.
In December 1991, at a debate in New Hampshire, he said China's access to the United States market should be closed entirely unless democratic changes were made by the end of 1992.
In his campaign manifesto last summer, Mr. Clinton wrote: "We believe that the Bush Administration erred by extending most-favored-nation trade status to the People's Republic of China before it achieved documented progress on human rights. We should not reward China with improved trade status when it has continued to trade goods made by prison labor and has failed to make sufficient progress on human rights since the Tiananmen Square massacre."
Since he assumed office, President Clinton has come under intense pressure from business and farm groups not to impose any conditions on China, which has one of the fastest growing economies. More than 300 large corporations and trade associations wrote him on May 12 urging an unconditional extension.
Under the Jackson-Vanik Amendment of 1974, China and other Communist countries may retain the favorable trade status only if they receive certification by the President that they allow emigration. China's status is to expire on July 3 unless President Clinton announces by June 3 that he intends to extend it.
Almost all of United States trading partners have the favorable trade status.
 
Threat of Retaliation
 Beijing has threatened to retaliate against United States exports if its trade status is canceled or if any conditions are imposed by legislation. For reasons that are not entirely clear, Chinese officials have been less critical of conditions imposed by executive order.
Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine and majority leader, and Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, have introduced legislation that would also require substantial overall progress on human rights, but both have said they would accept Presidential conditions instead. "What we want more than anything is a unified message from the President and the Congress," Ms. Pelosi said this evening.
Ms. Pelosi said she had spoken at noon today with Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, who did not present an Administration position. A spokeswoman for Senator Mitchell said the Senator had also spoken with Mr. Lord, who visited China this month but failed to win any clear concessions.
Mr. Lord is to brief the House Ways and Means Committee, which oversees trade policy, on Tuesday morning. Michael Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of Asia Watch, said a final announcement could come Thursday.
 
Possible Fight in Congress
 Today's decision does not solve the Administration's political troubles with China's trade status. Any member of the House of Representatives may force a floor vote within 60 days of a Presidential decision to extend the favorable trade status of a Communist country. To override the President, the House and Senate must both vote to cancel the decision.
In a recent interview, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York, said he planned to force such a vote in the House. But no one in the Senate has expressed any enthusiasm for such a move, making it unlikely President Clinton would lose.

HEADLINE: White House Asked Aid Of F.B.I. in Dismissals

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Amid concern in the White House last Friday over charges that cronyism lay behind the dismissal of seven travel aides, Clinton advisers summoned a senior official in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to a political strategy session and solicited a public statement from the agency backing their version of events.
By calling on the F.B.I. to help save the Administration from embarrassment, the White House appeared to be deviating from two decades of efforts to insulate the law-enforcement agency from even the appearance of Presidential manipulation. 
 It also put the bureau in the position of departing from what some F.B.I. officials said had been two long-standing practices: dealing with the White House only through the Justice Department to avoid the appearance that the bureau was being enlisted for political ends, and avoiding confirmations of the bureau's investigations. In the past, F.B.I. officials have been disciplined for disclosing investigations.
An Administration official said tonight that Attorney General Janet Reno had called the White House counsel, Bernard Nussbaum, today to complain about the White House not having gone through her office to deal with the F.B.I. statement. The official told of the complaint in confirming an account in the Tuesday issue of The Washington Post.
In an interview tonight, Mr. Nussbaum said that in his conversation with Ms. Reno he had "reaffirmed" that "it has been and remains the policy of the White House that any contact" with the F.B.I. would be made through the Attorney General's office. The original contact with the F.B.I. was made by the White House, he said, because officials there regarded the suspicion of improper acts in the travel office as a police matter.
The disclosure of the White House's interaction with the bureau came during questioning of George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, by reporters at today's news briefing.
 
'We've Got to Do Better'
 Mr. Stephanopoulos also acknowledged that President Clinton was "disappointed in what happened" last week, when the furor over the dismissal of the travel office staff and over the President's expensive haircut at Los Angeles International Airport diverted attention from his economic message. Mr. Stephanopoulos said the President "feels we've got to do better, and we will."
"What we saw last week isn't going to happen again," Mr. Stephanopoulos added. But he no sooner uttered those words than he found himself bombarded by questions about the links between the White House and the F.B.I. in the travel office dismissals.
John Collingwood, the bureau official who attended the White House meeting, said that no one had tried to manipulate the agency into backing the White House findings of mismanagement. "I'm very confident we followed our normal practice here," he said.
Nevertheless, he said he was "surprised" when Presidential aides on Friday took the highly unusual step of releasing an F.B.I. statement not intended for public release, confirming that a Federal inquiry was under way.
 
Political Strategy Session
 While the F.B.I. normally does not disclose investigations, he said, this particular statement was consistent with the bureau's policy of acknowledging some high-profile investigations if the facts have been disclosed by a credible source, in this case the White House.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said today that last Friday, Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, called Mr. Collingwood, the bureau's director of public affairs and Congressional relations, and asked him to meet in Mr. Stephanopoulos's office with Mr. Stephanopoulos; Ms. Myers; David Watkins, assistant to the President for management and administration, who supervised the travel office; Mr. Nussbaum and two members of his staff.
White House officials acknowledged that the meeting was a political strategy session on how to quell the furor over the abrupt dismissal of the travel office staff.
The F.B.I. official was asked to help draft a statement on Friday afternoon after several news organizations obtained a memorandum written by Mr. Clinton's cousin, Catherine Cornelius, less than a month after Mr. Clinton took office, proposing that the White House dismiss the seven career travel office employees and put her in charge.
The disclosure of the Cornelius memo had called into question the White House's claims that the members of the travel office staff were dismissed purely because of mismanagement and possible criminal behavior.
 
Possible Criminal Behavior
 Normally, bureau spokesmen neither confirm nor deny the existence of an investigation, except in unusual cases when it has come to light independently. Some F.B.I. officials said privately last week that they were uncomfortable with the way their agency was being brought into a case with apparent political ramifications.
Nevertheless, bureau officials also said there appeared to have been adequate grounds to begin a preliminary criminal investigation, as the White House had claimed.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said the Clinton team had "talked to" the F.B.I. official about issuing a statement backing the White House claim of possible criminality. That claim was based on an earlier investigation of the office by the accounting firm of Peat Marwick. Mr. Stephanopoulos said no coercion had been involved, and that it was simply a discussion between the White House and the F.B.I. about what, if anything, the bureau would feel comfortable saying at that stage of the investigation.
 
Reno Met With Sessions

As the White House was releasing the bureau's statement last Friday, Ms. Reno and the F.B.I. Director, William S. Sessions, were meeting to discuss his future with the agency. Mr. Sessions has been under fire for months, and his job is currently under review by the Clinton Administration because of allegations of wrongdoing that were brought by the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said Mr. Sessions played no role in approving the bureau's statement about its investigation of the travel office.
Asked if he had been aware that it was not standard practice for the F.B.I. to confirm investigations, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "I'd have to check the standard practice."

HEADLINE: TIBETANS PROTEST CHINA'S IRON RULE

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 24

 BODY:
Hundreds of Tibetans protested against Chinese rule today in the most serious such demonstration in the last few years, American travelers said by telephone.
The authorities initially permitted the protest, but when it grew, they responded by firing barrages of tear gas at the protesters. The police detained at least nine foreigners briefly and warned all foreigners to stay off the streets on Tuesday because of concerns that the protests will continue. 
 The last major demonstration in Lhasa occurred in March 1989, when anti-Chinese rioting led the Government to impose martial law for 13 months.
The demonstration today, in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, reportedly began shortly after noon as a protest against inflation and the lifting of price controls on food. But by the late afternoon the slogans changed -- to "Chinese out of Tibet!" -- and the crowd grew.
By some accounts, scattered stones were thrown at Chinese police cars, but by and large the protest was peaceful. The police also responded with relative restraint, relying on tear gas grenades instead of live ammunition as they did in demonstrations in the 1980's.
 
Protesters Disperse
 The tear gas dispersed the demonstrators, but some told foreigners that the protests would resume on Tuesday. The American travelers, all Tibetan-speakers who spoke independently by telephone, said that the Chinese police were patrolling the streets with machine guns.
The demonstration presents a major challenge to the Chinese authorities. If they do not respond harshly, the protests could quickly spread because of the simmering hostility that many Tibetans feel toward the Chinese. Many experts believe that animosity has reached the point that protests will grow unless they are immediately countered with force and fear.
Yet a major crackdown on Tibetan protesters would stir protests from abroad at precisely the time when Chinese leaders are trying to be on their best behavior. President Clinton must decide within the next two weeks what kinds of human rights conditions to attach to China's trade status, and the International Olympic Committee will decide in September whether to allow Beijing to play host to the Summer Olympic Games in the year 2000.
The authorities did not release any information about the protests.
 
Report From American
 "It started as an economic protest, and so the Chinese didn't stop them," a 25-year-old American witness said. Like the others, he declined to be quoted by name for fear of being detained and expelled. "There were about 150 people to begin with," he added. "Lots of police were watching, but they didn't do much at first."
The protesters marched several miles to the other side of Lhasa, all the way to a Holiday Inn, where a delegation of European ambassadors stayed last week. The ambassadors suspended part of their program after learning that three Tibetans had been arrested for trying to contact them. The protesters may not have realized that the entire delegation left Lhasa on Sunday.
The American witnesses said that by about 6 P.M. there were 500 or 600 protesters, and that the mood became much more political. In addition to demanding that Chinese leave Tibet, the protesters accused the Chinese of corrupting young Tibetans.
In addition to firing tear gas, the police may have used their guns. A 20-year-old American woman said she had heard what she believed were gunshots, and she and another American said they had reliable information that one Tibet man was shot in the leg.
Tibet, a remote Himalayan region that China insists is an indivisible part of its territory, is overwhelmingly Buddhist, and the inhabitants revere the Dalai Lama as their spiritual leader. China reasserted control over Tibet in 1950 -- after decades in which it was pretty much left to itself -- and on Sunday China commemorated the 42d anniversary of what it calls the "peaceful liberation" of Tibet.
Lhasa is 1,700 miles from Beijing, and reliable information is difficult to come by. No Western diplomats are based in Tibet, telephone connections are troublesome, and the authorities ban journalists based in Beijing from visiting the region.
An American woman reached by telephone said the police detained her for seven hours after she took photographs of the protesters. She said the police had confiscated her film but were polite and even friendly.

HEADLINE: Media Memo;
Struggling to Bring the Health-Care Debate Home to Readers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
There are many unknowns about the health-care proposal that President Clinton is to unveil next month, but one thing is certain: press coverage of it will be virtually endless after the secret Washington sessions end.
Less certain is whether all that coverage will be comprehensible. 
 The national health-care debate, perhaps as much as any news story in years, is testing journalism's ability to do its job, to explain to people why they should care. The issues are highly technical, and even the language of the discussion has been dictated in Washington by policy experts.
Journalists' ability to translate that debate effectively is likely to help determine the fate of efforts to change the health system. It could also set a standard for the news media in trying to explain an increasingly complex world.
 
What Does it Mean to Me?
 Around the nation, reporters and editors say they are struggling with how to bring the health-care debate home to readers. Like such difficult subjects as the economy or the savings and loan crisis, health policy almost defies simplification.
In interviews, editors said they were aware of the dangers in covering such a complicated issue.
"If you don't present the issues in ways that people can understand -- 'What does it mean to me?' -- your coverage is inadequate," said Clark Hoyt, chief of Knight-Ridder's Washington bureau.
But editors also said they felt compelled to keep up with the policy debate. "You have to cover the Washington maneuverings and cover them closely," said Norman C. Miller, national editor of The Los Angeles Times.
Mr. Miller and other news professionals said it was especially difficult right now to try to translate the topic into meaningful articles focused on individual problems and consumers because there was no specific plan.
 
From Country to Capitoal
 Americans put health care on the national agenda, motivated in large part by the reporting of such emotional subjects as people's fears of slipping through health-insurance cracks. And many major newspapers continue to try to show the impact of potential Washington decisions on individuals.
But as the debate moved from the country to the capital, readings of 10 major daily newspapers earlier this month showed that news coverage had centered less on the way decisions might affect people and more on policy battles, multibillion-dollar national price tags and political speculation about whether Hillary Rodham Clinton, the head of the President's Task Force on Health Care Reform, would be able to pull it off.
In a detailed policy debate, news organizations have two jobs: to explain how decisions are made and to show how those decisions affect people. The difficult part for news organizations, as the debate grows in Washington, is to keep the policy coverage from overshadowing the "what does it mean to me" coverage.
 
'Media Can Sink This Ship'
 "If we continue to see the multi-billion-dollar stories and the horse-race stories, if that continues to dominate media coverage, then the media can sink this ship as surely as they brought it up," said Kevin Anderson, a spokesman for the Alliance for Health Reform, a nonpartisan group that provides education on health-care issues. Mr. Anderson is a reporter on leave from USA Today.
If the health-care debate seems too remote or too focused on reducing costs nationally, some who have studied the issue say, that could persuade people to cling to the status quo.
Robert J. Blendon, chairman of the department of health policy and management at the Harvard School of Public Health, recently reviewed news coverage of efforts by the Truman and Nixon Administrations to enact health plans. Then and now, he said, news organizations had difficulty focusing on the relatively simple questions people ask: Will there be a doctor in my town? How much will I have to pay? Will I have a choice about where I go for care?
Dr. Blendon said that too many reports presented a muddle of official proclamations and trial balloons, analysis of health-care systems and expert debate about cost as a percentage of gross national product. At the same time, he said, opponents of proposed health-care changes zeroed in on people's real interests. In paid advertisements, opponents raised questions like this one from an old advertising campaign: Do you want the Government between you and your doctor?
 
Focus on 'Keyhole' Reporting
 "The press gets it wrong in terms of addressing what people care about," Dr. Blendon said, "and the people who take out full-page ads get it right."
In an article published this week in the Journal of the American Medical Association, Dr. Blendon argued that "in both historical cases, as well as the present day, the special interests found an inadvertent ally in the media" because news organizations were too often guilty of "neglecting the informational needs of the American public."
Mr. Anderson of the Alliance for Health Reform echoed the views of several journalists when he said he believed that reporters would cover the issue much more from a "what does it mean to the reader" perspective once the President makes his proposal public.
In the meantime though, he said, news accounts suffer because so many reporters are engaging in what he called "keyhole" reporting of what is going on behind the closed doors of the health task force. Major news organizations battle each other every week to report the latest leak.
In recent weeks, there have been some efforts to reduce the policy discussion to human terms. A Los Angeles Times article by Sara Fritz, for instance, approached the issue this way: "When Joan Ravenna had a heart attack a few years ago, she had to wait more than 20 hours before being examined by a cardiologist. As she remembers it, she could easily have died that day as a result of flaws in the system of 'managed care' that President Clinton is advocating for all Americans."
Much more of the coverage appears to be aimed at people who view health care as a policy question rather than a personal one. But, in interviews, journalists said that current coverage was not a fair sample of their work because there was no specific Clinton proposal to describe.
Even so, it is not clear that much of the media will be able to shift gears once the specifics are known. Even some of the nation's best newspapers have occasionally presented a mass of statistics and aggregate information that would be impenetrable to even the most informed reader.
For instance, Steve Sternberg in The Atlanta Constitution began a recent front-page article this way: "President Clinton's health-care reform plan hinges on a $1 trillion question: Can the Government cover 37 million uninsured Americans and enhance care for everyone else without adding $30 billion to $100 billion to the nation's annual $900 billion medical bill?"
Other reporting has become preoccupied with describing what the Clinton advisers are considering -- then afterward often reporting that they will not necessarily do that after all. Some Washington veterans say they sense a classic trial-balloon scenario, in which the Administration uses the press to test public reaction.
 
Balloons Floated, Then Popped
 The New York Times on May 11: "President Clinton's health-policy advisers have been developing plans to incorporate Medicare into a new health-care system, even as they have assured elderly people that no major changes were imminent."
USA Today on May 12: "White House health adviser Ira Magaziner said Tuesday, there's no plan to tinker with Medicare."
Some critics say news organizations have begun following the Washington doings as if the pressing national question were who's up and who's down. And they say the press often misses out on what kind of health care might be delivered in the neighborhood medical office.
Professor Blendon traced the media's institutional approach to the issue, in part, to the fact that health-care reporting is now largely the domain of political reporters who are used to seeing things from a Washington perspective.
But even health writers, he said, are often captives of the experts they interview. Mr. Magaziner, manager of the President's task force and therefore the current leading expert in residence, often uses jargon like "actuarially, you would get killed on your cost," when speaking publicly about the issue.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New CNN Channel Planned

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 24

 BODY:
Ted Turner said today that his Turner Broadcasting System Inc. was developing a new Cable News Network international news channel and a new entertainment channel that would offer classic films.
Speaking at the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. Turner, chairman of Turner Broadcasting, said the CNN international channel might be marketed in the United States by the end of the year, and the movie channel in the "not-too-distant future." 
 "Those are two new channels we have on the drawing boards," Mr. Turner said. "Neither one of them have been approved by the board of directors yet."
He said the commercial-free movie channel would offer older M-G-M, Warner Brothers and RKO films and would compete with the American Movie Classics channel.
The CNN international channel will be about 80 percent different from CNN's domestic news network and will be marketed "to people who are more interested in international news," Mr. Turner said. It will offer more in-depth analysis than network news programs do, he said.
Mr. Turner also said he was open to future changes in the operating and ownership structure of Turner Broadcasting. But he declined to be specific about the future roles of Tele-Communications and Time-Warner Inc., which own 23 percent and 19 percent of Turner's equity, respectively.
Both companies have reportedly discussed splitting up Turner's assets between them. John Malone, chief executive of Tele-Communications, has said his company is "very interested in all of the assets of Turner Broadcasting."
Mr. Turner said it was unclear how the company's relationship with its two major shareholders might change. "That's impossible to read," he said. "They're both very ambitious companies, and they want to grow."
