HEADLINE: A NEW PRESIDENT FOR CITY COLLEGE

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
The trustees of the City University of New York last night appointed a black anthropologist from an urban California campus as the next president of City College, long the jewel but now one of the most troubled of the university system's 21 campuses.
In selecting Dr. Yolanda T. Moses as City College's new president, the board chose a little-known vice president for academic affairs from California State University in Dominguez Hills, a largely black suburb of Los Angeles, who is known as a strong proponent of cultural diversity. 
 After a private 90-minute session, board members emerged to announce the appointment of Dr. Moses, echoing the earlier assessment of the search committee, that she was the best person for the job and would be familiar with many types of problems facing City College.
"We need someone who can deal with the rescuing and rehabilitating of the reputation of the school," said Dr. James L. de Jongh, chairman of the college's Faculty Senate and a member of the search committee. "I think she's the best person to deal with these things."
Chancellor Dr. W. Ann Reynolds said that Dr. Moses is a "teacher, scholar, administrator: she has done all three and done them extraordinarily well."
Dr. Moses, 46 years old, is to take over City College as it struggles with financial difficulties, faces a major reorganization and is still reeling from a controversy in which one of its department heads successfully sued the college for thwarting his First Amendment rights.
In a telephone interview last night, Dr. Moses said that she was well aware of the college's problems, and that her first move would be to "walk the halls, knock on doors and sit down and talk with different groups of people."
"I plan to do a whole lot of listening," she said.
The vote to appoint Dr. Moses, who is to take on the $119,000-a-year position beginning Aug. 1, was 12 to 1. One board member, Herman Badillo, objected to the appointment, saying he feared she would sacrifice scholarship at City College in her pursuit of diversity.
"I am very disturbed by many of Ms. Moses's ideas and philosophies," said Mr. Badillo, who is considering whether to run for City Comptroller.
Mr. Badillo said he was bothered by Dr. Moses's writings on cultural diversity in higher education, particularly a passage in one article he quoted as: "research is still more highly valued and rewarded by both the administration and faculty . . . that will have to change if cultural pluralism is to flourish."
Mr. Badillo said that passage indicated a willingness to drop standards for minority faculty, a mistake he said the college had made in hiring Dr. Leonard Jeffries.
 
'What Can I Do?'
 Mr. Badillo is one of four board members held liable by a Federal jury last week in the case of Dr. Jeffries, the head of the college's Black Studies Department. Dr. Jeffries sued the college when he was dismissed as a department head after a controversial speech in which he said, among other things, that rich Jews and the Mafia conspired to denigrate blacks in Hollywood movies.
After casting the only dissenting vote against Dr. Moses yesterday, Mr. Badillo left the board meeting saying the boardshould have taken more time to check Dr. Moses's credentials.
"What can I do?" he said. "It's over."
Dr. Reynolds, Mr. Murphy, and the head of the 11-member search committee, Calvin O. Pressley, also a trustee, said Mr. Badillo's misgivings had prompted them to consider Dr. Moses's qualifications more carefully.
But in the end, they said, they were even more convinced she was the right one to head City College.
"We think we have a winner here," said Mr. Murphy.
Mr. Pressley said the board was interested in cultural diversity, particularly because City College has a large minority student population. But he said that such diversity would not come at the expense of caring about academic excellence.
"Any person, especially Dr. Moses, who would come to City College would have to recognize our interest in making it the first-class institution it has been in the past, and hopefully will be in the future," he said. "She's committed to that."
Dr. Moses said that diversity and academic excellence enhanced each other.
She declined to discuss the Jeffries case because it is still under litigation.
The jury upheld Dr. Jeffries's contention that he had been denied his freedom of speech, and awarded him $400,000 in damages. The judge has yet to decide whether to reinstate him as a department head.
In addition to the aftermath of the Jeffries suit, Dr. Moses will face other difficulties. She will take over the college at a time when the university administration has proposed a restructuring of all its colleges, a move that many City College faculty and students fear will erode their school's standing as the premier academy in the system.
Dr. Moses said that as an administrator in a college system that has also been hard hit by state budget cuts, she will work hard to balance the financial realities with the fears of faculty members and students about educational standards.
"My role will be to get a balance of things and to look for ways to economize," she said. "But I also understand that this is the flagship of the whole university system. I respect that tradition. I promised the groups I met with at City that I would do everything I can to maintain that edge and to further the research and monetary goals of the college. You build on your strengths."
The college is also recovering from the incident in December 1991 in which nine students were trampled to death at a student-government-sponsored celebrity basketball game. Dr. Moses's predecessor, Dr. Bernard W. Harleston, resigned six months later.
A search committee made up of four board members, three faculty members, two students, one alumnus and the president of another CUNY college was formed shortly after.
Dr. Moses's selection by the search committee was first reported in yesterday's issue of in Newsday.
The search committee considered about 100 nominees for the job of president. They narrowed the list and in March four of them made visits to the campus. On May 16 trustees and the chancellor interviewed two of them, Dr. Moses and George Campbell Jr., a physicist.
In many regards, said Dr. de Jongh, Dr. Moses will find parallels at City College to her current campus. For example, the Cal State system has been one of the public college systems hit hardest by reductions in state financing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Yolanda T. Moses was appointed to be City College's new president by the CUNY board. She sat yesterday in her office of vice president for academic affairs at California State University in Dominguez Hills. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: LEADERS IN HAITI SPURN POLICE PLAN

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 24

 BODY:
After two days of talks and a month of intense diplomatic pressure, Haiti's military authorities have rejected an American-backed United Nations plan to deploy an international police force here as part of a settlement of Haiti's long political crisis, diplomats said today.
The rejection was delivered to President Clinton's special adviser for Haitian affairs, Lawrence Pezzullo, and the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo. It came after American diplomats expressed strong confidence in recent days that army leaders would accept the return of the country's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 Diplomats said the rejection set the stage for new economic and other sanctions against Haiti, which would be aimed at the military leaders and their supporters among the country's small elite.
Under the plan for the negotiated return of Father Aristide, he had agreed to an amnesty for the military leaders in the September 1991 coup and the subsequent political violence that has claimed as many as 3,000 lives.
 
'No Other Choice'
 A proposal to deploy 500 international police officers, which has encountered resistance from both military leaders and some Aristide supporters, was intended to help end the violence and to create a climate for negotiations on a new government and a deadline for the exiled President's return.
With the rejection, diplomats here said Haiti's military authorities had called the bluff of the United Nations and Washington, which have warned of serious new sanctions if diplomacy fails.
"We told them that they had left no possibility for the international community to end this crisis but to impose sanctions," said a diplomat close to the discussions. "We don't want to do this, but it was made absolutely clear that at this point there is no other choice."
Another diplomat said, "There are two sides to this thing, naturally, but so far we have only heard the details of one of them" -- a large international aid package being prepared for Haiti in expectation of a settlement. "It's time to begin talking seriously about the pain," the diplomat said.
 
Punitive Measures Suggested
 Since shortly after the coup, which forced Father Aristide into exile, there has been a hemispheric embargo on Haiti, but it has failed to sway the military and their allies among the Haitian elite. At the same time, however, the embargo has wreaked severe long-term damage to Haiti's economy and caused added pain for the bulk of the population in what had already been the hemisphere's poorest country.
Some diplomats here mentioned several possible punitive measures, including the prosecution of army leaders who are widely believed to be involved in narcotics trafficking, the blocking of petroleum shipments and the freezing of financial assets of supporters of the coup.
Adding to the pressure for sanctions, diplomats close to the negotiations here have said the United Nations has recently indicated that it will withdraw from the diplomacy here in the absence of support for strong punitive measures that can persuade the Haitian Army to move toward a resolution.
The United Nations special mediator for Haiti, Mr. Caputo, a former Argentine Foreign Minister, has made six trips here in recent weeks to seek an international settlement.
 
Frustration Is Expressed
 With great expectations of a breakthrough, fed by confident assessments from American diplomats, expressions of frustration toward the United States were common among diplomats here today.
"For weeks, the Americans have been telling everyone that the army is in agreement, that everything is in place," one said. "Then we come down here and see that there is nothing to it, absolutely nothing.
"Washington has one more opportunity to show that it is serious about settling this thing in a multilateral fashion, through sanctions. Otherwise, everyone else is going to withdraw and this is going to become an American problem again, all by itself."
But another diplomat close to the talks said that Mr. Clinton's special representative, Mr. Pezzullo, had "spoken very strongly" in warning the army leaders today, leaving "no doubt about where the Americans stand."

HEADLINE: Contracts Renewed Despite an Inquiry

 BODY:
New York City's Office of Contracts has ordered the limited renewal of several disputed contracts to a South Bronx antipoverty agency headed by Ramon S. Velez while investigators look into allegations of malfeasance raised by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
Ms. Holtzman had sought to block renewal of contracts totaling $1.6 million for Head Start and senior-citizen services from the Hunts Point Multi-Service Center, the flagship in Mr. Velez's South Bronx empire of social-service agencies and companies. 
 But Michael C. Rogers, director of the Office of Contracts, instructed her in a letter dated May 20 to approve those contracts and two others due to expire this fiscal year out of concern that an immediate halt would leave the community without an alternative source of social services.
The Comptroller's office expressed concern because the Office of Contracts had acknowledged the legitimacy of the objections and the office expected its legal staff to contact Mayor David N. Dinkins in coming days for a possible appeal. Under the City Charter, the Mayor can overrule the Comptroller and require the contracts to be registered or entered.
Ms. Holtzman said Mr. Velez had failed to disclose his chairmanship of several companies barred from bidding on Federal contracts after pleading guilty to bid-rigging in 1989.
Paul E. Bleifer, the lawyer for Hunts Point, said that the group had not engaged in financial irregularities and that Mr. Velez had complied with the city's disclosure requirements. Mr. Velez was not a defendant in the Federal case.

HEADLINE: Rural America Is Growing Slightly, Population Studies Show

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 20

 BODY:
Rural America, with its enticing vistas of fields, forests, buttes and mountains and its unenticing economy of failing farms, depleted mines and low-wage factories, hemorrhaged population throughout the 1980's. But new statistics for the early 1990's show that the countryside, at least for the moment, is holding its own again.
From one rural county to another, the changes documented by Kenneth Johnson, a demographer at Loyola University-Chicago, and Calvin Beale, a demographer at the Department of Agriculture in Washington, are slight but consistent. While only 47 percent of all rural counties in the United States gained population in the 1980's, two-thirds gained population from the spring of 1990, when the 1990 census was completed, to the spring of 1991. 
 Even more startling to demographers, Federal labor statistics show that in the fiscal year 1992, for the first time in 13 years, the unemployment rate in nonmetropolitan areas was lower than that for metropolitan areas. In rural areas the unemployment rate was 7.1 percent, and in metropolitan areas, 7.5 percent.
The reasons are many: a new factory here, a new retirement community there, a once-threatened farm turning solvent, the tentacles of urban growth beginning to touch once-empty spaces.
 
Tentative Rural Growth
 The new figures from Federal census surveys cover only one year, and because people are still leaving many rural areas -- particularly the Plains states and the Mississippi Delta -- demographers are not prepared to declare an end to the decline in rural population.
For most of the 20th century the exodus from farm and timber country has been a way of life. The notable exception was the 1970's, in what demographers call a "turnaround decade," when rural America grew faster than metropolitan America. That has not happened yet in the 1990's, but at least the rural population is growing, not shrinking.
In states as varied as Maine, Wisconsin, Missouri and Montana the numbers show rural population growth, often in counties that lost population in the 1980's. "In 33 states, nonmetropolitan gains were more widespread than during the 1980's," the study said. "Only seven states had fewer growing nonmetropolitan counties in 1990-91."
Commenting on reports of population growth in Aroostook County, a timber and potato-growing area that sprawls across the northern part of Maine, Dana Evans, a labor economist for the State of Maine, said: "It's true, it's there. But it's small."
State officials like Mr. Evans or Glenn Bobb, a Pennsylvania demographer, remain wary of the new numbers. And Mr. Johnson and Mr. Beale agree that, while the data may reflect the beginning of a new era of rural growth like the 1970's, they may also represent a momentary blip in a population curve that will continue downward.
 
Improving Job Picture
 But Mr. Beale, the dean of rural demography in America, said he suspects that something basic is changing. "The economic pictures in the rural areas was so poor from 1980 on," he said. "Three-quarters of the decade saw a combination of an exceptionally severe and long farm crisis with a general economic recession. What we see now, even though the country is having this in-and-out recession, is that the employment picture since 1990 has looked better in the nonmetro areas than in the metro areas."
The new population figures, the demographer said, reflect in part a desire by city dwellers to create a new place to provide respite from urban problems.
"There is this continuing tendency for urban America to want large chunks of rural America for urban playgrounds," Mr. Beale said. "Many of the growing rural areas are either within sprawling distance of metropolitan areas or else are being used as refuges or playgrounds for urban people, like western Montana."
In other areas, particularly the Ozark Mountains in Missouri and Arkansas, and the coastal areas of the Carolinas or the Great Lakes, the urban refugees are retired people seeking a bucolic life.
 
Defining a Rural Area
 Federal statisticians use a complex set of criteria to define metropolitan and nonmetropolitan, or rural, areas. These include population density and the presence of an urban center with a population of at least 50,000. After every census, more and more counties on the fringes of metropolitan areas are redefined, going from rural to urban.
In 1980 there were 2,369 rural counties with a population of 53.6 million. After the 1990 census the number of rural counties dropped to 2,288, with a population of 52 million. In the past year these rural areas have gained 532,000 people, the new surveys show.
In a place like Adams County in south-central Pennsylvania, all the current trends seem to converge. The job base is not growing dramatically, but the printing plants and the dairy farms have all grown a little. And outsiders -- usually "white license plate" people from Maryland, fleeing the urban sprawl of Washington and Baltimore, keep coming.
 
New Jobs, Low Wages
 Adams County has added almost 1,000 homes a year since 1980, a pace that continued in 1991 and 1992. The buyers include airline pilots, computer specialists and consultants who can work at home, and retired military officers and Federal employees drawn to the orchards and rolling hills around the Civil War battlefield of Gettysburg.
New jobs also appeared in recent years, thanks to businesses like Arcata Graphics, a book-printing plant in Fairfield that started in 1976 and now employs 604 people, or the Knouse Food Cooperative, or the dairy farm owned by Richard Waybright, an Adams County commissioner who is the sixth generation of his family to live here.
But the people working in the new jobs -- many of which are entry-level, paying $15,000 to $18,000 a year -- are not likely to be the same as the people in the new houses, which sell for $200,000 or $300,000.
Richard H. Shmoyer, the county planning director, said those in the first group are likely to live in a trailer park, hoping to save enough money for a downpayment on a permanent home.
The other group tend to have better-paying jobs on the fringes of Washington or Baltimore, he said. Mr. Schmoyer and his wife moved here from Norristown, a small city west of Philadelphia, where he had worked as a planner. His wife now commutes 50 minutes a day to her job in Buckeystown, Md.
If Adams County combines some of the trends that may help revive rural America, it is not alone. In eastern Wisconsin, along the shores of Lake Michigan, Kewaunee and Manitowoc counties, which lost population in the 1980's, gained some back in 1990-91.
Mr. Johnson, the Loyola demographer, said Manitowoc County has some light manufacturing plants that seem to be supporting the slight increase in population. Kewaunee County, he said, sends commuters north to Door County, whose economy is based on recreation and shipbuilding.
"I think there are a lot of people in nonmetro areas who want to stay there," Mr. Johnson said. "But they have to have some chance of having a reasonable economic life."
Tracing the ebb and flow of rural migration since World War II, he said surplus labor in rural areas forced young people to leave in the 1950's and 60's. The population of rural areas rebounded in the 1970's when there were more economic opportunities, he said, then dropped again in the 80's, when agriculture was hard hit.
Now things are picking up again in rural areas, Mr. Johnson said. There are more jobs, and young couples who grew up in the area and prefer the pace of rural America, feel able to stay. "The wife works at some place like McDonald's, the husband in an industrial plant," he said. "Then those people don't leave."

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Clinton's Woes on Capitol Hill Spur Sharp Criticism of His Top Lobbyist

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
When President Clinton made Howard Paster his chief lobbyist on Capitol Hill, he turned to the ultimate Washington insider.
As a lobbyist for the United Automobile Workers, Mr. Paster had played a leading role in negotiating the loan bailout for the Chrysler Corporation. He kept Eastern Airlines flying a few more years by negotiating tax breaks for the carrier. And representing the oil industry, he helped soften environmental provisions in the 1991 Clean Air Act. 
 But as Mr. Clinton's woes have snowballed in Congress, and the Administration girds for a crucial vote in the House on its economic package this Thursday, Mr. Paster's reputation as a master deal-maker on Capitol Hill has suffered.
The 48-year-old lobbyist is being blamed by many Democrats for misreading Senate Republicans before they filibustered Mr. Clinton's economic stimulus package to death last month. He is said to have ignored conservative and moderate Democrats before their objections to tax increases in the President's budget proposal blossomed into open revolt. And restless freshman Democrats complain that his staff does not return telephone calls or follow through on requests for favors.
 
'A Turning Point'
 Critics say Mr. Paster's disdain for the Democratic conservatives has helped harden the battle lines in the Senate. They say David L. Boren of Oklahoma, the leading Senate Democrat opposing the proposed energy tax, became more aggressive after Mr. Paster underestimated the importance of a February letter by Mr. Boren and seven other Democrats asking the President to retreat from his strategy of stimulating the economy with a jobs bill before enacting tax increases and enforcing budget cuts.
"It was a turning point," Mr. Boren said recently. Asked for his opinion of Mr. Paster, the Senator said, "I am concerned that the President is getting bad advice that causes him to always be publicly perceived as being in an adversarial role with conservative and moderate Democrats."
Lawmakers said Mr. Paster, whose dry, cutting wit and straight-talking style are sometimes interpreted as confrontational, made a bad situation worse during a meeting with 55 moderate and conservative House members last week. According to participants, Mr. Paster might have smothered the rebellion in the House by simply promising to address their concerns with the President and promising better access to the White House. Instead, they said, he looked bored.
"Instead of acknowledging the concerns expressed, he rebutted the concerns that were raised," said Representative Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota, one of the conservative Democrats who wants to put a cap on Social Security and Medicaid spending to guarantee that new taxes go to deficit reduction. "Paster doesn't empathize with us, so he doesn't act as an honest conduit to the President of our concerns."
 
Predicting a Victory
 For all the controversy generated around him and his President's economic package, Mr. Paster predicted the Administration would win a complete victory on the House floor on Thursday, when lawmakers vote on the President's economic program.
But Mr. Paster conceded that he has made some strategic errors lately. "It's fair to say that the fact the stimulus bill did not pass is my responsibility," he said. "I miscalculated over what it would take to negotiate a bill. The mistake I made was misreading what was going on in the Republican caucus."
Mr. Paster's capacity to take responsibility is not all that sets him apart from most officials his age in Washington. He does not play golf, he shies from publicity and the cocktail party circuit, and he belongs to no clubs. His office in the West Wing of the White House is mostly free of the political paraphernalia that decorate most Washington offices; the most distinctive decorations are the autographed baseballs and a bat. (He used to lobby for Major League Baseball.)
He shrugged off contentions that his background as a labor lobbyist made him insensitive to the ideas expressed by the conservative wing of the Democratic Party. "They have been heard," he said. "The problem arises because it is necessary in the process of governing to deal with all wings of the party."
 
'Completely Thankless Job'
 Mr. Paster's defenders say Washington is an unforgiving town, where political fortunes fall one week only to rise the next.
"I think Howard has a completely thankless job," said David Dreyer, a senior White House public affairs official and a former top aide to Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader. "When we score victories -- like family and medical leave or motor-voter -- the President gets the credit. But when things go awry, people who are reluctant to be critical of the President will be critical of the Congressional operation."
Mr. Paster won no public credit when he was the first senior Administration official to warn Mr. Clinton that the Zoe Baird nomination for Attorney General faced serious obstacles because of her hiring of two illegal aliens to do domestic chores.
Nor does he win many points by effectively keeping Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the often meddlesome chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, on the Administration reservation. "I love Howard Paster," said Mr. Dingell, who recommended Mr. Paster to President Clinton. "The President's problems are in the Senate, which has the same rules as the San Francisco Zoo. There's no way Paster can be blamed for that."
 
'Defeat Is an Orphan'
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, said: "John Kennedy's phrase applies here: 'Victories have one hundred fathers, and defeat is an orphan.' He'll get blame that shouldn't apply, but over all, he will do very well."
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, credited Mr. Paster with easing passage of most taxes Mr. Clinton wanted through his panel by helping to convince Mr. Clinton to appeal to influential corporate leaders for support.
Still, Mr. Paster is beginning to draw comparisons to Frank Moore, the Carter Administration's chief Congressional liaison, who was faulted for neglecting to keep lawmakers informed and for failing to build bridges to Republicans. Some lawmakers are even beginning to express nostalgia for Kenneth M. Duberstein, President Ronald Reagan's lobbyist, who knew what buttons to press to attract the support of conservative Democrats for his Administration's tax cut and backing of the anti-Sandinista guerrillas in Nicaragua.
"I'd call the Congressional-relations operation a disaster," said a senior House Democratic whip who spoke on condition he remain unnamed. "Paster's strategy is to deal with the old bulls and ignore the rank-and-file. His staff is young, not savvy, and stretched thin." The senior Democrat said Mr. Paster "has given faulty advice to the President" to ignore House Republicans and try to overpower conservative Democrats in the Senate.
A senior Treasury Department official complained that when the President was considering a compromise with Senate Republicans and Democrats and cut back the stimulus package, Mr. Paster gave him faulty advice not to bend.
Nicholas E. Calio, President Bush's chief lobbyist, was able to move little of his Administration's legislative agenda over the objections of a Democratic Congress. But he won high marks for reaching out to Democrats, especially Mr. Gephardt, and working the cloakrooms and marble stairwells like a candidate.
"Your job is to listen to everybody, and talk to everybody and feed information back," Mr. Calio said. "You shape the policy around the edges by determining what flies and what won't fly."
Democratic insurgents say unlike Mr. Calio, Mr. Paster acts like a proponent with an agenda. And when he ought to be doling out honey, they say, he doles out salt.
Several members said Representative Dave McCurdy, the conservative Oklahoma Democrat who is a leader of the House rebellion against Mr. Clinton's budget, could have been held in check had Mr. Paster granted his wish to become principal House sponsor of the Administration's national service bill. Instead, the Administration courted Representative William D. Ford of Michigan, chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, by asking him to handle the bill, avoiding one set of problems but inviting another.
Only a week later, Mr. McCurdy was the first Congressional Democrat to sharply criticize the Administration, and Mr. Ford handed the sponsorship off to one of his subcommittee chairmen.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices on Long-Term Bills Climb

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Longer-term Treasury prices rose yesterday, but the price of shorter- term maturities fell and the rates on Treasury bills moved higher.
Worries about a move by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates and the normal selling ahead of Treasury auctions contributed to the weak performance of shorter maturities. The Treasury is selling $41.5 billion of one-year bills and two- and five-year notes this week. 
 A fall in the price of gold and a drop in a key commodity index helped give some support to the Treasury bond, traders said. A report about the Fed taking a tougher stand on inflation might have also helped.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond due in February 2023 managed to drop below 7 percent during the day, but ended at 7 percent, down from 7.04 percent Friday. The price rose 15/32 to 10117/32 . Yesterday was the third day in the last trading week that the yield on the bond ended the day at 7 percent or higher.
 
Yield on Two-Year Notes
 But the prices of two- and three-year Treasury notes were off 4/32 and 5/32 respectively, while the yield on the two-year note rose to 4.18 percent from 4.11 percent Friday and the yield on the three-year note was up to 4.59 percent from 4.53 percent.
And at the weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills, the discount rates jumped to their highest levels since Jan. 11. The average discount rate on the three-month bill was 3.06 percent, up from 3.00 percent last week, and the average discount rate on the six-month bill was 3.19 percent, up from 3.10 percent.
While the bond market is still trading in a relatively narrow range, the top of that range, in terms of yields, appears to be moving a little higher. The tone of the entire bond market has been hurt recently as President Clinton's economic program has run into roadblocks in Congress.
And the Administration's handling of the dismissals of the employees of the White House travel office and the stories about the President's $200 haircut in Los Angeles last week added to the growing doubts about Mr. Clinton's effectiveness on Wall Street, traders and analysts said. The defection of key Democrats in the Senate on the proposed energy tax also added to doubts about the outlook for the the economic program.
"The market is more and more bearish on the Clinton Administration's ability to make substantial moves to fiscal restraint," said Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation, referring to the President's deficit reduction proposals.
 
Survey of 100 Fund Managers
 Michael Rosenberg, the manager of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch, said that the results of his most recent survey of 100 fund managers worldwide showed that "they are being more cautious toward the bond market."
The bond market spent much of yesterday focusing again on whether and when the Federal Reserve might move to raise short term interest rates.
The concern about the Fed has been around for the last week because the April inflation data was much higher than exected and the Fed's policy-making committee met last Tuesday.
A report in The Wall Street Journal that the Fed policy-making committee had voted last week in favor of a bias toward higher short term interest rates greeted traders in the moring and sent the prices of shorter- term maturities lower. A jump in short-term rates would have the greatest impact on Treasury bills and intermediate-term Treasury notes.
The new bias toward higher interest rates, if the Fed did adopt it, does not mean that interest rates will be raised immediately. But it does give the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, the authority to raise the target for the Federal funds rate without going back to the committee for approval between now the next policy committee meeting ealry this summer. The current target for the Fed funds rate, which is the rate charged on overnight loans between banks, is 3 percent.
 
Support From Gold Price Drop
 While these concerns were bringing down prices and raising yields across the board yesterday, the Treasury bond seemed to get some support from the drop in the price of gold, which fell $3.70, to $374.20 an ounce for June delivery on the Commodity Exchange in New York. In addition, the Commodity Research Index of commodity prices, which is a closely watched inflation barometer, fell 2.28 points to 209.28. Both declines could have eased inflation concerns a little, at least for the day.
As for the Treasury this week, the Treasury will sell $15.75 billion in two-year notes today, $11 billion of five-year notes Wednesday and $14.75 billion of one-year bills Thursday. In the when-issued market the two-year note was at a yield of 4.23 percent yesterday, up from 4.17 percent Friday, and the five-year note was at 5.39 percent, up from 5.35 percent.

HEADLINE: Health Care Keeps Rank As Job Leader

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Even amid the steep job losses that have buffeted the New York City economy since 1989, the city's health care industry has grown rapidly, solidifying its position as the city's largest employer by far, according to a new Federal report.
But the explosive growth of the industry also underscores a problem for the city, experts say, as the skills and education demanded by health-care jobs outpace what New York's young workers have to offer. 
 The report, released yesterday, shows that the city's private hospitals and health-care organizations added 30,000 jobs since 1989 and now employ 278,000 people. Health care has eclipsed banks, real-estate concerns, corporate headquarters, publishing houses and other large employers, and the industry's growth is expected to continue for at least a decade.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said health-care jobs would continue expanding because the city's population was growing older and because the advance of medical technology was creating a need for more specialized workers.
Whatever changes eventually are enacted in President Clinton's overhaul of the health system, "the demand will be there" for health services, he said.
The growth of the health care industry has been particularly important to New York because it has provided jobs in neighborhoods and for ethnic groups that have otherwise been hardest hit by the recession, experts said.
"Health care has emerged as the new point of entry," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade group representing 155 hospitals in the city, on Long Island and in Westchester County.
He said the industry, with jobs such as nurses, medical assistants and technicians, had in many ways supplanted garment manufacturing as a source of employment for recent immigrants. Often, he said, language skills and familiarity with other cultures are as much in demand among health care providers as the skills honed in nursing or medical school.
But Mr. Ehrenhalt maintained that the skill requirements for health care workers would become more and more rigorous, perhaps disqualifying even the recent immigrants. New technology, he said, is expected to make many entry-level jobs obsolete, while demanding more technical skills of workers.
 
Bleak Odds for Dropouts
 "The odds against high school dropouts are bleak now," he said. "They will be worse." Recent studies show that 31 percent of New York City's public high school students do not graduate.
A separate report yesterday -- on a survey of 300 of New York City's top corporate executives -- found that entry-level job requirements are growing far more rigorous across a spectrum of industries.
"Today's educational shortfalls could inhibit tomorrow's economic growth," said James J. Schiro , vice chairman of Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, which conducted the survey earlier this year. The executives in the study criticized New York City's public schools harshly.
Among the survey's findings were that over half the companies had increased their entry-level skill requirements over the last four years. More than half the executives also said that they would carry out policies over the next four years that would require most of their new entry-level employees to have four-year college degrees.
 
A Shift in Job Ranking
 After the health care industry, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, business services, wholesale trade, banking and social services, in that order, are the city's largest employers. In contrast, the Federal report said that in 1960, health care had not even made the top five, which then comprised wholesale trade, apparel manufacturing, publishing, restaurants and business services.
Among New York City's hospitals are some of the largest and most distinguished teaching institutions. At such hospitals as Memorial Sloan- Kettering Cancer Center, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Mount Sinai Medical Center, Columbia- Presbyterian Medical Center and New York University Medical Center the city provides medical training for 15 percent of the nation's doctors, far more than any other city, according to Mr. Raske's group.
Expansion of the city's health care industry can be measured in more than employment. In a wave of new construction, which should provide a much needed boost for builders and trades people, several hospitals have begun expansion programs.
They include New York Hospital, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens, Kings County Medical Center and others. Collectively, the hospitals plan to spend $6 billion on construction over the next decade.
The industry's growth is expected to be sharpest among health care providers who work outside the hospitals. Mr. Ehrenhalt said that the segments of the industry that had grown fastest since 1979 were home health care organizations, independent clinics, nursing homes and specialized outpatient facilities, particularly those dealing with alcohol and drug addiction, kidney dialysis and AIDS.
Although no government projections are available for New York City, the report yesterday cited Federal estimates that several categories of health care employment -- home health aides, physical therapists, medical assistants, radiologic technicians -- would be among the fastest growing until at least the year 2005.
In its separate survey of executives, which it conducted for the New York Chamber of Commerce, Price Waterhouse said it found that four of five executives believed the public schools failed to give students basic math and reading skills and the ability to think critically.
In its survey results, Price Waterhouse ranked what the executives believed to be the 11 most important problems facing New York City over the next four years. Public education ranked second, behind public safety.

HEADLINE: Race for Nassau Executive Tests Party Shift

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 21

 BODY:
The campaign poster from Richard M. Nixon's 1972 re-election bid still hangs in the Republican Election Commissioner's office here. In Nassau County, isolated somehow from the doubt Mr. Nixon has since ignited in much of the rest of the country, the picture is a reminder of the Republican Party's traditional invincibility.
But this year, this Republican stronghold faces its toughest challenge in 25 years in the race for county executive. The machine that could always be counted on to turn out a Republican majority in local, state and national elections, to provide funds and field statewide candidates, appears to be in trouble. 
 Two Democrats, and possibly a third, are vying for the right to challenge County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, on the November ballot, and Mr. Gulotta himself is running on a platform of "fundamental and sweeping change."
 
Statewide Impact Seen
 Though Mr. Gulotta has spent the last 12 years in top leadership posts in Nassau County, six as County Executive and six as Hempstead Town Supervisor, his campaign advertisements mention neither his party nor his current office.
Such a disavowal would have been unthinkable in earlier years. But these are troubled days in Nassau. A lengthy recession and cuts in military spending have, overall, cost Long Island 100,000 jobs. The shrinking tax base forced the county into its third straight year of deficit, with Nassau borrowing $107 million to stay afloat last year and invoking widespread layoffs.
Suddenly, the county that promised the American dream could no longer afford to test the water at its beaches or do autopsies in time for religious burials.
At the same time, Mr. Gulotta came under fire from within his own party for hanging onto the perquisites of wealthier years. Though he had nine secretaries on staff at the height of last year's budget crisis, for example, Mr. Gulotta brought in a tenth.
A defeat for Mr. Gulotta, in the words of Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant, "would be a dagger through the heart of the Republican Party" in New York State. A victory against today's odds could catapult Mr. Gulotta to statewide prominence.
 
A Test of Democratic Gains
 Locally, this year's race will determine whether Democratic gains in recent Nassau County elections were quirks, or signaled underlying shifts in the balance of power.
In the last four years, three Democrats have been elected to the six-member Board of Supervisors, Nassau's legislative body, which was previously all-Republican. Last November, a Democrat, Doreen Banks, became County Clerk in an election that some considered a bellwether for the county executive's race.
Adding to the political uncertainty, the county is under court order to dissolve the Board of Supervisors by 1995 for a more representative County Legislature. The post of County Executive will remain, but it is not clear how it will be affected.
Though banking on voter discontent, the Democrats measure their purses in the tens of thousands of dollars, for a race that Mr. Gulotta estimates will cost upwards of $1.5 million. He already has collected more than $1 million.
The Democratic challengers for the four-year term are Richard M. Kessel, the executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, who is probably best known for his opposition to the Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant, and Benjamin Zwirn, the North Hempstead Town Supervisor.
While the Democrats are to nominate a candidate at a party convention on Thursday, party faithfuls have already rallied to Mr. Kessel's side. Mr. Zwirn has assiduously not courted regular party leaders.
Many Democrats resent Mr. Zwirn for even seeking the post, fearing that a Democratic primary on Sept. 14 would divert attention from the effort to unseat Mr. Gulotta. Whatever the outcome of the primary, Mr. Zwirn will run on the independent line in the general election.
A third Democratic possibility is Lewis J. Yevoli, the Oyster Bay Town Supervisor, who could deliver the traditionally Republican Oyster Bay and Italian votes. Mr. Yevoli has met with the candidates but says he has not yet made up his mind whether to run.
"One would say that the Republicans are in trouble, but countering that is that Democrats don't appear to be able to take control," lamented Bruce Nyman, a Democrat and the Long Beach Supervisor. "This is the best opportunity that we've ever had, and we're about to blow it."
Amid the infighting, the issues are hardly clear. Democrats, who six months ago planned to present their candidate as an agent of change, have been pre-empted by Mr. Gulotta. As one who knows the system from the inside, Mr. Gulotta argues, he is the most able to detect its problems and push for solutions.
 
Running on Experience
 Mr. Gulotta has drawn criticism for using his office to advance his political fortunes. Critics contend that he has used taxpayer-financed mailings to advance his personal messages among voters and has instructed his top administrators to praise him in speeches before civic groups, following a script that says, in part, "Tom's leadership and experience has helped to guide Nassau County through this turbulent economic period."
Mr. Gulotta defended the script as informational, not political. "I would say that's a fact," Mr. Gulotta said, when read the quote. "There was nothing political whatsoever in it."
Mr. Gulotta's greatest ally in the race, may be the Democrats' disunity and lack of organization.
Mr. Zwirn, in announcing his candidacy, blasted both Mr. Gulotta and Mr. Kessel. He called Mr. Gulotta "Taxing Tom," for his proposals to double the mortgage tax to 2 percent and to increase the county's share of property taxes by 26 percent. He branded Mr. Kessel "Rate-Hike Richie" for his steps to close Shoreham and the subsequent increase in the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity rates.
Mr. Kessel points to his involvement in closing Shoreham and his role as chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, the agency responsible for decommissioning Shoreham, as his greatest achievement. He called Mr. Zwirn's charges "preposterous," adding that rate increases "would have been far greater" if Shoreham had been opened.
Mr. Zwirn is running on his record of cutting taxes and tightening government spending in North Hempstead, where he staged an upset in 1989 and then led a landslide that delivered a Democratic majority to the Town Board in 1991.
"I'm the only one of the candidates," Mr. Zwirm said in an interview, "who can stand up at a debate and say, 'Which of us has lowered taxes and cut spending?' "

He announced his candidacy last week for Nassau County executive surrounded by many top Democrats. HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
At Yale, Honors for an Acting Chief

 BODY:
Howard R. Lamar, who served as acting president of Yale University over the last year and was generally seen as a stabilizing force on campus, conferred degrees yesterday on 1,219 undergraduates and about 2,000 graduate and professional students at the university's 292d commencement exercises in New Haven. Mr. Lamar, who will hand over his powers on July 1 to Richard C. Levin, now dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, received an honorary degree of doctor of laws.
A poignant moment in the proceedings came when an honorary degree of doctor of humane letters was announced for Arthur R. Ashe Jr., the tennis champion who died of AIDS. The degree was accepted by Alexandra Dell, a junior at Yale who was Mr. Ashe's goddaughter. The graduates stood in tribute to Mr. Ashe. 
 Among others receiving honorary degrees were Elena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident and widow of Andrei Sakharov, the human rights activist; Rembert G. Weakland, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee and a prominent leader of the church's liberal wing, and Alistair Cooke, journalist, commentator and former host of "Masterpiece Theater."
In keeping with a Yale tradition of protest, a plane circled the proceedings bearing the message, "Resign Loucks." Some students are upset at Vernon R. Loucks Jr., a Yale trustee who is also chairman and chief executive of Baxter International Inc., a medical products supplier which violated a Federal law against cooperating with the Arab economic boycott of Israel. Mr. Lamar has said he stands behind Mr. Loucks for his service to Yale.
As is Yale's custom, there was no commencement day speaker. During Class Day ceremonies Sunday, the actress Jodie Foster, who graduated from the university magna cum laude in 1985, urged graduating seniors to "be advocates for people who don't have a voice" and to combat "racism, sexism and homophobia."
 
Seton Hall University
 Seton Hall University conferred degrees on 1,142 undergraduates and 500 graduates yesterday in ceremonies at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.
Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston gave the main address for the 136th commencement. Mr. Flynn, who has recently been nominated as Ambassador to the Vatican, spoke of the need for a new civil rights movement in America and urged the graduates to get involved in changing society. Mr. Flynn received an honorary degree of doctor of humanitarian service.
 
Yeshiva University
 Dr. Gershon Metzger, director general of Israel's Ministry of Science and Technology, delivered the main address yesterday at the 62d commencement of Yeshiva University. The commencement at Madison Square Garden, attended by 1,111 graduates, was the largest celebrated by the university this year.
Dr. Metzger spoke of recent political, social, economic and demographic changes throughout the world and said, "There is cause for guarded optimism as you look forward to your future careers."
Dr. Metzger, an alumnus of Yeshiva, received an honorary degree of doctor of science. Among the others receiving honorary degrees was Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York State Court of Appeals.
 
Johns Hopkins University
 President Richard von Weizsacker of Germany delivered the main commencement address yesterday at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. A total of 3,974 degrees were awarded at the school's 117th annual commencement.
After the main ceremony many of the university's divisions held their own diploma-awarding ceremonies. In an address before graduating seniors, the director Barry Levinson, who was born in Baltimore, talked about the chasm between the unalloyed hope of his generation in the 1960's and the complex problems of today.
"We were a promising generation," he said. "We had ideals and values. What went wrong is, it's easy to lose what's important today in this constantly cluttered world of media madness. We're told a thousand things we need, and we just get lost."
Robert S. Strauss, the Ambassador to the Soviet Union under President George Bush, delivered the main address yesterday at commencement ceremonies for the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. The school awarded 259 degrees at its 50th annual commencement, which was held at the First Baptist Church in Washington.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
General Mills Closing 31 of Its Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, May 24

 BODY:
General Mills Inc. said today that it would close 31 restaurants and revamp its manufacturing. It said it would take a $45 million to $50 million charge against after-tax earnings, or about 28 to 30 cents a share, as a result of the restructuring.
Twenty-seven of the restaurants to be closed are Red Lobsters; 4 are Olive Gardens. 
 Half are in economically depressed areas of Canada, which has been an unprofitable market over all. The remainder --mostly in Houston, Orlando and California -- have not been doing as well as the company had hoped.
General Mills currently operates 1,075 restaurants in North America, including 665 Red Lobsters and 405 Olive Gardens.
 
'An Effort to Stem Red Ink'
 General Mills' stock closed down $2 today, closing at $67.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the Kellogg Company's announcement that it expected lower second-quarter earnings pressured General Mills's stock.
Some of the moves had been expected, especially in Canada where General Mills has had problems for the past two years. "This is an effort to stem the red ink," said Bonnie Wittenberg, an analyst with Dain Bosworth.
General Mills currently operates 69 Red Lobsters and 23 Olive Garden restaurants in Canada.
General Mills estimated it would save about $15 million, or about 9 cents a share, in fiscal 1994, as a result of the changes. It said fourth-quarter operating performance remains on track as does fiscal 1993.
"General Mills' overall financial results, excluding unusual items, will represent another year of record sales, earnings and earnings per share," said Bruce Atwater, General Mills chairman.
The company had been expected to earn 72 cents a share in the quarter ending this month, according to analysts.
 
No Estimate on Job Loss
 General Mills had no estimate of how many workers will lose their jobs. Most of the cuts in the manufacturing resturcturing are expected in consumer foods, where General Mills is switching to high-performance work systems. It said the system, currently in 64 percent of its plants, has significantly increased productivity.
Employment in its restaurant group is expected to rise, despite the planned closings, a spokesman said.
"We will be opening 50 stores next year in each of our two divisions, Red Lobster and Olive Garden," said Peter Spokes.
Additional details of General Mills' restructuring are expected June 29 when the company reports its fourth- quarter earnings.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Sharp Gains As Short-Term Rates Climb

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply yesterday as rising short-term American interest rates attracted more money into dollar-denominated investments.
The dollar surged as speculation mounted that the Federal Reserve might tighten short-term interest rates to protect against a resurgence of inflation. 
 The policy-making body of the Fed met last week, after the Government had reported a jump in April inflation. Previously, the Fed had maintained a neutral policy but many dealers thought the central bankers might have grown more cautious.
Despite widespread questions about rates, speculation about a tighter Fed policy was enough to push the dollar higher.
The dollar rallied at the expense of the mark, which sagged on continued expectations that the Bundesbank would cut German rates, making mark-denominated assets less attractive.
The mark also sank against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc as investors sought a haven in the currencies of nations with stronger economies. The mark fell to a record low of 67.25 yen from 67.81 late on Friday.
Attempts by the United States and Japan to cool the yen's five-month surge lifted the dollar slightly, but gains were capped by persistent trade tensions, dealers said.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said recent comments by United States officials that have bolstered the yen were taken "grossly out of proportion." Specifically, he said, President Clinton was not urging a further appreciation of the yen.
The dollar rallied over one pfennig, to 1.6355 marks, in late New York trading, well above the 1.6250 marks of late Friday. Earlier in London, the dollar settled at 1.6380 marks, down from a 1.6430-mark peak, but well above Friday's 1.6268-mark finish.
In New York, the dollar rose to 110.60 yen in late dealings from 110.35 yen Friday. It closed in Tokyo at 110.58 yen, slightly above 110.52 yen Friday. The Australian dollar fell to 0.6932 cents, from 0.6953 cents, amid rumors that the Government is willing to accept a weaker currency.
The British pound settled at $1.5370 in New York, down from $1.5445 Friday. Earlier in London, the pound eased to $1.5355 from $1.5580 Friday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Tumble, Raising Doubts on the Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver prices tumbled from around a 32-month high yesterday amid heavy selling by investment funds.
Gold and platinum futures also sank, raising new doubts about the ability of the precious metals to continue a rally that began in March. 
 Silver for May delivery plunged 13.4 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $4.535 a troy ounce. The contract traded as high as $4.72 last week, the highest spot price for silver since Sept. 28, 1990, and nearly 34 percent above the March 8 low of $3.53.
June gold fell $3.70 on the Commodity Exchange, to $374.20 an ounce. On the Mercantile Exchange in New York, July platinum dropped $7.40, to $386 an ounce.
The declines followed reports that the Federal Reserve was leaning toward raising short-term interest rates in an effort to stifle inflation. The move would underscore the Fed's concern about inflationary pressures, which have been among the factors driving precious metals higher.
 
Correction Believed Due
 Investors normally turn to precious metals as a hedge against inflation. Higher interest rates would make borrowing money costlier, slowing industrial activity and curbing demand for silver and platinum, which have industrial uses.
"The potential for Fed tightening was a key factor," said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. She said the metals were due for a downward correction.
Lower commodity prices in general and a stronger dollar yesterday prompted additional selling, Ms. Raptopoulos said.
Silver and platinum fell more sharply than gold because they were more exaggeratedly high, said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. He said demand for gold out of Asia, another factor in the recent run-up, remained strong.
"Until now, people have been buying silver and platinum as a proxy for gold," he said. "I don't think that's a very good idea."
On other commodity markets, oil futures fell; orange juice futures rose sharply; grains and soybeans were mostly lower, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
Light crude oil for July delivery fell 16 cents on the Mercantile Exchange in New York, to $19.72 a barrel; June heating oil fell 0.54 cent, to 53.90 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline fell 0.47 cent, to 58.73 cents a gallon, and July natural gas sank 10.8 cents, to $2.009 per 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Going To Markets For $3 Billion

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
I.B.M. announced yesterday that it planned to raise up to $3 billion in the financial markets for corporate expenses that could include paying for higher-than-expected cutbacks in its work force.
The International Business Machines Corporation last year took a big charge against earnings to help pay for reducing its payroll by 25,000 workers this year. Earlier this year, the company acknowledged that the number would exceed 25,000, but has not been more precise. That, company officials say, is partly because work force decisions are increasingly left to the heads of its business divisions. 
 Industry analysts say the job cuts for the year could well exceed 40,000 and may go far higher, depending on how much emphasis the new chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., puts on paring costs further.
An I.B.M. spokesman, Rob Wilson, said that the new funds to be raised over the next nine months to a year would be used for "general corporate purposes." The extra cash, he added, would give I.B.M. "additional flexibility if more people than expected leave the company."
 
First Preferred Stock
 The I.B.M. financing plan includes an issue of $750 million in preferred stock, with the remainder long-term bonds. It is the first time I.B.M. has issued preferred stock. The timing of the borrowing program is an effort by I.B.M., like other companies, to lock in the current low interest rates. I.B.M.'s shares gained $1.375 yesterday, closing at $49.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Preparing financially for additional work force cuts is only prudent, analysts say. "I said the number would be more like 40,000 earlier this year, and I now think that number is too low," said Daniel Mandresh, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company.
The work force cutbacks will be mainly voluntarily, and the I.B.M. program gives workers considerable incentive to leave in the first half of the year. After June 30, the lump sum payments and extended medical benefits to departing workers are substantially reduced.
Separately, Mr. Gerstner picked another outsider to join his corporate staff, Abby Kohnstamm, a marketing executive at the American Express Company. Ms. Kohnstamm, 39, will become I.B.M.'s vice president of corporate marketing in charge of advertising, promotion and the company's many sponsorships.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Experts Ponder Cuban Epidemic

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
AMERICAN medical experts returning from Cuba have different theories about the nature of the epidemic that has struck there in recent months, affecting some 25,000 people.
The disease impairs vision and can damage peripheral nerves, causing symptoms like burning sensations in the legs. The underlying cause of the disease, all agree, is a nutritional deficiency, most probably resulting from changes in the diet caused by worsening economic problems in Cuba. 
 During their weeklong stay, the experts say, they met often with Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, to discuss their findings. President Castro is taking a deep interest in the mysterious epidemic.
But opinion is divided over the precise type of nutritional deficiency that is causing the disease. One group pinpoints a lack of thiamine, or vitamin B1. Another attributes the disease to a deficiency of folic acid combined with the drinking of methanol and natural cyanide in home-brewed rum.
The experts who have made themselves available for interviews on their return from Cuba are from Columbia University's medical school in New York and the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. The Columbia doctors went under the auspices of Peace for Cuba, a nonprofit organization that has lobbied against the American trade embargo against Cuba. The California group went for Orbis International, a nonprofit organization that fights blindness throughout the world.
The Cuban Government also asked the Pan American Health Organization to send a team. One of the nine members of the Paho team, Dr. D. Carleton Gajdusek, left Cuba last weekend but was not available for comment and his office referred all calls to Paho. A spokesman for Paho said members of the team would discuss the epidemic and provide a more definitive assessment at a news conference later this week.
Last week Dr. Michio Hirano, one of the Columbia doctors, said the evidence pointed to a vitamin B1 deficiency known as Strachan syndrome as the cause of the Cuban epidemic. But Dr. Hirano, a neurologist, said yesterday that he had overstated the case for vitamin B1 deficiency. He and Dr. Norah Lincoff, a colleague who is training to be a neuro-ophthalmologist, said they believed the disease was more likely a result of a deficiency of a combination of B vitamins.
But Dr. Alfredo Sadun, an expert in optic nerve disease at the University of Southern California, said the cause was a lack of dietary folate combined with the ingestion of two toxins, methanol in home-brewed rum and cyanide in sugar cane. He said the disease was a variation of a rare but well described condition known mitochondrial optic neuropathy, or M.O.N., that had reached epidemic proportions because of recent changes in nutritional and drinking habits.
M.O.N. is usually a genetic disorder, and ordinarily does not damage both eyes at the same time. Dr. Sadun said he was speaking of a nongenetic variation caused by toxins like methanol and cyanide.
Dr. Lincoff disagreed, saying that Dr. Sadun lacked proof for such a diagnosis and that there was no evidence that the disease could result in loss of vision in both eyes simultaneously, as is happening in Cuba.
Not only the name of the disease but the number of those affected is in dispute. Cuban health officials have said that almost 26,000 people are afflicted. Dr. Sadun said he and other experts from Orbis and Paho told Mr. Castro in their daily meetings last week that the number was inflated because many cases had been misdiagnosed. Many of these individuals had other serious visual and neurological disorders.
Initially, predominantly adult men were afflicted. But in recent weeks, Cuban doctors diagnosed the condition in many women. Dr. Sadun said his team had determined that many recent cases could be attributed to malingering or hysteria. The group used tests that are standard in the United States for determining whether a person can see, he said, in order to diagnose the cases of malingering or hysteria.
On being told about the misdiagnoses, Dr. Sadun said, Mr. Castro "was extremely receptive to what should have been a very threatening comment."
"His eyes lit up," Dr. Sadun went on, "he slapped his hand and said, 'I knew it. That explains why the characteristics of the disease have shifted so much.' "
Mr. Castro's views toward the cause of the epidemic seem to have changed between the meeting that Dr. Hirano had on May 6 and the ones Dr. Sadun's team had last week. Earlier, Dr. Hirano said, Mr. Castro favored a viral cause.
Dr. Sadun said that many of the most powerful Cuban scientists were virologists because the Cuban Government has invested heavily in that field and in molecular biology.
Cuban virologists claim to have isolated a virus in a large number of cases, Dr. Sadun said, adding that the virus also turned up in controls, indicating to virologists on the team that the findings were probably a laboratory error.
Dr. Sadun said that when he explained "why it was unlikely to be a virus, Castro just smiled and seemed relaxed, instead of being upset."
Dr. Sadun said that the Orbis and Paho teams agreed to work as a team after they met in Miami and that they decided to start their investigation in Cuba on May 17.
That morning, five members of the Orbis and Paho teams went to Cuba's main eye hospital in Havana and spent six hours thoroughly examining four of the most severely affected patients to get a feel for the disease. The medical histories and findings were the same for all four.
That afternoon, the team went to a general hospital to examine patients with other types of neurological problems attributed to the disease. "Each patient had something different, none looked like any of the patients seen in the morning, and we were terribly confused," Dr. Sadun said.
That evening, the group told Mr. Castro they suspected that many cases had been misdiagnosed.
Last Tuesday morning, the team returned to the eye hospital to examine three milder cases. One had the disease, a second had another eye disorder and the third turned out to be a case of hysteria, Dr. Sadun said. That afternoon, the team examined patients who had both the eye and peripheral nerve forms of the disease.
That evening, the group agreed to the need for a strict definition of the syndrome, as is standard for purposes of epidemiologic investigations.
On Wednesday, the scientists came up with a definition that included six points based on their examinations of the most severely affected patients.
To qualify as a case, a patient had to meet one absolute and three other relative components.
The absolute was the presence in both eyes of a wedge-shaped defect in the portion of the optic nerve known as the macular-papular bundle.
Among the other components were these:
*Loss of vision in both eyes within a month.
*Loss of a certain amount of color vision.
*Loss of central vision.
*An unusual type of eye movement. When asked to follow a moving object, an individual normally moves the eyes smoothly. But the eyes of the afflicted Cubans resembled a cog-wheeling pattern in which movement lagged, then jumped forward to catch up in a slow-fast-slow-fast pattern.
The visiting scientists met that evening with 15 leading Cuban ophthalmologists and Mr. Castro to explain the case definition. Many of the Cuban doctors protested, saying that they knew of many patients who definitely had the disease but who did not conform to the new definition.
Mr. Castro stood up, Dr. Sadun recalled, and said: "I get the point. You can only include real cases and cannot afford to have any false positives."
About a year ago, the Cuban Government restricted the purchase of rum. Dr. Sadun said his team had learned from patients who were promised confidentiality that they drank two or three bottles of home-brewed rum a week.
The home-brewed beverages are made from sugar cane, which contains small amounts of cyanide, and variable amounts of methanol, which can damage the eye.
Dr. Sadun said that 11 home brews were being tested for methanol and other toxins. Epidemiologists have gone into the homes of affected Cubans to determine their daily living and cooking habits to determine whether some other toxin, like a cooking oil, might be involved.
Dr. Sadun said he believed that many Cubans suffered from folic-acid deficiency. "The bottom line," he said, is that the folic-acid deficiency "has brought them up to the threshold, and at least two toxins -- cyanide and methanol -- are knocking them over the threshold."
"It's a metabolic problem and you could probably fix the disease in one of three ways," Dr. Sadun said. These are by raising the folic acid, stopping exposure to cyanide or stopping the exposure to methanol.
At one point Mr. Castro asked the group what he should do about rum. Dr. Sadun said he suggested dropping the law and giving away rum at no cost to avoid home brewing. "That could be done," Mr. Castro replied. Dr. Sadun said he was joking. But Mr. Castro said, "It's not such a bad idea."

HEADLINE: School Computers Emulate Games To Capture the Attention of Pupils

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A NEW wave of innovative computer programs and interactive devices is about to hit the nation's schools, driven by a national desire to address education problems, rapidly falling prices of computer and video technology, and the keenness of software companies to invade the vast educational market.
Representatives from Sega and Nintendo, the computer games companies, joined Apple, Sun Microsystems and Silicon Graphics and luminaries from government and education at a conference convened in Washington this month by the National Academy of Sciences. Their purpose was to explore how the bright new technologies of computer entertainment and communication might be harnessed to enliven the nation's classrooms. 
 The blackboard and chalk have not yet succumbed to the video screen, but some powerful new technologies are bidding to invade the long unchallenged domain of the school textbook.
 
New Technology on Display
 Multimedia kits, which enable home computers to accompany the text on a compact disk with sound and video, are already in the stores. The scope of the technology was displayed in an elaborate project on Columbus prepared by Synapse Technologies Inc. of Los Angeles for I.B.M. A special search technique lets students follow the consequences of Columbus's discovery by tracking chosen topics through history up until the American Revolution. In addition, said Synapse's president, Robert Abel, students and teachers can add their ideas electronically to the information to produce reports or to enrich the database of ideas.
A more advanced technology is the animation system developed by the SimGraphics Engineering Corporation of South Pasadena, Calif., that allows a person to choreograph directly the movements of an animated figure on a screen.
Sensors attached to an actor's head and face feed into a workstation that directs a figure on the screen to duplicate the eyebrow, cheek, head, chin and lip movements of its human counterpart. For its next trick, the SimGraphics system wires a room with remote cameras and microphones and hides the actor. Members of the audience watching the screen see a cartoon figure that can carry on a conversation with them.
Steve Glenn, vice president of SimGraphics, said the system could be used for business presentations, for entertainment or for producing hours of animation cheaply. In education, the possibilities include the animation of teaching material, or the use of a cartoon character to personalize lessons.
 
'Virtual Reality' Devices
 Even better than watching a cartoon character, people can now get a feeling for entering the computer screen themselves using the assemblage of devices that produce what is known as "virtual reality." The user wears a helmet with earphones and a screen in front of each eye on which a computer projects images. A pair of wired up gloves transmits every motion to the computer, which moves objects correspondingly in the fictitious environment it projects onto the subject's screens.
"Using virtually reality in education could have a significant impact because it is an immersive environment that blocks outside distraction," said Dr. Christopher J. Dede of George Mason University in Fairfax, Va. "Research shows that learning by experience is better than learning by being told something."
"Imagine being in a 'virtual' physics lab where you can change how time passes or turn gravity on and off," he said. "You would learn from the experience and remember it better." Until recently, virtual reality equipment cost thousands of dollars. But several companies have announced virtual-reality visors for video games that will be available for less than $200 by the end of the year. Dr. Dede said these would be cheap enough to be adapted for education.
The first wave of computerization has had mixed results, with many of the devices used only for drill and test exercises, or sitting in the corners of classrooms for the occasional game or class project. Still, many education experts are willing to keep trying.
At the meeting they noted that outside school, many children now live in a technology-rich world of television, personal computers, video games and myriad electronic devices, while the traditional classroom has remained largely unchanged.
"Schools today are one of the few work places in our society that our grandparents would recognize easily," said Dr. David V. B. Britt, president of the Children's Television Workshop in New York City.
"Outside of school, even the low-level technology of television has already proved its effectiveness as an educator, for good and for things not so good," Dr. Britt said. "Evidence suggests that other technology can help, enabling children to be powerful learners, if designed to deal with specific education areas."
Joseph Smarr, a sixth grader at Urbana Middle School in Illinois, told a session that activities outside school were more interesting and challenging than inside. Video and computer game software grabs youngsters' attention and provides a sense of accomplishment often unmatched in school, he said.
"With games and entertainment, kids are active and making decisions every second," he said. "In school, you sit there and make a decision every half-hour."
Susan Harman of Robertson, Stephens & Company, a San Francisco market analysis concern, estimated that the educational technology market would grow 20 percent a year for the rest of the decade because of pressure for reform, improved technology, falling prices and a high birth rate creating more students.
More than 65 percent of homes with school-age children have video games, far more than personal computers, industry data show. The devices, which typically cost less than $100, are ubiquitous in homes of every economic group. Instead of associating educational technology only with computers and other expensive hardware, some experts said, why not also think of using the lower-tech devices already in so many homes and add educational value to them?
"We are certainly capable of delivering entertainment with a strong educational content," Douglas Glen, a vice president for Sega of America Inc., said at the meeting while demonstrating some of this company's popular game software, including the latest version of Sonic the Hedgehog.
"There are millions of video game systems in homes and we will soon be testing a system to deliver new software directly to the home via a cable television channel," Mr. Glen said, "We would like to put this infrastructure at the service of education, but what we haven't got is the content, which the educators have to bring to the table."
Perrin Kaplan, a spokeswoman for Nintendo of America Inc., said in a telephone interview that her company was moving into "edutainment" software to augment the traditional entertainment value of video games. The company's new "Mario Paint and Mouse" package, which includes a video painting program and mouse control device for less than $60, is a best seller that is being used in some schools to teach art and animation, she said. She said Nintendo had also licensed its popular Mario brothers characters to Software Toolworks Inc., of Novato, Calif., to produce the "Mario is Missing!" game, which teaches world geography and history.
"Our research in the past has shown that anything you call 'educational' doesn't move off the toy shelf," Ms. Kaplan said. "Nintendo is in the entertainment business and to the degree that we can entertain and have educational value in products that sell, we will do more."
 
New Perspective on Education
 Dr. Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, said the view of looking at educational technology from the bottom up, as well as the top down, presented a new way of reaching children. "If we can combine the skills of the creators of the Mario brothers with those of people who understand education and cognitive science, and do it in a way that schools and homes can afford, this could be a major leap forward for education," he said.
But Dr. Press stressed, "Anyone who believes technology is a panacea for poor teaching, underfunded schools, poor community participation, the lack of discipline and all the other things that are wrong with education is making a big mistake.
"There are fundamental problems, such as underpaid teachers and school bureaucracies, that have to be addressed," he said. "But at the same time we have to find new ways of educating our children."
