HEADLINE: Trade or Colonialism? Ruins May Give Answer

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
ON a limestone bluff overlooking the Euphrates in southeastern Turkey, a low mound spreads across several acres, blanketing the ruins of a settlement that bustled with life and trade in the late fourth millennium B.C. The ruins may tell a tale of how the world's first urban societies reached into the hinterlands for raw materials and thus started the earliest practice of colonialism.
Or it may turn out to be a somewhat different story. 
 The first archeological excavations at the Turkish site of Hacinebi Tepe, begun last summer, have yielded surprising results. A preliminary examination of the stones, mud brick, ceramics and other artifacts suggests that the local people at Hacinebi may well have been trading with their supposed Mesopotamian masters as equals.
If so, these new findings do more than provide additional evidence of the widespread Mesopotamian presence among their neighbors to the north; they also raise serious questions about the nature of that relationship. Were they really there as colonialists? Perhaps they were only merchants in a widening network of long-distance trade, asserting little or none of the political, military or economic dominance usually associated with colonialism. They might even have been there, in some cases, as refugees.
Dr. Gil J. Stein, an anthropologist at Northwestern University who is directing the excavations, said the discoveries at Hacinebi are "provoking us to think of ancient colonization in a dramatically different way."
Further research at Hacinebi, scheduled to resume next month, promises to be equally provocative. Although other sites of Mesopotamian trading outposts and presumed colonies have been sampled before, this is the first one known to be superimposed on an existing local community. There is a well-preserved layer of artifacts of the people who lived there for generations before the Mesopotamians arrived. Immediately above it is a layer of indigenous artifacts and architectural remains mingled with clear evidence of a Mesopotamian presence.
Dr. William Sumner, director of the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, said this was the first opportunity for archeologists to investigate the role of the indigenous societies in these trading centers and determine their relationship with the foreigners.
Dr. Guillermo Algaze, an anthropologist at the University of California at San Diego who specializes in the colonialism of ancient civilizations, said: "This site has great potential. We will be seeing to what extent the enterprise was exploitative or more reciprocal, and seeing the social and economic impact it had on the locals."
A guiding hypothesis of ancient Mesopotamian studies has been that resource exploitation of foreign lands, not unlike modern colonialism, went hand in hand with the emergence of the first urban political states. This was happening in the midst of one of the most momentous transitions of antiquity, the beginning not just of history but also of civilization.
Some 700 miles down river from Hacinebi, in the years between 3500 and 3100 B.C., people living along the lower Euphrates and Tigris Rivers were cultivating the fertile plains with increasing success. Their irrigated fields were producing grain surpluses, and their flocks were shorn for a growing textile industry. People congregated in towns, notably Uruk, where they erected walls and imposing buildings and learned to keep account of their surpluses and industries by methods that would soon lead to writing, and so the beginning of history.
But these nascent city-states of southern Mesopotamia, in what is now Iraq, could not fill their need for metals and timber or their desire for semiprecious stones with which the elite could flaunt their rising status. For these goods, they had to look to the presumably less advanced but resource-rich societies on the plains and in the valleys of southwestern Iran and in the northern highlands of Syria and Turkey. Scholars described this outreach as the Uruk expansion.
Writing in next month's issue of American Anthropologist, Dr. Algaze compares Uruk's distant trading outposts to such modern examples as the Portuguese colony of Goa in India and the British colony of Hong Kong. The Uruk outposts, he said, "reflect a system of economic hegemony whereby early emergent states attempted to exploit less complex polities located well beyond the boundaries of their direct political control and that this system may be construed as imperialistic in both its extent and nature."
Recent excavations in the archeology of colonialism have revealed the ruins of several such Uruk outposts on major trade routes. One of the best documented is Godin Tepe, sitting astride the Khorasan Road, the most important east-west route crossing the Zagros Mountains of Iran. Settlers from the Uruk world appeared to have lived inside a fort that was surrounded by a local community. Their remains include some of the earliest evidence of beer and wine.
Since Godin Tepe must have existed far beyond Uruk's political control and presumably could not have survived for long without local acquiescence, archeologists have assumed this was not so much a colony as a trading post operated by Uruk merchants. One of the excavators, Dr. T. Cuyler Young Jr. of the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto, likened Godin to an early operation of the Hudson Bay Company, where merchants set up shop in remote places and bought and sold or traded goods with the indigenous population of Canada.
Archeologists think that Habuba Kabira had all the marks of a full-fledged colonial settlement. Situated on a bend of the upper Euphrates in Syria, just south of the Turkish border, this site appeared to be the hub of several nearby Uruk settlements. In the 1970's, German archeologists revealed Habuba Kabira to have been a fortified city with well-differentiated residential, industrial and administrative quarters apparently built as part of a single master plan. The architecture and artifacts leave no doubt that the inhabitants were colonists from southern Mesopotamia.
When Hacinebi was identified as a ruin from the period of Uruk expansion, archeologists saw it as an ideal site for addressing questions as to whether this was, in fact, an early form of colonialism.
The site occupies a strategic position. It is only a few miles north of the ancient east-west river crossing point at the town of Birecik. It is also on the main north-south riverine trade route, linking the copper mines of Anatolia with the Mesopotamian heartland to the south. In the colonial hypothesis, places like Hacinebi served as outposts for procuring resources or as transshipment points for materials destined for the Mesopotamian cities.
Digging there last summer, American and Turkish archeologists found a layer of buried ruins containing bowls, cooking pots and other ceramics that were all in the local Anatolian style. So there definitely had been a village at Hacinebi before the Mesopotamians came looking for copper and timber.
Moreover, Dr. Stein said, some of their artifacts could undermine the assumption by many scholars that Mesopotamian trade and colonization led to the emergence of complex societies in these resource-rich but relatively underdeveloped regions of Anatolia. A pendant made of soapstone, a product of southeast Iran, indicated that the villagers engaged in long-distance trade. Ruins of a monumental public building, the kind usually associated with more advanced urban centers, suggested that, as Dr. Stein said, these local people had evolved "a much more complex society than we've given them credit for up to now."
Immediately above the Anatolian village strata was a bed of beveled rim ceramics in the Mesopotamian style and the remnants of buildings on a raised stone terrace, an unmistakable change in architecture. Mesopotamian and Anatolian pottery are mixed together; in one place, the foreign pottery is found on one side of a wall and the local pottery on the other.
Dr. Stein said there are two ways of interpreting these findings. "One possibility is that a small group of Mesopotamians were living and trading inside the local settlement," he said. "Or perhaps the local people had come in close contact with the Mesopotamians and were emulating them."
Also uncovered at the site were chunks of bitumen, a tar substance that was widely used by the Uruk culture for sealing and waterproofing ceramic containers. Bitumen is rarely found outside ancient Mesopotamia, and Dr. Stein said its use as a sealant suggests that goods were being received at Hacinebi from the outside world.
The presence of embossed clay seals, Dr. Stein said, indicates that Hacinebi was somehow involved in administering the movement of goods. The seals were applied to the doors of storerooms and to ceramic storage jars to certify a transaction, mark the contents and prevent tampering. At least one of the seals was clearly stamped in the local manner, suggesting that local people, and not just Mesopotamians, participated in an official capacity in this trading system.
"Several lines of evidence suggest that existing models of the Uruk expansion may have underestimated the role of the local cultures," Dr. Stein said. "First, the locals were already relatively developed before contact with the Uruk culture. Second, they were not pawns in the trading system, but more or less equal partners. So you see, the classic colonial model doesn't really work."
In any event, the Uruk influence at Hacinebi lasted no more than 175 years, ending around 3100 B.C. Soon the Uruk culture would decline and be succeeded by the even more robust and innovative Sumerian civilization of the third millennium B.C.
Even before the Hacinebi discoveries, some scholars were taking shots at the hypothesis that the Uruk expansion was the manifestation of an early empire and its faraway colonies. Not the least of the problems with the hypothesis, according to Dr. Susan Pollock, an anthropologist at the State University of New York at Binghamton, is the absence of trade goods in the archeological record.
In an article last year in The Journal of World Prehistory, Dr. Pollock dismissed possible explanations that the goods were perishable or that as objects of trade, they would not have remained at the trading posts. It is assumed that textiles might have been a staple of trade from Uruk to the hinterlands, and so would have decayed over time. But the trade goods moving back to Uruk were supposedly such nonperishable materials as metal and semiprecious stones.
True, copper was showing up in Mesopotamia about the time that Uruk styles were showing up at Hacinebi. But to Dr. Pollock it is "difficult to conceive of a situation in which the traders or colonists would not have taken advantage of the opportunities to exploit the situation for as much as they could get away with."
If they had skimmed off some exotic goods, where were they in the ruins? The place to look, Dr. Pollock said, was in graves at the Uruk outposts. But few graves have been found so far.
Even more emphatic in opposition is Dr. Gregory A. Johnson, an anthropologist at Hunter College in New York, who said the colonial hypothesis "simply doesn't hold water."
Scholars tend to forget, Dr. Johnson said, that this was a period of severe population decline in many southern Mesopotamian cities, including Ur, Eridu and Nippur. "When you're losing half your population, something nasty must be going on," he said, and the collapse could be behind the sudden appearance of Mesopotamian settlements in the highlands. It was not an empire expanding, he said, but disintegrating.
As a leading exponent of the idea that colonialism sprang almost inevitably from the rise of the first political states, Dr. Algaze is not backing down from his imperial interpretation of the Uruk expansion. Indeed, he has expanded his brief to show that similar expansionary dynamics had led four other early civilizations -- the Sumerians, Teotihuacan in Central Mexico, the Harappan culture in the Indus River basin of Pakistan and the predynastic Egyptians -- to reach out for resources and territory.
With theories hanging in the balance, archeologists will be awaiting this summer's excavations on the east bank of the Euphrates at Hacinebi.

Drawings: Seals and Local Participation in Trade
Seal impressions found on storage jars and chambers at Hacinebi suggest that local people, not just Mesopotamians, were active in the ancient trade system. The seals studied are from the period of the greatest contact with Mesopotamia, and both stamp seals and cylinder seals were in use. Dr. Gil Stein believes the locals adapted the artistic style of the Mesopotamians in some seal designs.
Uruk (Mesopotamian) cylinder seal impressions
The animals on this seal are goats and ibex. The U shapes at the left and right ends may be boats carrying storage jars. The shape emerging from the jar near the top, left, suggests a stalk of grain.
Anatolian-style stamp seal impressions
Animals in the seal at the left are dogs like modern Saluki hunting dogs; those in the seal at the right are thought to be goats or ibex.
(Sources: Marcella Frangipane and Alba Palmieri/Origini; Dr. Gil Stein/Northwestern)(pg. C10)
 
Map: Colonialists or Merchants?
Excavations at Hacinebi, Turkey, have identified the first outpost of the Uruk city-state known to have been superimposed on an existing community. Archeologists theorize that these Mesopotamians were perhaps not exploiting the less-advanced but resource-rich Anatolians, but rather co-existing and cooperating with them.
(Source: Dr. Gil J. Stein/Northwestern University)(pg. C1)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
KELLOGG EXPECTS LOWER QUARTERLY EARNINGS

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The Kellogg Company, the largest maker of cereals in the world, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings would fall short of the $168 million in profits in the corresponding period a year ago. Kellogg, which is based in Battle Creek, Mich., said it expected its second-quarter earnings to be 10 percent below those of the second quarter last year. The company will report its results in July. Analysts said Kellogg and other cereal producers have had difficulty raising prices because of sluggish worldwide economies. 
 Kellogg stock fell $2.75, to a new 52-week low of $53.875, in trading of almost 1.2 million shares yesterday. Shares of other cereal makers also fell: the Ralston Purina Company lost $1.25, to $46; General Mills Inc. fell $2, to $67.375; and the Quaker Oats Company lost $1.125, to $72.50.

HEADLINE: For True School Decentralization, Close Central Board of Ed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"A School System -- For the Kids" (editorial, May 15) and "Who Can Fix the City's Schools?" (May 18), on school governance in New York City, claim that what is needed is to go beyond mere "tinkering at the margins." Yet this is the tack you take. Few argue with the need to abandon the byzantine fashion we elect local school board members or to take steps to stem the patronage that eats away at the system. However, it is only by attacking the systemic waste of resources that we can hope to turn the future around for our children.
The bill in Albany representing the proposal put forth by Queens Borough President Claire Schulman and myself gives parents, principals and teachers more authority over the running of their institutions. It has the most sweeping anti-corruption package of any current proposal. It increases mayoral accountability through a commissioner of education, who would oversee budget issues, monitor compliance with mandates and negotiate labor contracts. 
 By eliminating the central Board of Education and drastically shrinking the duties of 110 Livingston Street, our proposal moves dollars and responsibility toward the classroom.
You reduce this effort to a borough power grab. Regional boards exist throughout the state. Our call for similar units in New York City would insure a mechanism for economical interdistrict cooperation. We believe transportation, capital planning and a few other educational services are best delivered at the borough level. Our plan works against the bureaucratic concentration and graft you warn against by capping expenses for all levels of the system.
Sure, real decentralization has risks -- risks synonymous with the promise and perils of democracy. No centralized structure can competently run a system of 1 million students. The time for thoughtful and radical action to make decentralization real is now.
 
RUTH W. MESSINGER
Manhattan Borough President
New York, May 18, 1993

HEADLINE: Dow Advances 14.95 on Moderate Volume

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market rose yesterday in relatively modest trading after a sharp drop on Friday.
But the winning stocks seemed to be concentrated among blue-chip issues like A.T.& T., I.B.M. and Disney. Indeed, on the New York Stock Exchange, losing stocks narrowly outnumbered winners 992 to 950. 
 Stock traders appeared to have already discounted a reported willingness by the Federal Reserve Board to raise short-term interest rates. A rise in bond prices and a fall in gold prices kept traders firmly invested, at least for now, in stocks.
 
Gold Prices Drop
 While surging convincingly for much of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average failed to return to its record high of 3,523.28 and closed up 14.95 points, to 3,507.78. Other leading market indexes, except for the American Stock Exchange, closed up as well.
The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board voted early last week to lean toward higher short-term interest rates. What normally would have been viewed as hurting the stock and bond markets seems to have been interpreted by bond traders as a long-term positive by helping to fight inflation. When bonds firmed and gold prices fell, stocks rose.
Whatever the reasoning, the Dow fell into negative territory of about 5.5 points only fleetingly and traded as high as 22 points above the opening, to 3,513.59. Computerized trading did not appear to play as large a role yesterday as in sessions last week.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index closed up 0.80 point, to 247.07. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 198 million shares, well below the 273.2 million on Friday and the 279.5 million on Thursday, when the Dow hit a record high.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.16 points, to 448.00, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.40, to 694.69. The American Stock Exchange market value index, which reflects the Amex's higher proportion of gold stocks, fell 1.17, to 431.69.
Gold prices fell and gold stocks declined or remained unchanged. Gold spot contracts for June delivery declined $3.70, to $374.20 an ounce. Among gold stocks, Newmont Mining declined 1 3/8, to 50 3/4. Echo Bay Mines fell 3/8, to 11 3/4, and, as it has been for many of the sessions in the last several weeks, was the most-active stock on the American Stock Exchange, with volume of 2.75 million shares.
In Nasdaq trading, Tele-Communications was the most active stock, with 6.8 million shares changing hands. Shares of the nation's largest cable-television operator closed up 1 1/4, to 21 7/8.
Ted Turner, chairman of Turner Broadcasting, whose Cable News Network is carried on many cable systems, said his company was developing plans for a new CNN foreign-news channel as well as a new entertainment channel emphasizing old movies.
The warrants and stock of Andrea Electronics were the biggest percentage losers on the American Stock Exchange. The stock closed down 11, to 75, after news reports noted the speculative frenzy that had driven its price as high as 103. Thinly traded, the company, which expects to offer a noise-cancellation systems, plans to increase its shares outstanding.
Kellogg, the cereal maker, fell 2 3/8, to 53 7/8, on relatively heavy volume of nearly a million shares. The decline followed Kellogg's announcement yesterday that it expected second-quarter earnings to be 10 percent lower than a year earlier because of a slump in its foreign markets.
American Online, which provides computer information services to consumers and businesses, saw its shares rise 2 1/4, to 36 1/2, on the expectation that Paul Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, might buy it.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Monday's stock trading referred incorrectly to securities of the Andrea Electronics Corporation. The only publicly traded Andrea securities are common shares and the shares that will be outstanding after the company completes a five-for-one stock split; there are no warrants.

HEADLINE: Belgrade Reneges on Verification Of Ban on Arming Bosnian Serbs

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 25

 BODY:
Serbian leaders told a Russian mediator today that they were not prepared to accept international monitors on their border with Bosnia and Herzegovina to verify their assertions that they were not supplying Bosnian Serb forces with weapons or other military supplies.
President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who a month ago said international observers would be welcome to confirm that his Government was enforcing an embargo on military aid to Bosnian Serbs, told Vitaly I. Churkin, the Russian Deputy Foreign Minister, that there was now "no need" for them. 
 His remark confirmed a stiffening in Serbian attitudes in recent days that reflected their clear sense that they had won the war against the Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces, and that the feared American and European pressure against the Serbs had dissipated.
 
Reversal on Vance-Owen Plan
 Mr. Milosevic had endorsed the so-called Vance-Owen peace plan for Bosnia and had announced an embargo against the Bosnian Serbs when they refused to accept it. Those moves seemed to be made in part to persuade the West to lift the economic sanctions on Serbia and Montenegro, the two states that make up what is left officially of Yugoslavia.
On Monday, Radovan Karadzic, the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, told Mr. Churkin that his side would never recognize the division of Bosnia into 10 semiautonomous regions as provided in the Vance-Owen plan.
Serbs will recognize only one Bosnian state, Dr. Karadzic said, the "Republika Srpska" that Bosnian Serbs have carved out of lands they now control in Bosnia and Herzegovina. "On this, we will not give up," he vowed.
The hardening of terms reflected the Serbs' general contempt for the plan announced by the United States, Russia and three European countries last weekend to contain the war, a plan Mr. Churkin came to Belgrade to explain to their leaders before making a brief trip to the restive Serbian province of Kosovo, which is more than 90 percent populated by ethnic Albanians.
 
Why the Change in Attitude?
 Mr. Milosevic said the plan was seen as proof that the international community had decided against military intervention in the Balkans, but officials made clear that what he really meant was that the Clinton Administration had backed off from the use of force. A few months ago, when they did not know what President Clinton's policy would be, Serbian officials were acting more contritely, and some said they were willing to compromise to find peace.
Now that it is clear that Mr. Clinton and America's European allies are not going to commit their military forces to a cruel war in the Balkans, the Serbs have abandoned such statements, dismissing the latest international admonitions to shape up or face "new and tougher measures" as empty saber-rattling.
The language of brute force is understood in a part of the world where Serbs, Croats and Muslims have intermittently slaughtered and intermingled with each other over centuries. But they also can read the plain language in the weekend declaration out of Washington that makes it clear that Americans and Europeans are simply not willing to risk their own lives and money to stop the fighting here.
Few Serbs would disagree with the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, who a few weeks ago complained that the Serbs had led the Western countries around by the nose for the last year, promising peace while continuing war, and little has changed today.
 
Peace Plan Regarded as Dead
 At the time Mr. Clinton was proposing to lift the arms embargo for the Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces and selected air strikes against Serb positions, Mr. Milosevic persuaded Mr. Karadzic to support the so-called Vance-Owen peace plan. But the self-styled Bosnia Serb parliament, supported by an overwhelming majority of voters, again rejected the plan early this month, and now both Serbian leaders clearly regard the plan as a dead letter.
It may not have been just the threat of military force that made Mr. Milosevic waver briefly. The international economic embargo against Serbia is crushing the life out of its economy. There are now 1.5 million unemployed, about 50 percent of the labor force. As a cashier at the Hyatt Hotel mentioned the other day while counting a huge stack of 50,000-dinar bills, each now worth only about 16 cents, she wasn't worried about robbers, because skyrocketing inflation had made the money worth virtually nothing.
But even the ordinary Serbs who are the worst affected do not seem to object to the leaders whose war policies have brought misery upon them. Americans here are routinely accosted by people who blame Mr. Clinton for their deprivations.
"I don't think Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Karadzic lack anything," said Hamdija Jusuf Spahic, the Muslim Mufti of Belgrade, at the 300-year-old mosque here on Sunday, "but the poor, who are blameless, are suffering."
 
Radical Serbs Gain Strength
 The Mufti denounced Mr. Karadzic a criminal and the war as bestial, but like most ordinary people here he can do little to stop it. Instead, the radical Serb nationalists are gaining strength. Vojislav Seselj, the leader of the Serbian Radical Party, who like President Milosevic is a former Communist, spent much of the last week touring Bosnian battlefields like a medieval sovereign and decorating Serb fighters with paramilitary titles and medals.
With ultranationalists like him and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the commander of the Bosnian Serb fighters, now in the ascendancy, Mr. Milosevic and President Dobrica Cosic of the Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro have now retreated from earlier feints toward moderation.
"Anybody who suggested we make concessions to the U.N. now would have enormous difficulties, and we already do with our brothers over there," an adviser to Mr. Cosic said over the weekend, referring to the Bosnian Serbs.
The Yugoslav President objected to the continuation of the international sanctions in a meeting with Mr. Churkin here on Monday, and Dr. Karadzic even seemed to raise an obstacle to United Nations safety zones in Bosnia for the remaining Muslim refugees.
The self-styled Bosnian Serb parliament has rejected the presence of foreign military forces on Bosnian soil, Dr. Karadzic told the Tanyug press agency, implying that United Nations troop reinforcements to protect the refugees would be rejected just as resolutely as monitors would be kept from fanning out along the border.
 
Loss for the NATO Alliance>
 If the Bosnian Muslims are the big losers on the ground here, the NATO alliance and the United States are losers in a larger sense.
NATO officials in Belgium said before the latest international plan was issued that the alliance had failed to cope with the challenge of ethnic violence in the Balkans because the Bush and Clinton Administrations had not provided clear leadership. Both were undecided about what to do.
Faced with a decision between sending in American soldiers to fight and die in Bosnia or just watching while the slaughter of the Muslims continued, Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher gave mixed signals to the European allies, and got equally mixed signals back. In the end they compromised, agreeing to back European and other United Nations forces if they tried to contain the fighting along existing front lines and protect the Muslims in the five enclaves of territory left to them. But the United States would use only air power to protect the peacekeepers, and then only if they came under attack themselves and asked for help.
"Without a commitment of ground forces, without spending money and without spending lives, you're not going to play a role here," said a Western diplomat who believes international ineffectiveness will only prolong and further poison the Balkans conflict. "The only way this can be stopped is by strong outside intervention, and it's clear that it isn't going to happen."
 
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
 In YUGOSLAVIA, the plan to contain the fighting in BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA that the West has agreed on, appeared to be viewed yesterday as world acceptance of a Bosnian Serb victory.
With the West backing away from a showdown, the question in ZAGREB, CROATIA, is whether the Croatian President will bide his time or renew attacks on Serbian-held territory in Croatia.
The latest plan to end fighting in Bosnia drew fire in BRUSSELS from some NATO allies who say its provisions for setting up safe areas for Muslim civilians would reward Serbian aggression. Foreign ministers discussed plans for more peacekeeping troops.
Serbs in CROATIA said they would boycott scheduled talks with the Croatian authorities on future relations until Croatian troops withdraw from disputed territory.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia talking yesterday with relatives of people kidnapped in February from a Belgrade to Bar train. The relatives, who carried photographs of about 20 people taken at gunpoint from the train in Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanded an investigation. (Reuters)(pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Dental Care for Children Is Considered by Clinton

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton told consumer advocates today that she hoped the President's health plan would cover comprehensive dental care for children and some dental services for adults.
Mrs. Clinton said she hoped the plan would include coverage of "acute dental care for adults." Such care usually includes emergency care and services to control infection and bleeding and to relieve pain. 
 The study group on health care headed by Mrs. Clinton is recommending to the President that full dental care for children and partial coverage for adults be included, according to a briefing book prepared for Mrs. Clinton.
 
Balancing Pros and Cons
 But the President, who will have to weigh the costs of his proposals as well as their political appeal, has not made a final decision on dental benefits.
As work continues on President Clinton's health plan, the White House today identified 32 outside experts chosen to audit the proposal, amid indications of further delay in submitting it to Congress.
Mrs. Clinton described the Administration's thinking on dental care at a meeting with about 500 consumer advocates and health-care experts. The meeting was closed, but details were obtained tonight from people who attended the session and took notes.
In recent weeks, Administration officials have suggested that Mr. Clinton's plan will include some coverage of mental-health care, long-term care and prescription drugs. But Mr. Clinton might have to scale down some of his promises or defer coverage if he ultimately concludes that his proposals as a whole cost more than Congress, consumers and employers are willing to pay.
The White House has already said that Mr. Clinton will ask Congress to define a comprehensive package of medical benefits that must be provided to all Americans under public and private health insurance plans.
At today's meeting, Martha L. Liggett, general counsel of the American Association of Dental Schools, asked Mrs. Clinton whether the "mandatory package" would include dental care.
Ms. Liggett quoted Mrs. Clinton as saying: "I hope so. I hope it will include a children's program and acute dental care for adults."
 
Plight of the Poor
 A confidential briefing book prepared for Mrs. Clinton uses "children" to refer to people through the age of 17 or 18. The briefing book says that more than 90 percent of Americans have oral diseases like tooth decay, gum disease and oral cancer. The book says that poor people and members of minority groups are "particularly at risk" because they have no dental insurance or cannot afford the out-of-pocket costs of dental care.
Mrs. Clinton did not say how employers or the Government would pay for the dental health benefits.
Ms. Liggett of the dental schools' association welcomed Mrs. Clinton's comments today. "I'm delighted at the recognition that adults currently have no safety net for serious dental problems," she said. "It appears that Mrs. Clinton appreciates the need for acute dental coverage for adults. Without such coverage, poor people have to turn to emergency rooms of hospitals for oral health care."
While public health experts and dental colleges have urged that dental care be included in any national health plan, many practicing private dentists oppose this, saying it would disrupt a system that works well for most Americans. They call instead for separate programs to help poor people obtain dental care.
Dr. John S. Zapp, executive director of the American Dental Association, reacted cautiously to Mrs. Clinton's comments. "We would support a preventive dental health-care program for children and comprehensive coverage for all indigent people," he said. "But for the nonindigent adult population, we prefer the current private-sector benefits program, including private health insurance negotiated in the workplace, which has a good record of cost containment."
 
150 Million Lack Insurance
 The Government says that at least 150 million Americans have no dental insurance. From 90 million to 100 million people have private coverage, which has increasingly been offered by employers, but the coverage ranges from comprehensive to meager.
Americans spent $39 billion on dental care last year. That accounts for 5 percent of national health spending, as against 21 percent for doctors' services and 45 percent for hospital care, the Government says. Dental costs are rising, but not as fast as the overall cost of medical care.
The outside experts who will audit Mr. Clinton's health-care proposal are divided into three teams. One consists of lawyers analyzing possible legal problems in the plan. Another includes actuaries and accountants checking the cost. A third consists of executives who have experience slashing paper work and bureaucracy at hospitals and health maintenance organizations around the country.
In interviews today, several members of the legal audit team said the Administration appeared to have neglected legal issues in developing its proposals to revamp the nation's health-care system.
By contrast, Richard Ostuw, chairman of the cost audit team, gave the Administration high marks for its efforts to estimate the cost of proposed benefits. "Nobody can be totally confident about health-care cost projections, but the Administration has done a very thorough and professional job," he said.
 
Meeting Is Delayed
 With dozens of major decisions still to be made, Mr. Clinton had planned to meet Monday with his top advisers on economic and health policy. But the meeting was put off so White House officials could focus on the President's budget and tax package, scheduled for a vote this week in the House of Representatives.
Mr. Clinton originally said he would send Congress a detailed legislative proposal on health care by May 3, but he fell behind schedule. White House officials have been saying recently that the plan will be sent to Congress in mid-June, and Mrs. Clinton made a similar prediction on Saturday. But White House officials now say that the end of June looks more likely.
Many Administration officials want to wait until Congress has completed work on the President's budget and tax plans, the main vehicle for his efforts to revive the nation's economy, and the Senate is not expected to take up that legislation until late June.

HEADLINE: Guatemalan, Supported by Army, Disbands Congress and the Court

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, May 25

 BODY:
President Jorge Serrano Elias dissolved the Congress and the Supreme Court today and suspended constitutional rights in what appeared to be a military-backed effort to silence growing political and economic protests.
Mr. Serrano, a conservative former businessman whose two-year push to end the country's 32-year civil war has foundered in recent weeks, said he would rule temporarily by decree to stem a "breakdown in law and order." 
 Almost as Mr. Serrano announced the measures this morning in a broadcast address, the homes of the Attorney General and the presidents of the Congress and the Supreme Court were surrounded by security forces.
The Government's human rights ombudsman, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, who has accused the armed forces of responsibility for political murders and kidnapping, told reporters he was going into hiding.
The capital remained tense after the announcement, but stores opened and people seemed to go on with their lives. Police officers took over the Congress and soldiers patrolled some streets.
Mr. Serrano said he would hold elections within 60 days for a national assembly to change unspecified elements of the constitution. He also promised to leave office as scheduled, in January 1996.
"I have decided to suspend the constitution temporarily and partly," he said. Later he added, "Today they will criticize me, but tomorrow the people of Guatamala will thank me."
The President's move interrupted seven years of democratic rule that had been plagued by intermittent political strife, a leftist insurgency and the continuing power of right-wing military officers. Before the inauguration of Mr. Serrano's predecessor, Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, in 1986, the military had ruled almost continuously since 1954 when, with Washington's support, it ousted an elected leftist president.
 
Wielding an 'Iron Hand'
 In recent days, diplomats said, hard-line military officers have been taking a more active role in politics. In particular, they said, military leaders have pressed for a tougher line against labor union and student groups that have protested, sometimes violently, against economic austerity policies.
Apparently in response to military demands, Mr. Serrano said last week that he would apply an "iron hand" against protesters. On Friday the President formed a new riot squad of soldiers and police officers. But that same day, thousands of protesters marched peacefully through the capital, which buzzed with rumors of a military coup.
The chief military spokesman, Capt. Julio Yon Rivera, dismissed reports of a military role in the President's decision. He said military leaders supported Mr. Serrano because he is Commander in Chief.
Mr. Serrano's decisions today bore striking similarities to those taken in April 1992 by President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru, who suspended the constitution in the face of rising civil protests, military pressure and a far more serious threat from leftist guerrillas.
Though Mr. Fujimori assumed virtual dictatorial powers, he was praised by many Peruvians for acting decisively. His public support surged, and the United States and other countries eventually set aside their objections.
Like his Peruvian counterpart, Mr. Serrano justified his actions as necessary to "purge the state of all its forms of corruption with which you and I are totally fed up."
Mr. Serrano did not explain how he would do this. For the moment, officials said, the Government was suspending freedom of assembly and freedom of speech.
 
Criticism From Abroad
 At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Serrano said he hoped the international community would support him. Instead, his actions were criticized by other Latin American governments and by Spain, which has long sought an end to Guatemala's war.
The Clinton Administration was also sharply critical.
"This illegitimate course of action threatens to place Guatemala outside the democratic community of nations," the White House said in a statement. "We strongly condemn such efforts to resolve Guatemala's problems through non-democratic means."
Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said the Assistant Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, telephoned President Serrano this morning to urge him to reverse course.
 
Criticism From Within
 Opposition political leaders, human rights advocates and the Indian leader Rigoberta Menchu, winner of last year's Nobel Peace Prize, all assailed Mr. Serrano in blistering terms. "The entire world is repudiating what is really a coup d'etat in Guatemala," Miss Menchu said.
"There is a whole corrupt political tradition in this country," said Labor Minister Mario Solorzano, who joined other Social Democrats in a mass resignation. "But the way to resolve it is not a constitutional step backward," he added.
Guatemala's Ambassador to Washington, Edmundo Mulet, also resigned.
Manuel Conde Orellana, the Government's chief representative in its stalled talks with the leftist rebels, told reporters that the Government had been paralyzed by cocaine traffickers who had increasingly used Guatemala as a transshipment point between Colombia and Mexico.
But according to diplomats and drug-enforcement officials, that corruption has centered in the police and security forces, which did not seem to be affected by today's steps.
What seemed to have been the more immediate concern were the growing street protests. Their focus has been on economic measures like increases in bus fares, but the marchers on Friday also chanted loudly for Mr. Serrano's resignation.

HEADLINE: Savings Estimate Lowered

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced yesterday that savings from the Treasury's decision to shift more of its borrowing to shorter-term, lower interest rate notes and bills would save less than expected.
In the President's budget, the Office and Management and Budget had assumed a savings of $16.4 billion over the five fiscal years through 1998. But the O.M.B said in a statement that the savings were now estimated to be $10.8 billion, less than two thirds of the original goal. 
The Treasury announced its borrowing shift May 5. After the announcement, Administration and Congressional officials indicated that the savings would be only one-third to two-thirds of the $16.4 billion goal.
One reason for the lower savings is that the Treasury, which is cutting its 30-year bond sales by about 40 percent, is not shifting all this borrowing to three-month and six-month Treasury bills, which have the lowest interest rates. Instead, the borrowing will be shifted to three-year notes and two-year notes and Treasury bills.
The Congressional Budget Office's forecast of savings is much lower, at $6.4 billion, or more than a third of the original estimate. The main reason for the difference is the C.B.O.'s assumption that without the Treasury borrowing shift, annual sales of 30-year bonds would have stayed at $37 billion, which was the current rate. The O.M.B. assumed that these sales would have increased to $49 billion by 1988.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 FLORIO'S CHIEF OF STAFF RESIGNS
 Governor Florio has accepted the resignation of his chief of staff, Joseph C. Salema, whose bond firm is at the center of a Federal investigation into whether it improperly benefited from state bond deals. Mr. Salema resigned in an effort to spare the Governor further political embarassment in an election year. A1.
 
 NEW YORK CITY
 
 DINKINS WEIGHS SERVICE CUTS
 The Dinkins administration said for the first time that it would have to resort to serious cuts in city services to balance the new budget, and the City Council began considering what should be cut. B3.
 MAN WALKS AWAY FROM PRISON PROGRAM
 A man charged in the stabbing of a good samaritan in the subway on May 12 had walked away on May 1 from a work-release program that he had been admitted to less than seven months after he started serving a prison sentence. The State Corrections Commissioner said that while the case was an isolated one, it showed the risks posed by a program that is forced by tight money and prison overcrowding to return more than twice as many people to the streets as it did three years ago. B2.
 UNFULFILLED DREAMS FOR DEAD BOY
 From the hospital bed where she is recovering from multiple-stab wounds, Dana Blackledge-Poole remembered the dreams she had had for the 5-year-old boy, her legal ward, whose body was found in a Brooklyn trash compactor on Thursday. The police are searching for her husband, Stephan Poole, for questioning in the killing of the boy, Kayesean Blackledge, and the stabbing of his wife. B3.
 2 KITCHEN WINDOWS WIN A REPRIEVE
 The Landmarks Preservation Commission and the owner of a Park Avenue apartment have reached an accommodation over two kitchen windows. The owner can keep his windows as long as he owns his co-op but must change them if and when he sells. B3.
 
 REGION
 
 F.B.I. IN STING OF DRUG CARTEL
 The Federal Bureau of Investigation laundered $22.5 million in cash for the Cali cocaine cartel between 1991 and 1992 in a sting operation that exposed illegal financial dealings from Colombia to Israel, Italy, Canada and New York, Federal officials in Connecticut announced. Federal agencies jointly set up the sting by secretly running a small financial firm out of an office building near the Greenwich, Conn., railroad station. B6.
 ALBANY NOT RECEPTIVE TO CHANNEL ONE
 Amid concerns about the commercial and news content of Channel One, legislation to allow public schools to show the current-affairs program for teen-agers appears almost certain to fail in the New York State Assembly. B5.
 BID TO KEEP PRATT & WHITNEY
 In a bid to prevent Pratt & Whitney, Connecticut's largest private employer, from closing plants in the state, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has proposed a package of tax cuts and job-training grants that could save the company $32 million a year. B5.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Russia's Technology Tag Sale

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, May 24

 BODY:
Standing amid the largest exhibit yet of technology developed by the former Soviet Union, Sergei P. Gavrilov, the head of marketing for the Distant Radiocommunication Scientific Research Institute of Moscow, struggled to formulate a sales pitch for the radar system displayed on the wall behind him.
After intently pondering a question about the advantages his product might have over its Western counterparts, Mr. Gavrilov finally answered. "Basically," he said, "we're competing on price." 
 As it increases its efforts to attract Western investment and customers to the vast network of research laboratories and factories that once supported the Soviet military, Russia seems to be adopting a bargain-basement approach.
In displaying their wares, the Russians are looking for customers to buy ready-made products, or distributors to sell them in the West or companies willing to license any variety of technologies for manufacture abroad.
 
Fruits of Cold War
 On display here this week in a huge convention hall are the fruits of hundreds of billions of dollars and decades worth of work, Soviet industry's contribution to the cold war. There are designs for aircraft, highly advanced techniques for manufacturing artificial diamonds, mockups of nuclear power generators for ships, optical equipment, highly reliable valves and all kinds of electronic sensors. Formerly the guts of the nation's military hardware and software, they are now for sale -- but, the show's Russian organizers stressed, for peaceful purposes only.
The Main Department for Rocket Space Technology, once dedicated to building the missiles that might have been sent raining down on the United States, came here to peddle not just the latest in satellite thruster technology, but refrigerators, irons and ice cream makers.
The Chief Directorate of Ammunition and Special Chemistry offers special machinery to chop up unneeded ships, airplanes and missiles, as well as candy and baby-food production lines. Satellite sensors developed to detect missiles taking off are now being adapted to spot forest fires.
It is hard to say whether the Russians will make any sales to or attract any investment from the Western electronics companies, manufacturers, import-export companies, government representatives and venture capitalists invited to the show. The idea, the show's organizers said, was to take the wraps off technologies that had long been held as national secrets and to begin the process of marketing.
Then again, it was clear that the Russians had a long way to go in developing the Las Vegas-style pizazz that usually permeates trade shows. Instead of glamorous models handing out slick sales brochures, the Russians were represented by fidgety engineers smoking cigarettes in booths in an atmosphere that at times resembled a tag sale, with fishing rods propped next to the latest in plastic explosives.
Relatively few of the technologies and industrial processes that Russia is showing off are cutting-edge or offer significant improvements over what is already commercially available in the United States, Europe and much of the rest of the world.
 
Low Labor Costs

 
 But with Russia's low labor costs, and research and development costs that were borne by the Soviet Government before the collapse of Communism, the prices of the technology can often be well below those of similar products in the West.
Even with the price advantage, though, Russia is clearly having difficulty attracting the amount of Western interest it needs to support its beleaguered military-related industries -- which, like many of their Western counterparts, are now searching for a peacetime mission.
Russia, of course, is still selling arms outright to foreign purchasers in an effort to keep its huge arms industry afloat. But many factories and research centers, seeing little future in arms production, are converting from military to civilian output, using their skills and technologies to try to meet the needs of a wide range of industries as well as foreign governments.
With the Russian economy and the former Soviet trading bloc in shambles, the only hope for many of the enterprises to stay afloat is to develop markets in the West. And the Western business executives who came here to kick the tires of the former Soviet war machine said that even when a Russian product looks interesting, the risks and difficulties of doing business with a country in political and economic upheaval will often prove daunting, if not insurmountable.
"There's a lot of interesting technology with possible applications, but many of the real questions have yet to be answered," said James C. Brown of Harlow Associates, a company based in Reston, Va., that is seeking to become a middleman in deals between Russia and Western companies and governments.
Western executives said pricing information remained sketchy. They said there were great uncertainties about whether crucial technologies were really available to buy, and whether the Russian Government would approve all deals made by companies that are just beginning to move to private ownership.
 
Listening to Customers
 For all the problems, though, Western executives said their Russian counterparts were putting behind them their Soviet-era mentality, under which almost all technology was designed with its military applications in mind and with little regard for cost or commercial viability. Increasingly, they said, the Russians are learning to listen to what their potential customers want and to design products with a commercial market in mind.
"They're becoming businessmen very rapidly," Mr. Brown said.
Kvarz, a company that is part of the Institute of Electronic Measurements, has cracked the market in the United States for devices used to calibrate radio equipment with sales through an American distributor, and hopes to be able to expand its sales to the West. Indeed, said Valery V. Ruchkin, the technical director, the jobs of the company's 5,000 employees may depend on it.
Many of its products, he said, are half as expensive as similar Western goods. "We've had different economies, different standards of living, different salaries up to now, so maybe we can sell things cheaper," Mr. Ruchkin said.
But he said Russian workmanship and design should not be synonymous with inferior workmanship and design.
"Sometimes," Mr. Ruchkin said, displaying a budding capitalist's flair for unsubstantiated comparative marketing, "our standards are better than Hewlett-Packard."

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 8.85 Points, to Close at 3,516.63

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
With little encouraging news on the economy, the stock market once again drifted into a tentative trading range yesterday, although most indexes rose modestly.
Both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 closed up slightly. Volume on the Big Board was relatively light at 222.8 million shares, though heavier than Monday's 198 million shares. Gold, usually a siphoner of investments from stocks, soared in price but failed to pull up gold stocks, which rose only modestly. 
 The Dow closed up 8.85 points, to 3,516.63, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index closed up 0.63 point, to 247.70. Gaining stocks on the Big Board outnumbered losers 1,127 to 795.
 
Amex Sets Record High

 
 The Standard & Poor's 500, with a greater variety of stocks on several exchanges, was up 0.85 point, to 448.85. The Nasdaq composite index, reflecting smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, closed up 0.35 point, to 695.04. The American Stock Exchange market value index closed up 2.38 points, to 434.07, a record.
There seemed to have been little market reaction to the larger-than-expected decline in consumer confidence this month. Both the Dow and the S.& P. 500 dropped early in the session and then rose modestly through the rest of the day.
The Conference Board reported that its index of Americans' confidence in the economy dropped from 67.6 in April to 61.5 in May, the lowest since October. Analysts had expected a rating of about 65. The drop meant that consumer confidence was now at the same level as before President Clinton's election.
 
A.T.& T. Sets Pace

 
 The Dow was mostly lifted by just three stocks: A.T.& T., Alcoa and International Paper, with the latter two each rising 1 3/8 on no discernible news. The S.& P. 500 was lifted by a variety of stocks, led by A.T.& T., which hit a new high yesterday of 62 3/8 before closing at 62, up 1 1/2.
A.T.& T.'s rise followed several corporate developments, the most important of which was a new telecommunications alliance in Asia with Singapore Telecom and Kokusai Denshin Denwa, or KKD, Japan's largest international long-distance carrier.
The other significant corporate development seemed to center on Amax, which announced a merger with Cyprus Minerals for more than $1 billion, to form one of the world's largest mining companies with interests in copper, coal and gold. Amax closed up 4 1/8, to 22 3/4, while Cyprus Minerals closed down 1, to 26 5/8, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Gold for June delivery rose sharply, by $4.50 to $378.70 an ounce. But gold stocks reacted only moderately. Newmont Mining rose 5/8, to 51 3/8, on the New York Stock Exchange and Echo Bay Mines rose 1/8, to 11 7/8, on the American Stock Exchange.
Only Dell Computer, reporting unexpectedly poor earnings, and Station Casino, a gambling stock in an initial public offering, provided any action yesterday in a lethargic market. Dell, the most active stock on any exchange with 13.16 million shares changing hands, closed down 7 3/8 points to 24 3/4 in Nasdaq trading, after reporting setbacks in its notebook computer products.
Station Casino, the second most active at 12.49 million shares, closed unchanged at 20 in Nasdaq trading. Boomtown Inc., like Station Casino a gambling stock, rose 3/4, to 29 1/4.

HEADLINE: Plan to Unclog Herald Square To Close Broadway for 2 Blocks

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
After years of delays, New York City is now moving forward on an ambitious redesign of Herald Square that will permanently block off part of Broadway, which has stretched virtually uninterrupted from the northern Bronx to the tip of Manhattan since the early 1800's.
While the changes encompass only a small area, they will ripple throughout Manhattan as motorists accustomed to driving through Herald Square will be forced to take other routes. 
 Federal officials are expected to approve financing next week for the plan to unclog the square, the most congested and one of the most dangerous intersections in the city, by markedly enlarging its park space and sidewalks and by shifting the course of Broadway and Avenue of the Americas.
The project will close Broadway from 34th to 32d Streets, removing the venerable thoroughfare's diagonal line from the jumble of streets that converge there, and turning the pattern at the square into the kind of more manageable four-way grid that exists throughout the city where avenues meet streets.
"This is a tremendous leap forward," said Lucius J. Riccio, the city's transportation commissioner. "It is the greatest change since we went to one way on the avenues back in the 1940's and 1950's. We hope that by doing this we will create a little miracle on 34th Street that will attract more people and make the movement of those people work better."
The project, scheduled to be completed by 1995, reflects a growing interest among transportation officials around the world in reducing traffic in downtown areas by cordoning off streets and returning them to pedestrians. But some businesses around Herald Square oppose it, fearing that customers who drive to the neighborhood will be scared away.
Some motorists who frequent the area said they were skeptical that other southbound avenues would be able to handle the traffic that would be routed off Broadway. Even now, Seventh Avenue from Times Square to Madison Square Garden is often hopelessly overcrowded during the day, they said.
The square, named after The New York Herald newspaper, was last redesigned for traffic in the early years of the century, said Joseph DePlasco, a spokesman for the Transportation Department.
He said that the plan would cost $2.5 million for design and environmental studies, barricades, signs, traffic signals, sidewalks and curbs. That work would be coupled with at least $2 million in renovations to the park space at Herald Square and Greeley Square to the south by the 34th Street Partnership, a private group of neighborhood businesses.
The partnership will resurface the park space, essentially two 2,900-square-foot islands in the middle of the squares, with pink granite. It will build walls to block off the street, plant many more trees and shrubs, install benches and chairs and add food concession stands. Architects are also considering moving the statue of Horace Greeley to a more prominent spot.
After design plans for the traffic project are finished later this year, transportation officials will begin posting signs on Broadway north of 34th Street that will tell motorists that they cannot drive south through Herald Square and should instead use Ninth, Seventh or Fifth Avenues. All vehicles must turn off Broadway at 34th Street.
But buses and taxis will be able to continue south on two lanes that will be carved out of Avenue of the Americas, leaving four other lanes running north. The two lanes will run to 32d Street, where vehicles can turn east to return to Broadway.
 
'Return the Streets'
 The project will create 16,500 more square feet of pedestrian space in Herald Square. Traffic engineers estimate that it will also reduce by 6 percent the number of motor vehicle accidents in the square, to about 1,650 a year.
"We want to return the streets to their rightful owners, the pedestrians," Mr. Riccio said. "I am trying to get the department to redirect its policies toward using the public spaces for pedestrians."
He said the project had been under consideration since the early 1980's, but had been delayed because there was no financing until the Surface Transportation Act was passed by Congress in 1991.
Daniel A. Biederman, president of the 34th Street Partnership, said he supported the move to block off part of Broadway, on which traffic averages 5.1 miles per hour on weekdays. But he emphasized that some merchants in the neighborhood were wary of the plan, particularly Macy's, whose Herald Square department store is one of the world's largest.
"I think Broadway is responsible for most traffic problems we have in midtown," he said. "However, the people in my district also have other concerns. They are very fragile entities. We have got to treat these people with the utmost care. They are a great economic engine in the city."
Laura Melillo, a spokeswoman for Macy's, declined to comment on the project.
 
Merchants and Cabbies
 Eytan Schwartz, 34, manager of Herald Parc Jewelers at 1313 Broadway on the square, assailed the project, saying that it was another example of the city's making policy without considering the effect on small businesses.
"Traffic is one of the reasons that we have any kind of business here," he said. "Any time the city blocks off some portion of Broadway for a parade, it ruins business for everyone in the area. It seems that the city is trying to look for as many reasons as possible to ruin business in midtown."
Some motorists were also critical. Jacques Sanon, a taxi driver, said the shift off Broadway would only worsen traffic on surrounding streets. "You've got Penn Station with a lot of people trying to get in and of there," he said. "I don't see how this will help. I can only see how it can hurt."
But city officials and some private traffic experts insisted that there was enough resilience in the Manhattan traffic grid. Herbert S. Levinson, a transportation consultant who has worked extensively in New York City, argued that the pessimism of the area's businesses was misguided.
"How many of their customers are actually driving down the street, as opposed to taking the subway or walking?" he asked. "The typical merchant's perception is that everyone must drive to a shop. My opinion is that most people come into the area by public transportation."
"My sense that is that it will work," he said. "It might not work the first day, but after a while, people will get acclimated to it."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls to New Low Against Japanese Yen

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
The dollar fell to another record low against the Japanese yen today after the Treasury released a report on exchange rates that suggested the yen's rise could reduce the American trade deficit with Japan.
But at the same time, a senior Treasury official said that devaluing the dollar was not the route to increased American prosperity. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 109.35 yen, down sharply from 110.60 yen on Monday. The dollar's previous closing low in New York was 109.86 yen on April 22.
Also putting pressure on the dollar was a report today showing a decline in consumer confidence, which pointed to continued slow growth and less chance that the Federal Reserve would push up interest rates.
 
Treasury's Report
 The official, Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, steered clear of saying whether the yen should appreciate further, though he said the yen's rise should help reduce the Japanese trade surplus.
Appearing before a subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee today, Mr. Summers released the exchange-rate report, which said, "A decline versus the yen can be seen as a reflection of forces tending to limit and ultimately reverse Japan's widening trade surplus."
Some traders said that by suggesting a strong yen could help reduce Japan's trade surplus, the report appeared to be a veiled effort to push the yen higher. But Mr. Summers denied that.
Echoing recent statements made by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Mr. Summers said, "It is our firm conviction that there is no way to devalue yourself into prosperity."
Most economists say that devaluing a country's currency against those of other nations can give a short-term stimulus by increasing exports, but it makes foreign goods and foreign travel more expensive.
Mr. Summers told the banking subcommittee that Japan's economy was operating well below capacity and that its trade surplus continued to rise because of weak demand for imports.
Mr. Summer said Japan's $116 billion stimulus program should be expanded so that Japanese economic growth is fueled by domestic consumption rather than by exports.
The Treasury report also faulted China for manipulating its currency in a way that helped cause the Chinese trade surplus with the United States to swell to $18.3 billion last year from $12.7 billion in 1991.
"China's trade surplus with the United States is a very serious matter that must be addressed by Chinese action now," Mr. Summers said, noting that the Administration urged Beijing last month to remove its foreign exchange controls.

Dollar Falls Further
 TOKYO, Wednesday, May 26 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The dollar continued to hit new lows against the Japanese yen today, falling below 109 yen.
By late morning in Tokyo, the dollar was quoted at 108.80 yen, down sharply from Tuesday's Tokyo close of 110.56 yen. Currency traders said that the Bank of Japan tried without success to support the dollar when it approached 109 yen this morning.

SECTION: Section D; Page 14; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 799 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Volatile, Yet Change Little

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed yesterday in a day of volatile trading. Instead of getting a lift from a good two-year note auction, the benchmark 30-year bond seemed to have been pulled lower by the sale.
The 30-year bond's yield closed unchanged at 7.00 percent, with the price inching up 1/32 . 
 Ward McCarthy, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy in Princeton, N.J., said the last few days seem to have been dominated by what are known as curve trades. These rest on the expectation that the spread, or difference, between the yields on short-term notes and long-term bonds will change.
Since the release in mid-May of surprisingly high inflation figures for April, there has been speculation that the Federal Reserve might have to raise short-term interest rates to curb rising prices. Because such a move would push up short-term rates, narrowing the spread between these and the rates on bonds, many financial professionals have been dealing in curve-flattening trades.
In this sort of dealing, the investor sells short-term notes and buys longer-term bonds because the bonds' prices are expected to do better.
 
Agile Footwork
 Mr. McCarthy said that speculators and traders had been selling the two-year notes in the when-issued or pre-auction market and buying bonds. Since the auction was announced last week, the spread between the yield on the two-year note and the 30-year bond had narrowed -- on Monday to 282 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point -- down from 299 basis points.
But yesterday, Mr. McCarthy said, some investors decided to take part of their profits and also to cover short positions on two-year notes by buying them in the auction. This provided strong demand, with the yield 4.17 percent in the single-price auction. The coupon on the new two-year note is 4.125 percent. In the when-issued market, the yield on the new two-year note rose to 4.20 percent in late trading.
Combined with this buying, there was selling of 30-year bonds, which in part accounted for the drop in price after the auction results were reported early in the afternoon.
Trading was volatile all day. An early rise in the price of the 30-year bond that pushed the yield down to 6.97 percent was quickly wiped out about 10 A.M., traders said, after it appeared that a Treasury report on foreign-currency exchange favored a weaker dollar against the Japanese yen as a way to cut Japan's rising trade surplus with the United States.
The dollar reached a record low against the yen in the wake of the Treasury report. Comments in February by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that appeared to favor a weaker dollar started a slide that has sent the dollar lower and lower against the Japanese currency.
Yesterday, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, Lawrence Summers, told a Senate Banking subcommittee, where the report was released, that devaluing the dollar was not a way to promote prosperity in the United States.
 
Fewer Municipals?
 The prices of municipal bonds closed little changed yesterday, and there were some indications that the $6 billion in new issues expected this week may be reduced because of the volatility in the Treasury market.
One indication that some issuers are holding back came from the New York State Dormitory Authority, which is delaying the sale of about $700 million of refinancing bonds for the City University of New York.
In the largest tax-exempt issue of the day, the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation sold $550 million in bonds in a negotiated deal led by Dillon, Read & Company. It was the first major bond sale by the Health and Hospitals Corporation since it gained the right to sell its own bonds last fall.
Mark C. Fasteau, a managing director at Dillon, Read, said there was good demand for the issue, especially for the bonds maturing in 2020, which are not insured. After repricing in the afternoon, the yield on these bonds was lowered to 6.36 percent from the initial yield of 6.42 percent. Mr. Fasteau said the yields on several other maturities were lowered by about 5 basis points. Other yields ranged from 4.55 percent on the five-year bond, 5.30 percent on the 10-year bond and 5.68 percent on the 20-year bond. All three are insured.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of two-year notes:
