SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 3052 words

HEADLINE: The Bombing: Retracing the Steps -- A special report;
Fitting the Pieces of Terrorism -- Accounts Reconstruct Planning of Trade Center Explosion

 BODY:
The following article is based on reporting by Ralph Blumenthal, Robert Hanley, Alison Mitchell, Joseph B. Treaster and Mary B. W. Tabor and was written by Mr. Blumenthal.
At 4 A.M., in the early-morning chill of Feb. 26, a yellow Ryder rental van pulled into an all-night gas station on Kennedy Boulevard in Jersey City, tailed by a blue Honda sedan. 
 After fueling up -- $18 worth of gas for the van, about $13 for the car -- one of the passengers walked to a pay phone to make a call. Minutes later, they were joined by a man in a red car. The van driver paid for the gas with a $50 bill, giving the attendant a $2 tip. Then the motorcade drove off.
Something about the entourage stuck in the minds of several onlookers. But it was not until days later that they realized the van was the vehicle that investigators say carried the 1,200-pound bomb that exploded in the World Trade Center garage eight hours later, killing six people and injuring more than 1,000.
Now, three months after the bombing, that gas station rendezvous on a neon-lit urban strip has become a crucial tableau in the Federal conspiracy case. In the account of witnesses, it places several suspects together the very morning of the explosion, which law enforcement officials later called the most devastating terrorist assault on American soil. And it firmly ties those suspects to the van that one of the men later contended had already been stolen from him.
Indeed, with six suspects charged in the explosion and a seventh being held on lesser related charges, the account of what occurred at the gas station is considered so crucial that some witnesses have been hidden and placed under Federal protection. The suspects all maintain their innocence, and their supporters say they have been scapegoated because they are Arabs.
 
Inside but Not Invisible
 While the broad outlines of how investigators believe the bombing was carried out have already been reported, months of interviews with witnesses, investigators and associates of the suspects have produced a detailed account of the events leading up to the explosion -- beginning with the moment last September when investigators say Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, traveling on an Iraqi passport and using many aliases, arrived in New York and helped put the plot in high gear.
It is a tale that highlights the startling ease with which undocumented immigrants are able to enter New York, a story of how a small number of Arab immigrants used a string of false names and even false nationalities to elude identification, and yet drastically underestimated how memorable they would be to neighbors and onlookers.
Several mysteries of the bombing may have been deciphered. Investigators now say the absence of a warning call beforehand is recommended as a tactic to heighten the shock of terrorism in literature seized from one suspect. And the F.B.I. says it now believes that two brothers who gave crucial information about the bombing may have fled to Iraq.
But it is still not clear what blend of Palestinian grievance, Islamic militance or anti-Americanism may have finally motivated the attack on the 110-story twin towers, which dominate lower Manhattan and shine as a symbol of Western wealth and power.
And while investigators are tantalized by a possible Iraqi connection and have also found that tens of thousands of dollars were wired to some of the suspects from Iran, it is not known if the plot was directed from overseas. Indeed, investigators are still searching for Mr. Yousef and at least one other unidentified suspect.
Investigators say they have traced the first stirrings of the plot back to July, and say it accelerated rapidly when two men arrived in New York last September.
Arrivals
A Militant Circle
Grows and Moves
On any day at Kennedy International Airport, immigration officials corral 30 to 40 travelers carrying counterfeit travel documents or none at all, and making a desperate bid to get into America. Sept. 1, 1992 was no exception and on this late summer day, two of the day's offenders came in on Pakistan International Airlines flight 703 from Karachi. It was the moment, investigators now say, that put the bombing conspiracy in high gear.
Mohammad A. Ajaj, a 27-year-old Palestinian who would later be charged in the bombing conspiracy, immediately caught the attention of the authorities by using a crudely doctored Swedish passport in the name of Khurram Khan.
On closer examination, Mr. Ajaj had scarcely any clothes in his suitcases. But according to court documents, he did have a wide array of manuals on the use of knives, grenades, poisons and concealed weapons and the making of Molotov cocktails, pipe bombs and other explosives, including improvised bombs like the one that rocked the Trade Center. He was also carrying videotapes of suicide car bombings, guides to planting land mines and directions on how to forge documents.
Mr. Ajaj was taken into custody at the airport, pleaded guilty to using a false passport and served a six-month prison sentence. After a brief release, he was picked up again by immigration officials and has been indicted in the bombing conspiracy.
Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, who was on the same flight, gave immigration authorities his own Iraqi passport, minus a valid visa, and he claimed political asylum, which entitled him to a series of hearings. The 100-person Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center was full, as usual, so Mr. Yousef was let go.
The tall 25-year-old vanished into the airport crowd. He surfaced shortly afterward among circles of Arab immigrants in New Jersey, where investigators say he became a catalyst for the plot.
 
Nosair Defense in Common
 Some of his associates had already coalesced as fund-raisers and protesters in the defense of El Sayyid A. Nosair, the Egyptian immigrant who had been accused of assassinating Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Jewish militant, in 1990. Mr. Nosair was acquitted of murder but convicted on lesser charges.
As Mr. Yousef arrived last September the F.B.I. was already monitoring the group, and about 20 of them had been summoned by a grand jury looking into a Federal conspiracy case involving Mr. Nosair. Materials seized in 1990 from Mr. Nosair's files, investigators now say, shed light on the group that would later be charged in the Trade Center bombing. The imprisoned Mr. Nosair, through his family and lawyers, has denied any connection to the blast.
In Jersey City, Mr. Yousef quickly started rooming with Mohammed A. Salameh, a Palestinian who had long overstayed his tourist visa and was drifting from job to job.
Acquaintances said Mr. Salameh put his passion into political causes like supporting the Afghan rebels and the defense of Mr. Nosair. He visited Mr. Nosair in Attica prison and received calls from him, officials say.
On July 23, several weeks before Mr. Yousef's arrival, Mr. Salameh made the first of four failed attempts to get a New Jersey driver's license. He finally switched his efforts to New York and received a license on Sept. 8, using as his address the Brooklyn apartment of Ibrahim A. Elgabrowny, Mr. Nosair's cousin.
 
Moving Every Few Months
 While the false Brooklyn address gave Mr. Salameh the semblance of permanency, he and Mr. Yousef began a pattern of moving every few months, using fabricated names and nationalities. Their quarters were meager apartments with little more than single mattresses. It is not even clear whether his own close associates knew Mr. Yousef's real name. Several said they knew him only as Rashid, and Federal wanted posters now list 11 aliases for him.
The men's hub was Jersey City, near the Al-Salam mosque, a third-floor religious center above a check cashing office and a Chinese restaurant. Middle Eastern immigrants congregated at the mosque, sometimes to witness the incendiary preachings of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, a self-exiled Egyptian who advocates the overthrow of Egypt's secular Government.
Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef were friends with two other young men who would also be tied to the bombing. One was Nidal A. Ayyad, a 25-year-old chemical engineer and naturalized citizen with Palestinian roots whom Mr. Salameh had met at a Passaic mosque a year before. The other was Bilal Alkaisi, a 27-year-old teacher at a Brooklyn mosque and a taxi driver, who was taught the cab business by another Egyptian who would emerge as a suspect, Mahmud Abouhalima.
Mr. Abouhalima, 33, was an occasional driver of the sheik. Leaflets distributed in Arab communities also show that he had been named the local leader of Egypt's militant Islamic Group. He had also worked in a Brooklyn storefront that sent money and Islamic recruits to help fight the Soviet-backed Government in Afghanistan. Mr. Abouhalima, acquaintances say, even went to fight himself; his brother denies it.
 
Sharing Bank Accounts
 Some of the men, meanwhile, established interlocking financial ties. Mr. Ayyad and Mr. Salameh shared at least one bank account. Fingerprints later found inside a Newark safe-deposit box showed that Mr. Salameh and Mr. Alkaisi had access to it, according to an F.B.I. report. And investigators have found that close to $100,000 had been wired to several bank accounts linked to the suspects, some of the money from Iran.
It was in November that Mr. Salameh took a step that law enforcement officials later called a crucial milestone in the construction of the bomb.
On Nov. 30, according to a Federal complaint, Mr. Salameh appeared at A Space Station, a storage warehouse in Jersey City, using the name Kamal Ibraham. Attendants said he told them that he and some friends were starting a company and needed to rent a locker. On the contract, he scribbled the names of six associates who would use the 10-feet-square corrugated tin locker.
After the bombing, according to F.B.I. reports, agents found in the locker a virtual chemical factory: bottles of nitric acid, the propellant sodium azide and a poison, sodium cyanide; barrels and containers of sulfuric acid and urea. There was shotgun powder along with bottles, beakers, buckets, funnels, tubing and a fuse.
On New Year's Day, Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef moved yet again, to an apartment at 40 Pamrapo Avenue in Jersey City that Federal agents said became the bomb's testing ground. Mr. Salameh said he was a Turk named Alaa Mahrous, according to the landlord. He paid $1,100 in cash, which included a month's rent and a security deposit, and said he needed the apartment about a year.
Later, investigators found a corrosive powder-blue substance splashed over the walls and ceiling of the back bedroom.
On Jan. 24, while driving with Mr. Yousef at 2 A.M., Mr. Salameh crashed his car outside the Avenel, N.J., garden apartment complex of Mr. Abouhalima.
Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef were taken by ambulance to Rahway Hospital. Ambulance attendants recalled that neither man seemed seriously hurt. Mr. Salameh was released, but Mr. Yousef was admitted to the hospital and remained there until Jan. 29 -- gaining a postponement of his immigration hearing.
Preparations
Licenses, Vans
And Chemicals
By early February, the pace of events quickened.
Mr. Salameh prepared another move, telling his Pamrapo Avenue landlord that he and his roommate had found new jobs in Brooklyn and would be out by the end of the month.
On Feb. 15, Mr. Ayyad rented a red Oldsmobile sedan from the National Car Rental Company in Newark, listing the name "Salameh" as an additional driver. One week later, on the afternoon of Feb. 23, Mr. Salameh and another man later identified in a Federal criminal complaint as Mr. Ayyad appeared in the red car at a Ryder truck rental office on Kennedy Boulevard in Jersey City. Mr. Ayyad, through his lawyer, has said that he was not at the rental agency.
The two men looked at various trucks, recalled Patrick J. Galasso, the operator of the Ryder agency, and settled on an Econoline van for $220 a week or $59 a day, with 100 free miles and then 25 cents a mile. Mr. Salameh, who did not have a credit card, deposited four $100 bills.
Two days before the bombing, Mr. Salameh was still being taught how to drive the van, according to court papers citing an F.B.I. "confidential informant" who did the teaching. Federal authorities say they are now searching for the informer and his brother. They say the two men are missing and may be in Iraq. One of the two, according to an investigator, is Musab Yasin, an Iraqi who taught engineering and briefly shared an apartment with Mr. Salameh.
On Thursday, Feb. 25, the day before the bombing, Mr. Salameh made another trip to the storage locker, this time with another, unidentified companion who said he was from Israel, witnesses later reported. The F.B.I. is now searching for him. The two men described themselves as business partners who were waiting for a shipment to come for their company.
 
Yellow Van and Hydrogen Tanks
 As the two men waited, a delivery of tanks of compressed hydrogen arrived for them from the AGL Welding Supply Company of Clifton, N.J. The attendant, citing rules against flammable substances, barred the delivery. At that, witnesses said, Mr. Salameh and his companion broke into rapid Arabic and asked to use the pay phone. The calls, investigators later determined, went to the desk of Mr. Ayyad at Allied-Signal Inc., in Morristown, N.J.
The men then asked to keep the tanks until they could be picked up. Minutes later, investigators have been told, a yellow Ryder van showed up and drove away with the tanks.
It was about 4 the next morning, on Feb. 26, that witnesses saw the yellow Ryder van appear at the gas station, followed closely by the blue Honda. Investigators say it was the last time the van was seen in one piece before its deadly mission.
The gas station had been robbed before, and one witness started watching closely. He saw two men in the van and three in the Honda. As he tried to peer into the van, the two men got out, the driver seeming to plant himself directly in front of a window, blocking the view.
The passenger then walked to a pay phone and made a call. A few minutes later a red car joined the others.
 
Suspects Identified in Van
 Shown F.B.I. photographs, witnesses later identified the driver of the van as Mr. Salameh and his passenger as Mr. Abouhalima. In an interview earlier this month from the Metropolitan Correctional Center, Mr. Abouhalima denied being at the gas station that morning.
Just over eight hours later, at 12:18 P.M., a huge explosion rocked a parking garage under the New York Vista Hotel in the Trade Center complex, knocking out power, sending tens of thousands of workers fleeing down smoke-darkened stairwells, and crippling lower Manhattan.
Four days after the bombing, a letter was received by The New York Times claiming responsibility in the name of the Liberation Army Fifth Battalion, and attributing the action to deep resentment of United States policy in the Middle East. The letter, investigators said, was tied to Mr. Ayyad through texts found on computer disks seized from his home.
The letter did not explain why the Trade Center was the target, but investigators now theorize it was selected both for its symbolism and for its easy accessibility.
Capture
A Lot of Trouble
For a $200 Refund
If the suspects had immediately fled to Kennedy Airport and out of the country, they might never have been found. In fact, Mr. Yousef did manage to disappear.
But less than two hours after the explosion, Mr. Salameh reappeared at the Ryder office, claiming his van had been stolen the night before from the parking lot of a Shop Rite supermarket, Mr. Galasso said. "He wanted to know what he should do about it," the Ryder agent recalled. "I told him if it was stolen last night, why was he not here last night? He said he was totally confused and didn't know what to do." Mr. Galasso told him to get a police report.
On Sunday, Feb. 28, Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef moved out of their apartment about midnight. In Manhattan, bomb specialists had already scored a crucial breakthrough, finding in the Trade Center wreckage that day a piece of twisted chassis with a vehicle identification number traceable to the Ryder company.
On Monday, Mr. Salameh was back at the Ryder office, saying it would take him three or four days to get the police report. In the meantime, he wanted his deposit back. "I said no, you have to show the truck was stolen," Mr. Galasso replied. "He got a little upset."
By Wednesday, March 3, the F.B.I. and Ryder had traced the van to Mr. Galasso's business. Visited by F.B.I. agents, he retrieved Mr. Salameh's rental contract.
It suddenly dawned on Mr. Galasso. "Don't tell me my van blew up the World Trade Center?"
The address on the rental contract, 17 Park Place, turned out to be the address of the Islamic Center in Jersey City.
 
Large Hidden Audience
 The next day, the F.B.I. returned with a video camera in a gym bag and an agent wired with a hidden recorder. They handed Mr. Galasso a sheet of paper drafted by prosecutors with questions for Mr. Salameh to fill out.
About 9:30 A.M., in a gloomy drizzle, Mr. Salameh entered the office. With agents posing as Ryder employees, he retold the story of the theft before the hidden camera and recorder. One agent, on the phone, relayed a running account to superiors, interspersing, "Did you hear that? Did you get that?"
The refund after Mr. Salameh's use of the truck -- with $17 a day insurance -- came to $154. But the F.B.I. agents had no change, only $200. They said they were awarding him $50 for some furniture he claimed to have lost and offered him $200 back.
Then, said Mr. Galasso, Mr. Salameh asked, "Could you give me my gas money back?"
They gave him $200 and Mr. Salameh, still protesting over the money, filled out the paperwork and left.
For a moment, Mr. Galasso recalled, Mr. Salameh stood outside on the porch, looking out, his hands folded calmly. Beyond, a small army of F.B.I agents lay concealed in cars, stores and doorways. Mr. Salameh walked out of the car lot toward a bus stop. Suddenly agents seemed to pounce from every direction. They tackled Mr. Salameh and wrestled him into a waiting car that sped off.

GRAPHIC: Photo: On Friday, Feb. 26, at 12:18 P.M., a huge explosion rocked a parking garage under the New York Vista Hotel in the World Trade Center complex, knocking out power, sending tens of thousands of workers fleeing down smoke-darkened stairwells and crippling lower Manhattan. (Edward Keating/The New York Times); photos of alleged terrorists
 
Chart: Crime: The Suspects So Far In The World Trade Center Bombing
 
Mohammad Ahmad Ajaj (MO-hah-mahd AH-mahd ah-ZHAZH), 27, a Palestinian born in Jerusalem.
Arrested Sept. 1 after he tried to enter Kennedy Airport with a forged passport and a suitcase of bombing manuals, on same flight as Ramzi Ahmed Yousef. Charged in the World Trade Center bombing, though he was in Federal prison serving a six-month sentence for passport violations at the time. Considered by Israel to be a "minor follower" of the Palestine Liberation Organization; he says he was tortured in Israel.
 
 Mahmud Abouhalima (MAH-mood ah-bah-hoo-LEE-mah), 33, Egyptian-born cab driver.
Arrested March 10 in Egypt, interrogated and returned to United States for prosecution; investigators say he is a "key figure" in the bombing. Says he was tortured during interrogation by Egyptian officials. Immigrated from Egypt to Germany in 1985, then to New York where he obtained residency as a farm worker. Was a part-time driver for Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, served as the local emir of the fundamentalist group Gama'a al- Islamiya, and raised money for Afghan rebels until 1991; said he split with Sheik Rahman in disagreement. Moved last year to Avenel, N.J., with his German-born wife and four children. Says he knows the other bombing suspects, but denies any involvement in the attack.
 
 Bilall Alkaisi (bih-LALL alk-EYE-see), 27, a Brooklyn salesman and mosque teacher of Palestinian descent.
Turned himself in to F.B.I. agents on March 24. Shared an apartment, a bank account and a Newark safe deposit box with Mohammed A. Salameh. Name appeared on a credit card found in the possession of Nidal A. Ayyad.
 
 Nidal A. Ayyad (nih-DAHL ah-YAHD), 25, chemical engineer and Rutgers University graduate, naturalized American citizen born in Kuwait to Palestinian parents.
Investigators say calls made from a Jersey City storage locker, where they believe the bomb was made, were traced to his desk at Allied-Signal Inc. in Morristown, N.J. They also say a letter to The New York Times claiming credit for the bombing has been traced to his personal computer and printer. Went with Mr. Salameh to rent the yellow Ryder van believed to have carried the bomb into the Trade Center garage. His business card was found on Mr. Salameh when Mr. Salameh was arrested. Lived with his wife, mother and brother in Maplewood, N.J.
 
 Ibrahim A. Elgabrowny (EE-bra-him el-ZHAH-brah-nee), 24, Egyptian-born civil engineer.
Charged with hindering the search of his apartment in connection with bombing investigation and carrying forged passports, including one for his relative, El Sayyid A. Nosair. Mr. Nosair was acquitted in the 1990 murder of radical Rabbi Meri Kahane, but imprisoned on a related conviction. Lives at the Brooklyn address listed on Mr. Salameh's drivers license. Investigators say that they found traces of chemicals, like those used in the bomb, on his clothes. His lawyers insist the chemicals are found in his work. Held without bail, though never formally linked to the bombing.
 
 Mohammed A. Salameh, (sah-LEM-mah), 25, a Jordanian construction worker of Palestinian descent.
The first suspect arrested. Entered the United States in 1988 on a tourist visa and stayed after it expired. Shared apartments with Mr. Alkaisi and Mr. Yousef and bank accounts with Mr. Alkaisi and Mr. Ayyad. Rented the Jersey City storage locker where investigators say the bomb was made and the van they say carried the bomb into the Trade Center garage. Mr. Salameh says that the locker was for a business venture and that the van was stolen from him. Attended Jersey City mosque where Sheik Abdel Rahman preached.
 
 Ramzi Ahmed Yousef (RAM-zee AH-med YOO-sef), 25.
Known to friends as Rashid. Worked as a taxi driver and shared Jersey City apartments with Mr. Salameh and Mr. Alkaisi. Arrived in the United States on Sept. 1, on the same flight as Mr. Ajaj. Carried an Iraqi passport and an array of forged documents. His fingerprints were found inside Mr. Ajaj's bombing manuals. Court papers say Mr. Yousef was seen driving with Mr. Salameh in the yellow Ryder rental van used in the bombing. Worshipped at Mr. Abdel Rahman's mosque. Disappeared days after the bombing.

HEADLINE: Boys Predominate in a Contest, Fueling Complaint of Test Bias

 BODY:
Three out of five semifinalists for the National Merit Scholarships this year were boys, an advocacy group reports today, even though well over half of the high school seniors taking the qualifying test were girls.
The group, the National Center for Fair and Open Testing in Cambridge, Mass., says it has been compiling lists of semifinalists for seven years and has found little change in the ratio of boys to girls among semifinalists, despite a growing chorus of complaints that standardized tests are biased against girls. 
 Though no one has analyzed the list of scholarship winners, the National Merit Corporation, the private group that organizes the scholarships, says the sexual breakdown is usually similar to that of the semifinalists.
This year's analysis found that of the 15,850 semifinalists, 61 percent are boys and 35 percent are girls. (The sex of the remaining 4 percent cannot be determined from their names.) Boys outnumber girls in every state.
 
Arguments Over Test
 The National Merit semifinalists are chosen from their scores on the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test, which critics have long accused of being biased against girls. Although girls get higher grades on average than boys in both high school and college, they score 50 to 60 points lower on the P.S.A.T.
"The P.S.A.T. is not an appropriate indicator of how a student has done in high school or how a student will do in college," said Cinthia Schuman, executive director of the advocacy group. "It should not be part of the selection process for the National Merit Scholarships."
A spokeswoman for the National Merit Corporation said the organization had found no better way to screen high school students than the P.S.A.T., which is given to almost two million students a year.
"We are not convinced that the test is biased," said Elaine Detweiler, public information for the corporation. "It could be showing a disparity in academic preparation. If girls are getting better grades in home economics or things like that, they're not better prepared."
About 15,000 students nationwide are chosen as semifinalists for the prestigious scholarships, which can be either a onetime payment of $2,000 or a multiyear stipend of up to $2,000 a year. Those students then submit a full portfolio, including their S.A.T. scores, high school records, extracurricular records, a personal essay and recommendations, Ms. Detweiler said. Ninety percent are then chosen as finalists, and about 6,500 of those receive scholarships each year.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
New School Honors the Premier of a German State

 BODY:
The New School For Social Research conferred degrees yesterday on graduates from the Eugene Lang College, the New School, the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science and the Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy.
The commencements for two other divisions of the school, the Parsons School of Design and the Mannes College of Music, were held earlier this month. 
 Kurt Hans Biedenkopf, the premier of the state of Saxony in Germany, gave the address for the school's 57th commencement, at Riverside Church in Manhattan, and received an honorary doctorate of laws.
A total of 163 bachelor's degrees, 279 master's degrees and 21 doctorates were conferred by the school.
Among the others honored at the ceremony were Gwendolyn Brooks, who in 1950 became the first black person to be awarded the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, and Carolyn G. Heilbrun, a feminist literary scholar who retired early from a tenured position in Columbia University's English department last year, protesting what she said was bias against women.

CUNY
The Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York awarded 318 doctoral degrees and 44 master's degrees at its 29th annual commencement yesterday.
The main address was delivered by Felice N. Schwartz, founder and president of Catalyst, a national nonprofit organization that works to help women in business and professional life.
Among those receiving honorary degrees were Ms. Schwartz and the writer Ralph Ellison.

 Stevens Institute
Harold J. Raveche, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, conferred 850 undergraduate, graduate and professional degrees at the university's 121st commencement exercises yesterday at the John A. Davis Memorial Athletic Field on the campus in Hoboken, N.J.
In a short speech Mr. Raveche challenged the Clinton Administration to establish a strategic economic and technology policy to bolster manufacturing jobs for the United States.
Honorary doctor of engineering degrees were awarded to Norman R. Augustine, chairman and chief executive of Martin Marietta Corporation, and Raymond W. Smith, chairman and chief executive of the Bell Atlantic Corporation.

Cooper Union
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, delivered the main address yesterday at Cooper Union's 134th commencement exercises. Ms. Messinger addressed 210 undergraduates and 23 graduates in the college's Great Hall.
She urged the students to "continue the great unfinished, perhaps never ending, task of realizing the democratic dream on which this school and this city were founded."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Rebound On Brisk Buying by Funds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Metals prices rebounded yesterday as commodity funds bought gold and silver futures aggressively, betting prices would go higher.
Platinum prices rose amid concern about violence in South Africa, the world's largest producer of the metal, analysts said. 
 Gold for delivery in June rose $4.50, to $378.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange after falling $3.70 on Monday. July silver rose 9.3 cents, to $4.643 an ounce, after falling 13.4 cents on Monday.
"The funds were good buyers of metal today," said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. Commodity funds invest billions worth of investors' money in commodities markets, often basing their decisions on a technical analysis of price movements.
"Chinese demand for gold still looks strong as well," Mr. Milling-Stanley said. China became the world's largest consumer of gold in 1992 as the country's economy surged. The Chinese are using new-found wealth to buy gold jewelry, a traditional hedge against inflation in the country.
Platinum for delivery in July rose $4.90, to 390.90 an ounce, on the Mercantile Exchange in New York. December palladium rose 25 cents, to $118.25 cents an ounce.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Confidence Is Waning

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's economic program isn't playing any better on Main Street than the President's $200 haircut, according to the latest consumer confidence poll.
Virtually all the post-election surge in optimism about the new Administration's ability to turn the economy around quickly has evaporated, the Conference Board survey for May showed. 
 Confidence in May plunged to the lowest level since October, the private research group said yesterday. And job worries are intensifying again despite few reports of major new layoffs and Labor Department data suggesting that job growth has picked up modestly in the last six months.
 
Index Drops to 61.5
 Only 13 percent of consumers think jobs will become more abundant six months from now, compared with 21.5 percent in January, the survey showed. The May percentage is the lowest reading in more than a year.
The Conference Board's overall consumer confidence index tumbled to 61.5 in May from 67.6 in April. The measure fell in every part of the country except the Southeast and more than reversed a 4-point gain last month.
"The consumer voted for change, no tax increases for the middle class, health-care reform," Allen I. Questrom, chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc., said in a recent interview. "What she sees now are all kinds of trial balloons: taxes not just for the wealthy, a B.T.U. tax, a V.A.T."
Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's consumer research center, said, "The economy is just not getting off the ground."
What was striking about the survey results -- which confirmed equally downbeat surveys by the University of Michigan and ABC/Money magazine -- was that expectations for the future have now turned as gloomy as they were before the election. The Conference Board's expectations index plunged from 81.1 in April to 72.2 in May, a drop of nearly a third since December.
 
Losing Faith on Growth
 By contrast, perceptions of current economic conditions remain decidedly more sanguine than they were seven or eight months ago. The current conditions index, at 45.4 in May, was down only marginally from 47.2 in April and is still half again as high as last October.
The contrast between feelings about the future and the here and now suggests that while consumers can detect signs of slow expansion, they have all but lost faith that the President can do much to speed up job growth, one of the main sources of consumers' anxiety.
"Pessimists substantially outnumber optimists on this issue," Mr. Linden said. "Consumer confidence continues at levels that are historically associated with a weak economy."
The sharp deterioration in consumers' mood during the first four months of the Clinton Administration compares with growing faith in Reaganomics during Ronald Reagan's first spring in office -- even taking into account the surge in public sympathy after Mr. Reagan was shot.
Unless something happens to turn pessimism into panic, economists said, the gloom does not seem likely to bring about an outright drop in consumer spending. Consumers' mood is not the only thing that affects buying. Income is growing modestly, low mortgage rates are reviving home buying and car sales strengthened in mid-May.
 
Retail Sales Rise
 A survey by Johnson Redbook, issued yesterday, showed retail sales in the first three weeks in May 7 percent higher than a year ago and 9 percent higher than the corresponding period in April. But Ed Johnson, who conducts the weekly survey of 25 or so national retail chains, said, "It's not as weak as it looks because Memorial Day fell a week earlier last year."
In another sign that spending may be holding up better than spirits, the National Association of Realtors reported yesterday that sales of existing homes rose a solid 2.7 percent in April, to an annual rate of 3.46 million. That was the first gain this year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Low Interest Rates Help U.S. Vehicle Sales

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 25

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose 18.4 percent in mid-May as consumers put aside fears of economic weakness and responded to low interest rates on financing, the auto makers said today.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 7.4 million for the period of May 11-20, up from 6.4 million in early May and up from 6.7 million for the same period a year earlier. 
 Sales of cars built in North American assembly plants reached 224,957, up 14.9 percent from a year earlier. Sales of light trucks, which include sport utilities, pickups and mini-vans, reached 170,641, up 23.4 percent. Total vehicle sales were 395,598, compared with 334,066 last year.
 
 
Two-Year Delay for Buyers
 "The recession delayed consumers' replacement plans by two years," said John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York. "So low interest rates are irresistibly attractive."
Sean Cardeau, who sells Toyotas, Chevrolets and Oldsmobiles in Baton Rouge, La., said, "People are buying because of the low 6.5 percent financing rates." He also said Chevrolets were outselling foreign models because many buyers felt they should buy American.
The General Motors Corporation sold 101,606 domestically built cars, up 7.7 percent from a year earlier. All G.M. sales divisions except Oldsmobile showed an increase compared with last year. G.M.'s light-truck sales rose 14.2 percent, to 59,140.
 
 
Light Trucks Outsell Cars
 The Ford Motor Company sold 57,306 cars, up 6 percent from a year earlier. Ford's light-truck sales rose 28.1 percent, to 58,579. It was only the third time that Ford had sold more light trucks than cars during a 10-day sales period, reflecting the growing popularity of light trucks.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that the Chrysler Corporation sold 25,900 cars, up 50.8 percent compared with last year. Ward's estimated light-truck sales of 42,100, up 22.8 percent. Chrysler reports sales only once a month.
The Honda Motor Company posted a 1.4 percent decline in sales of domestically built cars, to 12,554.
The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 14,109 cars, up 42.6 percent. Toyota's light-truck sales were 3,448, more than double the total from a year earlier.
The Nissan Motor Corporation sold 6,839 cars, more than double the total of a year earlier. Light-truck sales were 4,624, up 43.6 percent from last year.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Reporter at the Creation of the New Russia

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Lenin's Tomb
The Last Days of the Soviet Empire
By David Remnick
Illustrated. 576 pages. Random House. $25. 
 It is winter 1991 in the Soviet Union. The spirit of the Moscow Spring of 1988 is gone. Mikhail S. Gorbachev is still leading the country, but the generals, the military-industrial complex, the Communist Party apparatus and the K.G.B. are demanding that he turn away from his reform-minded advisers, and he does so. Something is in the air. In the land of revolution, the modern counterrevolution that introduced perestroika and glasnost is about to eat its own children.
During a session of the Congress of People's Deputies that winter, David Remnick, a correspondent for The Washington Post, encounters Gorbachev on a stairway and blurts out, "Mikhail Sergeyevich, they say you are moving to the right." Gorbachev, his mouth clenched in "a pained, ironic grin," tells the reporter that the truth is he feels "as if I am going around in circles."
In "Lenin's Tomb," Mr. Remnick, now a staff writer for The New Yorker, has a great story to tell and he tells it brilliantly. During the four crucial years of counterrevolution, attempted coup and transition that led to the ascendancy of Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Remnick was present at the creation of the new Russia. The title of his book is metaphorical; it doesn't really cover the dictatorial reigns of Lenin and Stalin. Rather, it's about the disenchantment of many Russians with the theories and practices underlying Soviet Communism. Actually the subtitle, "The Last Days of the Soviet Empire," tells more about the book's contents.
The "riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma," as Winston Churchill described Russia in 1939, continues to be puzzling in 1993. But Mr. Remnick's book goes a long way toward answering the tantalizing question of why Americans and Europeans were once so enamored of Mr. Gorbachev and then, suddenly and surprisingly, discovered that he wasn't a man for all seasons in an unshackled Soviet Union. Mr. Remnick describes the Soviet breakup through the eyes of dissidents as well as of Stalinist stalwarts, and then supplies his own interpretations.
In a few straightforward lines that sum up the theme of "Lenin's Tomb," Mr. Remnick writes: "Once the regime eased up enough to permit a full-scale examination of the Soviet past, radical change was inevitable. Once the System showed itself for what it was and had been, it was doomed."
During the near-fictional high noon in the summer of 1991 for the two leading personalities in the book, Mr. Gorbachev was first restored by his rival, Mr. Yeltsin, and then discarded into the dustbin of history. How could this happen to the highly intelligent yet implacable leader of the counterrevolution? The answer that appears to emerge from Mr. Remnick's well-sourced book is that Mr. Gorbachev wanted to recreate Communism with a human face, a contradiction in terms that, given the record of seven decades of rigid state planning, could not work.
"In its way, Gorbachev's schematic view of the Soviet past was as ideologically driven -- though not nearly as pernicious -- as the old party version," Mr. Remnick explains. "To legitimize his plans for a liberalized socialism, Gorbachev and his generation in the party intelligentsia even created a new set of icons. They emphasized the 'late Lenin' of the less draconian New Economic Policy of the early 1920's; Khrushchev, as the initiator of the anti-Stalinist thaw; Yuri Andropov, as a general secretary of the party and technocratic reformer who 'died too soon'; and, perhaps most of all, Nikolai Bukharin, the relatively flexible Bolshevik ideologist who was executed by Stalin in the purges."
By contrast, Mr. Yeltsin had a better sense of what was really going on in the country. He and others detected that an attempted military coup was possible by anti-reformist elements; Mr. Gorbachev wouldn't believe it. Mr. Remnick is clearly a Yeltsin admirer. He writes, "Despite the Kremlin's best efforts, the history of Soviet politics will show it was Yeltsin -- vain, comic, clever, crude -- who accelerated the essential step in political reform: the shattering of the Communist Party monolith."
The high point of "Lenin's Tomb" is the attempted coup against Mr. Gorbachev, and Mr. Remnick delivers the details excitingly, including Mr. Yeltsin's courageous take-charge role in the face of the tanks and cannons.
There are a few minor shortcomings of style and substance. Mr. Remnick brings himself into the book a little too often, breaking the stride of his narrative and forgetting that he's an observer, not a participant in these momentous events. And though he touches upon it, he might well have placed more importance on the lingering significance of the tens of millions of casualties suffered by the Russians during the Great Patriotic War, as they call World War II, and the continuing effects of the cold war on the people and Government. These subjects have found an influential place in the works of Russian poets and novelists; some in fact are mentioned by the author.
In addition to talks with the major personalities in the Politburo, the most original contributions in "Lenin's Tomb" are the author's interviews with historical figures or their widows and children, both famous and little known, who somehow survived the Stalinist purges. For example, Mr. Remnick describes a visit with Yakov Rapoport, now 91 and the only survivor of the 1953 "doctors' plot." In that time of anti-Semitic paranoia at its worst, Stalin ordered the K.G.B. to kill prominent doctors, most of them Jews, who were accused of poisoning Kremlin leaders. Dr. Rapoport was let out of prison only after Stalin died later that year.
There are, literally, hundreds of such interviews with legislators, historians, militarists, nationalists, journalists and party apparatchiks. When future histories of these explosive years are written, Mr. Remnick's invaluable firsthand reports will have to be taken into account. They make "Lenin's Tomb" an engrossing and essential addition to the human and political literature of our time.

HEADLINE: Myopia at the White House;
Scrambled Ethics

 BODY:
After a week of one political blunder after another, a light bulb finally went on somewhere in the White House, and the Democratic National Committee canceled the White House fund-raising breakfast with President Clinton it was planning for lobbyists and other fat-cat contributors.
But the rest of the tawdry affair will proceed next month as planned. What possessed the party chairman, David Wilhelm, to schedule the event in the first place? And who in the White House approved a breakfast session so obviously destined to leave the populist-posing President with more egg on his face than on his plate? 
 The breakfast was just part of the package of privileges the D.N.C. began offering last week in an invitation faxed or mailed to lobbyists, big corporate donors and other Democratic high-rollers. So while participants will have to go elsewhere for their eggs and bacon, the $15,000-a-couple ticket will still buy a weekend of special briefings by senior Administration officials capped by a gala called "The President's Dinner."
Among possible "honored guests" and speakers when the "retreat" kicks off on June 27: Thomas McLarty, the White House chief of staff; Robert Rubin, head of the National Economic Council; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers; Leon Panetta, White House budget director; Mickey Kantor, U.S. Trade Representative, and Ira Magaziner, the manager of the President's Task Force on Health Care Reform.
The invitation may be more subtle than the hard sell used by the Republicans three years ago for its "Inner Circle" program. Gone, for example, is the G.O.P.'s tacky checklist where contributors could choose the cabinet officer with whom they'd most like to rub elbows at dinner. But the Democrats' program is basically the same. Much as a spokesman for the D.N.C. denies it, the party is selling special access to the President and the Administration. Indeed, as Gwen Ifill reports in The Times today, the June festivities are the tip of a soiled iceberg. Now that it's in power, the party has been expanding its donor base and pampering old givers by offering them private access to top officials. So much for setting a higher moral tone.
The timing of this episode couldn't be worse. It can only undermine Mr. Clinton's moral authority just as his campaign finance reform package is before the Senate. It's a strong measure that would close some of the loopholes that now allow corporations and other groups to easily evade Federal contribution limits to maximize their political clout.
Opponents are trying to kill real reform by removing the public financing essential to reducing the influence of special interests and give challengers a chance. But the Administration's courting program for big donors suggests the bill needs to be made even stronger: by barring parties from soliciting money based on access to high officials.

HEADLINE: Will a Lower Tax Break Be Bad for the Appetite?

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 23

 BODY:
For the thousands of restaurant owners, food and equipment suppliers and others involved in food service who gathered here for the annual trade show sponsored by the National Restaurant Association, new equipment and products were not the hot topics.
"All everybody's talking about is the tax issue, the deductibility," said Ralph Brennan, the owner of Mr. B's Bistro in New Orleans, as he left his hotel to go to the show at the McCormick Place Convention Center. 
 And to prove it, the association hopes that by the time the huge four-day show closes on Wednesday, many of the 100,000 expected attendees will have signed a giant card to be sent to President Clinton. It asserts that portions of his tax plan would damage the industry.
Heading the list is the Administration's proposal to reduce the deduction for business meals from 80 percent to 50 percent. "Deductibility is our biggest fight," said Stephen Elmont, the new president of the association. "We estimate that it will cost 165,000 jobs and represent $4 billion in lost sales."
Unlike the proposed energy tax, though, this tax change has not yet generated much opposition or debate. "It's not an issue the politicians or the body politic is getting excited about," Mr. Elmont said. "It's perceived as an issue of fairness, of fat cats eating expensive lunches."
Mr. Elmont said research done for the restaurant association in 1989 showed that 25 million Americans purchased business meals that year, at an average cost of $9.56 a meal, and that 70 percent of the meals were bought by people with incomes of less than $50,000. "Often, the only way a salesman on the road can meet with a prospective account and build a relationship is over lunch in a restaurant," he said.
Stephen Odell, the president of Sugar Foods, makers of Sweet'n Low and other products, said, "People think it's about going to Le Cirque, but in reality, Main Street, America, does business by taking someone to lunch at Sizzler." The proposal to reduce the deduction is part of the overall Clinton tax package, which may be voted on by the House on Thursday and which is now being considered by the Senate Finance Committee. Lorraine Voles, deputy press secretary at the White House, said the proposal was seen by the Administration as a "pretty benign way to collect much-needed funds." Businesses would still get a deduction, she added.
The Clinton Administration estimates that the change in the deduction will raise $16 billion. Restaurant owners, though, argue that the figure is misleadingly high because it assumes that business people will continue to spend money in restaurants at the current rate.
Until 1986, 100 percent of business meals could be deducted from Federal income taxes. When the proposal was made to reduce it to 80 percent, there were also warnings of harm to the industry. Asked about the potential loss of jobs, Ms. Voles said, "You heard the same argument when it went from 100 percent to 80 percent, but it didn't happen."
Growth in the restaurant industry has slowed since 1986, but the reasons aren't clear. Mr. Elmont said overall industry sales grew 16 percent between 1980 and 1986, but only 4 percent in the six years since the tax change was made. "We created 700,000 fewer jobs in the last six years than in the prior six years, but it's hard to say whether it was due to the recession or the decrease in deductibility."
The deductibility provision does not appear to be something members of the House and Senate are ready to fight. "I know it's important for New York, and a lot of jobs in my constituency depend on it," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, a member of the House Ways and Means Committee, which has already approved the President's tax package. "But it's awkward to give privileges to businessmen, to approve a giveaway for rich people at the taxpayer's expense, even though they spend money in restaurants and jobs depend on it."
Frank Richter, the general manager of the American Express Company for the Southern region, said the change would lead to job losses. "I've spoken to restaurateurs in my region who said they would have to close for lunch," he said.
Mr. Rangel said he understood that those who were most likely to be laid off were busboys and dishwashers -- many of them from minority groups -- and others who might not find other jobs. But, he added, the public does not see it that way.
Larry Jenkins, the food service product manager for Integrated Ingredients, a company that sells spices, yeast and other products to restaurants, said his business has not been the same since 1986, when the deduction was reduced.
Participants in the restaurant association show pointed out that other business expenses would still be fully deductible. "Why should the cost of advertising be 100 percent deductible as a business expense?" Mr. Elmont said. "Is the cost of a little clock a company sent me to convince me that cigarettes are O.K. more legitimate than the price of a business meal?"
Others mentioned loss of sales taxes to states, counties and cities if fewer people dined out. "I paid $880,000 in sales tax last year alone," said Jeremiah Tower, the owner of Stars, in San Francisco, who was here for the restaurant show. "Who is going to make up the difference? The last cut was a disaster. There was a noticeable drop in lunch business."
Some of those at the show complained that the National Restaurant Association had not been effective enough in presenting the issue to the public as a question of jobs, rather than as a matter of writing off fancy meals. But Mr. Elmont said: "We are encouraging people in the industry to talk to their representatives. We are going to unleash the nine million people in our industry."

HEADLINE: CRUCIAL BARGAINING BEGINS AS THAWING ON BUDGET IS SEEN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
With a critical House vote on President Clinton's budget imminent and perilously uncertain, the White House and conservative Democrats in Congress abruptly halted their sniping over the proposal's merits today and began talking up a deal.
By late today, it remained just talk. But for the first time, both sides seemed to agree that the proposal would be changed. The House wants to make at least a cursory effort to keep health-care spending from running up the deficit, and the Senate hopes to tone down at least part of a heavily debated energy tax. 
 Mr. Clinton's critics in both houses of Congress have demanded such changes as the price for supporting the President's five-year package of about $250 billion in new taxes and $250 billion in spending cuts, a package that some fear could cost them their seats.
 
Appeal to Public Urged
 Several leading Democrats urged Mr. Clinton to take to network television to raise public support for his proposals. There was some suggestion that the President would do that on Wednesday, the day before the scheduled vote in the House.
"I told him that I thought it was extremely important that he articulate this case more clearly to the American people -- that members of Congress will vote based upon what we're hearing from home," Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat of Kansas, said after meeting with Mr. Clinton this morning. "I got the clear impression that the White House would take that advice very seriously."
Today's bargaining was clearly driven by fears that the Democratic Party was about to self-destruct, rejecting the first budget of its first President in 16 years.
 
White House Strategy Session
 After weeks of mild attempts to rouse passions for his program, so much so that committee chairmen in the House openly complained about the soft sell, Mr. Clinton warmed to the task today. He hauled scores of wavering Democrats to the White House to pat them on the back, and summoned House leaders for a strategy session.
The campaign in the House was more frenetic than the one in the Senate, but only because it is more urgent. The House Democratic whips, whose job it is to corral support for the White House, were telling their leaders today that they were still 5 to 10 votes short of the 217 votes needed to push the budget through. Only last week House leaders had expressed confidence that the budget would pass easily.
Most lawmakers expect all 176 Republicans to oppose Mr. Clinton's plan when the House votes on it. A shift of only 41 of the 256 Democrats and one independent would doom the package to defeat, and at least 45 Democrats were still listed as being against the proposal.
The President faces a terrible whipsaw in the House. Moderate and conservative Democrats from suburban and rural areas, egged on by voters, are telling him that he needs to cut spending further. Oil-state representatives, a small but critical bloc, want him to scrap the energy tax, whose $71 billion in revenue is roughly a quarter of the White House's entire tax program.
But urban Democrats, a big, liberal and influential constituency, are adamantly opposed to further cuts or caps on spending that would hurt their largely poor districts.
 
Foley Speaks of Confidence
 Nonetheless, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he was confident that the bill would pass. "There are a lot of efforts to divert attention here," the Washington Democrat said. "They do not want to see this economic program go forward, many people, because it is a program in the interests of the American people."
Leaders in all the Democratic camps were markedly more hopeful today than on Monday that a deal to end the squabble could be worked out. Their hopes rested on a compromise plan that purports to accomplish the impossible: to allow spending on health care and other mandatory programs to grow as needed but still force Congress and the White House to keep that growth from inflating the Federal deficit.
The author of the plan is Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, a quiet but influential Democrat on budget issues. The compromise plan is devilishly complex, but essentially, whenever spending on mandatory programs like Medicare and food stamps exceeds the levels spelled out in Mr. Clinton's five-year budget plan, it would require the Government to consider cutting spending in succeeding years.
But the President and Congress would have several options. They could make up the excess, immediately or over several years, by reducing spending anywhere in the budget. They could make up part of the excess through a prearranged tax surcharge. Or the President could recommend that he and Congress simply ignore the excess spending, as has been done in the past.
In the last-named case, Congress would have to approve the President's recommendation. In each case the effect would be that Congress and the White House would have to address the rising cost of mandatory programs in public and in detail, something Mr. Spratt said had been lacking in recent years.
Representative Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota, an influential conservative Democrat, said today that he and his allies were negotiating the "fine print" of the compromise plan, and that he hoped it would defuse the standoff over Mr. Clinton's budget.
 
Positive Signs From Clinton
 As for Mr. Clinton and his allies, Mr. Spratt said tonight, "The House leadership is headed in this direction, and the White House seems to be at least looking at it."
Mr. Glickman said the President "seemed to be somewhat positively inclined to some form of entitlement control," but did not sign off on the proposal in his meeting with lawmakers today.
Oddly for everyone but politicians, the telling House vote will come not on Mr. Clinton's budget itself, but on the agenda for debating and voting on the measure, which the House Rules Committee will draft on Wednesday and the full House will consider on Thursday.
That rule, as the agenda is called, is expected to sharply limit debate and outlaw unfriendly amendments. Republicans and dissident Democrats want to throw the bill open to changes, but their only hope lies in defeating the rule -- and that is where the vote appears closest.
After the House comes the Senate, where Democratic unhappiness with the Clinton budget is even deeper and conservatives seem determined to unravel the compromise that the House was bolting together today. But even there, things seemed to be looking up for the White House.
In the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Clinton has seemed until now to have no more than 9 of the 11 votes he needs to get the tax, and his budget, to the Senate floor. Two swing-vote Democrats, Senators David L. Boren of Oklahoma and John B. Breaux of Louisiana, have publicly committed themselves to abolishing the energy tax, and Mr. Boren has threatened to tie the entire budget up in the Finance Committee unless the tax is largely replaced with more spending cuts.
But Mr. Breaux appeared to shy away from the fight today, putting off indefinitely his plan to unveil a gasoline tax as a replacement for Mr. Clinton's energy levy. For his part, Mr. Boren met for an hour today with the Finance Committee chairman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, and had nothing to say afterward.
A Clinton ally on the committee, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, was unusually cheery about the budget's committee prospects today, predicting flatly that Mr. Boren and Mr. Breaux would see the light and support Mr. Clinton's energy tax, with a few changes here and there. He also predicted that the Finance Committee would mollify Mr. Boren by making "real reductions" in the same mandatory spending programs that the House is seeking to preserve.
Asked about that, Mr. Moynihan replied, "Senator Baucus is right on both counts." Asked how reductions would be achieved, he said "you change the formulas" by which benefits are calculated.
"What we're talking about is Medicare and Medicaid," he said, but he declined to say how much money was at stake.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, another Democrat who supports further spending cuts in the Clinton budget, said he saw the elements of a White House legislative strategy beginning to emerge at long last: preserving mandatory programs in the House, cutting them deeply in the Senate, and splitting the difference when the final budget package goes to a House-Senate conference this summer.

HEADLINE: Charitable Giving Rose to $124 Billion in 1992

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Despite the sluggish economy, individuals, corporations and foundations contributed $124.3 billion to philanthropy in 1992, a 6.4 percent increase over the previous year.
Still, the showing was disappointing considering that the number of millionaires increased fourteenfold and the baby boom generation moved into the 35-to-64 age category, the prime age for charitable giving. The total giving for 1991 was $116.8 billion. 
 "Charitable giving is doing well, considering the economic climate, but lacks explosive growth," said Martin Grenzebach, chairman of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's Trust for Philanthropy, in announcing the findings yesterday of Giving U.S.A., a yearbook on philanthropy that is widely regarded as the most comprehensive survey in the field.
As usual, the largest sum came from individual donors; living donors contributed $101 billion, and bequests accounted for $8.1 billion.
 
Corporate Donations Fall
 Foundations, gaining from profitable investments in stocks, increased their contributions to nonprofit organizations in the arts, education and human service fields to $8.3 billion but giving by corporations continued to stagnate, hovering around $6 billion.
Giving to religion, always the largest recipient, amounted to $56.7 billion, or 45.6 percent of all giving. Education received $14 billion, slightly less than 1991. Giving to health totaled $10.2 billion and to human services, $11.5 billion. Giving to arts, culture and the humanities amounted to $9.3 billion. Groups involved in community development, civil rights and other public activities received $5 billion. Giving to environmental organizations rose to $3.1 billion, but giving to international affairs causes dropped to $1.7 billion, a decline of $40 million.
When adjusted for inflation, total giving represented a growth of 2.3 percent.
Giving to United Way organizations was clearly reduced after United Way of America's former president, William Aramony, was accused of mismanagement and excessive use of the organization's income. But the furor did not lead to a decline in giving to other nonprofit organizations, Giving U.S.A. reported.
United Way's own research, polling a random sampling of more than a thousand donors, showed the economy's decline was the major reason for the drop, and the Aramony controversy was the second. With less than one-half of United Way campaigns complete, results showed a 3.7 percent decline in giving.

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND ALLIES TWIST ARMS IN BID FOR BUDGET VOTES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 27

 BODY:
On the eve of the most crucial Congressional vote of his Presidency so far, President Clinton, members of his Cabinet and loyalists in Congress spent Wednesday twisting the arms of dozens of Democratic lawmakers who were still not committed to voting for his budget.
By nightfall, vote-counters said they still did not have enough pledges of support to forge a majority in the House of Representatives, but they expressed optimism that a majority would be in hand by the time the vote was taken on this afternoon. 
 "On tough votes like this, the votes are rarely there till the zero hour," said a staff assistant who has had years of experience following close votes in the House.
 
Subject to Persuasion
 Mr. Clinton met Wednesday morning with members of the Congressional Black Caucus and spent the rest of the day calling particular representatives who House leaders had told him might be subject to persuasion. At a morning photo session, the President said he expected to win.
Mr. Clinton rejected the suggestion of some lawmakers that he give a televised nationwide address promoting his program. But the White House said the President would appear today for two hours on the "CBS This Morning" program, which starts at 7 A.M. Eastern time.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen had lunch with the Texas delegation and managed to swing at least two important votes. Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, met Wednesday morning with a group of freshmen and then called other representatives.
In the Capitol about 30 Democratic whips, whose job it is to keep track of how their colleagues plan to vote, met every couple of hours to review where things stood.
 
Uphill Battle in Senate
 If the House passes the bill it will still face an uphill battle next month in the Senate, where party discipline is weaker.
The bill, the heart of the President's program to reduce the budget deficit, would raise taxes by about $250 billion and cut spending on benefit programs by about $100 billion over five years. Another $150 billion in spending reductions would come later, during the appropriations process, according to the President's plan, and would largely involve lower spending for the military and smaller interest payments as the deficit falls.
So far, Mr. Clinton has made some concessions, and the House Ways and Means Committee has made some changes. But the bill before the House contains the core of the President's proposals: much higher taxes on the wealthy, slightly higher taxes for corporations, a new tax on fuel and a tax cut for the working poor.
More than 70 percent of the tax increase would fall on families earning more than $100,000 a year, and more than 60 percent would come from those making more than $200,000.
With all the tax provisions in effect, families with incomes above $200,000 would owe an average of $1,935 a month more in taxes, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Those with incomes from $40,000 to $50,000 would owe only $23 a month more than now, and those with smaller incomes would have even less of a tax increase.
The Democrats uncommitted to the President's program generally objected aloud to the new tax on energy or complained that Mr. Clinton had offered too few spending cuts. But those were often smokescreens.
The real reason for much of the opposition, said a Democratic leader who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, was that many freshmen and others who feared they might lose their seats in the House were worried about voting for any tax increase, knowing it would make them vulnerable in re-election races.
The Democratic leadership in the House predicted victory. "When we have the vote tomorrow, we will have the votes," Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington said after a Democratic caucus meeting on Wednesday. But by the day's end the leaders were still at least 20 votes shy of a majority.
One of the most vocal opponents to Mr. Clinton's budget outside Washington, Ross Perot, has scheduled several television appearances today and Friday. According to his office, he is to appear on the NBC program "Today" on this morning and on the ABC News program "Nightline" tonight. On Friday, he is to appear on four programs: "CBS This Morning," "Donahue," which is syndicated, "Talking With David Frost" on PBS and again on "Nightline."
Republicans had a rally Wednesday on the east lawn of the Capitol to make their opposition to higher taxes photogenic. But the excitement was entirely among the Democrats. And the issue by this point was no longer the substance of the measure, but party loyalty and loyalty to the President.
One of the main Democratic opponents, Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, said, "My gut is that they should pull the bill before it's too late."
Mr. McCurdy was an early Clinton supporter in the Presidential campaign. But he has seemed to have his nose out of joint since the President turned him down for a Cabinet seat and Mr. Foley removed him from his chairmanship of the House Select Committee on Intelligence.
 
Crucial Vote on the Rule
 The crucial vote will come not on the bill itself, but on a procedural resolution called the rule, which sets the terms for the debate and determines which amendments will be in order.
Republicans asked to be permitted to offer a variety of amendments, but they had no hope of being allowed to.
Talks continued throughout the day on proposals that would force the President and Congress to face the facts and respond if the deficit turned out to be higher in the years ahead than the Administration was now projecting.
Early today, a small band of lawmakers led by Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, reached an agreement with the the White House and the House leadership on a mechanism to curb spending through ceilings on benefit programs like Medicare and food stamps. "This is a major, significant change regarding the budget process," Mr. Stenholm was quoted by The Associated Press as saying.
On the other end of the seesaw from Mr. Stenholm was the Congressional Black Caucus, whose members adamantly opposed a spending ceiling.
Under a possible compromise had the support of the White House, if the deficit rose higher than expected because of increased spending or a decline in revenue, the President would have to propose action, and Congress would have to vote on it.
On Wednesday morning, according to one nose count, only 6 of the 21 Democratic representatives from Texas were committed to backing the President.
At his meeting with the Texas delegation, Secretary Bentsen, a former representative and senator from Texas, managed to swing at least two more important representatives into the President's camp: Jack Brooks, the senior member of the delegation and the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and E. (Kika) de la Garza, chairman of the Agriculture Committee.
 
Warning of Economic Damage
 Mr. Bentsen reportedly said that the Administration would not be averse to making modifications in its proposed fuel tax when the measure reaches the Senate. He also argued, his spokesman said, that if the Clinton measure failed, interest rates would skyrocket and the economy would be seriously damaged.
The nerve center of the vote counting was the first-floor office of Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the chief Democratic whip. His lieutenants met there every couple of hours to compare notes.
One of Mr. Bonior's assistants, Representative Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, said recalcitrant Democrats were divided into four groups: leaning for, on the fence, leaning against and definitely against.
At each meeting, the names were called out one by one. The whip who had been assigned the representative whose name was called gave a progress report, and then others would often volunteer to try their hand at persuasion.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Best Friends Find It a Tough Role

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Harry Thomason says he and his wife are "fighting for the right to live in this country."
Linda Bloodworth-Thomason says she now empathizes with Bebe Rebozo, Bert Lance, Alfred Bloomingdale and others who have had bad experiences "being the President's best friend." 
 The same Hollywood team that packaged Bill Clinton as "The Man From Hope," the glossy biographical film that kicked off the campaign at the Democratic National Convention last summer, is now fighting back against accusations that they have smudged their longtime friend's populist image.
 
Calls to White House
 Even though some Clinton advisers are cringing, the creators of the sitcoms "Designing Women," "Evening Shade," and "Hearts Afire" are camped out at the Capital Hilton, defending themselves against criticism that they led the President astray by sending him to an expensive hairdresser named Cristophe of Beverly Hills.
There were also Mr. Thomason's calls to the White House on behalf of friends in the air-charter industry who felt they were getting shut out of bidding for White House travel business.
It has been a wild, wacky, stumbling, heart-wrenching week at the White House, where Mr. Thomason has a pass that allows him to roam freely and where he can be reached at an office in the East Wing by calling the White House switchboard.
Perhaps it is the inevitable coda of a year in which politics became suffused with a confessional talk-show sensibility and Hollywood production values that Washington would come to resemble a situation comedy that might be called "Designing Presidents."
Although some White House officials and Clinton strategists argued that talk-show appearances by the Thomasons this week could hurt the President by keeping a damaging story alive and preventing the White House from picking up the pieces of its message on the economy, the Thomasons decided to fight back Hollywood-style, guns and folksiness blazing.
"We don't think we are important people in Washington," Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason said, "but when someone says something scurrilous about us, we can stand on our lawn for a couple of days and say, 'No, we didn't do that.' "
Mr. Thomason agreed: "This is certainly not a publicity blitz. It's a right-to-live-in-this-country blitz."
Supporters of the Thomasons say the two are also furious at being tarred with the criticism that they are the Pied Pipers who have led the President and First Lady into being too cozy with Hollywood. Rather, friends of the Hollywood couple say the Thomasons have been warning the Clintons for the last eight months not to get too close to Hollywood.
Asked about his friend while jogging this morning, Mr. Clinton said: "He has no official role. He's just our friend."
Republicans, however, jumped in with extravagant praise for the Thomasons. As William Kristol, Republican analyst and former chief of staff to Dan Quayle, put it: "I encourage President Clinton to depend on them even more."
 
Criticism From Perot
 Mr. Clinton continues to be unconcerned with the appearance that he is too cozy with Hollywood, but Ross Perot was ready to put his spin on the situation in an interview on Tuesday with David Frost that will be shown Friday on the Public Broadcasting Service. "When you've got a different movie star in the White House every night," Mr. Perot said, "and you've got somebody up there from Hollywood pleading the case for the Dali Lama, the average hard working American in work clothes can't relate to that. He'd like for you to get back to business."
Indeed, just before he got his trim from Cristophe on Tuesday of last week, an incident that blew up when it was learned that planes had to circle the runway while the Beverly Hills hairmeister snipped, the President also had a "meet and greet" at the Los Angeles airport with some supporters from Hollywood and Los Angeles financial and political circles.
Quincy Jones, the music producer, and Dawn Steel, the movie producer, both got tours of Air Force One, and Cristophe said some important Democrats came in while he was clipping.
At a recent star-studded Democratic National Committee fund-raising event in New York, Mr. Clinton raised eyebrows when he ended up sitting next to Sharon Stone, who plays in steamy movies. When a seat next to the President ended up empty for the main course, a committee staff member ushered Ms. Stone, who was seated several tables away, to the Mr. Clinton's side.
Even some Hollywood big shots wondered about the political finesse of such a move. "The President looks like a groupie," one top producer said. "He shouldn't always see us when we want to see him."
But Barbra Streisand rejected the notion that the halo of stars around Mr. Clinton has become a distraction, telling The Los Angeles Times in an interview published this week that celebrities have unfairly been painted as air heads.
 
C-Span Devotee
 "My favorite show is the C-Span," she said. "That's what I watch: C-Span 1 and C-Span 2. When I'm not watching CNN."
For her part, Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason would not discuss conversations she has had with the Clintons. But she did indicate that she and her husband are not part of the new Hollywood crowd clamoring for access. "We don't go to the Emmys, we don't go to the Academy Awards, we never eat at Spago," said Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason, an Arkansas native who named her show "Evening Shade" at Hillary Rodham Clinton's suggestion. "We're outsiders in Hollywood and we're beaten up as insiders."
The Thomasons even distanced themselves from their friends in the White House, emphasizing that they do not get their hair cut by Cristophe.
"Cristophe has never cut our hair," Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason told ABC firmly.
But the Thomasons may also have added to their friend's image problems when they acquired, for the use of the First Family, a Western retreat, a lavish beach-front estate outside Santa Barbara, Calif.
The Hollywood elite who discovered Bill Clinton late in the game and who now fall all over each other trying to get invitations to the Lincoln Bedroom agree that the Thomasons were not part of their set. The Thomasons have been overshadowed as the new crowd vies for the title of Best Hollywood Friend.
"No one ever heard of them until the Bill connection," one top Hollywood producer said. "They were non-mainstream."
The Thomasons, who deftly incorporated the same romantic notion of small-town America into Mr. Clinton's biographical film that they ply on their Arkansas-based show, "Evening Shade," freely concede they are casting themselves as Capra-like heroes under siege by a corrupt and evil capital.
But at the same time that they painted themselves as just a couple of normal folks from Arkansas and Missouri, they also pointed out that with their whopping salaries, they would have no need to seek business from the White House.
"Given our salaries, setting our sights on the White House travel office would be the financial equivalent of us taking over someone's lemonade stand," Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason said. "It's ludicrous."
In an appearance with her husband today on the ABC program "Good Morning America," she called Washington -- with its echo chamber of reporters and Republicans -- "an incestuous insane asylum." She told USA Today that if she and her husband get this treatment, "then Mother Teresa better stay out of town."
Mr. Thomason's argument, repeated in interview after interview over the last two days, is that he did not engage in cronyism in appealing to the President and other White House officials on the issue of the White House travel office. Rather, he says, he was a whistle-blower who was trying to help clean up what he saw as mismanagement and prodigal spending in the White House travel office.
Appearing on the Fox Morning news show today, Mr. Thomason showed more Capraesque flair when he pushed the notion that Cristophe represented the American dream, a man who came here penniless and ended up a hairdresser to the stars. He said he would not feel embarrassed if he had introduced him to Mr. Clinton, because Cristophe "understands what it's like to be an American. I mean, he came over from Belgium, and so it's important to get him to participate."
But he made it clear he had not introduced Cristophe to the President. Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason did the honors during the campaign, suggesting to both the President and First Lady that the man who snips the hair of Markie Post, the star of "Hearts Afire," might do for them, as well. (Although she did not recommend they get a personal services contract with him when they got to the White House.)
Finally, Mr. Thomason suggested that reporters should focus on more important issues. In a comparison that might not thrill the White House, he said: "It's not right when you ask 70 questions about the holocaust in Waco and you ask 123 about the travel office. What's going on here?"
