LENGTH: 1181 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Ways to Isolate Iran; Describes Leaders as Dangerous

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is preparing a broad new effort to weaken Iran by persuading reluctant allies to cut off loans, investment and arms sales to what American officials regard as a permanently hostile Government.
The plan, drafted as part of an intensive policy review, reflects a conclusion that Iran must be isolated if it is to be prevented from emerging as a substantial threat to Western interests. Thus, the plan rejects Reagan and Bush Administration policies that offered to reward Teheran for good behavior.
 
Abandoning a Balance
 Administration officials said the new approach aimed at denying Iran access to the money and weapons needed to complete a military resurgence. They said it was based on a decision that the United States and its allies should now treat Iran as harshly as it treats Iraq. 
 For much of the 1980's, the United States sought to play Iran and Iraq against one another. But with United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq since the end of the Persian Gulf war, the Administration has concluded that the wiser policy is "dual containment."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher hinted at the emerging shift earlier this year by denouncing Iran as an "international outlaw" and a "dangerous country" for its support of terrorism and its pursuit of nuclear weapons. But the new policy is far more sweeping than Mr. Christopher indicated when he said the United States would seek to block loans to Iran by international organizations.
Administration officials say the isolation of Iran should end only if Teheran halts its support for terrorism, curtails its military buildup, stops its subversion of other governments and ends its quest for nuclear weapons.
 
Catalogue of Accusations
 Among the antagonistic activities that United States officials attribute to Iran is active support for efforts by the Hamas and Party of God organizations to use violence to disrupt the Mideast peace talks. The officials say Iran has also helped establish terrorist training camps in Lebanon and the Sudan, and has assisted groups trying to overthrow the Governments of Egypt, Algeria and Tunisia.
The United States already subjects Iran to stiff sanctions that prohibit military and most commercial ties. Administration officials said their new policy could succeed only if other countries change course.
Among the top priorities, Administration officials said, are efforts to convince Russia and China to cancel deals to provide Iran with weapons and nuclear reactors, and to persuade Japan, Germany and Britain to cut off loans.
None of those countries have shown any willingness to sever such lucrative ties, and Japan in particular has argued that commercial links can encourage moderate elements inside Iran. But while the United States once harbored similar hopes, Administration officials now regard all factions in the current leadership as bound to remain hostile toward the West.
While many deals between United States companies and Iran are already prohibited, the new policy would almost certainly lead the Administration to reject a request by the Boeing Company to sell 20 Boeing 737 jetliners to Iran, a deal worth more than $750 million, officials say.
The broad outlines of the new approach were described in a speech last week by Martin S. Indyk, the senior director for Middle East policy for the National Security Council, to the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, a research group.
Mr. Indyk said bluntly, "If we fail in our efforts to modify Iranian behavior, five years from now Iran will be much more capable of posing a real threat to Israel and to Western interests in the Middle East."
The Iran review was one of several dozen studies requested by President Clinton shortly after he took office.
But the atmosphere surrounding it has been intensified by suspicions that Iran might have had a role in the World Trade Center bombing, Government officials say. Investigators have found that tens of thousands of dollars were wired from Iran to bank accounts held by suspects in the bombing.
 
No Help Likely for Rebels
 Final details of the plan await White House approval, officials say. But while Mr. Clinton made overtures to the main Iranian opposition group before he took office, his advisers said there was no chance that the new policy would involve closer ties with the group, the People's Mujahedeen.
The Administration has concluded that the Mujahedeen's ties to Iraq and its terrorist attacks against Americans in the 1970's makes it an unacceptable partner.
The officials also expressed little optimism that the organized resistance or other domestic unrest could force a significant change in the Iranian Government. They said they expected President Hashemi Rafsanjani to win re-election to a second four-year term in elections on June 11.
 
The Political Issues
 Administration officials also said the United States had rejected seeking an embargo on sales of Iranian oil. The rebels have called for such a ban, but the policy review concluded that it could not be enforced without imposing a military blockade, a step Mr. Clinton's advisers are unwilling to take.
In outlining the effort to isolate Iran, officials acknowledged that the task would be more difficult than the containment of Iraq, which carries the weight of United Nations sanctions.
In March, an initial United States attempt to isolate Teheran failed when the World Bank overrode Washington's objections and approved a $165 million loan to upgrade Iran's electrical power system. But officials who outlined the new policy said the United States intended to mount an aggressive effort to persuade other countries of the dangers Iran poses.
Administration officials have begun to argue that Iran, which has borrowed $25 billion in the last four years, is not a good investment. Teheran has already fallen $5 billion behind on its payments, and the Administration intends to warn countries that go ahead with sales of weapons and nuclear goods that they run the risk of not being paid.
Because of high inflation and unemployment, a senior Administration official said, Iran was "more vulnerable than it has been in the past or is likely to be in the future." But he repeated Mr. Indyk's warning that "this moment will not last long."
 
The Military Issues
 The Central Intelligence Agency has warned that Iran may acquire a nuclear weapon by the end of the decade. Its deals with Russia and China for nuclear reactors are regarded with uneasiness by some American analysts, who say the plants may be being used as a cover to acquire sensitive technology.
A simultaneous Iranian buildup of conventional forces has prompted similar concern. Officials at the Defense Intelligence Agency have said Teheran's $2 billion military spending spree may be merely an effort to rebuild forces depleted during its eight-year war with Iraq. But purchases of Russian submarines and a bid to buy top-of-the-line tanks have persuaded other officials that Iran seeks to become the dominant power in the Mideast.

HEADLINE: 3 Florio Foes Hold 2d G.O.P. Debate

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLMDEL, N.J. May 26

 BODY:
In the last statewide forum before New Jersey's primary election in two weeks, the three major candidates for the Republican gubernatorial nomination met in a televised debate tonight, jousting over policy, campaign bickering and who is best qualified to defeat Gov. Jim Florio in November.
The tone of the town-hall style debate -- members of the audience put questions to the candidates, Christine Todd Whitman, Cary Edwards and James L. Wallwork -- was a marked departure from the previous rancor-filled meetings involving the three Republicans. 
 Business people made up a majority of the audience, and that was reflected in a string of questions on automobile insurance reform, managed health care, unemployment, pollution legislation and sports betting.
Mr. Edwards, Mr. Wallwork and Mrs. Whitman tended to agree on many issues. On the question of restructuring the automobile insurance system, for example, each candidate favored changing the laws to reduce the number of lawsuits from vehicle accidents, offering more insurance options to reduce rates for some drivers, and easing regulations to encourage more companies to write automobile insurance in New Jersey.
The candidates still found the opportunity to lash out at one another.
A question about New Jersey's bleak unemployment rate, from a young woman who said she had recently lost her job, set up the most heated exchange of the evening.
Mrs. Whitman was giving her response to the question when Mr. Edwards cut her off.
"Christie, you don't understand, the girl doesn't have a job today," Mr. Edwards said.
"Can you offer her one?" Mrs. Whitman said.
"At least I have had a job in my life," replied Mr. Edwards, who has tried to paint Mrs. Whitman as a wealthy elitist who would be out of touch with the people as Governor.
 
'You Owe an Apology'
 Mrs. Whitman said in response, "I would ask for an apology for that, Cary, but I think that you owe an apology to every woman for saying last weekend that you resent having to run against a woman."
Mr. Edwards said he owed no apology to Mrs. Whitman. After the debate Mr. Edwards accused Ms. Whitman of "setting him up" over the issue, saying that she had misrepresented his comments from a weekend debate that involved only him and Mr. Wallwork.
As in a televised debate two weeks ago, the clash ended when Mr. Wallwork intervened, telling his rivals to calm down.
The debate was co-sponsored by chapters of the New Jersey Association of Women Business Owners and by New Jersey Network, the state-owned broadcasting system. It was broadcast live over the network's four televison channels and New Jersey cable systems, and over N.J.N. Radio, which serves central and southern New Jersey.
 
Most Important Face-Off
 The sponsors said 500 people paid $10 apiece to be part of the live audience at the Gov. Robert B. Meyner Reception Center on the grounds of the Garden State Arts Center. The questioners were selected in advance, based on questions they submitted along with their requests for tickets.
Michael Aron, a senior political correspondent for New Jersey Network, moderated the 90-minute debate.
Over the last four months, Mrs. Whitman, Mr. Edwards and Mr. Wallwork have engaged in at least half a dozen debates, but none more important than tonight's face-off.
It was the last of two mandatory debates for candidates who have qualified for public campaign financing in the primary -- the first was held on May 11 in Whippany -- but more important, it was the last chance for voters to make a side-by-side comparison of the three candidates before primary day, June 8.
 
Crowd Seems Uncommitted
 Each candidate had a contingent of supporters in the audience, but except for a consensus in favor of lower taxes, a majority of the crowd appeared to be uncommitted.
Sidney Israel, a Rumson, N.J., engineeer who attended the debate with his wife, Rhoda, said: "What we got from the Florio administration was a tremendous loss of jobs out of state and a huge increase in the cost of living. If I had a question for the candidates, it would be about improving the economy enough to level these things out."
Rhoda Israel was more pointed. "My concern is about programs to give tax money to private schools," she said. "I don't think we should cross that line." Mrs. Whitman, the leading Republican candidate, repeated her support for for tax-financed school vouchers payable to private schools, although with a test program first. Mr. Wallwork, a former state senator, said the voucher quesiton should be settled in a public referendum, while Mr. Edwards, a former state attorney general, held to his oppostion to voucher programs.
According to the State Election Law Enforcement Commission, Mr. Florio, Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Edwards each have qualified for the maximum $1.6 million in matching funds. Mr. Wallwork has qualified for $800,000 in matching funds, according to his campaign.
 
Media Push Beginning
 Mr. Florio is running unopposed in the primary and has not participated in any primary debates.
The televised N.J.N. debates and very expensive broadcast advertisements on television and radio stations in New Jersey, New York City and Philadelphia are important parts of the strategy for each campaign in the final days before the June 8 primary elections.
Mrs. Whitman began her media push last week with a series of television and radio broadcasts that portray her as the candidate for change. The advertisements do not mention either her Republican primary opponents or Mr. Florio.
Mr. Edwards also began his media blitz last week. He has split his attack between Mr. Florio, criticizing him over a record $2.8 billion tax increase, and Mrs. Whitman, panning her for not voting in school elections and for using a tax loophole to pay $47 in property taxes on 50 acres of land on her estate.
 
Wallwork Starting Blitz
 Mr. Wallwork intends to start an intensive broadcast campaign on Thursday that hammers away at Mrs. Whitman as a "liberal" who voted 17 times to raise taxes as a Somerset County Freeholder.
Mr. Wallwork's campaign said the ad would run on television stations and 31 radio stations.
"We are going to be spending $400,000 on media ads between now and the primary," said Cristyne Lategano, Mr. Wallwork's spokeswoman.
Despite Mr. Florio's lack of primary opposition, his campaign began running a 60-second advertisement on Tuesday that praises him as a leader who made tough choices during tough times, a heroic challenger to the National Rifle Association over the state's ban on semiautomatic weapons and an environmental challenger for cracking down on ocean dumping.
A would-be challenger to Mr. Florio for the Democratic nomination, John Budzash, was disqualified after the Democratic State Committee challenged his qualifying papers in court.
 
'I Still Don't Know'
 As the debate drew to a close tonight, many of the people who had attended waiting to be won over remained undecided.
One of them was Robin Simko, president of Professional Insurance Agents of New Jersey, who had hoped for coherent answers.
"Whitman said she was for tort reform, and that's good," she said, referring to new laws to reduce lawsuits over car accidents. "Wallwork is for opening up the system to competition. Edwards? He wasn't very clear. We need a lot of change in this state, and I have a lot of hope, but I still don't know who I should vote for."
Al Zecca, an Essex County employee, went to the debate hoping to hear about his key concern, streamlining state government by consolidating bureacracies. That question was asked during the evening, but the answers were too vague for Mr. Zecca. As Mr. Wallwork was speaking, he declared, "The first thing we have to do is dump Florio," and the applause that followed this Republican mantra of three years was so faint that Mr. Zecca cocked an eyebrow.
"See?" he said, "Nobody knows for sure. It could even be Florio again."

HEADLINE: Brazil Answers Inflation With Cabinet Shuffle

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York TimesSpecial to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 25

 BODY:
With Brazil's Army discreetly flexing its political muscles, President Itamar Franco is gambling on a Cabinet shuffle that one newsweekly here called "Itamar's last chance."
Unable to cut back inflation from its current level of 30 percent a month, Mr. Franco has pinned his hopes on Fernando Henrique Cardoso, 61, a former Sao Paulo senator who enjoys wide respect, from company boardrooms here in Brazil's industrial heartland to the headquarters of multilateral banks in Washington. 
 But, by moving from the Foreign Ministry to the Finance Ministry, Mr. Cardoso now confronts a daunting challenge of credibility: he is the fourth Finance Minister to serve during Mr. Franco's eight-month-old Government.
"If Fernando Henrique fails, Itamar may have to resign in advance," said Andre Lara Resende, a director of Fintec, an investment bank here. "Things are evolving very quickly."
Since assuming presidential powers last October from Fernando de Collor Mello, who was forced from office by an array of scandals, Mr. Franco has proved to be indecisive, business people here complain. Presidential elections are to be held in October 1994.
But several bankers and political scientists predict that if the new Finance Minister is unable to reduce inflation, strong pressure will mount for Mr. Franco to resign and for elections to be held sooner.
Brazil's largest denomination bill, the 500,000-cruzeiro note, is worth $10. Unemployment in Sao Paulo, Brazil's business capital, has hit 16 percent, or 1.2 million people.
With no relief in sight, Veja, Brazil's largest selling newsweekly, called the appointment of Mr. Cardoso as Finance Minister "the best news that the country has received since Fernando Collor's impeachment."
One Brazilian banker agreed: "It's a gamble that the Brazilian business community has to take very seriously. The fact that the military have started sending signals is very important."
Indeed, the quiet re-emergence of Brazil's military in politics is a measure of the weakness of Mr. Franco, Brazil's third civilian President since 21 years of military rule ended in 1985.
On May 18, the military high command met in Brasilia with Mr. Franco. After the meeting, a joint statement issued by the President's office warned, "Democracy cannot commit suicide." The following day, the President dismissed Luiza Erundina, a left-wing leader of the Workers Party, as Secretary of Federal Administration and named Romildo Canhim, a recently retired army general.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Apple Aims for Ex-Soviet States

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 26

 BODY:
Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would begin a new effort to compete head-on with the International Business Machines Corporation in Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
The lifting of cold war restrictions on exports of technology to the former Soviet Union has provided Apple and other personal computer companies with a potentially enormous market. 
 "Virtually every household in the newly independent states will know that Apple Macintosh is now within reach," Brian Keating, general manager for Apple Computer in Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States, said in a statement.
 
 
'1984 Redux'
 As part of an aggressive debut, a revised version of Apple's famous 1984 commercial will be shown on news programs throughout the former Soviet Union on Thursday.
Called "1984 Redux," the 60-second television ad says: "For more than 20 years, Europe, Asia, America -- the whole world -- all toiled under the dominance of one personal computer system. A system whose inflexibility discouraged independent thought and personal creativity. A system whose power went unchallenged. Until Apple created Macintosh. The right to choose. The right to think. The right to be an individual. Apple Computer now in Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States."
While the former Soviet Union represents a potentially huge market, its economic weakness and instability have thwarted efforts to sell personal computers. Analysts say today's move by Apple, which has made previous efforts in the Soviet Union, is more a matter of laying the groundwork for a market that may develop in 5 or 10 years than something that will contribute to sales in the near future.
"It's evangelism," said Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies Inc. in Cupertino, Calif. "There is so much turmoil and the economy is so backward that the best anyone can do is go in as an evangelist now."
 
 
Economic Turmoil
 He said that Apple had tried to sell computers in the Soviet Union three years ago, and that John Sculley, the company's chairman and chief executive, had met with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and had given him a Macintosh. But the collapse of Communism and the resultant economic turmoil stalled Apple's efforts.
Charles Wolf, an analyst with First Boston, said the former Soviet Union was a very long-term proposition for Apple, but one worth pursuing.
"The two great opportunities clearly are the Soviet Union and China," he said. "The problem in both is that there's not an infrastructure to build a market. Consequently this is probably going to be a very slow build."

HEADLINE: France Is Selling 21 Big Companies

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 26

 BODY:
Making good on a campaign pledge, France's new conservative Government today announced a sweeping privatization program involving 21 big state-controlled companies, including Air France, Renault and the Elf Aquitaine oil giant.
The selloff is to begin on a company-by-company basis this fall, with the Government hoping to raise about $7.25 billion this year alone. In contrast to a similar program carried out between 1986 and 1988, no limit will be placed on the acquisition of shares by foreigners. 
 The order and timing of the privatizations will be announced next month, but the inclusion of Renault stirred immediate interest since it should accelerate the auto maker's eventual merger with privately owned Volvo of Sweden, which already owns 20 percent of the French company.
 
'Operating Flexibility'
 "Private ownership should be a net positive for Renault," said Jean-Claude Gruet, auto analyst for UBS Securities in New York. "This will mean operating flexibility for management, which will now be able to control costs without Government interference."
Renault, despite a deep slump in the European auto market, has managed to return to profitability through a mixture of radical cost-cutting, sharply improved quality, some inventive new models and the highly successful alliance with Volvo.
The company's net profit surged 84 percent in 1992, to 5.68 billion francs, or $1.03 billion, on sales of 179.45 billion francs. But in the first quarter of this year, profits slumped to 240 million francs, a 90 percent drop from the similar 1992 period.
Renault's sale value will obviously increase if it is accomplished as the European auto market is recovering.
Market analysts said they expected the Government to begin its program with those companies most certain to attract investors, among them the Banque Nationale de Paris.
While Banque National de Paris's profits have declined in the European recession, it still earned 2.17 billion francs, or $390 million, last year.
 But another well-known French banking company on the privatization list, Credit Lyonnais, will be less attractive to investors because of recent loan problems and losses stemming from the financing of Giancarlo Parretti's acquisition of Metro-Goldwin-Meyer, which the bank now owns.
Among those expected to look closely at the two banks are other large European banking companies that want to create pan-European institutions. Banque National de Paris has already swapped 10 percent of its stock with Dresdner Bank of Germany. And Credit Lyonnais has aggressively sought international acquisitions, including buying 50.01 percent of Bank fur Gemeinwirtschaft in Germany last December.
All of the French banks, however, have found their expansion limited because state ownership has kept them from raising capital by selling stock.
Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the world's seventh-largest chemicals and pharmaceuticals company, is also expected to be among the first companies to be privatized.
Investors were disappointed by Rhone-Poulenc's 1992 results -- it had $15.4 billion in sales -- which the company said were hurt by the recession in Europe. But it is developing some promising new drugs, including Taxotere for ovarian cancer, said Arvind Desai, an analyst at Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Pharmaceutical Drug Research.
Its American holdings include 68 percent of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, a publicly traded drug maker, and Rhone-Poulenc Inc., a wholly owned chemicals company.
The French Government owns 43 percent of the 56.9 million Rhone shares outstanding, Government-controlled banks and insurance companies have 19 percent and 38 percent is publicly held.
As for Elf Aquitaine, it is considered a strong company with a tradition of technical proficiency that has enabled it to become a significant force in energy exploration in Africa and northern Europe. The company has been willing to take risks, putting much of its future exploration effort in Russia.
"It's a very good oil company," said Bernie Picchi, oil analyst for Kidder, Peabody. "It's had a terrific track record in finding oil and gas in West Africa, the Middle East and the North Sea."
It is also on the way to becoming a large force in distributing gasoline in eastern Germany by planning one of the largest refineries in Europe.
But some analysts are concerned that it is moving too aggressively. Frank Knuettel, an oil analyst at Prudential, said that while Elf looks attractive in the long term, it may not be moving as cautiously as it should.
 
Need for 'Decentralization'
 "The world economy is evolving," Edmond Alphandery, who took over as France's Economy Minister less than two months ago, said today. "We recognize that a modern and competitive economy depends on decentralization of management decision making."
But it is also no secret that Prime Minister Edouard Balladur sees the privatizations as the best way to raise tens of billions of dollars to reduce the budget deficit and revive economic growth. The conservative Government is in a hurry to show results before the scheduled presidential elections in 1995.
On Tuesday, Mr. Balladur announced plans to issue $7.25 billion worth of state bonds to stimulate employment and tide the Government over until the privatization revenues start to flow. Bond holders will then have the option of exchanging their bonds for shares in privatized companies.
The Paris Bourse barely reacted to today's news, with the CAC-40 index dropping just 0.66 point, or three-hundredths of a percent, to 1,890.43. But the Government hopes recent cuts in interest rates will encourage the French to shift some savings to the stock market in anticipation of the privatizations. Mr. Alphandery said a new poll showed 14 percent of the French would consider buying shares in privatized companies.
 
Criticized by Mitterrand
 President Francois Mitterrand, whose Socialist Party was swept out of office in general elections in late March, immediately raised objections to the privatization plan. His spokesman quoted him telling a Cabinet meeting before the announcement that "in the nation's interests" some companies should remain in state hands. Several of the concerns now to be privatized were nationalized soon after he took office in 1981.
Between 1986 and 1988, Mr. Mitterrand was able to slow the privatization program of the former Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, by refusing to sign a decree and forcing the Government to seek parliamentary approval. After only eight big privatizations, the program was cut short by a stock market collapse late in 1987 and the defeat of the conservatives in elections in 1988.
Mr. Balladur, however, who managed the last privatization as Economy Minister under Mr. Chirac, now plans first to send a bill to the parliament, where conservatives hold more than 80 percent of seats and quick approval is assured. Among the 21 companies named today are 12 that Mr. Chirac had listed for privatization when the conservatives were last in office.
Mr. Alphandery said that while in the late 1980's foreign ownership was limited to 20 percent of privatized companies, no such limit would apply this time. But he said the Government would retain what he called a "golden share" in some companies in order to influence key decisions.
Under the new law to be sent to the National Assembly in June, the Government will be required to approve any holdings larger than 5 percent in privatized companies in the health, security and military industries. It will also be able to name two nonvoting members to the boards of privatized companies, he added.
Mr. Alphandery, who disclosed no timetable for the sales, said that an independent privatization commission, which will probably be named late in June, will determine the market value of the companies. The first list of companies to be privatized will be announced shortly, he noted.
Many of those named today, among them Air France, Aerospatiale, Usinor-Sacilor, Credit Lyonnais and Groupe Bull, recorded heavy losses last year and may need restructuring before their shares can be floated. Even Mr. Alphandery acknowledged today that some companies were less than attractive.
The state will continue to control four large public utilities -- France Telecom, French Railways, Electricite de France and Gaz de France.

HEADLINE: Clinton Budget Strains At House's Short Leash

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Spring is here, the budget is on the House floor, and elected representatives are pontificating, cutting back-room deals, plying and being plied by lobbyists and angling for their hometowns.
Simply put, they are conducting the political equivalent of what any hog farmer would immediately identify as a good warm-weather roll in the slop. 
 A few hundred yards down the hall, in the Senate, Republicans and Democrats are narrowing their differences on campaign finance roughly as fast as wind erodes mountains. In the House, where President Clinton's own party is in a tug-of-war over his fiscal agenda, lawmakers are so many atoms in a heated vessel, combining and splitting and throwing off energy each time their political interests collide with those of their rivals.
"We've got 98 percent of what this damned thing is going to look like, so it's doable," Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, one of the House's more experienced and liberal Democrats, said of the budget negotiations.
But it is not done, the vote is hours away, and the pungent odor of deals being cut is in the air. "This," Mr. Frank said, "is what politics is all about."
The House is a rowdy place, thanks to the nation's founders. They deliberately made the House larger and more immediately answerable to the public than the more sedate and removed Senate. And so many Democrats who otherwise would cast a vote to help out the new fellow in the White House are looking out first for their own political interests and, by implication, those of the people who voted for them.
The strains are evident among freshmen Democrats. Many of them rode into office not so much on Mr. Clinton's coattails as on the back bumper of the populist movement that Ross Perot whipped up and Mr. Clinton attached himself to. Some replaced Republicans or come from nominally conservative districts. Some ran on platforms of opposing new taxes, and now they are being asked to approve $250 billion in new taxes.
Many are nervous, which is why the President took pains on Monday to invite the freshmen to the White House as a separate group for one of the backbone-strengthening sessions he has been conducting lately.
"President Clinton is asking us to go out on a limb, and he says 'Don't worry, I'll be out there with you,' " said Representative Jane Harman, a freshman Democrat from a comparatively conservative California district. "But the question that does at least cross my mind is whether the limb is going to break and fall off."
Ms. Harman backed Mr. Clinton's effort that failed earlier this spring to spend $19 billion on an economic stimulus package of jobs and public works projects, and she says she regards his budget as "a basically sound package." But she is not unhappy that more conservative Democrats are trying to saddle the budget plan with new restraints to limit the growth of the Federal deficit.
"My constituents are keenly interested in deficit reduction," she said. "We support change, as long as it's fair, and we'll take our portion of the pain. But we insist on real deficit reduction and spending cuts first."
Asked whether her constituents believe the budget offers that, she replied, "They're unsure."
Another freshman Democrat, Representative Scotty Baesler, replaced a Republican member who had ruled his central Kentucky district for 16 years, and he has been personally wooed by Mr. Clinton to back the budget. "But as of 7:29 P.M., I'm voting no," he said tonight.
Mr. Baesler said his tobacco-farming constituents were already bracing for a cigarette tax to finance Mr. Clinton's health-care plan, and he was unwilling to burden them further. Beyond that, he said he felt that the White House plan did not reflect the "political climate" in which he and many other freshman came to power.
"Ten or 15 I talked to," he said. "We all have the same views. We were elected saying Democrats need a little more conservative approach, not tax and spend. Me, I think we need to get the ratio of cuts to taxes much better than it is now."
 
Budget Cuts Worry Some
 Perhaps Mr. Clinton could ease the tax-and-spending fears of conservatives and moderates easily enough. But at the other end of the Democratic spectrum, equally answerable to their constituents, are lawmakers whose poor urban and rural districts are most dependent on Federal programs like Medicaid and food stamps that the new taxes are intended to finance in part.
Having already lost a chance at the jobs and other aid Mr. Clinton promised in his stimulus package, they are adamant that health-care and welfare spending not be restrained to placate the party's more comfortable elements. They are led by the Congressional Black Caucus and the Hispanic Caucus, groups that have signaled before that they wanted more attention.
The President offered it today, calling in the Black Caucus to urge that they compromise with conservatives on a proposal to offset increases in health-care and welfare spending with cuts elsewhere in the budget. If they were much moved, it is not yet evident: the two sides were still at loggerheads as the House worked late into the night.
"Nobody is in love with this thing," Representative Kweisi Mfume of Maryland, the caucus chairman, said of the budget proposal. "It's an ugly child in many respects. But we're working, because we have to do something."

HEADLINE: U.S. Blacks and Africans Seek Stronger Ties

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, May 26

 BODY:
"Africa is open for business," Mohammed Fall Ainina, the Mauritanian Ambassador to the United States, told a group of black Americans meeting here this week, "and the first people we're going to seek business from are you."
Mr. Ainina's remarks summed up an important goal of the second African/ African-American Summit: to encourage business between blacks on both continents. And increasingly, sponsors of the conference say, black Americans are beginning to compete with businesses from the former colonial powers of Europe. 
 To drive that point home, Mr. Ainina announced that Mauritania, a former French colony in West Africa, had granted an offshore fishing license to a group headed by Mervyn M. Dymally, a former Democratic Congressman from California, the first such contract granted to a black American. Just a few years ago such a deal would have been virtually unthinkable because France had a virtual lock on the economic life of its former possession.
The four-day conference, with nearly 1,000 Americans and about 3,500 Africans, was said to be the largest of its kind ever. Among Americans attending were the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Andrew Young, Coretta Scott King, Louis Farrakhan, Governor Douglas Wilder of Virginia and the actress Cicely Tyson.
The first such meeting, sponsored by the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, head of the International Foundation for Educational Self-Help in Phoenix, was held two years ago in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. Mr. Sullivan is best known for devising a code of conduct in 1977 for American corporations doing business in South Africa. He was also in the forefront of those who encouraged corporations to divest themselves of interests there.
But while many Americans at Abidjan said that the meeting there helped them connect emotionally with their ancestral homeland, many Africans at that meeting complained that it had accomplished little of substance. "Many of us who attended the Abidjan conference expected to come away with some solid financial commitments," said a Nigerian businessman, "but all they got was a lot of rhetoric from black preachers about returning to their roots. It was nice to hear, but it didn't put any money in our pockets."
Many here hope the Libreville meeting will go beyond fiery Afrocentric language, a point made in a speech by Mr. Jackson, who said African nations too often ignore black Americans when offering business opportunities. "We have to move to a level beyond romance, to finance, beyond causes, to contracts," he said.
Mr. Jackson noted that African nations often depend upon the 40-member Congressional Black Caucus to lobby for aid from the United States.
One of the best-attended meetings was a prayer breakfast featuring Mr. Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader. Mr. Farrakhan, citing the example of Israel, said black Americans should also be able to form a country of their own on the African continent, and said he plans to ask African leaders to "carve out a territory for all people in the diaspora."
He said black Americans should also be granted dual citizenship by all African countries. "We want dual citizenship," he said, "and because we don't know where we came from, we want dual citizenship everywhere."
While Mr. Sullivan's concept has, by and large, run smoothly, it is not without critics. One question is why, as more African countries become multi-party democracies, the conference is being held in Gabon, which has been under the one-party rule of President Omar Bongo since 1967.
In September 1990, Gabon held its first multi-party elections, but they were marred by widespread violence and charges that the voting was rigged in favor of Mr. Bongo.
Makau Matua, head of the human rights project at the Harvard Law School, described Mr. Bongo as "one of the longest-serving despots that the continent has produced."
Asked about such criticism, Mr. Sullivan said: "I wouldn't say they're inaccurate. But that's a political judgment and I'm not a politican." Nonetheless, he added, "I'm encouraged that democratization will be coming."

HEADLINE: Florio Replaces Aide Who Left Amid Inquiry

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 26

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio appointed a new chief of staff who has both governmental and political credentials today to replace the longtime confidante who left the post in the midst of an investigation into possible improper steering of state bond business.
Richard L. Wright, an associate state treasurer, will preside over an administration buffeted by the resignation Tuesday of Joseph C. Salema, who has been subpoenaed in a multistate Federal investigation involving New Jersey Turnpike bonds. 
 In an interview, Mr. Wright, who immediately assumed the duties of chief of staff, said he intended no major shake-ups. "I don't think it will be any different from the way Joe did it," he said, which he said was largely a matter of "establishing a mood, establishing a theme, deciding what our goal is."
For Mr. Salema, the major goal was the political rehabilitation of Mr. Florio in the wake of the record tax increase he pushed through the Legislature in 1990, causing his popularity ratings to plummet.
The abrupt departure of Mr. Salema this week left a considerable vacuum in both the State House and the Governor's re-election campaign. In accepting Mr. Salema's resignation, Mr. Florio acquiesced to entreaties from aides to shield himself and his campaign from Republican attacks on Mr. Salema, whose bond company is at the center of an investigation into whether it improperly benefited from state bond deals.
 
Political Role Unclear
 Mr. Wright said in the interview that he was not sure how much of the political dimension of Mr. Salema's job he would inherit.
"I just don't know," he said. "My relationship with the Governor has been in the area of economic development, which is the absolute critical issue of our time."
That fits with the Governor's political agenda, which in addition to overcoming the onus of having raised taxes, is to take the state out of the economic doldrums that have plagued it for three years, with unemployment, at about 9 percent, a particular problem.
The new chief of staff also said he was not sure how he would divide political responsibilities with his former boss, Douglas Berman, now a consultant to the Florio campaign, at a salary of $25,000 a month.
The 50-year-old Mr. Wright has had a brief brush with an ethics inquiry of his own. As associate treasurer he took part in awarding a lease for space for a state agency in a building partly owned by a Camden County Democratic leader in the Legislature who was reprimanded for failing to properly disclose his interest in the building.
In a deposition before the Joint Legislative Committee on Ethical Standards, which held hearings into the leasing arrangement in May 1992, Mr. Wright said that he was unaware at the time the lease was signed in January 1992 that one owner of the building in Cherry Hill was Assemblyman Wayne R. Bryant, then majority leader of the Assembly.
Mr. Wright testified that when he discovered the ownership interest, he inquired and found that there were no conflicts with state policy. No improprieties were found on Mr. Wright's part, but Gov. Florio subsequently issued an executive order barring the state from leasing from members of the Legislature.
In the interview today, Mr. Wright reiterated that he did not know of Mr. Bryant's involvement when the lease was negotiated.
Mr. Wright, a Princeton graduate who received a law degree from the University of California at Berkeley, worked as executive director of Amnesty International, as an aide in the United States Department of Energy and on the Presidential campaign of Robert Kennedy in 1968. He was the campaign manager for Carol Bellamy in her 1972 New York State Senate campaign and was director of development for the National Committee for an Effective Congress in 1976.

HEADLINE: Joseph Pulitzer Jr. Is Dead at 80; Publisher Was Avid Art Collector

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Joseph Pulitzer Jr., chairman of the Pulitzer Publishing Company and owner of one of the world's finest collections of modern art, died yesterday at his home in the Central West End of St. Louis. He was 80.
Mr. Pulitzer died of colon cancer, the publishing company said in a news release. 
 Tall, elegant and reserved, Mr. Pulitzer had, for the last seven years, served primarily as chairman of Pulitzer Publishing, which owns three newspapers, seven television stations and two radio stations. He had led Pulitzer Publishing and its flagship publication, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, for 38 years, serving for 31 of those years as editor and publisher of the newspaper.
Mr. Pulitzer relinquished his positions with the paper in 1986 to devote his attention to the company, which went public that year. From 1955 to 1986, he served as chairman of the board of the Pulitzer Prizes, the highest awards in journalism, which were established by his grandfather.
 
Avid Collector of Art
 Though principally identified with journalism, Mr. Pulitzer was widely recognized for the art collection he began as a student at Harvard University, a collection that ultimately became one of the most important and generously shared in the world.
Art News magazine called Mr. Pulitzer's acquisitions "one of the most brilliant and comprehensive collections of modern art in the country," and John Russell of The New York Times described it as "one of the most discriminating" in the nation, saying it was "as remarkable for range as for quality."
Born on May 13, 1913, Mr. Pulitzer was baptized in the Episcopal Church as Joseph Pulitzer 3d, but he later adopted the junior designation, which his father had dropped after the death of the first Joseph Pulitzer.
Mr. Pulitzer graduated from St. Mark's School in Southborough, Mass., in 1932, and went on to earn his bachelor's degree in fine art from Harvard in 1936. His newspaper career began with a stint as a cub reporter for The San Francisco News in 1935, the summer before his senior year at Harvard. After graduating, he joined The Post-Dispatch news staff and helped cover the Roosevelt-Landon campaign of 1936.
 
'Illuminate Dark Places'
 Over the next 20 years, he worked in every department of the paper, including periods as editor of the daily magazine and editor of the Sunday rotogravure, or pictorial. In 1948, he became associate editor, a position he held until he became editor and publisher on the father's death in 1955.
In an editorial he wrote on the day he took over the paper, a week after his father's death, Mr. Pulitzer pledged that The Post-Dispatch would maintain its tradition as one of the nation's great crusading papers. "We will not only report the day's news but illuminate dark places, and, with a deep sense of responsibility, interpret these troublous times," he wrote.
At the time, besides the newspaper, Pulitzer holdings included only a radio and television station in St. Louis. But under Joseph Jr.'s guidance, the company bought The Arizona Daily Star in Tucson and The Southtown Economist in Chicago, six other television stations and another radio station.
In 1986, the Pulitzer company faced its greatest financial challenge. It had accrued a large debt, and a group of dissident relatives who owned stock in the privately owned company found a buyer, A. Alfred Taubman, a Michigan real estate developer, who offered $625 million for the company. The company successfully resisted the takeover bid, going public with the stock in order to offset its debt.
In 1989, the company faced another challenge when Ralph Ingersoll 2d began publishing The St. Louis Sun. Although that newspaper failed after only seven months, its presence spurred the staid Post-Dispatch to improve its coverage.
 
A Litany of Firsts
 During Mr. Pulitzer's tenure as editor, The Post-Dispatch won five Pulitzers, including prizes for commentary and editorial cartooning. In 1987, Mr. Pulitzer received a special citation from the Pulitzer Prize board, citing his "extraordinary services to American journalism and letters."
The Post-Dispatch was one of the first newspapers in the country to oppose the war in Vietnam, and it was also one of the first to publish excerpts from the Pentagon Papers, the secret history of the war.
It was also the first paper in the country to replace the old letter-press printing process with offset cold-type printing, which allowed high-quality color printing. "Color was of special interest to an art connoisseur like Mr. Pulitzer," the company's statement yesterday said, "and at his insistence The Post-Dispatch moved early into color publication."
 
Hobby Became a Passion
 Mr. Pulitzer's art collecting began simply enough in 1936 when as an undergraduate he bought Modigliani's "Elvira Resting at a Table." Three years later, at an auction in Lucerne, Switzerland, he bought "Bathers With a Turtle," by Matisse for $2,400, a piece that is now easily worth 10,000 times that amount.
Mr. Pulitzer's father had no enthusiasm for modern art and sometimes took his friends into his son's room to ridicule the purchases. "He was convinced that I had been fleeced by shrewd and unscrupulous New York dealers," Mr. Pulitzer said in a speech earlier this year.
Later, when his father realized the value of his collection and asked where he learned so much about art, Mr. Pulitzer told him that the knowledge had been acquired at Harvard and that the elder Pulitzer had footed the bill.
The Pulitzer Collection came to include 86 pieces, all of which were shown at the Fogg Art Museum in Cambridge, Mass., in 1988. The collection could have included Picasso's seminal work "Demoiselles d'Avignon," but Mr. Pulitzer had bought it before World War II and then donated it to the Museum of Modern Art.
Mr. Pulitzer always insisted on anonymity when lending his works to museums.
His collection included Vuillard's "Self Portrait," and "Head of a Man" by Degas, one of Monet's "Water Lilies," as well as works by Braque, Picasso and Miro.
Mr. Pulitzer's first wife, Louise Vauclain, died in 1968. He married again in 1973, to the former Emily S. Rauh, who at the time was curator of the St. Louis Art Museum.
He is survived by his son, Joseph Pulitzer 4th; his half brother, Michael of St. Louis, two sisters, Kate Davis Quesada of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Elinor Hempelmann of Rochester, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Go to Vietnam Memorial Despite Protest

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The White House announced today that President Clinton would deliver remarks at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial on Monday, despite the risk that the visit could revive the debate over his draft record, which dogged his campaign.
Administration officials said the White House had received postcards from veterans as part of what the officials called an organized protest. The veterans charged that Mr. Clinton would "engage in hypocrisy" if he visited the memorial. 
 But the officials said it was important for the President to go forward with his plans for Memorial Day, which also include a breakfast with veterans and a wreath-laying ceremony at the Arlington National Cemetery.
"He's aware of the protests, of course," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said: "He is the President of all the people. He believes it's important to show his respect for the veterans who served in all our wars, and that's exactly why he's going to go."
Some White House officials said Mr. Clinton had decided to make the visit to silence public doubts about his mettle as Commander in Chief and to divert attention from the controversies that had consumed the White House for several days.
 
Distractions Keep Mounting
 But as Mr. Clinton sought to make an all-out push in the House for his economic program today, the White House faced a fresh round of distractions: more assaults by Ross Perot, questions about Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, who suggested that the United States might have to retreat from its past leadership role, and even complaints by a New Hampshire news anchor, who said she had been asked to apply makeup to the President's face before she interviewed him.
Mr. Perot, in a television interview taped on Tuesday, attacked Mr. Clinton with relish about the dismissal of the White House travel staff and about the expensive haircut that the President got aboard Air Force One as the plane sat on the runway at Los Angeles International Airport last week.
"What we have here is a person who does not have the background or experience for the most difficult job in the world, which we, the American people, have elected him to fill," Mr. Perot said. "If you were interviewing him for your company, and you had a medium-sized company, you wouldn't consider giving him a job anywhere above middle management."
In an Interview for the PBS program "Talking with David Frost," Mr. Perot said the President was "still doing things the Arkansas way, like trying to give the travel business as a political payoff."
 
Leadership 'Undiminished'
 Asked to respond, Mr. Clinton said, "Well, we know he doesn't like my state, but he spent several million dollars to bad-mouth it last year, but that doesn't have much to do with America."
In another effort to tamp down potentially damaging comments, Secretary of State Warren Christopher distanced the Administration from Mr. Tarnoff's assertions about a weakened leadership role for this country. Mr. Tarnoff had spoken to reporters at a Tuesday lunch on background, a common Washington practice meaning they had agreed to identify him only as a senior official. No reporter from The New York Times attended the lunch, but the source of the remark became known around Washington within hours.
"I think the U.S. responsibility for leadership is undiminished in this new post-cold-war period," Mr. Christopher said in an interview today, adding that the aide's remarks were "inconsistent with my policy and the President's policy."
Ms. Myers also said that White House officials had apologized to Nanette Hansen, the anchorwoman of WMUR-TV in Manchester, N.H.. She said she had been asked by a White House aide to apply the President's makeup because no make-up person was available.

HEADLINE: Old Tactics Shadow Ex-Florio Aide;
Revolving-Door Politics Lead to Enrichment, and a Liability

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
Those who have followed the rise to power of Jim Florio and his longtime lieutenant, Joseph C. Salema Jr., say clues to their considerable success were evident in their Camden County origins. There, they say, a pattern was established that the pair carried 35 miles up Interstate 295 to the capital in Trenton.
Mr. Florio, as the governor of New Jersey, has continued to pursue the liberal agenda and calculating, tough-minded political style that served him well as the Congressman representing the Camden area. 
 But in the case of Mr. Salema, the pattern was prospering at the intersection of business and politics. He has earned a small fortune in the arena where governments make choices that determine who gets public contracts worth millions of dollars. It is an arena where some say political judgment is paramount, others say raw political contacts.
For the second time in their political partnership, Mr. Salema has become a liability for Mr. Florio, who is locked in a difficult re-election campaign. On Tuesday, after weeks of pressure generated by a Federal investigation into possible paybacks by Wall Street investment bankers to obtain a larger share of public bond offerings, he resigned as Mr. Florio's chief of staff.
In the early 1980's while Mr. Florio was serving in Congress, Mr. Salema ran Mr. Florio's home district and helped bring into public service a cluster of Florio proteges who came to control most of the county government.
These self-styled reformers had brains and vitality. They mapped plans to modernize 19th-century water and sewer systems and other public works, and ordered the design of plants to meet new environmental standards.
But by 1984, Mr. Salema and another trusted lieutenant, Nicholas Rudi Jr., began cashing in on their political careers. They resigned from government to become partners in a management and financial consultant business that was quickly hired to advise county departments and agencies they had once ruled. The pair became wealthy, critics claimed, by using their ties to Mr. Florio to attract bond underwriters, lawyers and others who wanted to do business in Camden County.
Outside of being brought in as a partner in two real estate deals arranged by Consolidated Financial's partners, in which he made no investment of cash, Mr. Florio apparently did not personally benefit from their soaring success.
Mr. Salema and Mr. Rudi have declined to discuss their early days, having referred all questions to their lawyers. An aide said Mr. Florio did not want to comment further about his chief of staff's business dealings.
 
Political Loyalty, Financial Rewards
When the propriety of his proteges' activities was questioned, Mr. Florio returned their loyalty, saying they were smart, ambitious and broke no laws.
Mr. Salema and Mr. Rudi left government at a time when sky-high interest rates, which had discouraged bond offerings and created a huge backlog of financing needs, were starting to tumble from the levels of the early 1980's.The eventual decline also created a welcome opportunity to refinance existing bonds and thereby save localities millions of dollars in lower interest payments.
The intertwining of politics and public bond issues has been a powerful part of state government for years, with both Democrats and Republicans receiving millions of dollars in campaign contributions from Wall Street investment houses and politically connected law firms.
"Bond sales are the new political patronage," said Ed McCool, director of Common Cause of New Jersey, a good-government advocacy group.
Mr. Salema had first worked in 1972 for Mr. Florio, then a legislator making an unsuccessful attempt to win the First Congressional District, which embraces the broken port city of Camden across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. Two years later, when Mr. Florio was elected to Congress, Mr. Salema managed the campaign.
 
A Reform Slate, New Political Muscle
By that time, the county Democratic machine was under the thrall of Angelo J. Errichetti, the street-tough and engaging Mayor of Camden, and James E. Joyce, the county Democratic leader. Local politics, Mr. Florio said later, was "a cesspool."
Mr. Florio, finding an ally in Lewis Katz, then the Democratic leader in Cherry Hill, a sprawing suburb outside Camden, offered a reform slate in the 1979 election that defeated the machine's candidates, emerging with political muscle stripped from the bosses.
Mr. Rudi, who worked in Bill Bradley's successful campaign for the United States Senate in 1978, entered the picture in 1980. He served as treasurer for Mr. Florio's first campaign for governor in 1981, a contest he narrowly lost to Thomas H. Kean, a Republican. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance, Mr. Rudi impressed Mr. Florio with his financial acumen and was installed as chief administrator and treasurer of Camden County.
From most accounts, the team was scandal-free. It operated a progressive administration that tried to grapple with Camden's dire social and economic problems and the burgeoning growth of the rest of the county.
"There was a feeling that while Jim Florio was building power in the suburbs he and his team never went after money for themselves," said the Rev. Michael Doyle, a Roman Catholic priest in a squalid ward of South Camden for the last 17 years.
Yet at the same time, Mr. Rudi looked upon government as a stepping stone to business success. "I was interested in developing contacts," he said about his public service career.
 
From Public Arena To Private Sector
That time came in 1984 when falling interest rates were encouraging many municipalities and public agencies to issue bonds to refinance debt or to raise capital for roads, bridges and other public works. Mr. Rudi opened a firm called Consolidated Financial Management, with Mr. Salema as half-owner.
Mr. Salema also left the government payroll, first as an executive in Mr. Katz's string of South Jersey banks, First Peoples, but in 1985 he joined Mr. Rudi as a full-time partner. They brought into the firm Brenda J. Bacon, a former county freeholder and a Florio protege, and Mr. Salema's sister, Roberta Acampora, who had previously been the county finance director.
In the meantime, another Florio political insider, Steven D. Weinstein resigned as chief county counsel and opened a Camden area branch of a prominent Philadelphia law firm, Blank Rome Comisky & McCauley, that was hoping to expand into counseling work in southern New Jersey.
By coincidence or design, Mr. Florio's inner circle now was in a position to take advantage of the building projects they had helped conceive as public servants and to share in the millions of dollars in fees and commissions associated with them.
Consolidated Financial Management was awarded contracts to serve as financial adviser to Camden County and the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority. And Mr. Weinstein's Philadelphia firm was appointed bond and special litigation counsel for the utilities authority, producing $600,000 for the firm in the next two years and spinning off contracts with other Democratic-controlled public agencies.
About the same time Mr. Weinstein's Philadelphia law firm became a big contributor to Mr. Florio's 1984 re-election fund with 45 of its lawyers giving a total of $25,870, according to published reports.
And the firm owned by Mr. Salema and Mr. Rudi was earning consulting fees that often amounted to hundreds of thousands of dollars.
"They feasted on the power, all these bright young hotshots who had kicked out the old regime and were now making millions from the new regime," said John Kolesar, former managing editor of The Camden Courier Post which in 1987 ran a series of articles on how revolving-door politics enriched the business partners.
 
Devising a Plan And Profiting Later
Those who watched them operate said that Mr. Rudi was a financial whiz who could package complicated deals and that Mr. Salema was a master of politics who could cut through official paperwork and make things happen fast.
Under Consolidated Financial Management's guidance, the Municipal Utilities Authority issued more than $1 billion in bonds to build water and sewer systems. Mr. Salema and Mr. Rudi picked up public clients in neighboring Gloucester and Burlington Counties, parts of which were within Mr. Florio's Congressional District. They also used their growing expertise, and political contacts established in Mr. Florio's 1991 gubernatorial race, to win no-bid contracts in northern New Jersey.
A look at how the partners profited from a plan they helped devise while still in county government, as recounted in The Courier-Post, is representative of how they operated.
In the early 1980's county officials began to lay the groundwork for several capital projects to address water, sewer and pollution-control needs. After Mr. Rudi and Mr. Salema left government, they were hired as financial advisers for several of the projects, including an innovative "trash-to-steam" resource-recovery plant. The Pollution Control Financing Authority, which the county created on their advice, issued $108 million in bonds needed to build the plant. Consolidated Financial Management received a fee of $176,000.
Meanwhile, a county freeholder who was a regular contributor to Mr. Florio's campaigns received an $80,000 retainer to negotiate a contract between the authority and the company chosen to operate the plant. The New York underwriting firm of Bear Stearns, which contributed $3,000 to a "better government" committee that Mr. Salema controlled, was tapped as the non-bid seller of the bonds, at a fee estimated at $1 million. The engineering firm hired without bids to design the plan, for a fee of some $500,000, donated $2,000 to the county Democrats and $2,500 to the same "better government" panel.
Reports of these dealings raised questions about Mr. Salema, who was kept in the background during Mr. Florio's 1989 race for governor. For the first time since 1974 he did not manage a Florio campaign.
 
A Distress Signal, Inner Circle Reunites
It didn't matter. Mr. Florio trounced the Republican candidate, James A. Courter, by a wide margin. By the dawn of 1990, Mr. Florio moved into the state house in Trenton. Mr. Salema and Mr. Rudi formed a new enterprise, Armacon Securities, licensed to buy new bond issues and resell them to the public.
But before it could get rolling in mid-1990 the Governor sent out a distress signal to Mr. Salema. The new administration had run into a political firestorm in its first months over a $2.8 billion tax package, and Mr. Florio wanted his former aide to take over the role of chief of staff.
Mr. Salema accepted the post, placing his assets in a blind trust, rejoining the Governor and Ms. Bacon, the Florio aide who had resigned her executive vice president's job with Consolidated Financial Management to become Mr. Florio's director of planning. The former business partners constituted the Governor's new inner circle, barely changed from the Congressional days.
Bonds issues boomed, a result of declining interest rates that made it good policy to refinance existing bonds at favorable rates.
In New Jersey the growth was explosive.
After averaging 300-plus issues from all sources in the years 1985-90, with total value of $3 billion to $4 billion, the numbers jumped to 539 issues with a value of $10.8 billion in 1991, and 623 issues with a value of $13.6 billion in 1992.
In that period, Consolidated Financial Management catapulted from nowhere to take the No. 1 ranking among the top consultants for state and municipal bonds in New Jersey, handling 98 issues representing more than $3 billion in value, according to Securities Data, a Wall Street research company.
Meanwhile, the late starter Armacon earned more than $1 million fees in 14 bond issues, a performance that Wall Street executives now say largely reflected efforts by established underwriting firms to sow good will with the smaller firm and its influential founders.
Mr. Weinstein, the lawyer friend of Mr. Rudi and Mr. Salema from the old days in Camden, complained that they were getting a raw deal in the attention being paid to Armacon.
"A great injustice is being done," he said in a telephone interview before Mr. Salema resigned. "It is just another disincentive for talented people to come into government, work hard, and then pay the price later by being labeled as trading on their political connections."
