HEADLINE: Overstepped Bounds: An Empire Under Scrutiny -- A special report;
Fed Inquiry: An Arkansas Family

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
A powerful business empire with close links to the Clinton White House is under investigation by the Federal Reserve, an inquiry that has opened the fiercely private business group to unusual scrutiny.
The civil inquiry into holdings of the Stephens family of Arkansas has already uncovered information that could prove embarrassing to the family's companies, a White House lawyer and government regulators. 
 While there have been no suggestions that anyone -- at the White House or elsewhere -- has asked for special treatment in this case, the matter is clearly politically sensitive and has attracted the attention of top officials at the Fed, including the chairman, Alan Greenspan. And in the coming weeks, they must decide how vigorously to pursue the inquiry.
 
Family Control at Issue
 The issue in question is the extent of the family's control and ownership of two banks, the First National Bank in Stuttgart, Ark., and the Worthen Banking Corporation, the state's largest bank company, and whether the relationships violate laws to limit concentrations of financial power.
There are differences within the Fed on whether it was too quick to resolve one violation in the mildest way possible, as well as on how vigorously to pursue the questions that remain, according to officials at other agencies who asked not to be identified. None of the Fed's top officials have been appointed by the Clinton Administration.
The Fed has already determined that the Stephens holdings violate a Depression-era law that prohibits people who control securities firms from owning more than 50 percent of banks. The violation, which carries potential fines and the threat of embarrassing public disclosure, involves the family's ownership of more than half the shares of the bank in Stuttgart, a small but important corner of the sprawling Stephens financial empire.
Rather than levying a fine or bringing a formal enforcement action, the Fed has suggested that the bank become a state-chartered bank, according to the Stuttgart bank chairman, Harry Erwin, thus allowing it to avoid future Federal scrutiny. At a closed meeting three months ago, two members of the Fed's board of governors favored tougher enforcement, but Mr. Greenspan and four other members backed the milder course, according to officials at other agencies.
Interviews with bankers and former Stephens associates and documents show that representatives of Stephens Inc. and the Stuttgart bank failed to disclose to the Government the full extent of the family's ownership and control of the Stuttgart bank. These incomplete disclosures helped convince regulators that the family's holdings were permissible.
The incomplete disclosures also allowed the family to exercise control over the Stuttgart bank for more than a decade -- a relationship that allowed the securities firm and the Stephens family to profit from dealings with the bank, according to former officials of the bank.
William H. Kennedy 3d, now associate White House counsel and formerly a Little Rock lawyer who headed Hillary Rodham Clinton's law firm, filed one of the documents that gave incomplete information about the Stephens holdings in the bank in 1984. A White House spokeswoman said Mr. Kennedy would not comment on the Stephens case, or his role in it, because of the attorney-client privilege.
But David Knight, a lawyer with the Stephens firm, said that the family did not agree with the Fed's findings that it had more than 50 percent ownership in the Stuttgart bank, arguing that some of the family's trusts are independent and should not be counted.
 
Cooperating With Regulators
 Nonetheless, he said they and the bank were cooperating with regulators to resolve the matter. Mr. Knight also said that the omission of some of the Stephens bank holdings on the 1984 document stemmed from a legal "misunderstanding" of disclosure requirements by the lawyer handling the application. Mr. Knight said the Stephenses would have no other comment because of the pending inquiry.
As for Worthen, in which family members own more than a fourth of the stock, the Fed is trying to determine whether the Stephens Group, the family's holding company, exercises a controlling influence in the bank, according to Worthen officials. In addition, the Fed has subpoenaed stock trade records to see whether Stephens Inc., a brokerage firm, dominates the market for the bank's stock, an inquiry that could be complicated by a maze of offshore accounts, according to bankers.
Last March, the Fed approved Worthen's acquisition of another Arkansas bank despite reservations by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, which has oversight for Arkansas and wanted any approval to await the completion of the inquiry, according to officials at other agencies.
 
The Empire
Big in Arkansas And Elsewhere
 The Stephens Group is at the center of a multibillion-dollar empire, including Stephens Inc., one of the largest brokerage firms outside New York City. The family-owned empire stretches to the Middle East and Asia, with holdings that include a waste incinerator in Massachusetts, the nation's largest nursing home operator, real estate developments in the Midwest and South, oil and gas, a savings and loan in New Mexico, an insurance company, a nationwide group of manufacturing companies and a management company for entertainers like Burt Reynolds.
The name Stephens is virtually synonymous with the economy of Arkansas, where the family owns a large chunk of more than a dozen banks, the most exclusive hotel in Little Rock and the building that houses Bill Clinton's Arkansas office.
Jackson T. Stephens, the laconic family patriarch, is comfortable amid national establishment institutions like the Augusta National golf club, where he is chairman of the Masters golf tournament. He owns an apartment in the Sea View hotel in Bal Harbour, Fla., an oceanfront watering hole for political heavyweights like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, and the former Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. And for decades he has maintained close ties to Presidential administrations of both political parties.
But never has the nexus between the Stephenses and Washington been as tight as it is now. No group raised more money for the nascent Clinton Presidential campaign. The Worthen National Bank, whose ties to the Stephenses are part of the Fed investigation, lent more than $2 million to the campaign when it was on the ropes.
 
The Investigation
St. Louis Fed Initiates Inquiry
 It was an examination last year by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis of Worthen and its plans to expand that opened the door into the issue of Stephens holdings in the Stuttgart bank. The St. Louis Fed's report helped initiate a formal investigation by the Fed in Washington in an area where it has rarely employed its formal investigative powers.
For years, the Stephens family and officials at the Stuttgart bank promoted a public image of independence from the rest of the Stephens empire. Regulators, relying on these representations and disinclined to investigate, took the same view.
In fact, according to former bank officials and bank records, the bank's operations were quietly directed for more than a decade by W. R. Stephens, known as Witt, who along with his brother, Jackson, built the empire.
Not until March of this year, however, did the Fed decide that "Stephens family members and trust holdings violate the Glass-Steagall Act," the 1933 Federal law, according to Mr. Knight. He said family members and family trusts that control the brokerage firm, Stephens Inc., hold about two-thirds of the stock in the Stuttgart bank.
Family members and family trusts had owned more than half the Stuttgart bank's stock for more than a decade. A 1979 opinion by Bruce Heitz, a lawyer in the Memphis office of the Comptroller of the Currency, another Federal agency that regulates national banks, permitted the Stephens family to increase its holdings in the Stuttgart bank from 49 percent to more than 60 percent.
Mr. Heitz approved the increase in stock ownership because he believed that a family trust for two Stephens daughters that was buying 11 percent of the bank was independent, and that the two owners of the brokerage, Jackson Stephens and his older brother, Witt, while owning 49 percent of the bank's stock, did not try to dominate the bank.
 
Superiors Not Consulted
 That opinion, which Mr. Knight cited to demonstrate his clients' innocence, explains, in part, the Fed's reluctance to take sterner action. But the fact that Fed officials learned about the 1979 letter only recently, is "one of the reasons we have an investigation," said Joseph Coyne, a spokesman for the Fed, who would not comment further.
When Mr. Heitz issued his opinion in 1979, he did not consult his superiors in Washington or fellow regulators at the Fed, which has traditionally been the primary arbiter of the separation of brokerage and banking activities. In addition, he relied largely on information provided by the bank suggesting that the family did not exercise its controlling interest in the Stuttgart bank, according to documents and regulators.
But former officials of the bank suggest that the independence may not have been so real. Wayne Hampton, a Stuttgart rice farmer who served as a director of the bank during the 1970's, said in an interview that Witt Stephens had had him removed from the board. Mr. Hampton said that he, unlike other directors, had refused to support and donate money to a Stephens relative who was running for the Senate in 1978.
"Witt was the boss and I didn't support his nephew and I got my butt kicked off the board," he said.
 
Bank and Brokerage
Influence Reported In Bond Buying
 Mr. Hampton also said the Stephens securities firm controlled the buying of municipal bonds by the bank even though that was the legal responsibility of the bank's directors and no member of the Stephens family served on the board.
"All the board knew about bonds was that a list was sent to us from Little Rock," Mr. Hampton said, adding "we approved, but we had no discretion to choose which bonds to buy. I kind of resented it."
Stephens Inc. has long been the major underwriter and seller of municipal bonds in Arkansas. Competing regional securities firms, in complaints to a reporter and to municipal officials, said they were at a disadvantage because officials at Stephens-owned banks, have helped steer business in several Arkansas cities to the Stephens brokerage firm.
Other former officials of the Stuttgart bank, who asked not to be identified, supported Mr. Hampton's assertion. They also provided other details about Witt Stephens's control of the bank until his death in late 1991, control that sometimes worked to the benefit of the Stephenses and their brokerage firm at the expense of the bank and its customers, the former officials said.
According to these officials, Witt Stephens not only controlled the bank's purchases of bonds but also personally directed, usually by telephone, many of the bank's lending activities, including restrictions on the amount, type and location of loans the bank could make.
One former official recalled that Witt Stephens, after learning in 1988 that the bank had bought bonds from a rival financial institution, ended the practice even though the bank received better terms in its dealings with the third party than it was receiving from Stephens Inc.
Witt Stephens also earned commissions when the bank's trust department bought government bonds with the idle money it had to invest from municipal bonds it was handling for Stephens Inc., according to bankers. The tiny Stuttgart bank, with assets of around $120 million, handled as much as $200 million in Stephens-underwritten municipal bonds in its trust department.
Mr. Erwin, the bank's chairman, said he was unable to talk about the influence of Witt Stephens since he became chairman about the time of Witt's death.
A former Stuttgart bank official said that officials of the bank and Stephens Inc. were concerned that regulators might restrict the dealings between the bank and the brokerage firm. The Fed's first opportunity arose in 1984 when it reviewed an application by the Stephens and other stockholders to form a holding company, Investark Bankshares Inc., to acquire the Stuttgart bank
The application listed Stephens family holdings at 43 percent, when in fact they exceeded 60 percent, according to bankers, documents and Mr. Knight, the Stephens's lawyer. Records show the application was filed by Mr. Kennedy of the Rose firm. The holding company later disclosed in routine filings various Stephens stock holdings totaling well above 50 percent.
 
Issue Quietly Dropped
 An examination of the Stuttgart bank in 1991 by the Federal comptroller raised questions about the bank's ties to Stephens but the issue was quietly dropped, according to regulators and bankers, who say the handling of the 1991 examination is now part of the Fed inquiry.
The Stephenses first acquired stock in Worthen in 1983, after they were rebuffed from buying another Little Rock bank. Their application with the Fed to acquire the stock was handled by lawyers at the Rose firm, including Mr. Kennedy, according to public records. Because Worthen's stock is publicly traded, dealings between the bank and Stephens affiliates are subject to Federal disclosure.
In 1985, when Stephens Inc. underwrote a stock offering designed to help refinance the ailing bank, Worthen's dealings with the Rose firm, Stephens and Stephens' business partners took up several thousand words in the public offering circular.
The offering also said that the Comptroller of the Currency found that some of the transactions involving Stephens-related companies or foreign business associates violated banking laws.
A 1985 letter to Fed lawyers raising questions about the dealings between Stephens affiliates and Worthen received little attention within the Fed but now is receiving more attention in the current investigation.
Curt Bradbury, Worthen's chairman and president and formerly an official of Stephens Inc., denies that the Stephenses have a controlling influence in the bank. Worthen and Stephens Group Inc. have both told the Fed that the company and its subsidiaries "do not and will not exert control over the management or policies of Worthen," Mr. Bradbury said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Rally on Note Sale

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes shot higher yesterday afternoon after a surprisingly strong auction of five-year notes.
Traders said the rally, which sent the price of the 30-year bond up a point, was prompted by the strong demand for the 5-year note in the auction and in the trading that followed the announcement of the auction results around 2 P.M. 
 But traders said the jump in prices, which helped pull the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.92 percent from 7 percent Tuesday, did not signal a new direction for the market or indicate that the yield on the long bond was safely below 7 percent again. The yield broke above 7 percent last week and had held at 7 percent or above since Friday.
 
 
'Crazy Market'
 "We're still in a range," said Barbara L. Kenworthy, portfolio manager for taxable fixed-income funds at the Dreyfus Corporation. "All we have done is widen the range to 7.125 percent," she said, referring to the fact that the yield on the 30-year bond had popped over 7 percent several times recently.
But she also noted that while the market was stuck in a narrow range, it had remained volatile. "It has been a crazy market," she said, adding that some of the mood swings have been "to the moon."
The prices of other Treasury securities were also up sharply yesterday. The 10-year note rose 20/32 as the yield dropped to 6.08 percent from 6.16 percent. And the yield on the 2-year note auctioned Tuesday was also down sharply. The yield at the auction was 4.17 percent, but it rose to 4.2 percent by the close of trading Tuesday. Yesterday, the price of the new two-year note was up 5/32 as the yield fell to 4.14 percent.
Among the concerns of traders and investors are inflation, a threat that the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates to curb rising prices, the performance of the Clinton Administration and the fate of the President's economic program.
Yesterday's durable-goods report for April, which showed no increase after a steep 3.7 percent drop in March, signaled that the economy is still growing sluggishly. If that picture is borne out in the data for May, that should help ease the inflationary fears created by the surprisingly sharp jumps in both the Producer and Consumer Price Indexes for April.
In trading yesterday, the durables report had only a marginal impact when it was released in the morning because traders and investors were waiting for the results of the five-year note auction in the afternoon.
 
 
House Vote
 But the problems in Washington are continuing. While the market was rallying yesterday, traders were talking about the vote in the House of Representatives on the President's economic program that is scheduled for today. Even if the President and the Democratic leadership in the House prevail in a close vote, the deficit reduction plan still faces problems in the Senate, both from Democrats and Republicans.
What happened in the Treasury auction yesterday is that many traders who bid for five-year notes did not get any or as many as they anticipated. Ronald Connors, a senior managing director at Bear Stearns & Company, said that showed that traders were still having problems with the new auction system the Treasury is testing.
Like the two-year note auction Tuesday, the five-year note sale is being conducted under the Treasury experiment with single-price auctions. In these auctions, all securities are awarded at one price and yield rather than the sliding scales in the other Treasury auctions. Prices and yield move in opposite directions, with the yield dropping as the price rises.
The five-year notes were auctioned at a single yield of 5.39 percent. But only 8 percent of the bids were at this level with the rest at a lower yield. Because the yield in the when-issued, or pre-auction, market was 5.4 percent to 5.41 percent at the time of the 1 P.M. bidding deadline, it was clear that a lot of dealers did not get the bonds they wanted.
"Everyone figured they would get their notes at 39 or 40," said Mr. Connors, using market shorthand for bids of 5.39 percent and 5.4 percent.
This left a lot of dealers short of what they needed and set off a scramble for the new notes after the auction. The buying was persistent enough to drive the yield all the way down to 5.29 percent by the close of trading in the when-issued market.
The buying of five-year notes set off buying across the board. As the price of the 30-year bond rose, it broke through some important trading levels, which set off more buying by speculators and investors.

HEADLINE: Durable-Goods Orders Were Flat Last Month

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Too much inventory and too little enthusiasm for new investment spending seem to be taking some steam out of the nation's factories, a Government survey shows.
Orders for machinery, transportation equipment and other durable goods were flat in April, failing to recover from a sharp 3.7 percent drop in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. And shipments of durable goods actually fell 1.9 percent last month, a big drop. 
 That came as a surprise to economists and investors who had expected orders and shipments to bounce back. The evidence of a stalled economy helped support bond prices, which in turn sent stocks higher.
 
A Low-Gear Recovery
 "These numbers show the crosscurrents in the economic environment between companies' long-term commitment to becoming more competitive and companies' sitting on their hands until the final outcome of the tax battle," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Yesterday's report was the latest to show that the economic expansion is still stuck in low gear. The report dampened inflation fears a bit because it suggested that manufacturers would have trouble making price increases stick because of slack demand. But it stoked worries over production cuts and layoffs in coming months.
Indeed, the backlog of unfilled orders shrank for the second consecutive month, dropping to the lowest level in three and a half years.
"Orders are softening,"said Randall Eberts, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland. "We have this inventory overhang, and it hasn't been reflected in production schedules yet. There's going to be an adjustment."
 
Working Off Inventory
 Retailers and distributors got stuck with extra inventories in March when bad weather kept consumers home. Even though retail sales have been perking along since then, the pileup is taking a while to work off.
But economists and executives said the weakness in orders did not point to renewed recession. Orders for big-ticket manufactured goods tend to gyrate from month to month, and preliminary readings are often revised substantially. More important, orders remain at a reasonably high level, 10.4 percent higher this winter and spring than in the corresponding period last year.
Still, April orders were mostly weak across the board. Orders for primary metals fell for the third straight month; orders for transportation equipment slipped for the second straight month, and for the first time in months, orders for computers and office equipment nose dived.
The only gains were reported by makers of military gear, aircraft and electronic components. But, as Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch pointed out, military orders are on a long-term decline and despite the April gain, aircraft orders are a lot weaker than they were a year earlier.
The shrinking military industry and ailing airlines are also hurting machine-tool makers, many of whom are in Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Their orders are also being hurt by the recession in Europe.
"We're seeing some spurts and sputters due to uncertainty about what's happening," said Mr. Eberts at the Cleveland Fed. "Also, Europe, one of our major customers, is still slowing down."
 
Business Orders Slip
 There were hints in the durables report that the mini-boom in business investment of the last several quarters may be cooling a bit. Business orders for capital goods from laptop computers to turbines edged up 1.2 percent, a paltry gain given the steep 10.8 percent decline in March. Excluding aircraft, orders for capital goods slipped 1.7 percent.
Still, the National Association of Manufacturers expects capital spending by industry to rise 7 or 8 percent this year.
"No matter what Washington does about taxes," Mr. Jasinowski said, "there's a long-term commitment to invest to make us more competitive."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Jump But Taxables Are Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Average yields on tax-exempt money market funds were substantially higher in the latest period after a jump in all short-term interest rates, while the yields on taxable funds were down, according to the latest survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
Analysts at the Money Fund Report said investors probably believed that the Federal Reserve might be ready to raise short-term rates to stall inflation. The concern was strong enough last week to lower prices and consequently raise interest rates on the short end. 
 For the week ended Tuesday, yields on tax-exempt money market funds were up an average 14 basis points, as investors moved $780 million into the funds, bringing total assets to $102 billion. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Money managers held fast; the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in portfolios was unchanged at 48 for the third consecutive week.
IBC/Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt money market fund rose 15 basis points, to 2.18 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield up 14 basis points, to 2.15 percent. Analysts noted that for the last 30 days, the compounded yield was averaging 2.05 percent and the simple yield about 2.02 percent.
Excluding state and local taxes, the taxable-bond equivalent yield for the average seven-day yield for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket is 3.03 percent and about 3.16 percent for investors in the 31 percent bracket.
The Money Fund Report said that among the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund led for the fourth time in five weeks, producing a yield of 2.86 percent.
 
Taxable Funds
 For the week ended yesterday, the assets of taxable money market funds fell $2.1 billion, to $486.6 billion, as institutional funds again represented most of the cash outflow. The assets of the institutional funds declined $1.8 billion, to $170.8 billion.
The average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios was unchanged at 64 for the second straight week.
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund slipped a basis point, to 2.63 percent, with the seven-day simple yield down the same amount, to 2.59 percent. The compounded average yield over 30 days is 2.64 percent and 2.62 percent for a simple yield.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for the Money Fund Report, said there might be some small pickup in yields in the short run. "The only two things that could move interest rates higher over the long term," he added, "are if President Clinton's deficit-reducing package runs into trouble and inflation numbers start to form an inflationary trend."
The Dreyfus Basic Money Market fund provided the best return among general-purpose funds this week as it has over the last month, reporting a yield of 3.43 percent.
Banks, which compete directly with money market funds, are offering an average yield of 2.52 percent to depositors.

HEADLINE: Mixed Outlook From Fed

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 26

 BODY:
Two Federal Reserve policy makers gave a mixed reading of the nation's economic health today and forecast no immediate acceleration in the sluggish pace of job growth.
But neither Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federarl Reserve, nor Robert D. McTeer Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, who votes on the Fed's policy-setting committee, raised any flags that economic growth was in danger of faltering. 
 Mr. Greenspan said at a banking conference that the six-point slump in a consumer confidence index for May, to 61.5, reflected a slowdown in output from an unsustainably rapid pace late last year and was not a good indicator of future economic activity.
He said "exceptionally good" auto sales for mid-May countered the index's message that people were afraid to make significant financial commitments. Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks surged in mid-May to a 12.5 million annual rate from 11.1 million a year ago.
Mr. McTeer gave a similar reading of the economy, calling recent economic data mixed.
"The 50-miles-per-hour headwinds are probably down to 30 miles per hour," he said, adding, "I don't have the sense that the sustainability of the recovery is in danger."

HEADLINE: A Photo Center With a Huge Job Vacancy

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN

 BODY:
Although not wholly unexpected, Cornell Capa's announcement last week that he intended to step down as the director of the International Center of Photography in June 1994 took many people by surprise. The ebullient Mr. Capa, who founded the center in 1974 and has been as closely identified with it as Joseph Papp was with the New York Shakespeare Festival, recently turned 75, and he remains a seemingly tireless advocate for photography.
In an interview shortly before his announcement, though, Mr. Capa said he had grown weary of the administrative and fund-raising aspects of his job and was resigning to spend more time with his wife, Edie. 
 His departure will close another chapter in his own long and colorful career, which began in the 1930's in Paris, where he made prints for his brother, the celebrated photojournalist Robert Capa. But it also signals the beginning of what may be a difficult transition for the center, which must find a director resourceful enough to build on Mr. Capa's considerable achievements while moving the institution beyond his very long shadow. Indeed, it is a problem not unlike that faced by the Shakespeare Festival, which has gone through unsettled times since Papp's death.
Mr. Capa, however, is very much alive and is in every way the International Center of Photography's driving force. Under his leadership the center has grown into one of the foremost photography institutions in the country, if not the world. With a staff of 65 and an annual budget of $5.7 million, it offers major exhibitions both in its main building, a Georgian-style mansion on Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, and at I.C.P. Midtown, on the Avenue of the Americas at 43d Street. It attracts over 250,000 people a year to its programs and has built a permanent collection of more than 25,000 prints.
All in all, Mr. Capa seems to be leaving his successor a stable institution. The center has weathered the recession and has balanced its budget for the last 10 years. Moreover, it owns its main building outright and has a lease from the Eastman Kodak Company to rent its midtown space until 1999 for a dollar a year.
In some ways Mr. Capa is like a marvelous chef, with the center his ultimate souffle. "For 18 years I could do what I wanted," Mr. Capa said. "The shape of the programming, the exhibitions -- it's mine."
A very real question, though, is whether the next director will be able to keep this rich concoction on the rise. The center has no endowment and every year must raise nearly half its budget from corporate and individual sources, including American Express, Chase Manhattan Bank and Mobil.
The center also faces increased competition from other institutions in the city. When Mr. Capa began his venture, only the Museum of Modern Art, among the city's major museums, showed much interest in photography. But in recent months both the Whitney and the Guggenheim museums have begun to collect and exhibit photographs, joining the Modern and a revitalized program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
"With glamorous institutions like the Met and the Guggenheim getting involved in photography," Mr. Capa said, the center faces heavy competition for attention and support. "We have to be as attractive as they are, and that's difficult. What is our niche?"
With Mr. Capa's departure, the center will have to confront questions about its very identity. The center presents an eclectic mix of exhibitions, but it has always given special emphasis to documentary and commercial photography. In the last two years it has exhibited Roman Vishniac's photographs of Jews in Eastern Europe before World War II and a retrospective of work by Dmitri Baltermants, the Russian photojournalist, as well as exhibits by the portraitist Yousuf Karsh, by Sheila Metzner and Joyce Tenneson, the fashion photographers, and by Lois Greenfield, the dance photographer.
This emphasis on presenting photography that does not fit into current definitions of art reflects Mr. Capa's own prejudices. "I don't like the gallery art of photography as I see it now," he said. "The photography I'm interested in is urgent. It's humanistic and concerned."
Nevertheless, other staff members have organized shows that feature work by a new generation of art photographers. "Special Collections," shown last year, included work by John Baldessari, Christian Boltanski and other well-known artists; "Commodity Image," at I.C.P. Midtown through July 18, presents photos by such 80's gallery stars as Cindy Sherman, Richard Prince and Barbara Kruger.
Exhibitions of this sort are more in keeping with shows put on by the Modern, the Met and the Whitney, which tend to view photography as part of contemporary art. Depending on one's point of view, I.C.P.'s eclectic programs can be seen as a celebration of photography's diversity or as a confused attempt to blend essentially incompatible directions in the field.
A basic question the center has never adequately addressed, though, is whether exhibitions are the most appropriate form in which to present journalistic or commercial photographs. Out of the context of magazine layouts and advertisements, they risk being seen simply as esthetic objects, with their social message obscured.
The immediate task facing the center is to find someone to fill Mr. Capa's capacious shoes. Many of the decisions in that process will fall to the board, which has been headed since 1989 by Jill Rose, a photography collector and the wife of Marshall Rose, the chairman of the New York Public Library. Not surprisingly, though, Mr. Capa himself will have a big say in choosing his successor. At its meeting last week the board formed a search committee, with Mr. Capa and Mrs. Rose among its members. A prime criterion in selecting a new director, Mr. Capa said, will be to find "someone who can operate by the seat of his or her pants, someone capable of showing us how to live in the new world" in which photography finds itself today.
Both Mr. Capa and Mrs. Rose expressed their determination to continue the center's focus on documentary photography. That emphasis, Mrs. Rose said, is "the concept that we began with and that sets us apart from other institutions."
In some ways the center can be seen as the ultimate proof of Mr. Capa's devotion to his brother. In 1954 Robert Capa was killed while on assignment in Vietnam. "From that day," Mr. Capa said, "I was haunted by the question of what happens to the work a photographer leaves behind, by how to make the work stay alive."
Born into a middle-class Budapest family, the brothers were remarkably close, to the point of sharing the same pseudonym. After following his brother to Paris in 1936 Mr. Capa dropped the family name, Friedmann, and adopted his brother's new last name, which was based on the name of the movie director Frank Capra.
Mr. Capa also followed his brother into photography, printing for him in Paris and New York, and then picking up a camera himself. He worked as a staff photographer for Life magazine from 1946 until 1954, when he joined Magnum, the photojournalists' cooperative. He continued to shoot assignments around the world until founding I.C.P. in 1974.
But the question of how to preserve the images of his brother and other photographers remained. In 1966 Mr. Capa set up the International Fund for Concerned Photography to promote the work of photojournalists and documentary photographers, and by the early 1970's he had begun to look for a permanent base for his activities in support of photography that is characterized, as he termed it, by a "concern for mankind."
When a landmark red-brick Fifth Avenue mansion built in 1915 for Willard Straight, the founder of The New Republic, became available in 1974, Mr. Capa was able to scrape together a down payment on the bargain-basement purchase price of $550,000.
The new institution opened that November amid a splash of publicity, including a Talk of the Town item in The New Yorker written by Jacqueline Onassis, whom Mr. Capa had photographed in the 1960's and described as "a very good neighbor." With that glitzy send-off, I.C.P. was well launched into the often tricky world of New York museums.
The thought that the center might now have to become an institution, with the stability and staidness that the term implies, does not sit well with Mr. Capa. "I'm afraid it may be true," he said. "But I'll do my best not to let it happen."
"We have to remain different," Mr. Capa added. "We are not just another museum." Whatever happens after he leaves, he said, he hopes the center will remain "an alternative something."

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
FROM an outsider's perspective, it would seem that the couple's children had done well. Their 30-year-old son was a manager in a high-technology firm. Their daughter, a 26-year-old lawyer who had recently become pregnant, had decided to take time away from practicing law until after her child was born. Both young adults were well educated and financially successful.
But in their parents' eyes, the children were failures. Their son had not married and was devoting his energies to his work. Their daughter was a disappointment because she'd temporarily given up her law practice to share more time with her family. Neither had followed the schedule or path their parents had envisioned for them. 
 The problem was not with what the young adults were doing with their lives but with how their choices differed from their parents' expectations. "Parents like this are holding an immense amount of responsibility for their children's behaviors as adults," said Dr. William S. Pollack, a psychologist at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass., and instructor in psychiatry at Harvard Medical School.
"It's a way of not letting go. Sometimes all the parents want is something good for their child, but they are too inflexible over what is good."
Parental expectations begin early. Parents who look into their newborn baby's eyes often see unbounded potential. They also see reflections of their own lives, a chance to correct old mistakes and to improve upon successes.
"We each have an assumed timetable for our children," said Dr. Nancy K. Schlossberg, a professor of counselor education at the University of Maryland at College Park. "But no child grows up according to her parents' timetable."
Those images change as parents note their children's true skills and interests. The son who was given a tiny bat and ball on his first birthday will never be good enough to play for the Yankees. The daughter who was supposed to follow in her father's footsteps as a physician is more interested in art.
Parents' aspirations for their children also change as they take into account the differences between the social and economic pressures they faced as young adults and those their children face. Today's young adults will probably marry and have children later than their parents did. They're less able to buy a house without help and more likely to come back to their parents' home to live.
Still, there are parents who stick to their own agendas for their children's lives.
"The more disappointed you are in your own life, no matter how objectively successful you are, the more you'll turn to your child to succeed where you couldn't," said Dr. Eleanor Bromberg, an associate professor of social work at Hunter College in Manhattan. "But it's never possible for a child to make up for the deficits in the parent's life."
A result of trying to live out a parent's unfulfilled dreams is usually frustration for both generations. But the reasons for viewing a child as a failure are not always that obvious. The transition to adulthood marks a change not only for adolescents but for their parents as well. It's difficult for some parents to step back from their children's lives, to allow them to choose their own course and to make mistakes.
For others, staying overly involved in their children's adult lives keeps them from facing how their own lives must change. It can be a way of denying the shift in their roles within the family, and a way of feeling needed. This attitude is most often seen in adults who view themselves primarily as parents. Allowing their children to grow up becomes a threat to their self-image.
Ironically, for some young adults, not succeeding in their parents' eyes can be a source of power rather than shame.
"If it's so important to you that your child do well, you need to look at whether that child can punish or rebel against you by not living up to your expectations," said Dr. Jerrold Lee Shapiro, an associate professor of counseling psychology at Santa Clara University in California, and the author of "The Measure of a Man: Becoming the Father You Wish Your Father Had Been" (1993, Delacorte Press, $22.95).
In these families, the young adults are trapped in the rebelliousness of early adolescence, desperately trying to assert their independence by rejecting their parents.
"Adulthood," Dr. Bromberg said, "is about renegotiating relationships."
 
Talking About Failure and Disappointment
 IT'S difficult to talk about feelings of failure, as if putting words to the emotions will make the situation worse. "You have to ask yourself what it means to you personally that your child is a disappointment," said Dr. Jerrold Lee Shapiro, an associate professor of counseling psychology at Santa Clara University in California. "Does it mean that you're a failure? Does it mean that what you've accomplished won't be passed on to the next generation?"
The answers to those questions are often a good way to begin a discussion with your family. Often, the parents have to broach the topic.
"If your children have made a bad decision about how to live their lives, they may be afraid that if they talk to you, they'll hear a lot of 'I told you so,' " said Dr. Sandra J. Eller, a psychologist and clinical assistant professor of psychiatry at the University of Rochester Medical Center. "You have to resist the urge to rub your child's nose in the problem."
Here are some other things to keep in mind when talking to your children about these feelings:
Look for ways in which your children have met your aspirations for them.
These may not be obvious. A girl who was taught to be tenacious in the parents' hope that she would become a lawyer may use that quality to get work as a musician. While some parents may think of that as a failure, it's actually a sign of success, for it shows how, as an adult, she could apply her parents' values to her life.
Acknowledge your children's maturity.
Doing so is important, even if you disagree with some of the choices they've made. It helps avoid falling into parent-child roles that are no longer appropriate.
"Parents have to take responsibility for their own feelings of disappointment," Dr. Eller said. "There's often grieving that comes along with letting go of some of those dreams."
Keep your advice to yourself.
Young adults need to make their own choices and mistakes if they are to mature. "Listen respectfully," Dr. Eller said, "but leave your child to solve her problems in her own way. Don't rush in with solutions. Patient listening can be more helpful than giving advice."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at New Low vs. Yen; Gold and Silver Prices Drop

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell to yet another record low against the Japanese yen yesterday as declining United States interest rates and fresh signs of a sluggish economy undermined the currency.
The dollar's slide came despite efforts by United States and Japanese officials to end speculation that the Clinton Administration is seeking an even stronger Japanese yen. 
 Gold and silver prices also declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for June delivery fell $3.40 an ounce, to settle at $375.30. Silver for July delivery lost 8 cents, to $4.563 an ounce.
The dollar ended the day in New York at 108.50 yen, down from 109.35 yen on Tuesday, although it traded yesterday as low as 108.42 yen. Its five-month decline gained momentum Tuesday after a Treasury report suggested that a stronger yen could reduce the United States trade deficit with Japan.
 
A Bid to Stop the Slide
Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, tried to arrest the plunge in the dollar by saying the United States was not seeking a stronger yen. But dealers were not convinced as the Federal Reserve failed to buy dollars to back up Mr. Summers's statements.
"The market believes that whatever the U.S. says in public, what it really wants is to see the yen higher," said Troy Bowler, chief economist at Bank of Tokyo Capital Markets in London.
Earlier yesterday in Tokyo, attempts by the Bank of Japan to support the dollar when it fell below 109 yen were foiled by matching sales by dealers. Two institutions alone sold $2 billion, Tokyo traders said. The dollar fell to 108.65 yen in Tokyo, from 110.56 yen Tuesday.
Dealers predicted the dollar could fall to 107.50 yen, an important resistance point, in the next few days.
The dollar also fell to 1.6283 German marks in late New York trading, from 1.6305 marks late Tuesday. The British pound settled at $1.5485 in New York, up from $1.5435 Tuesday.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Dollar Continues Fall
 TOKYO, Thursday, May 27 (Bloomberg Business News) -- The dollar continued its plunge against the yen here today, hitting a new low of 107.83 at midday, compared with an opening of 108.65 yen.
The dollar was being sold throughout Asia.
"We're into uncharted territory," said Paul Kammel, manager for corporate business on the currency trading desk at Westpac Bank in Sydney. "The market wants to take the dollar lower. Selling is coming from all quarters."

HEADLINE: Guatemala's Do-It-Yourself Coup

 BODY:
It's the latest fashion in Latin American authoritarianism, and it seems to be catching. Following the path marked out by President Alberto Fujimori of Peru 13 months ago, President Jorge Serrano of Guatemala enlisted the army Tuesday to help him abolish Congress, the courts and the Constitution. His purpose was to stifle criticism of his economic austerity policies.
Unless the hemisphere's democratic governments respond more effectively this time than they have in the past, Latin America's recent political gains could begin slipping away. 
 Guatemala's democracy, like Peru's, was badly flawed. In both countries a white elite dominates an Indian and mixed-race majority, powerful armies trample human rights and resist civilian control and corruptible courts mock the idea of impartial justice.
But in Guatemala as in Peru, yet another army-backed coup, combined with a clampdown on the press and other independent voices, makes a bad situation even worse. In Peru, escalating Shining Path terrorism and a badly discredited congressional opposition at least gave Mr. Fujimori a plausible pretext for betraying democracy. In Guatemala, Mr. Serrano can claim no such excuses.
The Clinton Administration, which quickly condemned the coup, should now move to halt Guatemala's $60 million in U.S. aid. Meanwhile, the Organization of American States is preparing for an emergency meeting. But that probably won't be enough to turn the tide. Similar moves after the Peruvian coup brought only a small concession, the election of a new constituent assembly. Mr. Serrano has already promised to take that step on his own.
The failure of hemisphere governments to restore democracy in Peru, and their even more glaring failure in Haiti, have encouraged authoritarians elsewhere. Guatemala's do-it-yourself coup is one obvious result. Military rumblings in oil-rich Venezuela, and now in Brazil, Latin America's largest and economically most important democracy, are further ominous signs.
Two years ago, at the high-water mark of Latin democratization, member countries of the Organization of American States pledged to take active steps to protect their proud democratic achievements. Without resolute and aggressive steps against Mr. Serrano's seizure of power, that pledge will be proved meaningless.

HEADLINE: Can the Democrats Govern?

 BODY:
A lot will be on the line when the House votes on President Clinton's budget, possibly as early as today. The fight is nominally over such economic issues as deficit reduction, tax hikes, Medicare cuts, subsidies for low-paid workers and investment in a high-tech future. But what's really at issue is the credibility of the Democrats as a governing party.
If, after regaining the White House from 12 years of Republican rule, the Democrats now split apart and let the new President's budget tumble, they will be portraying themselves as too disorganized to govern. In 1992 voters delivered a verdict on divided government. They put Democrats in charge of the White House and Congress to end gridlock and deliver action. 
 The vote is uncertain because some moderate and conservative Democrats are threatening to sabotage the budget over one myopic demand or another. Representatives from oil-producing states don't want higher energy taxes. Conservatives demand a smaller government -- which requires, they say, an ironclad ceiling on entitlement spending.
The Clinton plan, while hardly perfect, is the only proposal with a chance of majority support that would take a sizable chunk out of the deficit, protect the poor and invest in infrastructure and education. True, it's not the final step toward fiscal prudence; lots more will have to be done four or five years out. But it's a first, important step.
Two issues stand in the way of Democrats mustering a majority in favor of the Clinton plan. Oil-state lawmakers like Senator David Boren of Oklahoma demand that Mr. Clinton's energy tax, which applies to the heat content of fuels, be scrapped or at least substantially modified. Conservatives, led by Charles Stenholm of Texas, demand that government be further downsized, starting with a cap on entitlements -- the part of the budget that rises automatically without annual review and has been exploding out of control.
Neither of these issues need undermine Democratic solidarity. If Messrs. Boren and Stenholm and their friends truly want a deficit-reduction package, compromises are readily at hand.
Senator Boren and others charge that the B.T.U. tax that Mr. Clinton proposes, which would account for more than 25 percent of the $250 billion tax hike, would put U.S. businesses that use lots of energy to manufacture their products at a competitive disadvantage. A possible solution is to levy the tax also on imports while exempting U.S. exports, if that can be made consistent with trade rules.
On entitlements, Mr. Clinton wisely rejects a simple cap because it would trigger across-the-board cutbacks aimed at the elderly, poor and disabled who are the primary recipients of entitlement spending. It would also risk throwing the economy into deeper recession, because entitlement spending on welfare and unemployment insurance rises during economic downturns and helps maintain consumer purchasing power.
Mr. Clinton offers a sensible compromise: If entitlements run above target, he would propose compensating spending cuts and revenue hikes that Congress would have to consider. An even better answer would be for Congress to cut specific entitlement programs directly.
But the crux of today's vote is governance. The Democrats told voters they were ready to take over and function like a party. If they show today that they aren't, voters are unlikely to forget that next year.

HEADLINE: Dow, Up 23.53 Points, Sets Another Record

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A dip in interest rates helped the stock market surge yesterday, establishing a record high for the Dow Jones industrial average in heavy trading.
Analysts said stocks became a more attractive investment as prices for long-term Treasury bonds rose and their yields fell below 7 percent. 
 Gold, a traditional refuge in nervous economic conditions, fell after reports that Russia had more gold than traders had expected. Gold stocks closed mixed.
"There's a lot of cash around," said Bernard J. Spilko, managing director of Julius Baer Securities. "And bonds, baseball cards, art on the wall, and gold in a safety deposit box just aren't delivering, so equities become the place to be."
 
Several Indexes Advance
 The 30-stock Dow industrial average rose 23.53 points, to an all-time high of 3,540.16. But unlike last week, when the blue-chip stock index set a record high that the rest of the market failed to follow, other major indexes with a wider variety of stocks also advanced yesterday.
The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 4.59 points, to 453.44, approaching the March 10 record of 456.34. The Nasdaq composite index, led by high-technology stocks, rose a sharp 9.05 points to 704.09. The American Stock Exchange market value index, despite being weighted with gold stocks, rose 3.06 points to 437.13.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index also rose sharply 2.20 points to 249.90. Gaining stocks on the Big Board outnumbered losers by a two-to-one margin. Exchange volume totaled 278.8 million shares compared with Tuesday's 222.1 million.
The Dow was lifted by a wide variety of stocks, with 20 out of the 30 component stocks rising. The International Business Machines Corporation was the leading winner in the Dow and also the second most-active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, with 4.05 million shares changing hands.
I.B.M. closed up 2 3/8, to 52 3/4, partly because of an analyst's remarks that investors saw as positive. Daniel Mandresh of Merrill Lynch & Company said he expected as many as 70,000 layoffs by year's end, up from the 40,000 he previously estimated. He also said he thought that I.B.M.'s personal computer and disk-drive businesses were improving.
 
Intel Jumps 6 3/4 Points
 The Standard & Poor's 500 was led by Intel, which closed up 6 3/4, to 110 1/2, after another Merrill Lynch analyst raised his earnings estimates for the company.
The S.& P. 500 was moved by another high-technology stock, Motorola, which closed up 3 7/8, to 82 5/8. It rose on no discernible news, but may have risen in sympathy with I.B.M. and Microsoft, which rose 4, to 95 1/4, on favorable publicity about its new NT software.
But the major trading activity again centered on Spectrum Information Technologies, down 1 3/8, to 4, on volume of 13.6 million shares, as well as on Novell, down 2 3/8, to 29 7/8, on 13 million shares.
Spectrum's troubles stem from shareholder suits and other problems from the recent speculative frenzy about the company's stock. Analysts downgraded Novell's stock partly because its quarterly earnings only met their expectations rather than exceeded them. There were also doubts that its Netware 4.0 software would sell as briskly as expected.
American depositary receipts for shares of British Petroleum rose 5/8, to 58 3/8, after B.P. announced the sale of a consumer-products unit. It was the Big Board's most active issue, with volume of 10.47 million shares.

HEADLINE: Ruling Seen To Weaken Layoff Law

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
A Federal judge has ruled that the General Dynamics Corporation did not violate a Federal law requiring most employers to notify workers in advance of a mass layoff when it furloughed 3,000 workers in 1991 after the Navy canceled the $57 billion A-12 Avenger warplane program.
The ruling appears to reduce the protection for workers and widen a legal loophole that employers, particularly military contractors, may use to avoid issuing warning notices, legal and industry experts said yesterday. 
 Federal District Judge Jean C. Hamilton in St. Louis ruled on Monday that General Dynamics was not liable for an estimated $12 million in back-pay claims by 1,200 former employees, who had filed suit.
Even though General Dynamics executives knew the program was over budget and irrevocably delayed, the judge ruled that "in the unique context of defense contracting, a contractor exercising commercially reasonable business judgment would not necessarily conclude on the basis of this information that the A-12 contract would be cancelled."
 
'Creates a Larger Loophole'
 The ruling "does not bode well for defense workers," said Julie Hurwitz, director of the National Lawyers Guild's Sugar Law Center for Economic and Social Justice in Detroit.
The group has monitored an estimated 100 cases filed since the Worker Adjustment and Retaining Notification Act, known as the Warn Act, became law in 1989. The law requires employers to warn employees 60 days before a mass layoff instead of simply giving them severance pay. Companies are exempt if the warning would result in a business failure or if the layoff was not forseeable.
"It creates a larger loophole than had already existed for companies to get around giving notice," Ms. Hurwitz said. "It also reduces worker protection that the Warn Act had afforded."
The A-12 Avenger warplane program, the largest weapons program ever terminated by the Pentagon, ultimately cost General Dynamics and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation about 9,000 jobs.
The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which filed the suit against General Dynamics, settled a similar case out of court with McDonnell Douglas, said Stephen E. Tallent, a Washington lawyer for General Dynamics. Both military contractors still face suits, contending similar issues, filed by non-union employees.
 
Conditions for Military Contractor
 Mr. Tallent said the ruling clarifies under what conditions a military contractor must notify its employees of a probable layoff. "Otherwise, every time the Government barks, you would have to issue a warning notice," he said. "It would mean issuing them very frequently and most would be disregarded and a real one wouldn't be believed."
Forcing a military contractor to issue warning notices whenever a Congressional committee threatened to cut spending would have a harmful consequence, Mr. Tallent said. "Then you will lose the best part of your work force and when it turns out to be a false alarm, you haven't got the employees," he said.
Rod Tanner, a lawyer for the machinists union, said the union is considering whether to appeal the ruling. "We're disappointed," he said.
Lawrence Korb, a former Defense Department under secretary who was called as an expert witness by the machinists, said the ruling strips protection for employees of military contractors intended by the Warn Act. "It seems to me, if you're in the defense business, you don't have to comply," he said.

HEADLINE: Relax! There's Still Time To Shop for a Summer Camp

BYLINE: By CARIN RUBENSTEIN

 BODY:
EVELYN LEE, 38, a single working mother in Stamford, Conn., depends on summer camp to occupy her two children every year. It wasn't until a few weeks ago, however, that she realized that "I had completely spaced out and forgotten to send in the camp applications."
Believing she had missed the deadline, she panicked. 
 Other parents may also assume that if it is May, then it is too late to get their children into summer camp.
But that is not true, especially if parents are willing to be flexible. After all, there are 8,500 day and overnight camps in this country, says the American Camping Association, a nonprofit organization that provides referrals to its accredited camps.
"There is such an enormous variety of camps, it's certainly not too late to find one suitable for your child," said Laurie Edelman, executive director of the New York section of the association.
Sally Ziegler, executive director of the Child Care Council of Westchester, a nonprofit child-care referral agency in White Plains, said that although two years ago "most camps were full by May," only a few of the 111 licensed day camps in Westchester County are full right now.
Several camp-referral experts said that camps seem to be filling up slowly this year, perhaps because of a weak economy. Parents may even find that space is still available in their camp of first choice, Ms. Edelman said, although they may not be able to get the weeks they want.
Because there are so many camps, Ms. Edelman suggested that parents limit their choices to four or five. "We recommend that parents don't consider 12 camps, since they will just get confused," she said.
To her great relief, Ms. Lee did not have to fret long about her memory lapse. Not long ago, her daughter, 14, and her son, 12, were accepted at their camps of choice.
Summer camp fees tend to be highest in the Northeast, industry experts said. Day camps in the New York area range from $75 to $400 a week; transportation and lunch are not always included. Overnight camps cost from $200 to $600 a week.
"Camp sounds expensive," Ms. Lee said, "but try keeping children busy on a day-to-day basis."
Agency and not-for-profit camps tend to be less expensive than private camps, since their fees are subsidized by donations. Low-cost camps include those sponsored by the Y.M.C.A., Girl Scouts and religious organizations. Some private camps offer scholarships based on the ability to pay. Although most financial aid may have been allocated for this year, Ms. Edelman said, parents who can't afford camp should still inquire about scholarships for this year or next.
Less expensive alternatives include town camps, usually reserved for resident children only. There are also a variety of short-term, specialty camps run by nature centers, zoos, historical societies and museums.
Since most day camps run from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M., working parents should ask about the availability of extended hours. Camps that offer this service usually charge an extra fee.
The American Camping Association is still accepting requests for information about camp this summer and will continue to do so through August.
Based on a child's interests and needs, an association specialist will help parents determine what kind of camp is best and will suggest four or five possibilities. The specialist will notify each camp, and parents will receive camp packets at no charge. An A.C.A. specialist familiar with 250 accredited overnight and day camps in the Northeast is available at (800) 777-CAMP. For A.C.A. referrals in other parts of the country, the number is (800) 428-CAMP.
The national network of child-care resource and referral agencies also provides free information about local camps. Child Care Inc., a nonprofit agency in New York City, lists 2,000 camps in the New York metropolitan area; information is available at (212) 929-4999. The Child Care Council of Westchester, (914) 761-3456, makes referrals to day camps in Westchester. Child Care Aware, at (800) 424-2246, provides information on referral agencies nationwide.
Ideally, parents should plan now for the summer of 1994, Ms. Edelman said. "Make an appointment while camp is in session this year, to get an idea about how campers and counselors interact, who the children are, and what kind of supervision they receive," she added.
 
Camp Scouting
 THE American Camping Association publishes a "1993/94 Guide to Accredited Camps" that includes advice on how to select a camp. Copies, at $10.95 each, are available from the New York office: (800) 777-CAMP.
Included are key questions to ask a camp director:
How old are the counselors and how many children does each one supervise?
What activities are required? Do children have a choice of special activities?
How often do children take trips and what transportation is provided? Is there an extra charge for this?
What medical services are available at the camp and nearby?
Does the camp provide references of parents whose children have attended the camp?

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: A Victory Most Precious;
Breathlessly Narrow, Desperately Needed, Clinton's Triumph in the House Buys Time

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Standing on the burning deck, President Clinton sailed his ship to victory in the House of Representatives tonight. It was a harrowingly narrow victory, desperately needed after months of adversity, hard won.
It was not decisive, but the Administration gained time to prepare itself for other, harder battles ahead. 
 Perhaps the most important aspect of the week's performance by the Clinton legislative team, headed by the President himself, was its new-found single-mindedness. Awakened late to the danger faced by the economic plan upon which so much depends, the team did the analysis, deployed its troops and worked day and night, perhaps not with perfect skill but with enough. It was a far cry from the feckless performance that cost the Administration its stimulus package last month.
 
Momentum May Shift
 For a time at least, less will be heard from the chorus of critical voices comparing Mr. Clinton to the two other Democratic Presidents of the last 30 years, Lyndon B. Johnson and Jimmy Carter, who left town with heads hanging.
If Mr. Clinton and his associates can repeat in the Senate what they did in the House this week -- prowling the corridors, cutting deals, working the phones -- they may actually get their tax and spending package. And if they can keep up the momentum, they may even have a chance of hitting big casino: carrying out an effective reform of the nation's faltering health-care system, which, as the President said this morning, would be one of the major legislative accomplishments of his generation.
To do either of those things, Mr. Clinton will need to continue repairing his bridges to the moderate and conservative Democrats who, having backed him last year because they considered him one of them, have come to see him this year as an apostate. As they did under President Ronald Reagan, who wooed them so effectively, they hold the balance in both houses and the country at large.
A very great deal was at stake as the clerk called the roll in the House this evening -- far more than usual on votes that wear that weary label, "pivotal." Representative David R. Obey, a dour Democrat from Wisconsin, said with pardonable hyperbole before the vote, "Life ends after today if this doesn't pass, in my view."
Had the first Democratic budget in a dozen years been rejected in the House, with the Democrats in control there more securely than in the Senate, with the rules more favorable to them than in the Senate, the smell of failure -- of yet another Presidency turning sour -- would have been overpowering. Mr. Clinton must have sensed that keenly, because he frantically called recalcitrant legislators almost to the last minute.
"This vote is about whether we as a nation can govern, whether we can eliminate the gridlock of the last 12 years," said Representative Bill Richardson, Democratof New Mexico, during the debate today.
But in fact it was about whether the Democrats can govern, given the dominant role in both the White House and Congress that they were awarded last November. The Clinton Administration's legislative, diplomatic, political and symbolic fumbles of the last four months have led many people -- including many who wish the Democrats well -- to doubt whether they had completely lost the knack of running things, and there is nothing more corrosive, nothing more self-perpetuating in Washington than a reputation for incompetence.
Ross Perot did what he could, in an interview taped on Tuesday, to sharpen that image of Mr. Clinton. He mocked the President's qualifications for the job, dismissing him as an out-of-touch "middle manager" who might get by in Arkansas but would never do in Washington.
In normal times, that might be dismissed as sour grapes from a man whom Mr. Clinton defeated. But the Texan's standing in the opinion polls has held up over the last six months while the President's has plummeted, with his approval rating dipping below 50 percent in a pair of national surveys only this week.
In the negotiations that ended early this morning and made House passage possible, the President conceded the point that Mr. Perot and the new Democrats have been making for weeks: that larger spending cuts and smaller tax increases were needed.
He accepted a new mechanism for checking increases in Medicare and other Federal programs, which may or may not work, dropped a request for more money for White House salaries and hinted, though not broadly enough for some, that the energy tax would be scaled back to make it acceptable to powerful Senators from oil-producing states.
 
Donning Common Clothes
 Mr. Clinton also did what he could during a two-hour question-and-answer session on CBS this morning to put his populist clothes back on. He ridiculed a suggestion that he had gone Hollywood, said he wore a cheap watch even if he got $200 haircuts from a tony Beverly Hills trimmer and tried hard to dissociate himself from the bungled changes in the White House travel office.
Addressing the issue that started many of the traditionalists among his supporters along the road to disenchantment, the President walked away from the homosexual pressure groups who are demanding that he keep his campaign promises of full integration of gay men and lesbians into the armed forces. He identified himself instead with the calls for compromise issued by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and Representative Barney Frank, the openly homosexual Massachusetts liberal.
In fact, Mr. Clinton seemed eager to suggest that he had never much liked homosexuality as a way of life, anyway -- a suggestion that Mr. Frank said struck him as gratuitous.
The President has yet to show the country that he can get the stars out of his eyes. He has yet to demonstrate that he and his inexperienced White House staff can stop making silly mistakes and keep the nation's attention focused on the main chance.
He must still do a lot of careful negotiating, keeping the liberals reasonably happy while pacifying the conservatives. And he must persuade the country that the new taxes are fair, necessary and solidly committed to reducing the deficit.
Even as he crowed in victory in the White House Rose Garden late tonight, President Clinton was careful to fix his gaze not only on what had been won, but on what remained to be won.
"Tonight the House said yes to jobs, yes to lowering the deficit, yes to lower interest rates and yes to a brighter future," Mr. Clinton said. "Tomorrow, we go back to the Senate and back to the country.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BACKS A GAY COMPROMISE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
President Clinton today endorsed a compromise on ending the ban on homosexuals in the military, emphasizing that the Government should not "appear to be endorsing a gay life style."
The President offered support for the approach of "don't ask, don't tell" -- the label given to a range of plans that would allow homosexuals to serve but leave limits on how open they could be about their sexuality. 
 "We almost have a compromise here," Mr. Clinton said in a nationally televised question-and-answer session with tourists this morning in the White House Rose Garden. "Most Americans believe if you don't ask and you don't say and you're not forced to confront it, people should be able to serve."
 
A Distancing Tactic
 The President's remarks on homosexuals in the military, which came in response to a question from a pastor who said he was worried about Christian values, seemed calculated to put some distance between himself and gay rights groups.
"We are trying to work this out so that our country does not -- I understand what you're saying -- so that our country does not appear to be endorsing a gay life style," he said. "But we accept people as people, and give them a chance to serve if they play by the rules."
Mr. Clinton's remarks came toward the end of two-hour appearance on "CBS This Morning" in which he probably endured the most aggressive questioning in such a forum on a variety of topics, including these:
*He confirmed that he would extend China's favorable trade status for one year to help that country's modernization drive. But he said any future renewal would depend on the China's making gains on human rights.
*He blamed reporters for making too much of the expensive haircut he got on Air Force One, delaying traffic at the Los Angeles International Airport. "I mean look, I wear a $40 watch," he said. "Do I look like the kind of guy that would go and sit on an airport? You know it was just a blow up." In jest, he added, "I'm glad they didn't find out about the manicure."
*He defended his aides' calling in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to examine accusations of mismanagement at the White House travel office, a move that was done without the knowledge of Attorney General Janet Reno. Mr. Clinton said that while there was no policy to alert the Attorney General on internal White House matters, he would do so in the future "because I trust her."
*He was unenthusiastic when asked whether the cost of abortion should be covered in a national health care package, saying no decision had been made. He said a broad package was essential rather than a limited one "that's not worth a nickel."
*He said it was "absolutely not true" that his Administration had become infatuated with Hollywood and celebrities. Questioning why the reporters focused on two meetings in the White House with celebrities, he said, "When my preacher from Arkansas stayed here, nobody wrote it up."
Mr. Clinton did not spell out any policy specifics. But his comments mark what some gay rights groups today called a retreat from his campaign pledge to fully overturn the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces.
 
Different Meanings
 As for the issue of homosexuals in the military, proponents of "don't ask, don't tell" have used the term to mean different things.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, has argued for a policy in which the military would not ask members of the armed forces about their sexual orientation, and opposes their being open about their homosexuality, on or off duty.
Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat who is open about his own homosexuality, has pressed for a far more lenient policy in which homosexuals could be open about their sexual orientation off duty but silent while on duty. But the various proposals are all based on a sense that Congress would not allow homosexuals to serve openly without restrictions.
At the Pentagon, where officials have until July 15 to deliver a proposal on the issue to the White House, officials said they were toying with language that is closer to Mr. Frank's recommendation. But they also said they were still trying to determine how to impose consistent regulations guiding the activities of servicemen and servicewomen on and off duty.
Mr. Frank, who angered many gay rights groups last week when he proposed a compromise, said he did not know if the President was accepting his proposal. But he, as did some homosexual groups, objected to Mr. Clinton's comments today on life style.
"It seemed to me somewhat gratuitous," he said. "One theory is that he is saying that as cover" so he can move ahead and press for allowing homosexuals in the military.
Speaking tonight on the Senate floor, Mr. Nunn commended the President, saying that he had "made it clear that any resolution of this debate should not appear to be endorsing any particular life style."
While he spoke only generally about Mr. Clinton's comments, the Senator flatly rejected Mr. Frank's proposal, asserting that permitting members of the armed forces to be open about their homosexuality off base would provide a "safe haven for homosexual conduct," leading to "a dramatic liberalization of military standards."
Today's remarks were the first in two months that Mr. Clinton has spoken extensively about homosexuals in the military, an issue that has dogged him since his election. Pentagon officials said the Administration had all but abandoned any consideration of separating troops by sexual orientation.
Although it had been clear that Defense Department officials and lawmakers were moving toward a consensus, some homosexual organizations criticized Mr. Clinton today for saying he was willing to accept some form of the "don't ask, don't tell" approach.
" 'Don't ask, don't tell' does not lift the ban, it simply reformulates it, and does so in an 'Alice in Wonderland' fashion," said Thomas B. Stoddard, coordinator of the Campaign for Military Service. "At its essence, it says that soldiers can continue to serve if they're gay so long as they pretend not to be gay."
While Mr. Clinton had toyed with addressing the nation on the eve of the House vote on his economic package, White House officials decided instead to accept a long-standing offer to appear today on "CBS This Morning."
Advisers to the President say he is often at his best taking questions from the public. But today he was often on the defensive.
In addressing the controversy over his haircut, he said he asked Secret Service agents whether "anybody would be held up or inconvenienced and I was told, 'No.' " He added: "I'd never do that. Not in 100 years. Not ever. I mean, I wasn't raised that way."
Mr. Clinton elaborated: "I think you've got to learn to laugh at things like that. You know, when little things get made big and big things get made little, you know, and you make a boner." He added that "if you didn't have a sense of humor in this business, you'd be grounded down to nothing pretty quick."
