HEADLINE: Guatemalan's Power Grab Brings Street Protests

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, May 27

 BODY:
Demonstrators took to the streets for the first time today to protest President Jorge Serrano Elias's use of dictatorial powers, and the United States cut off most of its aid to Guatemala.
The protests were tentative and relatively small, but they seemed to raise tensions quickly after two days in which it was often difficult to tell from the city's movements that anything had changed. The appearance of hundreds of demonstrators outside the Supreme Court building that Mr. Serrano shut down on Tuesday was enough to draw scores of military policemen and several armored vehicles. 
 After a clandestine meeting today of about 70 legislators, leaders of the Congress, which Mr. Serrano also dissolved, issued an unusual call for military intervention. In a statement distributed by the human rights office of the Roman Catholic Church, the legislators appealed to the military "to assume its historic and patriotic role and reinstall the constitutional order."
But after two days in which the armed forces had seemed to keep to the shadows, military leaders instead offered their first public endorsement of Mr. Serrano's actions.
 
Hints of Corruption
 The congressional leaders also charged that Mr. Serrano had assumed authoritarian powers to avoid formal corruption charges.
In an interview this evening, the president of the Congress, Jose Lobo Dubon, cited reports that appeared just before Mr. Serrano's decree that while in office, he had acquired several ranches, a Mercedes-Benz, polo ponies, a 12-seat airplane and other properties. Mr. Serrano has denied any wrongdoing.
The country's military leaders, who had remained conspicuously in the shadows since Tuesday, showed no interest in the congressional statement. Rather, the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Domingo Garcia Samayoa, said the military would heed the President's orders.
In the face of rising public criticism, Mr. Serrano moved to restore a semblance of the old order by naming nine new justices to the Supreme Court, with his former Education Minister, Maria Luisa Beltranena, as its president.
The Government also said that newspapers could now circulate after the removal of all articles that it deemed "opinion." But only one of the country's major newspapers agreed to publish under the censorship, and at least several of its top editors resigned.
A spokesman for the President announced that while Mr. Serrano would not keep his promise on Tuesday to hold elections for a constituent assembly within 60 days, the elections would take place soon after that.
In a statement issued in Mexico City this afternoon, leaders of the rebel alliance, the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Union, announced that they would abandon their peace talks with the Government until Mr. Serrano reversed himself.
The struggle today was largely confined to downtown Guatemala City, where a rally of court workers and a mass for a slain student turned into angry protests.
In the morning, about a thousand demonstrators gathered in front of the court building, chanting slogans and waving signs. Lines of military policemen quickly marched out after them. Armored personnel carriers rushed into the plaza in front of the court, and as tear gas filled the air, the demonstrators scattered.
Hours later, hundreds more Guatemalans turned out for what was virtually a protest mass at the National Cathedral.
The cavernous colonial church, across the main plaza from the National Palace, erupted in applause as the crowd parted to let in Rigoberta Menchu, the Guatemalan Indian leader who won the Nobel Peace Prize last year.
Outside, the gathering turned more overtly political as most of the worshipers marched to the palace chanting for Mr. Serrano's resignation
"Our presence here is a clear message that we cannot be silenced or shut up," Miss Menchu said.
In Washington, the State Department's spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, announced the suspension of all military aid and most economic support to Guatemala with more sharp words for the Serrano Government.
"We condemn this oppression of freedom in Guatemala and continuing censorship," he said. "These actions are a sign that Guatemala is on a dangerous course leading to further repression and further threats to democracy."
Mr. Boucher said the cutoff involved all military and police-training aid, economic development funds and cash support. Those programs were expected to be worth nearly $50 million this year.
Germany also announced it was freezing $78 million in aid.

HEADLINE: RENEWAL BACKED FOR CHINA TRADE

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he would renew China's favorable trade status for one year to help its modernization efforts, but he suggested that any future renewal would depend on China's making progress on human rights.
Administration officials had recommended Monday that Mr. Clinton steer such a middle course between groups pressing for trade sanctions as a lever to force change in China and business's demands not to encumber trade with this huge, fast-growing country. 
 In response to a question on a televised "town meeting" at the White House today, Mr. Clinton said: "I want to support modernization in China, and it's a great opportunity for America there. But I want to make it clear to them that there has to be some progress on human rights and the use of prison labor."
 
Carrot and a Stick
 But even as he offered China a carrot, Mr. Clinton made sure to talk tough, saying, "I think they will appreciate the gesture I'm making, but I hope they understand that the United States just can't turn its back on the abuse of lots of people."
A White House official said the President would issue a formal executive order on Friday that will condition renewal of China's favorable status beyond June 1994 on significant progress in several specific areas.
Mr. Clinton's position is a softening of his approach during last year's campaign, in which he argued that President Bush was wrong to extend China's favorable trade status without first demanding improvements in its human rights record.
In recent months, the President has faced immense pressures from businesses that feared being closed out of China's huge market. The Chinese Government has threatened to retaliate.
 
Sought Renewal
 China's government has eagerly sought renewal of its most-favored- nation trading status because without it tariffs on Chinese goods sold in the United States would soar to about 40 percent from an average of 8 percent.
Some of the President's advisers have told him that extending China's favored status was an important way to improve its economic conditions and to promote its transition from Communism to a market economy.
One official involved in formulating the policy said that some of the Administration's economic officials, fearing the possibility of retaliation, had pushed for renewing China's favorable status without conditions.
Some members of Congress criticized the President's decision, saying they preferred immediate revocation of China's favored status.
Gerald B. Solomon, a New York Republican, said he was disappointed by the renewal of China's status for one year "because the Chinese regime has done nothing in the last year to warrant the extension -- blatant violations of basic human rights continue unabated." He said he would push for legislation to revoke China's most-favored-nation status.
 
Capitol Hill Favorable
 But the predominant sentiment on Capitol Hill was a willingness to go along with the President's move because he had said any further extensions would be contingent upon China's improving its human rights record.
Mr. Clinton's move seemed largely in line with legislation introduced by the Senate Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, who wants China's favored trade status conditioned on progress on human rights, removing trade barriers and limiting China's arms sales.
Mr. Clinton said today that he wanted to negotiate directly with China about its arms sales and its trade disputes with Washington. Administration officials say they are concerned about China's sale of missiles to Pakistan, adding that the executive order would involve provisions calling on China to stop its nuclear proliferation.
In his campaign manifesto, Mr. Clinton chided President Bush for renewing China's favorable status "before it achieved documented progress on human rights." Human rights groups said they were eager to see the details of the President's executive order. Curt Goering, acting executive director of Amnesty International in the United States, said the Administration should demand that detainees be allowed to see their lawyers and relatives and that commissions be established to investigate allegations of torture.
Michael Jendrzejczyk, Washington director of Asia Watch, said it was important that the Administration make sure that China's compliance with the announced conditions be verifiable.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The House approved the heart of President Clinton's budget plan by a 219-to-213 vote, giving him the most crucial legislative and political victory of his Presidency. The measure would raise the taxes of most Americans except the poor, and new steps would be taken to restrain spending to lower the budget deficit. [Page A1.]
The harrowingly narrow budget victory was desperately needed by the President after months of adversity. Although not decisive, it gave the Administration time to prepare for harder battles ahead. News Analysis. [A1.] 

Markets
The dollar plunged against the Japanese yen to the lowest level since World War II as traders seemed convinced that the Clinton Administration wants a weak dollar to reduce the nation's bulging trade deficit with Japan. The Government tried to reverse the slide, with the Federal Reserve selling yen and buying dollars. [D1.]
The Dow industrials rose to another record, gaining 14.67 points to 3,554.83, but the rest of the market failed to follow. [D4.]
Short-term Treasury prices were hit hard amid more reports that the Fed was leaning toward higher short-term rates. [D12.]
Platinum and other precious metals soared in response to a weaker dollar and strong overseas buying. [D14.]
 
International
Companies from nine European countries were banned from bidding for some Federal contracts in retaliation for European rules that discourage buying U.S. telecommunications gear. [D1.]
The Clinton Administration plans to take a new tack in trade talks and press Japan more than ever to increase imports from all countries and not just the United States. [D4.]
Britain's embattled Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, was dismissed by Prime Minister John Major in a Cabinet shuffle designed to restore confidence in his Government. [A3.]
President Clinton will renew China's favorable trade status but called for further progress on human rights. [A5.]
 
Companies
RJR Nabisco hired Conagra's chairman, Charles M. Harper, to be its new chief executive. That means the man who launched Healthy Choice foods after having a heart attack will soon run a company that gets half of its sales from cigarettes. [D1.]
Dell Computer's disastrous misjudgment of the notebook computer market raises questions about the company's tactics, as well as the judgment and credibility of its management. [D1.]
Chevron will sell two refineries accounting for about 25 percent of its capacity to raise capital for expansion overseas. It will also dispose of hundreds of gasoline stations. [D1.]
Florida legislators moved to prevent insurance companies from dropping hundreds of thousands of property policies until the end of the hurricane season in November. [D3.]
Northwest Airlines unions have been offered a 30 percent stake and board seats for $886 million in concessions. [D3.]
Macy junk bonds rose in price the day after the retailer announced accelerated plans to reduce costs and expenses. [D3.]
M-G-M's co-chief executive Dennis Stanfill is expected to resign amid discord with the studio's owner, Credit Lyonnais. [D3.]
Grumman and a unit of Japan Airlines are discussing a venture to bring magnetically levitated trains to the U.S. [D3.]
 
Today's Columns
Nutri-System's financial problems could prove to be a bonanza for one of its chief rivals, Jenny Craig. Market Place. [D4.]
R. J. Reynolds will promote Winston cigarettes with its "Winston Weekends" campaign. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: Families;
$1.3 Billion Aims to Keep Families Intact

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Despite a debate that led to a freeze on most automatic spending programs, the budget approved today by the House of Representatives includes a big new cash program for states to help them keep children out of foster care.
Under the program, state child-welfare agencies would get Federal aid to help them keep families intact rather than placing children in foster care. 
 The family preservation program would cost $1.3 billion over the next five years, rising sharply from $60 million next year until 1998, when it would provide $600 million. From then on, the program would continue to increase in line with future inflation.
The money would be spent to pay for intensive counseling and therapy for children and their parents, either when a child is on the verge of being removed from his or her home, or when a child in temporary foster care is about to be returned home.
 
Aim of Program
 The goal is to counteract the problems caused by an explosive growth in foster care over the past decade.
"For the first time, this program looks to see if you can have early intervention to keep families together," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, a leading proponent of the measure.
While the Federal Government spends billions of dollars each year matching state payments for foster care, little Federal aid has been aimed at keeping families intact. A similar bill passed the House and the Senate last year as part of a tax and urban aid program, but it was vetoed by President George Bush after the election.
The program's likely enactment this year could have a profound influence on local decisions about removing children from families in crisis.
The program has strong support in the Clinton Administration from the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, who advocated the program as chairwoman of the nonprofit Children's Defense Fund, and from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who sponsored the Senate version of the legislation that was vetoed.
 
Flaws Seen in Bill
 But the new program has raised concerns from some child welfare professionals. They argue that it will encourage the child protection system to leave children in abusive or neglectful homes when they should be put into foster care or placed for adoption.
"Our concern is that the kids whose families can't be preserved are left out of this bill, and they have the most serious problems," said Mary Beth Seader of the National Council for Adoption, an advocacy group representing private nonprofit adoption agencies. "Not every family can be saved."
"Family preservation programs have been studied, and there is no proof that they work," she said.
Republicans in the House, who fought to have automatic spending reduced in the bill that was considered today, attacked the plan to include this new program when there are already six automatic-spending programs devoted to child welfare. Entitlement programs, as they are known, are those whose financing, once set into law, continues automatically without annual Congressional action.
 
Gains for New York State
 New York State would be a major beneficiary of the new program because its funds are apportioned to the states on the basis of how many children in each state receive food stamp benefits. According to officials at the Department of Health and Human Services, New York State would get 7.7 percent of the total Federal money.
Last year, New York State for the first time put a cap on the amount it would spend on foster care, and New York City set aside up to 5 percent of its foster-care budget for a program in which social workers intervene in families to keep children from being placed in foster care.

LENGTH: 252 words

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET;
A Deficit-Cutting Scorecard

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
To Republicans, President Clinton's economic package is the largest tax increase in history. Democrats insist it is the biggest deficit cut.
Inevitably, both sides are wrong. And right. 
 The Congressional Budget Office, the official scorekeeper in such matters, estimates that the package will increase taxes by $270 billion over five years. That appears to make it larger than the 1982 tax increase, which raised $215 billion in new taxes over five years under President Ronald Reagan.
But if inflation is factored in, the Clinton package raises taxes less.
Viewed another way, the Clinton package would raise taxes in its fifth year by slightly more than 0.9 percent of gross domestic product. The Reagan tax increase ends up being larger because it increased taxes in its fifth year by 1.3 percent of gross domestic product. The Reagan tax increase followed the 1981 tax cut, which slashed taxes each year by 5.5 percent of the gross domestic product.
The deficit debate is murkier. The Congressional Budget Office says it cannot estimate the size of the package exactly because parts of it are not before Congress.
The White House estimates that over five years it will cut the deficit by $500 billion, $350 billion of which was voted on today. According to the Congressional Budget Office, President Bush's budget accord of 1990 would have cut the deficit by $496 billion over five years. But if inflation is factored in, Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction package ends up being slightly smaller.

HEADLINE: Christopher Reaffirms Leading U.S. Role in World

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, May 27

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that despite the Government's fiscal difficulties, the United States would continue to take the lead in international affairs.
Mr. Christopher made his comments in the wake of questions that arose when Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, told reporters on Tuesday that the Federal budget deficit would force the United States to be more judicious in deciding when to assume a leadership role in international crises. 
 The Administration immediately disavowed Mr. Tarnoff's comments. But the concern over their possible repercussions is apparently great enough to cause Mr. Christopher's speechwriters to redraft remarks he delivered to an students and faculty at the University of Minnesota today. While the main theme of the speech remained the need to provide aid to Russia, Mr. Christopher devoted more time to the determination of the United States to remain in the forefront in world affairs.
"I think our need to lead, our determination to lead is not constrained by our resources," Mr. Christopher said in a brief interview here. "I think that where we need to lead, where our vital interests are threatened, we will find the resources to accomplish that."
In the speech, sponsored by the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs, Mr. Christopher repeated what he said in a television interview this week: that the United States would at times act unilaterally, and at other times try to mobilize multinational efforts.
 
'Must Be More Engaged'
 Such consideration, he said, would depend on the perception of vital American interests rather than on the country's financial resources. That was the major difference between his view and the one expressed by Mr. Tarnoff, Mr. Christopher said.
"Some say -- and I'm sure you've heard this said -- that our nation is on a course of decline, that we can no long afford to lead," Mr. Christopher told an audience of about 1,200 that overflowed a concert hall on the college campus. "And certainly, it is true that the United States faces many challenges unlike our nation has ever felt before in our history. But to me, that means that we must be more engaged internationally, not less; more ardent in the promotion of democracy, not less; and more inspired in our leadership, not less."
Mr. Tarnoff's remarks came after Russia and the European allies rejected an American plan to aid the Bosnian Government and the Administration declined to act alone. Today Mr. Christopher called the war in Bosnia a "quagmire" and a "morass" and said the United States would not act unilaterally there.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Clinton's Question-and-Answer Session in the Rose Garden

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's meeting today in the White House Rose Garden as transcribed by Federal News Service. The moderators were Harry Smith and Paula Zahn of "CBS This Morning."
PRESIDENT CLINTON There was an agreement made last night that I had been supporting for a good long while, sponsored by the conservative Democrats, essentially to put a mechanism in the budget to force us every year to make the budget cuts that we say we're making in this five-year budget; that is, it's obviously very hard to predict what will happen in every year for the next five years. 
 If you had to do a family budget for five years, it might not be possible, or a business budget or a farm budget. So these numbers are as good as we can make them. But this amendment actually says that every year, if we miss the deficit reduction target, the President has to bring in a plan to meet it and the Congress has to vote on it. And if they want to change it some, they can, but we've got to meet the deficit reduction target. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	MS. ZAHN What happens if you don't get this through in the House today?
A. We keep working until we get a budget through. The real problem is -- I think that there are two problems. One is that the details of the plan have been lost in the rhetoric. The second is that a lot of the Republicans who might otherwise want to vote with us got into a position where they said they wouldn't vote for any tax.
Over 60 percent of this money, of the tax money, over 60 percent comes from people with incomes over $200,000. Seventy-four percent of it comes from people with incomes over $100,000, people whose taxes went down in the 80's while their incomes went up. People with incomes under $30,000 are protected even from the B.T.U. tax. And next year, people in the middle will pay about a dollar, and it goes to $7 a month and then about $15 month. I think that -- but a lot of -- we have to get all of our votes apparently from the Democrats this time. I hope it won't happen anymore.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
'What Went Wrong?'
 MR. SMITH I just want to see a raise of hands this morning -- and don't be intimidated just because you're in the Rose Garden. . . . Do you feel like there's been a gap between the promises of the campaign and the performance thus far? If you think so, raise your hand. So a lot of folks feel that way. What went wrong?
A. First of all, I don't know that anything went wrong except I'm glad nobody found out about the manicure I got in California. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	What went wrong was I was not able to keep the public focus on the issues that we're working on after I gave the State of the Union address, even though that's what we kept doing. Now, look, we've been here four months and look what's happened in four months. They give you a four-year term. Look what's happened in four months.
We had a major foreign policy challenge in Russia right after I got in office. If Yeltsin had gotten beat in Russia and a militant regime had returned, we would have had to turn around with the defense budget. A lot of bad things could have happened to America. The United States went to work, organized the rest of the world, supported Yeltsin. He won the election. We're back on track there making this world a safer place. That's my No. 1 job. I think that's pretty impressive.
The Congress passed a resolution committing to do a budget that reduced the deficit by $500 billion on time for the first time in 17 years. Congress passed the family leave bill they've been fooling around with for eight years to guarantee people some time off without losing their jobs. They passed the motor-voter bill they'd been fooling around with for years. No one now asks, Are we going to reduce the deficit? The question is, How much, and how? No one now asks, Are we ever going to do anything about health care? The question is, When, and exactly what are we going to do? I think that's a pretty good record for four months.

 	 	 		. . .	 	MS. ZAHN But the fact is, you've also had to do a lot of fighting with Democrats of your own party. And I think a lot of people were hoping with a Democratic President and a Democratic Congress that things were going to move more smoothly. Do you think issues like the haircut and the problems in the travel office have made it harder for you to get this economic plan through?
A. No. I think this economic plan is tough. I think it does, because if you publicize something like that -- and people don't know, for example, on the haircut, that I asked whether anybody would be held up or inconvenienced, and I was told no. I asked twice and I was told no. And I would never do that, not in 100 years, not ever.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Travel Office Dismissals
 MR. SMITH You know what? We need to talk about this -- travelgate. Who knew what when? And why was the F.B.I. called in? And why did you hire your cousin? And why did you have a firm from Arkansas take over this business? And --
A. First of all, let's get back to the beginning, O.K.? Let's talk about my cousin. She's about my fifth or sixth cousin who worked in the campaign and ran the travel operations. But we had a very efficient travel operation. Every operation of the White House was reviewed because I said I was going to cut the White House staff by 25 percent. That's not easy to do.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We found out that there were seven people working in the travel office, primarily to book travel for the press, and that the press was complaining that the cost was too high. So there were all of these recommendations made to change it. But nothing was done until an accounting firm came in and reviewed the operation and found serious management questions in terms of unaccounted-for funds and things like that. So then, the person in charge of that made the decision to replace them.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Relations With China
 Q. My name is Eleanor Philips. I'm from Tarzana, Calif. I've been going to China since 1980 -- seven or eight times. I've lived and worked in China for two years. I'm very concerned about what you're going to do with the . . . most favored nation.

 	 	 		. . .	 	MR. SMITH Is this a done deal, your decision on this?
A. I think it is a done deal for the next year. Let me explain the issue here. In order for a country to trade with us, they have to get what's called 'most favored nation status' in order to have big trade. China is a huge trading partner of ours. We have our, I think now, our second biggest trading deficit with China, just behind Japan. They've got one of the fastest growing economies in the world. They're moving away from Communism to market economics very quickly. They still put political prisoners in jail. They still, we think, have used prison labor to make products. And we have some other problems with them.
The issue is, should we revoke that or should we put conditions on it. I basically have decided to extend most favored nation status for a year because I want to support modernization in China. And it's a great opportunity for America there. But I want to make it clear to them that there has to be some progress on human rights and the use of prison labor. Our trade disputes and our disputes about arms sales, I'm going to take out of this issue and negotiate directly with them.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Health-Care Plan
 Q. My name is Dan Beeman. I'm from Springfield, Mo. . . . I work for a company that has less than 500 employees. I pay $50 a month for a health plan, a dental plan, life insurance. Our health plan is self insured. I am concerned -- I don't want to pay more money for health care individually. I'm concerned that my employer may be taxed and have to pay more money and I would receive less benefits than I'm receiving, as well as I want to keep my self-funded health plan. How would the change in health care, how would it affect me as an individual?
A. Well, let me say, first of all, one of the decisions that has not been finalized yet, at least in our original report, is to what extent any companies of any size should be able to, in effect, continue their self-insurance efforts. And that's a tough issue, because what we're trying to do is to get these pools of insurance big enough for small businesses to have affordable health care, because that's been a back-breaker for a lot of small businesses.
The requirement that they're working on in terms of financial contribution would not be a tax over and above what people are paying now. They're trying to hit the national average, maybe even a little below the national average of what employers are paying now. And many, many employers and employees in this country will actually save money if the health-care plan comes into effect. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Homosexuals in the Military
 Q. Mr. President, my name is Bill Roberts. I'm the senior Pastor at Christ Chapel in Woodbridge, Virginia. . . . Allow me to ask the question . . . about the issue of gays in the military, if I may. I'm concerned about the degradation of morality in our nation and our society in the military as a whole.

 	 	 		. . .	 	A. There are and always have been homosexuals in the military. The question is whether they should be kicked out, not because of what they do but because of who they are. My view is, people should be judged on their conduct. I have not called for any change in the Uniform Code of Conduct. I simply believe if people work hard, play by the rules and serve, they ought to be able to serve. That does not imply that the rest of the society agrees with the life style, but you just accept as a fact that there are in every country, and always have been, homosexuals who are capable of honoring their country, laying down their lives for their country, and serving. And they should be judged based on their behavior not their life style.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Most Americans believe if you don't ask and you don't say and you're not forced to confront it, people should be able to serve. Most Americans believe that the gay life style should not be promoted by the military or anybody else in this county. The issue is a narrow one: should you be able to acknowledge, if asked, that you are homosexual? And if you don't do anything wrong, should you be booted from the military?
We are trying to work this out so that our country does not -- I understand what you're saying -- so that our country does not appear to be endorsing a gay life style, but we accept people as people and give them a chance to serve if they play by the rules. I think that is the tough issue for us. And I think we're very close to resolving it here.
MS. ZAHN Could you be satisfied with 'Don't ask, don't tell, don't investigate?' Might that be where you might end up?
A. Well, we might end up that way as long as it doesn't lead to a whole range of deliberate outings. Do you know what I mean? We don't want to make it worse. I think we're very close to a compromise along those lines. And I think most Americans will agree when it works out that people are treated properly if they behave properly without the Government appearing to endorse a life style. I think that's what you're concerned about, and it's a legitimate concern. But I have to deal with people as people. And I've had so many people in the military come up to me and say that they have served with homosexuals who served bravely in Vietnam and other places, who were good people who did not violate any rules. It is them that I am trying to protect.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Dow Hits New High but Other Indexes Lag

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average rose to another record yesterday, gaining 14.67 points to 3,554.83, but in contrast to Wednesday's record session, the rest of the market failed to follow.
Analysts said the market might have lacked direction because of the House of Representatives' scheduled vote on President Clinton's economic program. The budget plan passed, some five hours after the market closed, by a vote of 219 to 213. 
 Nonetheless, trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 300.8 million shares, compared with 274.2 million shares on Wednesday. Much of the trading, however, was concentrated in large companies like Chevron, Caterpillar and United Technologies, which are Dow component stocks.
 
 
Gold Shares Jump
 In another contrast to Wednesday's trading, gold prices and gold stocks rose sharply. Investors sought investments other than Government bonds, which still offer relatively low yields, and the dollar, which has dropped to a post-World War II low against the Japanese yen.
Gold for June delivery on the New York Commodity Exchange rose $6.10 an ounce, to $381.40, and gold stocks closed mostly higher. Newmont Mining rose 1 7/8, to 52 1/4, and Echo Bay Mines rose 7/8, to 12. Echo Bay was the most-active stock on the American Stock Exchange, as it has been in many recent sessions, with 2.43 million shares changing hands.
While the Dow rose, the Standard & Poor's 500, which has a greater variety of stocks, fell 1.03, to 452.41. The Nasdaq composite index, with more than 3,500 smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, gained 0.5 point, to 704.59.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 0.47 point, to 249.43, and losing stocks outnumbered winners on the Big Board by 998 to 923.
 The Dow was lifted mainly by two stocks, Chevron and Caterpillar. Chevron closed up 3 3/4, to 88 5/8, after announcing an ambitious restructuring program that impressed industry analysts.
Caterpillar, the maker of construction machinery, hit a new high of 73 before closing up 2 3/8, to 72 3/4. There was no discernible news to account for Caterpillar's rise, but many portfolio managers have bought cyclical stocks like Caterpillar, which could benefit from an economic recovery, as part of their investment strategy.
British Petroleum and Tele-Communications were the most noteworthy stocks yesterday in terms of trading volume. Trading remains high in British Petroleum shares, partly because of Triton Energy's Colombian oilfield project. British Petroleum is a partner in Triton. The company's American depositary receipts closed up 1/8, to 58 1/2. With 8.4 million A.D.R.'s changing hands, British Petroleum was the most-active stock yesterday on any exchange.
Tele-Communications, the cable television company, closed up 1/2, to 23 3/8 following upbeat and assertive remarks by its chairman, John C. Malone, at the company's annual meeting. Mr. Malone predicted "a bloodlet on both sides" over whether the television networks can charge cable operators to carry their programs. Capital Cities/ABC closed down 7 5/8, to 524 7/8, in light trading.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Press Japan On Broadening Imports

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
In an attempt to end criticism that it is selfishly trying to help only American companies, the Clinton Administration plans to take a new tack in trade talks and press Japan more than ever to increase imports from all countries and not just the United States, Administration officials said today.
The officials, who spoke on the condition that they would not be identified, said the change would be part of a new trade strategy toward Japan that is scheduled to be announced next week. They said they would try to enlist European countries in the effort. 
 In the past, European countries have described Washington as a selfish bully that had pressed Japan to increase its imports from the United States but not other countries.
Foreign officials have said the unilateral pressuring to open Japan to American goods and services, when backed by threats of retaliation, had violated international trade rules and sought to create improper favoritism for American companies.
 
Bringing International Pressure
 This time, an American official said, "While the talks will be bilateral, the focus will be multilateral."
Administration officials said they hoped to bring maximum international pressure on Japan before the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations met in Tokyo from July 7 through July 9. They planned to press Japan to agree to import more in specific sectors and to do more to stimulate its economy to end its slump -- a move that should increase its demand for imports.
Some American officials said they saw an opportunity to wrest concessions from Tokyo because Japanese officials were usually eager to minimize foreign disapproval -- and embarrassment -- when the world's spotlight was turned on them.
Under the new approach, the United States might press Japan to increase imports of certain goods by a specific amount, but those additional imports would not have to come from the United States.
"They won't be able to use the excuse that we're not going to import more widgets, because the widgets made in the United States aren't as good as those made in Japan," one official said. "Under this policy, Japan could always buy widgets from other countries."
 
Complaints About Pact
 In Washington's existing semiconductor agreement with Japan, Tokyo had promised to help insure that foreign-made computer chips would capture 20 percent of the Japanese market. While the accord was not limited to American chips, some foreign officials have complained that the pact was most beneficial to American producers.
"We have never said, 'Let's look at what's in the interests of the whole world," one American official said. "We said, 'What are the problem areas for us.' Obviously we'll look for areas where we're the most competitive."
American officials said all countries would benefit if Washington succeeded in its goal of pressing Japan to reduce its current account surplus to less than 2 percent of gross domestic product; it is now running at nearly 4 percent. Many economists predicted that Japan's surplus would exceed $150 billion this year, with its surplus with the United States representing about one-third of that.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Treasury Prices Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Short-term Treasury prices were hit hard yesterday amid more reports that the Federal Reserve had decided to set a policy biased toward raising short-term interest rates.
But the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was down only slightly and the yield was unchanged at 6.92 percent. Combined with the sharp rise in shorter-term yields, the gap between short- and long-term yields narrowed to its smallest spread of the year. 
 The price of the two-year Treasury note, which was auctioned Tuesday, was off 6/32 point as the yield jumped to 4.24 percent from 4.14 percent Wednesday. The yield at the auction was 4.17 percent.
The price of the new five-year note was also off sharply, falling 8/32 as the yield rose to 5.35 percent from 5.29 percent. The yield at the auction Wednesday was 5.39 percent, but it fell to 5.29 percent in a late rally that afternoon.
 
 
CNBC Report
 What hurt the shorter end was a report on CNBC that the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee was nearly unanimous when it decided May 18 to shift from neutral to biased toward raising short-term interest rates if inflation continues to rise. The decision gave the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, the authority to move on his own to raise short-term rates if there was a need to do so before the policy group met again in early July.
Although the Fed has not disclosed what it decided, it had been reported earlier this week that the Fed had voted in favor of a bias to higher interest rates. But the report of a near unanimity in the vote added to the conclusion in the market that the Fed could act quickly if inflation, which rose at an annual rate of 4.3 percent in the first four months of the year, did not subside.
The flattening, or narrowing, of the yield curve -- the spread between short-term and long-term yields - had been expected since April inflation reports came in higher than expected and talk began that the Fed, despite the sluggishness of the economy, might have to raise short-term rates to prove that it would resist rising prices.
But the sharp narrowing yesterday, with the spread dropping 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 268, was a little surprising. That was in part because traders said they would have expected the price and yield of the 30-year bond to suffer more, given two other events that affected trading.
 
 
Jump in Gold Price
 One event was a jump in the price of gold back over the $380 level, which some analysts took as a sign that expectations of higher inflation are taking hold. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the price of gold for June delivery rose $6.10, to close at $381.40 an ounce.
Another was the sharp drop in the dollar. It fell to another post-World War II low against the Japanese yen, closing at 107.20 yen to the dollar in New York, despite repeated intervention to support the dollar by the Federal Reserve. On the day, the dollar was down 1.2 percent against the yen and 1.5 percent against the German mark.
The decline in the dollar also has inflationary consequences because it makes imports more expensive. In addition, it appears that domestic car makers are raising prices under the cover of price increases that have been forced on the Japanese manufacturers because of the decline in the dollar.
"I was surprised that the market did not sell off across the board with the weaker dollar today," said Stephen Slifer, financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. "That is usually inflationary."
Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company, said that it did not appear that debate in the House on President Clinton's economic and deficit reduction legislation had a big impact on the market yesterday. The package survived a key vote early in the afternoon while trading was still under way. The final vote, 219 to 213 in favor of the plan, came last night after the close of the market.
The President worked to gather support for the plan with a last- minute compromise that would include a form of spending caps on programs like Medicare. But because similar caps have been tried in the past -- and failed -- it is not clear if this will give the bond market any more confidence that the President's plan, which promises deficit reduction, will actually achieve it.

HEADLINE: PEROT VS. CLINTON: WAR OF THE WORDS

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 27

 BODY:
Ross Perot asserts that President Clinton does not have enough executive experience to handle "the toughest job in the world."
The President dismisses Mr. Perot as a political malcontent who "doesn't like my state." White House aides go even further, asserting that Mr. Perot, a Texan who made billions as a computer entrepreneur, is a man "desperate for attention." 
 The latest exchange comes as Mr. Clinton's ability to govern is being questioned in many quarters, particularly on Capitol Hill, where his economic plan faces crucial tests.
It also comes as Mr. Perot faces mounting criticism that he has been dictatorial in managing his organization, United We Stand America.
 
A Question of Experience
 Mr. Perot opened his new offensive on Tuesday in an interview with David Frost. He said that Mr. Clinton had enough executive experience to handle a "middle management" job in a medium-sized company but not enough for the White House.
This morning, on NBC's "Today," Mr. Perot continued his attack: "His background and experience didn't prepare him for the toughest job in the world. He's very bright. He has a high energy level. But right now he has a learning curve that's like a cliff."
The President, when asked Wednesday by reporters how he planned to deal with Mr. Perot's latest charges, at first quipped, "You deal with it." But when pressed, he added: "Well, we know he doesn't like my state. He spent several million dollars to bad-mouth it last year. But that doesn't have much to do with America."
In the first few months after the election, in which Mr. Perot ran third with 19 percent of the vote, he seemed to go out of his way to avoid attacking Mr. Clinton, saying the President deserved time to prove himself.
 
Verbal Cease-Fire Ends
 But about a month ago, Mr. Perot, who in the meantime had been working hard to build up his own political organization, apparently concluded that Mr. Clinton had been accorded more than enough time. He began to attack.
The President responded in kind.
Last Sunday at a rally in Kansas City, Mr. Perot began an all-out assault, saying the President had mishandled everything from economic policy to White House travel arrangements. He then spent 10 minutes of his 90-minute speech poking fun at the two-hour break Mr. Clinton had taken at the Los Angeles airport for a haircut.
Mr. Perot reiterated most of those charges this morning, adding: "When you're $4 trillion in debt, you cannot afford to make mistakes of the magnitude they are pushing for now. We have to be very careful not to do further damage to our country and our economy while they are getting organized, learning how to do the job."
While Mr. Clinton dismissed Mr. Perot yesterday as a malcontent, Paul Begala, a top Presidential adviser, accused Mr. Perot of being "desperate for attention," adding: "When he goes to a wedding, he wants to be the bride. When he goes to a funeral, he wants to be the corpse. He just wants to be the center of attention."

HEADLINE: U.S. Takes Retaliation On Europe

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Following through on a public pledge last month, the Clinton Administration released regulations yesterday that would ban companies from nine European countries from bidding for Federal Government contracts for legal services, certain telephone service and other services.
The ban, which takes effect today, covers $29 billion a year worth of contracts andis in retaliation for new European Community rules that discourage sales of American telecommunications equipment there, said an American official who insisted on anonymity. But the actual effect of the sanctions is likely to be tiny because many of the services are highly local, like operating airport concessions. 
 European companies won an average of only $20 million a year worth of these contracts from 1989 through 1991, the official said.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, announced last month that the new regulations would be issued after negotiations with the European Community failed to resolve the dispute. Mr. Kantor made the announcement the same day that a nearly identical dispute over European rules on electrical power generation equipment was resolved.
Mr. Kantor had originally threatened in early February to bar European companies from $50 billion a year worth of contracts, of which the companies typically won only $45 million a year. The sanctions announced today were only half as large because of the settlement on power generation equipment.
 
American Move Is Condemned
 Sir Leon Brittan, the community's Commissioner for External Economic Affairs, nonetheless condemned the American move. "I greatly regret the U.S. decision," he said in a statement. "In view of the progress we have made, notably on public procurement, it is neither justified, wise nor necessary."
Sir Leon issued a thinly veiled threat that the community might retaliate, but stopped short of saying that it was willing to risk a broader confrontation by abandoning the 112-nation global free trade talks that began nearly seven years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay.
"We are not going to allow this issue to delay or frustrate the progress we are making in the Uruguay Round, nor let it poison the atmosphere, but the U.S. cannot expect us to ignore wholly unjustified action of this kind," he said.
There are 12 countries in the European Community. The American sanctions apply to only nine of them because Greece, Portugal and Spain have agreed to give American companies some access to their markets for telephone company equipment.
Utilities in the European Community buy about $20 billion a year worth of telecommunications equipment and an equal amount of power generation equipment.
The likelihood of actual counter-retaliation is unclear, because it would require the endorsement of 9 or 10 European countries, European officials said in recent interviews in Brussels. Germany, Britain and the Netherlands have all been reluctant in the past to endorse trade sanctions, although it is not clear where they stand this time.
The community's council of foreign ministers, which would make the final decision on any counter-retaliation, is next scheduled to meet on June 8. A European official who insisted on anonymity said that counter-retaliation was likely but not certain.
The dispute began several years ago when the European Community drafted new regulations for government purchases of telecommunications and electrical power generation equipment, to take effect on Jan. 1 of this year. The new rules, which replaced varying and more restrictive government procurement rules in each of the 12 member countries, allow European utilities to reject bids from non-European companies on two grounds: if less than half of the goods for the bid are made inside the community or if a European company submits a bid that is up to 3 percent more expensive.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative during the Bush Administration, announced in February 1992 that the United States would take action by the end of January 1993 if the rules took effect. Mr. Kantor ended up extending this deadline three times in an effort to strike a deal.

Pact Gains in Canada
 By Bloomberg Business News
 OTTAWA, May 27 -- The North American Free Trade Agreement cleared its first legislative hurdle today when Canada's House of Commons approved the pact's implementing legislation by a vote of 140 to 124. The bill now proceeds for a vote in Canada's Senate; the Conservative Government holds a majority in both the Commons and the Senate. Passage of similar legislation in Mexico and the United States is required before Canada puts the accord into force, the spokesman said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Platinum Reach 2-Year High as Metals Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices rose to a two-year high yesterday as precious metals soared in response to a weaker dollar, strong overseas buying and uncertainties over Russian supplies.
Platinum for July delivery surged $10.40 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $399.20 an ounce, the highest settlement for near-term deliveries since April 17, 1991, when the market settled at $402.80. July prices touched the psychologically important $400 level during the session. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, June gold rose $6.10 to $381.40 an ounce and July silver jumped 13.7 cents to $4.70 an ounce.
 
Rally Seen Building Momentum
 The decisive rise in metal prices after a week of back-and-forth action suggests the broad rally that began in mid-March has solidified, said James Steel, a metals analyst with Refco Inc., a New York brokerage.
He said platinum benefited from strong Japanese buying and from gains in the palladium market on worries that Russia, a major producer, cannot meet its normal delivery commitments for that metal.
Precious metals in general were supported by the dollar's weakness against major foreign currencies, which could have inflationary effects. Precious metals are traditional investment hedges against inflation.
Buying in the gold market erased Wednesday's losses as participants grew convinced that a rumored sharp increase in Russian gold reserves was exaggerated, Mr. Steel said.
The reversal from Wednesday's downturn also fueled buying, said Stephen W. Platt, metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "You keep looking for the corrections and they keep falling short of your expectations," he said. Those events reinforce the notion among investors that the rally in precious metals is solid, he said.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Unchanged

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits was unchanged last week, the Government said today.
New applications for unemployment benefits totaled 340,000 for a second straight week, the Labor Department said. For the week that ended on May 8, the total was revised down to 337,000 from 344,000. 
 The four-week moving average of jobless claims fell by 1,500, to 339,750, the lowest since the period that ended Feb. 20, when it stood at 334,250. Analysts prefer the four-week average because it smoothes out weekly variations and more accurately reflects the labor situation.
The report also said that 25,468 applications were filed under a Federal emergency unemployment program during the week that ended on May 15, down from 25,826 the previous week. The emergency claims and individual state figures lag behind the overall total and the four-week moving average by one week.
Forty states and territories showed decreased claims during the week that ended on May 15, while 13 had increases.
California reported the largest decline, a drop of 5,782 that was attributed to fewer layoffs in agriculture.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Modest Proposals From Immodest Fans

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
"I will accept the job," said Bill Murray, who is also part-owner of the St. Paul Saints of the Northern League, "if you give me unlimited powers."
"Get serious," I told the comic actor. "If the job came with unlimited powers, I would take it myself." 
 He curled his lip and eyebrows simultaneously, a dangerous signal. I edged back into the maw of a GQ magazine cocktail party for Peter Richmond's tasty new book about Camden Yards, "Ballpark" (Simon & Schuster).
While my private search for a new Commissioner of Baseball has not exacty been the season of living dangerously, I've had to be alert. There are heady emotions out there. People really care about The Pastime. There have been so many letters and phone calls applying for, no, demanding, the job that I have been able to conduct only one more formal luncheon interview.
But first, the applications.
Charles Brocato of Staten Island submitted a thoughtful 11-page "revitalization" proposal stressing fair-play business practices. If Brocato doesn't get the job, his proposal will be sent to whoever does, including Jason B. Harris, a 27-year-old public relations executive from Chicago, whose 10-point plan includes youth leagues, more doubleheaders and a "Take In a Baseball Game While At Work" radio campaign.
Frank R. Badali of Middletown, N.J., has proposed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a former minor league player, as the next commissioner. Robert N. Sillars Jr. of Darien, Conn., has proposed the political pundit George Will, author of the baseball treatise, "Men at Work" (Macmillan, 1990).
Gerry Gold of Bethesda, Md., while recommending Felix Rohatyn as a resource, wisely did not link a prospective commissioner with his own radical plan; he would wrest control from "the current generation of owners . . . a national disgrace" and distribute 95 percent of the stock of major league clubs to the general public. Tod Parrott of Larchmont, N.Y., son of Harold, former traveling secretary of the Dodgers, is promoting the candidacy of his brother, Brian, a Portland, Ore., sports entrepeneur.
"Baseball needs a spiritual leader," maintains Rabbi Benjamin A. Kamin of The Temple, a Reform Jewish congregation in Cleveland. The rabbi's application arrived with various published Op-Ed pieces and the admission that he has been lobbying Milwaukee owner and Commissioner pro temp Bud Selig for months.
Even more aggressive than Rabbi Kamin was Ira Glasser, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, who thundered, "That job is mine. I've been preparing for it all my life."
Over the second glass of red wine at The Ballroom, a Manhattan tapas restaurant, Glasser modified that statement. The passion truly began, he said, when he was a 9-year-old Brooklyn Dodger fan and Jackie Robinson appeared at Ebbets Field.
"My generation of white kid grew up identifying with the struggle of a black man," Glasser said. "It was accessible, it was in prime time. It was an integration of the soul."
Does that mean Glasser would use the commissioner's platform for social engineering?
"The game may be a social instrument," he said, "but you can't approach it as a social engineer. You have to be pragmatic. Hey, in my job I deal with unions, negotiations, employees all the time. The first thing I'd want to do is convince the owners that they are a single employer, an economic entity, all dependent on each other. Their product is exciting competition.
"Next, what I call 'the fiction of loyalty' must be returned to the game. Players have to be loyal to their clubs and clubs have to be loyal to their fans and fans have to be loyal to their players. We can't go choosing sides every year. There has to be continuity. Long-term contracts. No jumping around from team to team. The worst traits of the owners have been transferred to the players, and the fans are losing interest.
"And let's not forget this is a kids' game. How do we make sure the kids are awake for the World Series? How do we keep the playoffs without allowing them to cheapen the long season?"
Reminded that he hadn't been called in to ask questions, Glasser, a quick, lively man of 55, submitted to the standard litmus questions of the search interview.
He said that he would allow Pete Rose into the Hall of Fame, since that honor is for performance, not character. He said he would like to investigate the amazing size of contemporary gloves, the vagaries of the strike zone and the possibility of eliminating artificial turf and the designated hitter. It would close the circle of his own education as a fan, he said, if the first woman player entered the major leagues during his time as commissioner.
Asked about his chances, I told him truthfully that Jim Bouton and Richard Ravitch were already on the short list, and that Bill Murray, although he would become an owner next month with the opening of the new independent minor Northern League, was also under serious consideration. After all, Baseball is an entertainment. Maybe it needs, for a change, a commissioner who admits he's a comedian.
Glasser bristled. "Baseball is a serious part of American culture. No one would say that ballet or opera is merely entertainment."

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
A Sample of Drawings From the Getty's Riches

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
The drawings collection at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., a selection from which has gone on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is one of the recent success stories in the museum world. A cynic might say the collection goes to show merely what great wads of money can buy. And to a point, that cynic would be right. Certainly no other museum and few private collectors could have afforded the array of pricey works that the Getty acquired since it began buying drawings a dozen years ago.
But there is money well spent and money merely spent, and this exhibition of 121 works proves that the world's richest museum, as it has inevitably come to be known, has distinguished itself above all in this department. 
 One drawing after another is of a quality to inspire envy among rival museums and awe among just about everyone else. The Getty may have paid extravagantly, but who would question the wisdom of buying a work as near to perfection as Raphael's "St. Paul Rending His Garments"? The same goes for a portrait by Hans Holbein the Younger, acquired in one of the Chatsworth sales in London a decade ago, that gave such a lift to the Getty when it was just beginning to put its drawings collection together. It also goes for a dazzling Cezanne still-life watercolor bought 10 years ago for a price that today, considering the sum recently paid for a still-life painting by the artist, can seem like a bargain.
But more important, the Getty has acquired plenty of stellar drawings for comparatively moderate prices, works by artists like Pontormo and Parmigianino that are among the highlights of this exhibition. And it has ferreted out drawings that have been overlooked by less savvy buyers, as in the case of an Albrecht Altdorfer that was sold in 1985 at a London auction as the work of a lesser artist.
The credit for all this belongs to George R. Goldner, the Getty's curator of drawings (and since 1990, its curator of paintings, too). Mr. Goldner is nothing if not shrewd. He joined the Getty in 1979 as head of the department of photo archives, working in a windowless basement office pasting photographs onto white cards. But he was a scholar of Old Master drawings, and when a red chalk drawing by Rembrandt of a naked Cleopatra came up for sale at Christie's in London in 1981, he persuaded his superiors at the museum to buy it. J. Paul Getty himself had not collected drawings, and the nascent museum intended to acquire art only in those areas its founder had pursued: paintings, decorative arts and antiquities. But with a work as unimpeachable as the Rembrandt, Mr. Goldner came up with an offer the museum could hardly refuse.
The next year, drawings by Bernini, Fragonard, Goya, Ingres and Rubens joined the Rembrandt. And when John Walsh became director of the Getty in 1983, a department of drawings was officially established with Mr. Goldner as its head. Shortly after, Lee Hendrix was hired as an associate, and she brought a specialty in Northern art that complemented Mr. Goldner's strength in Italian art.
What they have done has proven to be something of an oddity in the museum world. Most museums acquire drawings, unlike paintings, to build a study collection, with works that demonstrate different techniques, works that relate to sculptures, paintings and prints in the museum, works by little-known and unknown artists. The Getty has turned out to be one of the few museums that collect drawings pretty much the way Henry Frick collected paintings: the emphasis is on amassing a comparatively few choice works by great artists. To be sure, the museum has made its share of speculative purchases, as in the case of the Altdorfer, although not all of them have turned out so fortunately. It has acquired examples by obscure artists, like Lucas van Uden and Jacopo Zucchi. And with Northern art in particular, it has occasionally bought lesser works to illustrate one or another point about the uses of drawing.
But the Getty has clearly been concerned with quality above all else. It has been helped along these lines by the fact that the 1980's, late though they may have seemed to begin collecting first-rate Old Masters, were in fact great years for such a pursuit. The Chatsworth sales in 1983 and 1987 and the sale of drawings from the collection of John Gaines in 1986 put many prime works on the market. A booming economy and a group of private collectors that included Ian Woodner, Leonardo Mondadori and Mr. Gaines, who were willing to pay top dollar for great drawings, further stimulated the market and inspired the sale of even more works, for which the Getty, almost alone among museums, had the money to compete. Others, notably the Art Institute of Chicago, acquired a large number of great drawings during the decade. But none bought more lavishly than the Getty.
This exhibition, organized by William M. Griswold, an assistant curator in the drawings department at the Metropolitan, in collaboration with Mr. Goldner and Ms. Hendrix, includes more than one-fourth of the nearly 400 works the Getty has accumulated so far. The show emphasizes breadth as much as quality, and with few exceptions (like some of the Northern drawings) the quality remains high. Raphael, Mantegna, Titian, Bassano, Piranesi, Martin Schongauer, Durer, Cranach, Rubens, Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Watteau, Chardin, David and Ingres are all represented, and all of them by outstanding examples.
There is a Titian landscape, limpidly drawn and compellingly strange in its combination of a nude bather, a flock of sheep with goat and pig, two shepherds, the whole scene set against the backdrop of a burning city. There is a colored chalk drawing of feverish energy and flickering light depicting "Christ Driving the Money Changers From the Temple," by Titian's contemporary Bassano. By Schongauer is a gouache and watercolor study of peonies that is the epitome of precise draftsmanship and close observation. And by Watteau are two drawings, one of a group of musicians typical of the artist in its blending of physicality and nuance, the other a nude of unbelievable beauty characteristic in its exquisite eroticism.
The fanciest drawings are not always the most impressive. A landscape by Rembrandt that consists of precious few markings and makes cunning use of large stretches of the blank page turns out to be at least as memorable as the Cleopatra. A similarly understated and subtle rendition of a theatrical performance, by Francesco Guardi, holds its own in fast company, too. And so do drawings by relative lesser-knowns like Taddeo Zuccaro, whose red-and-black chalk sketches of figures exude a certain crazed energy, and like Girodet, whose highly finished "Phaedra Rejecting the Embraces of Theseus" is something else entirely. Don't miss any of them.
"Drawings From the J. Paul Getty Museum" remains on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Aug. 8. The show travels to the Royal Academy in London in October.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Raphael's "St. Paul Rending His Garments," at the Metropolitan. (Metropolitan Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: Review/Architecture;
The Unconventional as a Convention

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
The small, wedge-shaped gallery at Storefront for Art and Architecture, which can resemble a nightmare torture chamber with sadistically contracting walls, is a poignant metaphor for the perennially pinched economic circumstances of this "alternative" downtown space. If the walls contracted one more inch, Storefront would be out on the street, and architecture would move another step closer to homelessness in the imperial city of real estate. No other New York gallery or museum has provided new architectural ideas with such stalwart shelter.
But the 90's have challenged the identity of alternative galleries. With the loosening of post-modernism's grip on the mainstream, and the weakening of the economy that supported it, the question arises: alternative to what? No one movement dominates architecture today. Theoretical "paper architecture," which once offered an alternative to conventional practice, has itself become a convention. Everything is an alternative on architecture's fragmented terrain. 
 "Discontinuous Spaces," a small show of recent work by the New York firm Smith-Miller & Hawkinson, tries to reckon with this changed configuration. Henry Smith-Miller and Laurie Hawkinson, the firm's principals, are not conventional commercial architects, but neither are they space cadets who think that to build is to compromise their artistic standards. Though the projects on view here -- a mix of commercial and residential designs and two large public works projects -- are designed to be built, they are conceptually sharp.
So is the show's installation. Working with the artist Silvia Kolbowski, Smith-Miller & Hawkinson has transformed Storefront's funky space into a pint-sized parody of a gallery at the Museum of Modern Art. Sloping plywood platforms straighten out the triangular floor into a more respectable rectangle. Bright overhead lighting, dazzling white walls, a gray painted floor and crisp modern graphics complete the clinical simulation, while the crumbling tin ceiling injects a hint of grunge. It's a downtown dream of uptown glory.
This kind of conceptual transposition is typical of Smith-Miller & Hawkinson's work. Many of their projects are intended to break down the barriers between dualisms like "uptown" and "downtown" by combining the visual forms that represent them. At times, their work can seem like word play, rather than design, especially in their collaborations with Barbara Kruger, a master of verbal visuals. They also want to erode architecture's conventional boundaries, as in two of the projects represented here: large, outdoor "art parks" for two American cities.
Working with Ms. Kruger and with the landscape architect Nicholas Quennell, Smith-Miller & Hawkinson seems to view architecture as a mediator between nature and culture. "The Textualized Landscape," shown here in models, is part of the team's master plan for a 160-acre park, now in construction, surrounding the North Carolina Museum of Art in Raleigh. The words "picture this" are spelled out in jumbo (85-foot-tall) capital letters, variously executed in boulders, gravel, plantings, concrete and jets of sprayed mist. The picture we're asked to imagine could be a movie, shown on a giant outdoor screen (the plan provides seating for 2,500 people), or it could be a vision of nature projected on the mind's inner screen. Landscape is land transformed by the eye into a visual image.
"Unoccupied Territory," the team's entry in a 1989 competition to design a cultural park for Los Angeles, rethinks the idea of the urban park in a decentralized city. The concept here is recentralization; instead of following the competition's instructions to disperse built elements over the 60-acre site, this plan concentrates them in one corner. In the remaining acres, new landscaped areas are juxtaposed with terrain carved naturally by floods. It's Capability Brown in La-La Land: a post-modern, desert version of an artificially natural English garden.
Like the proverbial beauty who sports fake eyeglasses, Smith-Miller & Hawkinson seems to fear that people won't respect their minds. The team often accompanies its projects with elaborate texts, packed with more ideas than mere forms can easily convey. The most striking object in the show is a section from a metal canopy the firm designed to hang over the ticket counter at the new USAir Terminal at La Guardia. The wing-shaped form, designed in collaboration with Guy Nordenson of Ove Arup & Partners, floats within an airy skein of cables and glass panels. Whether or not travelers will grasp all the ideas behind it, this ethereal object nonetheless conveys a primal connection between flying and aspiration. It says, "Look up!"
Ascent is also a theme in a current project for the New Jersey Institute of Architecture in Newark. Asked to design a staircase in the open space between two existing campus buildings, Smith-Miller & Hawkinson has turned a simple circulation route into a place where people will want to linger. Made of steel and concrete, the stair will rise five stories in a gentle slope; broad steps at the top will provide informal seating. At once glamorous and severe, this is a theatrical design, like something Ziegfeld might have commissioned from Piranesi.
"Discontinuous Spaces" remains at Storefront for Art and Architecture, 97 Kenmare Street, at Lafayette Street, SoHo, through June 8. Laurie Hawkinson and Henry Smith-Miller are to give a lecture on their work at the Urban Center (457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street) on Thursday at 6:30 P.M. Admission: $5.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A detail of "Unoccupied Territory," a park design for Los Angeles, at Storefront for Art and Architecture. (Henry Smith-Miller)

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
American Dream Shrinks to a Nap

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Declining Fortunes
 The Withering of
 the American Dream
 By Katherine S. Newman
 257 pages. Basic Books. $23.
The message of "Declining Fortunes: The Withering of the American Dream," a new book by the anthropologist Katherine S. Newman, is a familiar one: namely that the middle class has been squeezed in recent years by the national economy and by Reagan-Bush economic policies; that a shrinking job market, rising housing costs, higher taxes and growing cost-of-living expenses have imperiled some of the most basic, optimistic assumptions of the American Dream. It's a message that was debated at length in last year's Presidential campaign, and a message examined in detail by Kevin Phillips's recent book, "Boiling Point: Republicans, Democrats and the Decline of Middle-Class Prosperity." 
 Indeed, Ms. Newman appears to have taken as her jumping-off point one of Mr. Phillips's more casual observations: that Americans under the age of 35 are "in danger of being the first generation of Americans to suffer a lower standard of living than their parents" and "the first generation to receive -- or not receive -- much of their economic opportunity from family inheritance, not personal achievement."
What Ms. Newman proposes to do in "Declining Fortunes" is to examine these developments through the prism of a single suburban community. The community -- which she chooses to call Pleasanton -- is a small New Jersey town within commuting distance of New York City. She has changed the names of its residents to protect their privacy, and quotes them at length to illustrate her own ideas on the subject of the middle class's declining fortunes.
These ideas -- reiterated so many times as to bore the reader to distraction -- are neither new nor surprising. As Ms. Newman sees it, the postwar generation -- the generation that grew up with memories of the Depression and joined the work force during the booming 1950's -- benefited enormously from an upturn in the national economy, and from Government programs like the G.I. bill and low-interest mortgages, which swelled the ranks of the middle class. Successful members of this generation, says Ms. Newman, speak of their upward mobility in Horatio Alger terms of virtue and hard work, and tend to discount the role that large extra-personal forces had in shaping their prosperity. Their offspring -- members of the baby-boom generation -- have not been nearly as lucky.
Recession, unemployment, anemic rates of growth and higher living costs -- along with the sheer size of the baby-boom generation itself -- have combined, Ms. Newman argues, to make homeownership, "that essential piece of the American dream," harder and harder to achieve. Indeed, the unfortunate confluence of these developments, she says, effectively undermines the old article of faith that every generation will do better than the one that preceded it.
As seen through the lives of Pleasanton residents, this downturn in fortunes has led to disappointment and bitterness on the part of baby boomers and their younger siblings. It has also resulted, Ms. Newman reports, in changing patterns of living. Because financial security is increasingly elusive, baby boomers tend to marry later than their predecessors. They tend to have fewer children, and to have those children later. Women frequently continue working to supplement their husbands' incomes (here, Ms. Newman seriously underestimates the role that changing expectations and ambitions, wrought by the women's movement, have also played), though even with two incomes, baby-boom families find it more and more difficult to recreate their parents' standard of living.
As a consequence, there is a growing population of "boomerang" adults, that is, those who return home to live with their parents, and an increasing number of boomers who are forced to leave Pleasanton altogether for more inexpensive towns. This, in turn, Ms. Newman contends, leads to a dissolution of community, as outsiders -- many of them wealthy Asians -- move to Pleasanton, which in turn leads to growing resentments and racial tensions. The economic squeeze of the 1990's in general, adds Ms. Newman, has heightened feelings of prejudice toward both monied foreigners and the poor who benefit from welfare, as people from all income levels fight for bigger slices of a diminishing pie.
Having tossed off such unoriginal observations, Ms. Newman then switches gears and makes an impassioned appeal to members of the baby-boom generation to transcend their intergenerational differences (that is, the differences that separate the more idealistic boomers who grew up during the 1960's from the more pragmatic ones who came of age during the 80's) and unite as a political lobbying force.
"The baby-boom generation could become the most powerful political-interest group ever seen in the United States," Ms. Newman writes, pointing out that the elderly, a wealthy and well-organized population group, have long benefited from favorable governmental policies.
Although some of the interviews with Pleasanton residents succeed in giving the reader a highly personal sense of the consequences of America's economic problems, "Declining Fortunes" as a whole sheds little new light on the subject. Ms. Newman's prose is repetitious and long-winded, and it's put in the service of ideas that are banal, obvious or borrowed. Some of her generalizations are nothing more than shallow cliches. She solemnly declares that "without the boomers, we might never have seen the phenomenon of the Beatles, the Stones and the Grateful Dead, with their legions of followers now turning gray." And writing of one woman's desire to marry and have a family, she declares, "Edith's desire to settle into a 'Leave It to Beaver' life style was shared by virtually every other woman in Pleasanton."
This sort of silly attempt to make broad, anthropological generalizations undermines the intimacy of individual interviews in "Declining Fortunes," and it erases whatever positive feelings the reader might have had about this bloated, overly familiar book.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Katherine S. Newman. (Joe Pinero/Basic Books)
