HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Clinton Mystery

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
What has gone wrong with the Clinton Presidency? Can it be fixed? Or are we headed for another failure that will further erode public faith in the political system?
The questions are being asked -- astonishingly so, if you think how early it is. Four months into a new Administration, people who voted for it are wondering whether it can be saved. 
 Mr. Clinton has just won a big victory with House passage of his budget measure. That will raise morale in a bruised White House. But the doubts will not so easily go away.
It is the little things that hurt, as always in politics -- because they are a metaphor for larger worries. How could a man as smart as Bill Clinton tie up the Los Angeles Airport to get himself a $200 haircut? How could he be so oblivious to public reaction? Is there no one on his staff with the sense and the independence to tell him no?
Oblivious is the word, too, for the handling of the White House travel office affair. Put aside the cronyism charge being made by some in the press. Did no one on the Clinton staff understand how unfair it was to fire long-time employees as suspected wrongdoers without giving them a chance to defend themselves? Or how idiotic it would look to deny later that they had been fired?
The puzzle about this smart Administration is how it can be so oblivious to reality. And that goes much deeper than the attention-getting incidents of recent weeks.
A clue may lie in Mr. Clinton's campaign last year. It was a campaign of sweeping promises: sweeping and explicit. He did not just utter generalities about making America proud again. He said he would end welfare as we know it, end adult illiteracy within five years, give all Americans health care and pay for it out of cost controls, cut middle-class taxes, reduce the deficit. And so on.
Were those cynical promises by a candidate who knew how hard it would be to carry them out? To the contrary. Bill Clinton was part of a generation that rejected as an excuse the idea that things are hard to fix. It believed the country's problems stemmed from inept leadership, and believed it could solve them if it took power.
There is idealism in that view, but also dangerous naivete. The President is not a Galahad whose strength is as the strength of 10 if his heart is pure. Governing is hard work, the more so in a country whose Constitution divides power so it will be difficult to change things.
The President is the focus of the vast apparatus of modern communications. Americans look to him to solve all their problems. But the desire greatly outpaces the reality of Presidential power.
By all signs Bill Clinton believed in the Presidential myth when he took office. He seemed not to understand what it takes to govern: explaining, threatening, making friends, making enemies. Instead he wanted to be loved by everyone: which is not governing.
He has been a surprisingly uncommunicative President. He has talked a great deal: to this or that group just about every day. But he has hardly ever communicated a Big Idea to the public in a way that would sell it, not even his economic program.
It is a savage world for presidents these days, as those of us who criticize them ought to recognize.
The press is ravenous, ready to see scandal in a speck of dust. Its self-importance passes belief. Some kind of record may have been set this week, when a New Hampshire television anchor complained about being asked to put some makeup on President Clinton before interviewing him. Lese-majeste!
The talk show hosts are out there, spewing ignorance and hate. No rumor is too absurd or too invasive to repeat.
The Republican opposition is rigidly partisan, showing no willingness to face the economic mess that Republican Administrations created. And Mr. Clinton also has to worry about a midget Mussolini who claims he can make the trains run on time -- as long as you don't ask him how.
It is far too early to write Bill Clinton off. He is actually trying to deal with America's problems, unlike his predecessor, and he is famously resilient. But the realities of the Presidency are hard. If Mr. Clinton is going to recover from these first months, he had better add to his staff some people who understand political reality -- and show that he can deal with it himself.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Mayoral Poll Gives Asian-Americans the Invisible Treatment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the last decade, the number of Asian-Americans in New York City more than doubled. As the fastest growing racial group in the city, Asian-Americans amount to nearly 10 percent of its population, affecting every segment of society and bringing new cultural and economic vitality to its neighborhoods. 
 I was dismayed to see that your May 19 front-page report on a New York Times/WCBS-TV poll of support for Mayor David N. Dinkins along racial lines excluded Asian-Americans. Furthermore, your article ignorantly claims that, according to the poll, "a preponderance of New Yorkers of all ethnic and racial groups say they believe conditions in the city are worse than they were four years ago."
Does this include Asian-Americans? How do Asian-Americans feel about living conditions? How does Mayor Dinkins fare among Asian-Americans? Does anyone care?
This blatant exclusion of Asian-Americans in a poll that claims to have included "all ethnic and racial groups in the city" reflects the attitudes of those decision makers who are often lethargic in responding to the needs of Asian-Americans because of that community's political marginality. It is disheartening to see Asian-Americans dismissed as insignificant. Your poll sends the message that all communities are not valued equally and that Asian-Americans do not have much say in policy making, though we share many concerns and interests with all other Americans.
Asian-Americans are beginning to realize that our needs are not articulated adequately, and that there are inequities in the sharing of public resources. More and more, we are organizing to mobilize our vote and unlock the potential for participating in decision making. In New York City, a collaboration of more than 20 Asian-American organizations plans to begin a nonpartisan, citywide voter-registration and education drive in the summer months to increase voter participation by Asian-Americans.
We no longer want to be at the mercy of the political majority and apart from making decisions that affect our daily lives.
 
JONATHAN KIM
Coordinator, Coalition
for Korean American Voters
New York, May 19, 1993

HEADLINE: Mexico Wins, U.S. Workers Lose in Trade Pact

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Ross Perot is dead right on the North American Free Trade Agreement. If Congress approves it, we will be deafened by the "giant sucking sound" of jobs moving from the United States to Mexico. 
 It is surprising that so many otherwise sensible public officials, such as Don E. Newquist, chairman of the International Trade Commission, in "Perot Is Dead Wrong on Nafta" (Op-Ed, May 10), put so much faith in the dozens of blue ribbon studies that conclude otherwise.
 Yet, these studies are based on flawed assumptions and simplistic economic models that render them useless, even dangerous for policy making. Virtually all depend on mathematical models that assume the United States economy will operate at full employment after the agreement is enacted.
A recent International Trade Commission survey of the leading studies, including its own, reports that the mathematical models omit key parts of the agreement because they were "hard to quantify." These include the rules-of-origin requirements in the computer, automotive and textile sectors. Yet, these three industries constitute a major component of United States-Mexican trade.
The International Trade Commission also reports that these models do not analyze the intellectual property protections in the trade agreement. Nor are these models able to calculate the effect of the trade agreement on important agricultural sectors, such as sugar. So large segments of United States-Mexican agricultural trade are omitted as well.
Most significant, the International Trade Commission reports that these economic models are unable to "incorporate potential increases in Mexican investment" resulting from the agreement. This is a huge gap, especially now that the Clinton Administration acknowledges that it is mainly an investment agreement.
The lure is simple -- lax Mexican regulations and $1.15 an hour wages. By the Mexican Government's estimates, investors gain roughly $15,000 for each United States job that is shifted to Mexico.
The most famous of these groups is the AmeriMex Maquiladora Fund, which is buying and relocating United States manufacturers where labor is 20 percent or more of production costs, and wages top $7 an hour. For such companies, labor costs largely determine competitiveness and where they put their facilities. By applying this yardstick nationally and by states to Census Bureau data on United States manufacturing, we can identify which industries and jobs are vulnerable to relocation to Mexico or low-wage Mexican competition.
More than 5.9 million United States production jobs in 75 distinct industries meet the AmeriMex investment and relocation criteria. Nationally, these jobs provide more than $138 billion of payroll. Under the trade agreement, most of these United States jobs would be at risk.
The trade agreement's most important feature is that it would make Mexico safe for foreign investors. It provides for quick payment at market prices of expropriated properties, protects the intellectual property rights of investors and allows foreigners to repatriate their profits. Disputes are to be handled by a new institution beyond the reach of Mexico's corrupt courts. And these investor protections are locked up in an international agreement beyond the reach of Mexico's politicians.
The trade agreement is Mexico's "Field of Dreams." If it is enacted, United States investors will come. Ross Perot is right.
 
PAT CHOATE
Washington, May 19, 1993
 
The writer, a political economist, wrote the study "Jobs at Risk."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: The Overview;
HOUSE GIVES NARROW APPROVAL TO CLINTON BUDGET PROPOSALS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The House of Representatives approved the heart of President Clinton's budget plan today, giving him the most crucial legislative and political victory of his young Presidency.
The vote, 219 to 213, was solidly along party lines, with 218 Democrats and an independent voting for the measure and only 38 Democrats defecting to join the 175 Republicans in opposition. [Roll-call, page A12.] 
 President Clinton went to the White House Rose Garden after the debate and declared, "Tonight, the House said no to gridlock, no to the status quo and no to the special interests who worked so very hard to frighten millions of Americans about this program."
 
Few Votes to Spare
 With nearly every seat taken on the House floor, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington closed the debate by declaring, "It will be remembered tonight what we do in this chamber."
Democratic leaders said the President had fewer than a half-dozen votes in reserve after the final tally -- Democrats who would have voted for the measure if it had meant the difference between victory and defeat.
An hour and a half before the vote, with a majority still uncertain, a letter was circulated threatening Democratic subcommittee chairmen with the loss of their positions if they voted against the measure. In the end, only 11 of 110 subcommittee chairmen, none of national stature, opposed the measure.
 
Basic Clinton Plan Survives
 "The last five votes were like pulling teeth," said Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a deputy whip.
After a debate that began in the morning and lasted well past the dinner hour, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, made a final pitch for the President's deficit-reduction program. His son had just graduated from college, Mr. Gephardt said, adding: "The gift I want to give him is to remove this dagger that's pointing at our economic heart. I want his future to be better than mine, as mine was better than my mother's and father's."
To lower the Federal budget deficit, the measure would raise the taxes of almost all Americans except the poor, and new steps would be taken to restrain spending.
Small changes were made, but by and large the bill that was approved contains what Mr. Clinton proposed in February: higher tax rates for wealthy individuals and all but the smallest corporations; a new tax on almost all forms of fuel; income taxes on a larger portion of the Social Security benefits of upper- and middle-income retirees; tax cuts for the working poor and near-poor, through an expanded earned-income credit; limits on spending for benefit programs like Medicare, and a freeze on total spending for all other Government programs after adjustments for inflation.
Almost two-thirds of the tax increases would be borne by families earning more than $200,000, and almost three-quarters would come from those with incomes above $100,000 -- about 6 percent of the American taxpaying public.
 
2 Houses, 2 Battles
 The legislation, called a reconciliation bill, is sure to be changed in the Senate, where the President has faced persistent trouble from his own party. But the nature of those changes is unclear, and no one can predict what the final bill will look like after the differences between the House and Senate are worked out.
Senators who oppose the proposed energy tax are especially influential, and the White House has already promised some concessions on it to gain support for Mr. Clinton's plan. In addition, party discipline in the Senate is more lax than it is in the House. The Senate Finance Committee could begin work on the legislation as early as next week, and a vote in the Senate could come before July 4.
But with the political future of the Clinton Presidency riding on today's vote, Administration officials set aside their worries about the Senate for the time being and concentrated on rounding up support in the House of Representatives. They said that if they failed to get the budget through the House, where the Democrats hold nearly a 3-to-2 majority, they could forget about health-care changes, welfare reform, a national service program and other Clinton initiatives.
The debate followed days of arm twisting by the President and his allies from the inside and furious lobbying from the outside. A few concessions were made to persuade the undecided, several of whom were brought around by an early-morning agreement to institute new budget procedures designed to control spending on benefit programs.
 
'A Nice Booster Shot'
 But the White House based its attack primarily on party loyalty, warning freshmen Democrats that if the budget plan failed, they would be held personally responsible for the damage to Mr. Clinton's Presidency.
With the early-evening nose counts showing a victory in hand, the mood in the White House today had been upbeat for the first time in days, if not weeks.
David Dreyer, an assistant to the President, called the House vote "a nice booster shot at a time when we need it."
Mark Gearan, the deputy chief of staff, said it was "hard to overestimate" the importance of the vote to Mr. Clinton and his Presidency.
The vote's political significance to Mr. Clinton pervaded the House debate. Pleading for support from his Democratic colleagues, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn said that a defeat for the President's plan would "cut him off at the knees early in his term, and we can't do that."
Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader, said a defeat was deserved. "Candidate Clinton promised middle-income Americans a tax cut," he said. "President Clinton now wants to thrust upon middle-income Americans an enormous tax increase."
Mr. Michel continued: "Let's face it. The Clinton White House is out of touch. It's out of synch. It's out of ideas. It's out of excuses. And it's out of control."
Like many other Democrats, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin implored the House to "give the President a chance."
To such pleas, Representative Jim Bunning, a Kentucky Republican, retorted: "Bill Clinton was elected on promises. A promise to cut the deficit. A promise to cut middle class taxes. Yes, Bill Clinton deserves a chance -- a chance to live up to his promises."
After a long day of lobbying that continued right up until the House vote, more than 40 members of the President's staff who had anxiously watched the close decision spilled onto the lawn in the Rose Garden to hear Mr. Clinton claim victory.
Standing on the West Wing portico flanked by Vice President Al Gore; Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff; and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Mr. Clinton praised members of the House for having the "courage and conviction" to make "hard choices."
 
G.O.P. Sees Election Leverage
 Outside the House chamber, Mr. Clinton's budget director, Leon E. Panetta, wearily accepted congratulations from friends.
"I've never seen Democrats working so hard to win a vote," said Mr. Panetta, a former Representative from California.
Republicans took some solace from defeat. Mr. Michel, the party leader, asserted, "It meant they had to squeeze everyone they possibly could."
The No. 2 Republican, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said he looked forward to the next election when Republicans would be able to accuse every Democrat of being one of the votes that swung the tide for a tax increase.
There was little pattern to the Democratic defectors except that they tended to be somewhat conservative and to have shaky seats politically.
Seven of 21 Texans voted against the bill, as did three of seven Democrats from New Jersey: Robert E. Andrews, Herbert C. Klein and Frank Pallone Jr.
 
With 1 Minute to Spare
 Democratic freshmen voted 51 to 11 to support the President. One who voted against him was Carolyn B. Maloney of Manhattan.
With 4 1/2 minutes to go in the 15 minutes allotted for the vote, the tally in favor of the measure was stuck at 210, eight shy of an absolute majority, the 218 votes needed if all 435 members voted. Democrats began applauding rhythmically. Gradually new votes were recorded on the electronic tally board -- 211, 212, 213 -- and with each one, a cheer went up. Finally, with a minute to go, the magic number, 218, was reached. Democrats began jumping for joy and hugging each other.
Among the last to come around for the President was Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, who as recently as Wednesday had said he would vote against the bill.
During the debates, Republicans stood firm against higher taxes, repeating their mantra from the 1980's that a sound economy depended on low taxes.
But Democrats said the Clinton plan represented a turn to new policies and away from the excesses of the 1980's.
The chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, put the case this way: "This bill requires sacrifice. But the sacrifice is small compared to the price of continuing on our present course, risking our fiscal integrity and the standard of living for ourselves, our children and our grandchildren."
 
Biting (and Spitting) Bullets
 Mr. Rostenkowski, a master at manipulating legislation, was largely responsible for packaging the Clinton proposals to win the most possible support, and he was the main floor manager of the bill today. This was the first time he had presided with a Democrat in the White House, he told his colleagues, and that meant extra responsibility.
"There is no credible alternative," he asserted. "We have but one choice: to lead."
Biting the bullet was the favored Democratic metaphor. "Today is the day," said Al Swift of Washington. "This is the bullet."
Democrats maintained that their program to lower the deficit would keep interest rates down, leading to business expansion and more jobs. Republicans challenged that, returning time and again to the argument that higher taxes would increase unemployment.
"This bill," said Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican from Connecticut, "takes more money than has ever been taken at any one time from the sector that creates jobs."
In all, the bill would raise taxes by about $250 billion over five years and would lower the spending on automatic benefit programs by nearly $100 billion. The lawmakers also voted for the freeze in other programs, called discretionary spending, that would save about $100 billion over five years.
How much will actually be available for each of these discretionary programs will be decided later during the appropriations process, but much of the savings is sure to come from the military.
The rest of the total deficit reduction, which is projected to be nearly $500 billion over five years, would come from lower interest payments as the deficit falls.
Before passing the bill, the House rejected a Republican plan that would have contained no tax increases and much deeper cuts in spending than the Clinton program.
The vote, basically along party lines, was 295 to 138.
On a key procedural vote early in the day, the House adopted a resolution known as a rule, which set the terms for the debate. The vote was 236 to 194, with all but 19 Democrats in favor and all Republicans against.
In many respects, the emphasis lawmakers from both parties placed on reducing the budget deficit reflected the political influence of Ross Perot. But Mr. Perot's own proposals, including a 50-cents-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes, probably could not command 100 votes in the House.
Lobbying on the measure has been ferocious all month, especially from businesses and petroleum interests who oppose the fuel tax.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 29, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A roll-call listing yesterday showing the vote on the tax bill in the House of Representatives showed an incorrect total in some copies for Democrats who voted for the measure. The total was 218, not 248.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Sinks Against Yen Despite Fed's Moves

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The American dollar, falling all week against the Japanese yen, took a sharp plunge yesterday -- to the lowest level since World War II -- because the traders who buy and sell currencies seem convinced that the Clinton Administration wants a weak dollar to reduce the nation's trade deficit with Japan.
As the dollar fell to 107.20 yen in late New York trading from 108.50 on Wednesday, the Government tried to reverse this impression and stop the slide in the dollar's value. The Federal Reserve, for the second time this year, sold yen and bought dollars -- hoping that traders would follow its lead and that the demand for dollars would increase the dollar's value. A Treasury official helped that cause by denying the existence of a Clinton policy favoring a strong yen. 
 But the traders preferred their view that the Administration really wants a much smaller trade deficit with Japan, and one way to achieve this goal is through a weaker dollar, perhaps as weak as 100 yen. A weak dollar makes American goods less expensive in Japan, thus increasing exports, and Japanese goods more costly in the United States, thus reducing imports from Japan.
"The Fed's intervention this time was just a tap on the shoulder and not large enough to signify strenuous opposition to the slide or to muscle the market," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
Although the Federal Reserve intervened at least three times yesterday, currency traders concluded that the Fed lacked the determination of its efforts on April 27, when the dollar broke below 110 yen for the first time and the Fed repeatedly bought dollars and sold yen, temporarily reversing the slide.
The April intervention, in turn, was the first by the Fed since 1988. It was intended in part to quiet criticism from Japan about the rising value of the yen and the damage that might result to Japanese exports. During the Bush Administration, the dollar never fell in value below 120 yen.
"There is this general feeling that the Administration has been talking down the dollar vis-a-vis the yen, and for the foreseeable future, the pressure will be there for the yen to continue to appreciate in value," said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter.
The dollar also fell yesterday against European currencies, including the German mark. It was pushed down in part by reports earlier this week suggesting that the American economy might be weakening again. But the fall was only slight. Since President Clinton's inauguration, the dollar has remained strong against every major currency except the yen, and there the fall has been breathtaking at times, including this week. Since last Friday, the dollar's value has declined by nearly three yen.
 
Toward a Currency Crisis?
 "There is a cumulative process occurring, accumulating in the direction of a currency crisis," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston Inc. Mr. Jones and others also cited, as a reason for the dollar's slide against the yen yesterday, a growing optimism that Japan might be shaking off recession.
Some Japanese interest rates have risen recently, perhaps in anticipation of a strengthening economy. Whatever the reason, rising Japanese interest rates encourage people with dollars to sell them and purchase yen in order to buy Japanese securities. The performance yesterday was the week's highlight. The dollar fell to new lows after each of the Fed's first two interventions and, after the third attempt, it finally leveled off -- but without regaining lost ground. "The interventions were only symbolic," Mr. Sullivan said.
Lawrence H. Summers, Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, tried yesterday to distance the Administration from the dollar's falling value. But his remarks failed to have an impact. "We certainly are not seeking and have no policy of promoting the appreciation of the yen," Mr. Summers told the Bloomberg News Service. "The market has moved too far, too fast."
 
A Different Tack
 But on Tuesday, Mr. Summers had taken a different tack. He said that the Administration in no way favored "a policy of trying to devalue your way into prosperity." Nevertheless, a Treasury report issued the same day recognized that a rising yen served as "a counterweight to the forces tending to increase Japan's" trade surplus. That linking a strong yen to a shrinking trade deficit is a theme that has been cited several times in recent months by Administration officials.
Until this week the dollar had generally stayed above 110 yen, after having fallen to that record-low level in April from 125 yen in January. The Federal Reserve rarely acknowledges its interventions, but traders said that the Fed clearly came into the market three times yesterday -- twice yesterday morning, when the dollar was still trading above 108 yen and once in the early afternoon when the rate was 107.4 yen.

Dollar Falls in Japan
 By Bloomberg Business News
 TOKYO, Friday, May 28 -- The dollar fell in Tokyo today, after its plunge in New York. In the afternoon, the dollar was quoted at 107.43 yen, down from 108.05 yen in Tokyo on Thursday, but slightly higher than the late New York quote of 107.20 yen.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the dollar's sharp decline against the Japanese yen referred incorrectly to the Federal Reserve's intervention in the currency markets on April 27. That intervention was the first since November 1989 in which the Federal Reserve sold yen to buy dollars.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Where an Arc Once Ruled
The General Services Administration has come up with a new and decidedly politically correct plan for the space surrounding 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan. It involves the American sculptor Beverly Pepper and the Boston landscape architect Martha Schwartz, and the new scheme comes with the neighborhood seal of approval.
Four years have passed since the furor over Richard Serra's "Tilted Arc," the monumental steel sculpture that bisected the space in front of 26 Federal Plaza from 1981 to 1989. After a prolonged and heated artistic battle that involved the plaza's tenants and neighborhood residents, the 12-foot-high, 112-foot-long piece was proclaimed by the agency to have rendered the plaza unusable. In 1989 the work was dismantled and removed, an act that the artist said was tantamount to destroying it. 
 The new plans for the outdoor spaces surrounding the Government offices at 26 Federal Plaza are intended not to make waves. "We're not trying to be more conservative, but public art has changed since the 'Tilted Arc' days," said Dale Lanzone, the agency's director of arts and historical preservation. "These decisions are a public process now. I'm not saying we can please everyone, but it's not like driving a train into a wall."
Mr. Lanzone explained that art is commissioned by an 11-member panel, consisting of the project architect, five representatives of the arts and five members nominated by civic leaders like the Mayor or members of Congress, or by the occupants of the building where the art will be placed.
In two years, Mr. Lanzone said, Federal Plaza will be have "one large environmental piece" in the spot where "Tilted Arc" once was. It is being designed by Ms. Schwartz. The $1.4 million project is a combination of landscaping and repairs, since there was water damage to the plaza's pavement. "The plaza will be treated very much as a work of art, but it will be a usable space, the antithesis of Serra's treatment," Mr. Lanzone said.
Because of the site's turbulent history, Mr. Lanzoni said, the new design was submitted to the tenants of 26 Federal Plaza, which are all Federal agencies, and to neighborhood representatives. The agency decided not to commission a sculpture for the plaza because it was just "too sensitive to ask an artist to design a sculpture for the same place where 'Tilted Arc' was," he added.
 
Trees, Columns and Light
 For the west side of the building, which faces Broadway and has always been empty the agency has awarded a $355,000 commission to Ms. Pepper, whose site-specific environment will be on the terrace.
"I'm trying to bring landscape back into the city," Ms. Pepper said. Her design includes a series of 30 cast-iron columns, 36 feet high, in circles of three, which rise through a cluster of trees with seating areas. During the day, it will feel as though one is sitting in a parklike setting, she said. At night, fiber-optic lights will make each column appear as a vertical strip among the trees.
"This is a kind of romance about landscape," Ms. Pepper said. "In winter, the branches will resemble lacework." The artist, who lives in Todi, Italy, a medieval town near Perugia, said she likes the Italian tradition of people sitting on steps. "I'm not trying to invite controversy," she added, "but to create a landscape with sculpture set in an urban atmosphere."
 
A Friedrich for the Getty
 The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., reached into its deep pockets yet again last week and spent $3.6 million for "Walk at Dusk," a Romantic landscape painting by the German artist Caspar David Friedrich, at Christie's in London. The work, which depicts a man approaching a monolithic tomb by moonlight, is one of the last pictures painted by the artist before he died in 1835.
"The tomb actually existed; it wasn't something Friedrich invented," said George R. Goldner, the Getty's curator of paintings and drawings. "It was a place where he would go to sketch."
Works by Friedrich rarely come up at auction, and almost none are in the United States. The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth is the only other American museum with a Friedrich in its collection. The Kimbell bought "A Mountain Peak With Drifting Clouds" from the Colnaghi gallery in London nine years ago.
Lord Poltimore, director of 19th-century Continental pictures at Christie's in London, said several American museums had shown considerable interest in this Friedrich. "It was a brave choice for the Getty," he said. "It shows it is breaking into new territory." Lord Poltimore added that the painting had originally been discovered in 1965, in the attic of a house owned by a German doctor known to Christie's only as H. Voith. Dr. Voith apparently sold the painting, and for a number of years it went into obscurity.
"In the 60's the opinion was the painting was by Karl Gustav Carcus, a contemporary and pupil of Friedrich," Lord Poltimore said. "But over the years, the scholars changed their minds. Now there is no doubt but that it is by Friedrich." When the painting surfaced again, its owner, an unidentified German collector, put it up for sale at Christie's. Lord Poltimore said the painting had never been on the open market before.
 
Big Spender
 In the last few years, the Getty has been a frequent buyer at the London painting auctions, and most of its purchases have set record prices. In December 1991, for example, the Getty bought Titian's "Venus and Adonis" at Christie's for $13.4 million, and last December, it bought Goya's "Bullfight Suerte de Varas," for $7.9 million at Sotheby's.
The $3.6 million the Getty paid for the Friedrich was another record for an artist; it exceeded the $2.3 million paid in 1987 for his "Winter Landscape" by the National Gallery in London at Christie's in Monaco. "We felt this was a fair price, and it fits our program well," Mr. Goldner said this week. "It's a good balance to our 19th-century works."
"It was a good moment to be buying a Friedrich," he added. "Were the German economy not so weak, there would have been big competition."
 
Millions for Americans
 American art is fetching seven-figure prices at auction this spring. Childe Hassam's "Room of Flowers," from 1894, sold for a record $5.5 million yesterday at Sotheby's in New York. The scene of a room crammed with furniture, paintings and flowers was bought by Richard Manoogian, a Detroit industrialist who is a major American collector. The seller was Arthur Altschul, the financier. The previous record for a Hassam was set in 1989 when "The Fourth of July," from 1916, sold for $3.1 million at Christie's in New York. Another big-ticket painting sold at Sotheby's was "Peonies," from 1897, by William Merritt Chase, which was bought for $3.9 million by Berry-Hill, the Manhattan gallery.
At the sale of American paintings, drawings and sculpture on Wednesday at Christie's in New York, Remington's "Wounded Bunkie," from 1896, a recently discovered cast of cavalrymen on horseback, was sold for $1.9 million to an unidentified American dealer. It was the only work that brought more than $1 million.
 
Losing a Deputy
 Perhaps there's room for only one Earl at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. It's been eight months since Earl A. Powell 3d became the gallery's director. Now, Earl Roger Mandle, the gallery's deputy director, is leaving to become president of the 116-year-old Rhode Island School of Design in Providence. His new job takes effect in August.
"I've been at the National Gallery since July 1988, and I'm leaving for a great opportunity," Mr. Mandle said. "Education has always been my special interest, and there are a lot of artists in my family: my sister, my son and my daughter. So the move is a perfect one for me."
A spokeswoman for the museum said that no decision had been made about who would fill Mr. Mandle's position, but that the post would not be left vacant.

HEADLINE: A Lover Leaps to Join Her Slain Fiance in Death

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Shaleen Wadhwami and Hema Sakhrani met and fell in love at New York University, two successful children of immigrant families from India who seemed to have limitless futures. They planned to marry in July, a month before Mr. Wadhwami started medical school on a full scholarship, a courtship as well as budding careers that delighted their families and friends in the closely knit Indian communities of Queens and Long Island.
One man did not share their joy. Chandran Nathan, the police said, had an obsession with Ms. Sakhrani. Late Wednesday night, the police said, he went to the door of Mr. Wadhwami's home in Manhasset, L.I., carrying a semiautomatic rifle and fired 20 bullets at the young man, killing him as his parents slept upstairs. 
 Anguished, Ms. Sakhrani jumped to her death yesterday morning from the 16th-floor terrace of her family's apartment in Rego Park, Queens, the police said.
"We are all in such mourning," Mr. Wadhwami's father, Nari, said numbly yesterday afternoon as he and his wife, Sunita, left the apartment building of their son's fiance after consoling her family. "We cannot talk at all right now."
Mr. Nathan, a 35-year-old actuary for the City of New York, who is married, was arrested on Thursday near his home in Richmond Hill, Queens, and charged with the murder of the 20-year-old Mr. Wadhwami. He was arraigned yesterday in First District Court in Hempstead, L.I., and ordered held without bail.
Neighbors in Richmond Hill said Mr. Nathan was quiet and unfriendly. The neighbors, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that he had reported people for building violations, including one person who had an illegal tenant in his basement and another who built a shed without a permit.
Mr. Nathan would also place notes on parked cars in front of his modest two-story home, signing them as an Emergency Medical Service paramedic who needed the space, one neighbor said.
Another neighbor said that he and his family heard two gunshots from Mr. Nathan's house around 3:45 A.M. on Tuesday.
"He is a very antisocial guy," said one man who lives two houses down. "He never speaks. A real mysterious guy."
A neighbor said that Mr. Nathan's wife had told another neighbor that she planned to go to the Philippines on Tuesday. She had said that she grew up there, he said.
Detective Lieut. Frank B. Guidice, the commander of the homicide squad for the Nassau County Police Department, said that Mr. Nathan, a friend of the Sakhranis who had known the young woman most of her life, had begun expressing an interest in Ms. Sakhrani on numerous occasions recently.
Mr. Nathan, who lives with his wife at 107-23 124th Street, became upset when he learned of her engagement, though he did not make any threats, even after meeting Mr. Wadhwami for the first time last week, Lieutenant Guidice said.
"He knew her most of her life," he said. "His interest developed into a romantic interest, and he actively pursued her. He had just learned of the engagement, and we believe that's what precipitated the killing."
The killing and the apparent suicide, and the jealousy that seemingly led to them, deeply shocked the middle-class communities of South Asians in Queens and Long Island, as well as those in the university and medical communities who knew the young couple. Friends, relatives and colleagues described both as warm, charming and intellectually precocious, models of immigrant success.
In the driveway outside Mr. Wadhwami's home in Manhasset, its bullet-pocked foyer visible through the front door, a family friend, Ram Kumar, described the deaths as a tragedy for both families and the entire community. Mr. Wadhwami and Ms. Sakhrani, both born in the United States, were comfortable in American society but remained rooted in their deeply religious Hindu culture, he said.
"They had the best of both worlds," he said as Mr. Wadhwami's brother, Deepak, and his wife, Renu, stood silently nearby, visibly shaken.
Later, Sham Bhatia, the father of Renu Wadhwami, said the family's tragedy came at what should have been a time of joy, as plans for the wedding in July neared completion. "The wedding dresses are all made," he said. "When I saw them, I had tears in my eyes."
At Ms. Sakhrani's home in Park City Estates, a complex of five brick apartment towers surrounding a verdant garden square, a stream of relatives and friends came to console her family, described as too distraught to speak about the deaths yesterday.
 
'A Perfect Couple'
 "Nobody knew something like this could happen," said Sheela Wanti, a friend of the Sakhranis and the Wadhwamis who lives in Floral Park, Queens. "Everybody knew them. He was very bright, the best intellect the community had seen in a long time. Together, they were a perfect couple."
Mr. Wadhwami, who went to Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, studied economics and graduated cum laude at New York University in October 1992. A premed student and an Alumni Scholar, he received a scholarship to attend New York University Medical School starting in August, a spokesman for the university, Virgil Renzulli, said.
Ms. Sakhrani completed her junior year at the university this month. A chemistry major, she received a presidential scholarship, given by the university to students for academic success and community service in high school.
Awaiting medical school, Mr. Wadhwami worked as a research assistant at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, a part of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. Dr. Ira J. Goldberg, an associate professor at the college, described Mr. Wadhwami as "a thoughtful, serious and dedicated young man" and called his death "a loss for today and for the future."
According to the police reconstruction, Mr. Wadhwami was in his bedroom at his family's home on Bayview Avenue overlooking Manhasset Bay when the doorbell rang at 11:45 P.M. When he answered the door, he saw a man with a rifle who said nothing.
As he tried to close the door, the police said, the man fired through the door, then forced it open and continued to fire a barrage of at least 20 bullets. Mr. Wadhwami, who would have turned 21 yesterday, died in the hallway, struck 11 times in the torso.
Detectives from Nassau County arrested Mr. Nathan on the street near his home about noon on Thursday. They seized a semiautomatic rifle, but the lieutenant said they had not yet determined if it was the rifle used in the killing.
Detectives told Ms. Sakhrani and her family of the killing Thursday. "She was obviously very upset," Lieutenant Guidice said.
Yesterday morning, Ms. Sakhrani became even more distraught after reading a newspaper account of the killing, he said. She spoke with her brother before she jumped from the apartment's terrace, but Lieutenant Guidice declined to discuss any more details of what happened in the apartment, saying the family had been disturbed by the publicity and wanted to mourn privately.
Relatives said they would hold a funeral for Mr. Wadhwami and Ms. Sakhrani together on Monday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The courtship of Hema Sakhrani, left, and Shaleen Wadhwami ended in tragedy as Mr. Wadhwami was slain, according to the police by a jealous admirer of his fiancee, and Ms. Sakhrani killed herself. Chandran Nathan, who is charged in the murder of Mr. Wadhwami. (pg. 22)

HEADLINE: Tokyo, Outrageously Costly, Gets More So for Americans

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 28

 BODY:
Tokyo has long ranked as the world's most outrageously expensive city. American tourists loved to go home with tales of street vendors selling muskmelons for $100 apiece. Now, with a surge in the yen that has shaken Japan for the last three months and driven the American dollar to historic lows, the outrageous has turned to the ridiculous for anyone brave enough to measure prices in dollars.
So ridiculous that when President Clinton arrives here in five weeks for his first economic summit meeting, he won't have to summon a big-name hair stylist to Air Force One to run up a $200 tab. He can easily drop that much getting his hair styled in the Okura Hotel, where Presidents traditionally stay. 
 If political prudence induces him to settle for a quick trim and a shampoo, the hotel's barber said the other day that he could handle it for 11,500 yen, a mere $107.50 based on today's record high rate of around 107 yen. For the Japanese, of course, the price in yen has remained the same; only those paying in dollars suffer.
That includes Mr. Clinton, and Japanese officials clearly would not mind if his trip to Tokyo burns a hole in his pocket. After all, they say, isn't a rising yen what he wanted? On the airwaves and in the newspapers, where the soaring yen dominates the news, the Clinton Administration is portrayed as the chief villain in the latest round of endaka, the term for a rising yen.
Under the many conspiracy theories circulating here, the Clinton Administration has decided to cause the maximum pain to Japanese industry by driving up the price of its exports. The only problem is that the strategy has so far done nothing to narrow the trade gap between Japan and the United States; in fact, when Japan reports new trade figures in coming days, they are expected to show a huge jump from the previous few months.
But if the rising yen has yet to slice a chunk out of the trade numbers, it certainly has left a mark on the tens of thousands of Americans in Tokyo -- especially those who are paid in dollars. Over the last few months they have watched in horror as their salaries have dropped in value by roughly 15 percent.
At least it has made the math easier. Working out costs in dollars used to involve thinking in multiples of seven or eight. For example, a 10,000-yen note, which passes through the hands the way a $20 bill does in America, was actually worth somewhere from $66 to $80 in recent years. But that was with the yen flitting between 125 and 150 to the dollar.
"Now it's simple," said Kathleen A. Kriger, the general manager of Jardine Business Services here, which rents out furnished offices to foreign companies unable to afford regular Tokyo real estate costs. "There's no multiplication. To convert to dollars you just drop the last two digits. And you've spent a hundred dollars."
If classical economic theory meant much in this town, though, foreign-made goods should suddenly be cheaper -- 15 percent cheaper than they were a few months ago based on the rising yen.
But like everything in Japan, these things operate by Japanese logic, something Adam Smith never witnessed. Companies that buy their raw materials overseas go into marvelous contortions these days explaining why they have not dropped their prices in yen.
 
Energy Prices Stay High
 Japan's utilities, for example, which charge more for electricity than any other utilities in the world, have not passed on their savings from buying oil, which is priced in dollars. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has backed them up, saying they "do not have sufficient resources."
Prices of American-grown food have not dropped either. But a few companies are reacting to criticism that they are simply pocketing the difference: Tiffany's said the other day that it would shave a few yen from jewelry prices in hopes of drawing Japanese back into its stores.
Still, to make one's way through Tokyo these days is to feel that $100 bills are flying through your hands -- and all you did was meet someone for a quick lunch and took a 10-minute taxi ride back to the office.
And that's a cheap day. A bullet train ride to Kyoto, about the distance between New York and Washington, now runs $120. At Meidi-ya, a supermarket that caters to the affluent, a gift fruit basket, the kind you would send to a prospective client, runs $231. Taking clients out to a kaiseki dinner -- the traditional Buddhist meal of exquisitely presented sushi, sashimi and vegetables -- can run $230 to $400 a head, more if you drink.
All this has thrown something of a monkey wrench into President Clinton's strategy of making American business grow in Japan. While American-made goods should be cheaper here, the cost of doing business has caused many companies -- which often give their American employees in Japan a cost-of-living adjustment -- to think twice about sending more of their employees abroad.
No wonder. A few weeks ago a consulting firm that advises American companies on how to arrange compensation packages for their workers abroad concluded that to feed and house a family of four on a mid-level executive income would require roughly $110,000 a year in extra payments for housing and cost-of-living adjustments.
That was before the yen's run-up; now the figure would be closer to $125,000. The biggest component of that, of course, is housing. Unlike the Japanese, most expatriate senior executives live close to the center of Tokyo where a three-bedroom apartment can easily rent for 1 million yen a month, which at today's exchange is $9,345.79.
 
Big Japanese Salaries
 Hiring Japanese workers instead of Americans is not much of a solution. The other day the office head of an American electronics company, having a beer after work with a friend (three beers: 3,200 yen, or $29.90), confided that he had made a horrifying discovery. His Japanese deputy, already well paid in yen, was now making nearly twice as much in dollar terms as the American executive, who is paid in dollars.
"We can't pay him less; we'd lose him," the executive said. "And he doesn't even feel rich," he said, noting that his colleague stands for an hour on the train every morning to get to work.
In the meantime, Government officials here have begun lashing out. Yuji Tanahashi, the Vice Minister of International Trade and Industry, said that the problem was that the Administration's desires were "incomprehensible," a series of mixed signals to the markets.
"We cannot understand why they say that they welcome a stronger yen, and then deny their previous words," said Mr. Tanahashi, who contends that the yen's run-up, by making Japanese exports so expensive abroad, is going to choke off Japan's efforts to recover from its current economic downturn.
In fact, some things here have become cheaper. Because of the Japanese recession, property prices are still dropping, though from stratospheric heights. Prices of long-distance telephone calls and personal computers have all come down sharply, largely because of American-induced competition.
And the muskmelons? They are now $138, on the shelf next to the $185 box of perfectly formed, individually cushioned cherries. Cheapskates should go over one aisle, where a can of Spam costs $6.48.
It is almost enough to make you skip eating and drinking and just stretch out with the papers. But that can be costly, too. A Sunday issue of The New York Times now costs $42.91, three days late.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: Arm-Twisting;
When the President Rings, Mavericks Run for Cover

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
The White House telephone operators can reach Boris N. Yeltsin or Queen Elizabeth II in a snap. But they could not find Representative Collin C. Peterson all Thursday afternoon.
He was hiding from the President in the House gym. 
 By his own account, the Minnesota Democrat preferred straining his biceps with barbells to telling President Clinton that he did not want to vote for the Administration's budget plan. Like a score of other lawmakers coming under the White House squeeze, Mr. Peterson agonized that his vote could sink the new President.
 
Last-Minute Switch
 But a junior lawmaker can only sweat it out so long. Mr. Peterson broke down to take Mr. Clinton's call in the final minutes before casting his vote on Thursday night, and then he changed his mind.
"The President said, 'I'm new on the job and I need your help,' " Mr. Peterson recalled. "He said, 'Give me a chance and I'll try to help you out with your problems.' "
Mr. Clinton clinched Mr. Peterson's vote when he promised to agree to reduce the energy tax, which the Minnesota lawmaker contends would hit farmers especially hard. Still, Mr. Peterson said his commitment was conditioned on the pledge that the final version of the legislation would have a very different energy tax when it is sent back to the House after votes by the Senate and a House-Senate conference committee .
"If we don't get changes, I'll vote no" on final passage, Mr. Peterson concluded. "I told him that."
 
Night of Deals
 Mr. Peterson's decision was one of a handful of last-minute switches that helped Mr. Clinton eke out his 219-to-213 victory. Backed by the House leadership, Mr. Clinton doled out heaps of sugar and salt to cook up deals.
Some conservative Democratic lawmakers said that in exchange for their votes, Mr. Clinton even agreed to remove some younger, inexperienced officials in the White House -- and to steer his Administration back to its original centrist course.
The intensity of the Administration lobbying was so fierce that some of the 38 Democrats who broke with their party have expressed fear that they may be punished by their leaders and the White House for years to come. One lawmaker said the daylong anxiety was punctuated by Ike Skelton of Missouri, a ranking 62-year-old member of the House, when he sprinted out of the Democratic cloakroom rather than take a call from the President to explain his opposition.
 
Political Whip Marks
 "I have the marks; I have been whipped," said Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky of Pennsylvania, who nevertheless voted with the Republicans.
After he reluctantly voted against the President, Representative Sam Coppersmith of Arizona slouched in an antique chair off the House floor. His body limp and his eyes bloodshot, he looked as if he had aged a decade in the last few hours. Recalling three phone calls from the President that day, he said: "I couldn't say no to the President, so I said: 'Mr. President, I can't say yes.' I didn't cast the vote with any pleasure."
In the final two days, Mr. Clinton bucked up two black Representatives from Texas who were worried that the energy tax would hurt their state. The two, Craig Washington and Eddie Bernice Johnson, won a pledge that sanctions on Haiti would be tightened to increase pressure on the military regime there.
Charlie Rose, the North Carolina Democrat who heads the House Agriculture Committee, was able to deliver another handful of votes from rural lawmakers by winning promises that the Administration would consider raising tariffs on imported peanut and tobacco products.
In the hours before dawn on Thursday, House leaders won the commitment of a few influential moderates and conservatives by agreeing to a new set of budget procedures meant to control spending on Social Security and other automatic benefit programs.
A group of female Representatives came up with their own campaign to twist the arms of more senior committee and subcommittee chairmen who were threatening to bolt the party. Exploiting a new Democratic caucus rule that had not been put to use before, the women distributed a petition that would have brought any dissenters before the caucus membership for a possible vote of no-confidence that would remove them from leadership positions.
House leaders noted that after the petition attracted more than 60 signatures, Representatives William J. Hughes of New Jersey and Bob Carr of Michigan dutifully fell in line rather than risk their subcommittee chairmanships.
But Mr. Clinton was still short, and at 4 P.M. House leaders discussed whether to delay the vote until after the Memorial Day recess. "They rolled the dice," said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, after concluding that a delay would be widely viewed as a defeat for the President and might cause a further erosion of votes. "This was a real slog."
As late as 7 P.M., less than two hours before the vote, the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, had only 213 firm votes, four short of what they needed to win. The White House thought that about five Democrats would change their votes at the last minute rather than embarrass the President, but some House leaders were not so sure.
The White House made a special effort to win over Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, a prominent member of the Democratic Party's conservative wing. He had publicly declared his opposition to the economic program and had openly criticized the Administration for veering left. House leaders had already written off Mr. McCurdy and advised Mr. Clinton against calling him.
But the President disagreed, in part because of his long friendship with the Oklahoma Democrat but also because he thought Mr. McCurdy could bring a few votes with him. Throughout Thursday, Mr. McCurdy received calls from Mr. Clinton; the White House chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen. In each call Mr. McCurdy asked for reductions in the energy tax and sought pledges that the Administration would work for more spending cuts.
Working in tandem with Representatives Calvin M. Dooley of California, W. J. (Billy) Tauzin of Louisiana and Jay Inslee of Washington State, Mr. McCurdy said, he won promises of more spending cuts to reduce the reliance on the energy tax. Mr. McCurdy and his allies struck their deal with the Administration 10 minutes after the voting began. Then, Mr. McCurdy recalled, "Billy Tauzin turned to me and said, 'Let's do it.' "
 
'A Near-Death Experience'
 Their votes put the President over the top.
"This Administration experienced a near-death experience," Mr. McCurdy said. "We couldn't afford to let him die."
Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a chief deputy whip, attached himself to Missouri Representatives Harold L. Volkmer and Alan Wheat through the entire vote, pleading with them to vote yes. Both are loyal Democrats who wanted to help their party, but the letters from back home carried the mantra: cut spending, don't raise taxes.
Mr. Wheat is especially sensitive to political trends because he wants to run for the Senate seat that will be vacated by John C. Danforth, who is retiring. But he and Mr. Volkmer, voting in tandem to reinforce each other's courage, took the plunge together for the President.
But other members decided to look after their own political careers first. Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky had eked out a 1,373-vote victory in her Main Line district, a prosperous Philadelphia suburb that usually votes Republican.
"I got calls from half the Cabinet; I got calls from all the leadership, the President, the Vice President," she recalled. "I agonized."
She said she told Mr. Clinton, " 'Throughout the campaign, I pledged that I would not vote for an across-the-board tax.' I had to keep my promise. He understood. I could hear it in his voice."

HEADLINE: NATO's Leadership Gap;
Washington's Seeming Confusion on Bosnia Throws Alliance Into Crisis of Relevance

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 28

 BODY:
Confused and ambivalent signals from Washington about handling the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina have thrown the NATO alliance into its most serious crisis since the end of the cold war.
Critics in Washington and New York, but also in Brussels and Bonn, have begun to question whether an alliance designed to stave off the Soviet Union has any relevance to the prevention of the ethnic and national conflicts that have broken out in the ruins of the Communist empire and threaten to endanger the stability and security of Europe if they are not contained. 
 Diplomats here suggest that the alliance will continue to bicker ineffectually until the United States makes up its mind on what approach to pursue.
 
Failure to Agree
 The Clinton Administration did try, but failed, to get its European allies to agree to a policy of threatening Bosnian Serb forces with military strikes while allowing the Bosnian Muslims to rearm. The Europeans tried, but failed, to get the Americans to beef up United Nations peacekeeping forces on the ground to enforce a cease-fire.
In the view of many Europeans, Secretary of State Warren Christopher was too tentative when he came earlier this month to explain the American proposals, saying he was in a "listening mode." American diplomats suggest that he might have done better to send junior officials to take soundings first.
The result was an unsatisfying compromise announced by the United States, Russia, Britain France and Spain in Washington last Saturday, calling for "safe havens" for the Muslim refugees and American air power to protect whatever ground forces are eventually sent in to protect them.
Though every country involved in the compromise except Russia was a member of NATO, the 16 alliance defense ministers who met in Brussels on Wednesday could not even agree on a communique endorsing the plan.
France, often the most troublesome ally to the United States, has vigorously defended the compromise. But as Foreign Minister Alain Juppe explained in an article in Le Monde on Friday, its effectiveness depends on considerable military strengthening of the mandate of the United Nations forces that would defend the population inside the safety zones.
"The Russian Federation declared its readiness to provide troops in Bosnia," he wrote. "We have not yet been able to convince the United States to do the same." All the Administration has said it would do is to provide air cover if the United Nations forces -- not the refugees they will protect -- came under attack from the combatants.
Past crises in the trans-Atlantic relationship have nearly always resulted when the allies got the impression that the United States did not know what it wanted. Seldom has the impression of confusion in Washington been as strong as it has over the 14 months of the Bosnian crisis, in both the Bush and Clinton Administrations.
The last time the allies drifted this far apart was in the late 1970's and early 1980's over a NATO decision to deploy American medium-range nuclear missiles to counter equivalent Soviet ones. Uneasiness, particularly in Germany, about what seemed to be a confrontational approach by the Reagan Administration deepened the crisis, but the seeds had been sown in March 1978, when President Carter canceled a decision to deploy a neutron bomb he had earlier pressed the Germans and the other allies to accept.
Mr. Carter's national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, tried to get him to stick with his decision. "I still made my pitch to the effect that his decision, which involves a reversal of everything we have been doing for the last four months, will stamp him as weak and will be so construed elsewhere," Mr. Brzezinski wrote in "Power and Principle," his 1983 memoirs. "I made the point that leadership means making the decisions which the Europeans are not prepared to make."
 
Impression of Self-Doubt
 Ten years later, it still means that. But the Clinton Administration seems to be radiating self-doubt.
A speech last week by Assistant Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff that seemed to lower expectations of American leadership because of United States economic difficulties was later clarified by the White House and by Mr. Christopher, but the damage had been done. A German newspaper, Die Welt, suggested on Thursday that Mr. Christopher was a "product of the cold war" who was not up to the new challenges, and should be replaced.
Until it defines its role in the Balkans, NATO could continue to drift. Many who depend on it for their future security, in Eastern as well as Western Europe, hope that the Clinton Administration can find firm strategic ground soon.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: On Democratic Turf;
In St. Paul, Clinton Faithful Wince

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, May 28

 BODY:
When President Clinton's economic package narrowly passed the House on Thursday night, there may have been no one outside the White House more relieved than Thaddeus Austin, a real estate agent here.
It is not because Mr. Austin expects anything from the budget personally. In fact, he has been expecting higher taxes since Election Day. He figures an energy tax will hit Minnesotans especially hard, what with the harsh winters and long commutes. And besides, he, like many Americans, views the Federal budget as a bulbous enigma that the average citizen may not fully grasp no matter how many hours C-Span is on. 
 No, the reason he is relieved is that he has been waiting all his life for this moment when a President he voted for gets in and does something. For 12 years, as long as he has been eligible to vote, he has been on the losing side -- Carter, Mondale, Dukakis, even Anderson and Jackson in the primaries. Now things are different.
"I feel like I'm coming in from the wilderness," said Mr. Austin, who is 30 years old.
 
Educated Citizens
 There are lots of people like Mr. Austin in Merriam Park, a leafy, middle-class St. Paul neighborhood of geranium-flanked Victorian houses and literate residents who watch "MacNeil-Lehrer" and read The New Republic.
It is one of the scattered pockets of true Clinton support outside Arkansas, where people seem willing to forgive his $200 haircuts and travel-office missteps. St. Paul is a liberal city in a liberal state that voted for Mr. Clinton over Mr. Bush almost 3 to 1.
People here are frugal and progressive. They worry about the deficit and endangered species, see taxes as a civic duty and feel government has a responsibility to the disadvantaged. Even Republicans here are different. Many favor government-run health care or the right to an abortion. Merriam Park is, after all, the home of Hubert Humphrey and Eugene McCarthy.
Like nervous parents worried about the children they just sent off to college, this has been a tough semester for Democrats here. They watched their man stumble over the issues of Haitian refugees, homosexuals in the military, cabinet appointees and their nannies. They winced as he got sidetracked by haircuts and his travel staff and seemed a little too dazzled by the Hollywood types for their taste.
Then they watched him squeeze his budget package through a Democratic-controlled House. Now they are bracing for the real fight in the Senate, wondering what could go wrong next.
"It's been extremely painful," said Deborah Keenan, a writer and professor of poetry sitting with her family at a Dairy Queen here. "I can hardly bear it. I haven't given up yet. I don't think that he's a character disorder. But that's the last clinging hope."
In interviews before and after the House vote, more than 40 people who live or work in Merriam Park said they were impatient and frustrated with Congress, accusing it of grandstanding, and with Mr. Clinton, saying he'd made dumb mistakes and had lost his way.
Most people said he had not had time to prove himself, but they saw at least a glimmer of hope in the House vote.
"The guy is in an awful pickle," said Roger Westholter, who owns a shoe repair shop in Merriam Park. "I don't give up on him yet just 'cause he does a few stupid things. The guy just hardly got in there. Give the guy a chance. Look at Carter. He was a good man. He was smart. The poor guy couldn't do nothing. His own party is against him. It's too bad."
 
Annoyed With Trivia
 Many people were angry at the news media, saying it has emphasized the trivial. "What do I care if he got a $200 hair cut?" said Ken Schultz, an antique-furniture dealer. "That's his business."
After months of hearing the mantra of change, change, change, people here are still waiting to see some.
"He was given permission to do things people don't like but knew had to be done, and he's not doing it," Bill Oetting, a research biologist here, said. "When I hear him speak, he says the right things, and I think his intentions are good. But it's not happening."
Voters who thought that a bright Rhodes scholar would take care of everything are sitting up and taking notice.
"I'm beginning to think that nothing much is going to change," said Carol Kusnierek, a Merriam Park secretary. "I used to think his naivete was nice. Now I think we need somebody who can fight dirty."
 
Not Tough Enough?
 Her sentiments -- that Mr. Clinton does not seem to be tough enough -- were voiced over and over again, with Don Ladig, a transportation coordinator here, saying, "I want to see him get bloodied."
Mr. Ladig voted for Mr. Clinton but appears to be losing faith.
"I haven't seen him walk the talk," Mr. Ladig said. "I voted for a man I thought was a professional politician, an instinctive politician. But I haven't seen it. I've seen a bumbler."
"Even smart people make dumb mistakes," said his wife, Sherry, a bookstore clerk, as the two stood outside their Victorian frame house. "I'm willing to forgive him the little ones."
Still, her Midwestern pragmatism got the better of her when it came to one seeming mistake. "It's real dumb to have a $200 haircut and ask people to pay higher taxes," Mrs. Ladig said. "He seems a little too dazzled with the high life and Hollywood," a place as suspect as Washington to many Midwesterners.
"I picture him in this fairy tale castle, and he's wandering around and saying, 'What do I do first?' " said Mat Hollinshead, a business consultant.
Mr. Hollinshead was frustrated by the emphasis on homosexuals in the military in the first months of the Administration. He feels that was an unnecessary distraction that tripped up the Administration.
"Why did he have to do it so early?" he asked. "He knows how things work. I don't disagree with the idea. But why did he have to do it so soon? I just didn't see the need for that now. He was supposed to understand politics. He could have been in a better position now with the budget if he hadn't taken that on."
As for the budget, some people find it overwhelming -- and suspect Congress does, too. "It's hard to get your mind around that many millions," said Mrs. Kusnierek. "Can you comprehend all those zeroes? That doesn't mean anything to me. The deficit to me is kind of unreal."
If people knew anything about the budget -- and most people knew quite a bit -- they knew taxes would go up
Some people said they were willing to accept higher taxes combined with spending cuts, but seemed not to have imagined what their bill would be. Some figured that a few hundred dollars a year in higher income taxes would be worth the peace of mind of a lower deficit. Some people were resigned to it. Some seemed almost giddy, figuring they would not have to pay that much because most of the increase, they thought, would be aimed at the wealthy.
"We danced in the 80's," said Mr. Schultz, the antique-furniture dealer. "Now we have to pay."
While a few people here worried that the energy tax might lead to inflation, many others seemed to like the idea because they think it will get people to stop squandering energy resources. They felt especially good about a proposed energy credit for low-income families to offset higher energy prices.
But the conversations always returned to President Clinton and how he is doing. "Who would think that a man who played the media so well and came out of the rubble of the campaign would make the kind of mistakes he's made?" Ms. Keenan asked.
Many people accuse the Republicans in Congress of being sore losers and getting in the way. "We gave them people 12 years," Mr. Schultz said. "The Republicans should say: 'The ball's in your court. We don't agree with it. But we'll let you have it.' And if it don't work, you won't be President anymore."
Some say it could be a good thing that the young overachievers in the White House are learning their lessons now. "They're making mistakes," said Ferdinand Peters, a Merriam Park lawyer. "That shows they're human."
Mr. Hollinshead, another forgiving Democrat, said: "It's not just a new man learning the Presidency. It's a new generation learning the Presidency."

HEADLINE: Dockside Commerce and Industry;
In Fleet Week, Russians Raise Cash; Americans Talk Love

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
It has been 130 years since a Russian warship docked in New York City, so before steaming into town this week at the helm of his Russian destroyer, Comdr. Mikhail Soldatov said he tried to bone up with some background reading: Jack London, Mark Twain and James Fenimore Cooper.
Despite all the preparation, many aspects of life in New York City have surprised Commander Soldatov and his crew. Chief boatswain's mate Nikolai Nagut, for instance, said he was most impressed by New York drivers. "They are masters of the road, this way the cars move through the traffic," Mr. Nagut said. 
 The 400 Russians on the destroyer, the Bezuderzhny, and its accompanying oiler ship have joined some 7,300 American sailors for the United States Navy's sixth annual Fleet Week, when warships dock in New York City and American sailors deploy themselves throughout the city on thousands of search-and-enjoy missions.
 
A Good Time
 So far, everyone seems to be having a good time.
Many of the Russians, confined to their ships except for a few chaperoned excursions and apparently short on hard currency, have turned their destroyer's stern deck into a veritable bazaar, selling uniforms and insignias with good-natured enthusiasm to tourists. For their part, the Americans have been doing what sailors do when dockside -- sightseeing, drinking and proposing marriage to female bartenders.
"I've had a lot of them ask me to go back to their ship and sail away with them," said Heidi Snyder, the 18-year-old drink-pourer at the Olympic Bar, at 12th Avenue and 48th Street, just across from Pier 88, where the Bezuderzhny and the American aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy are docked. She said "about 40" American sailors have told her that they have fallen in love with her since the fleet docked on Wednesday.
"I've had everything from marriage to will you have my kids? I've gotten it all," Ms. Snyder said.
More than a dozen American ships and the two Russian ships steamed into New York harbor to a 21-gun salute on Wednesday, and on Thursday evening there was a splendid assemblage of the two countries' naval officers -- white-shoed, epauleted and draped in gold braid -- under the ballroom chandeliers at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.
"New York is a great Navy town," Adm. Henry H. Mauz, the commander in chief of the United States Atlantic fleet, said at the dinner. "New Yorkers seem to respond to sailors in uniform, like they evoke memories of Gene Kelly or something."
Vice Adm. Alekseyevich Poroshin, deputy commander of Russia's northern fleet, nibbling hors d'oeuvres, said through an interpreter that after researching naval records he had concluded that the last visit to New York waters by any Russian warship came in 1863, when three Russian ships docked to express Russian solidarity with the Union cause during the Civil War.
 
Sailors Meet the Mayor
 Admiral Poroshin's spokesman, Mikhail Borikov, said that besides the formal dinner, Russian officers and some sailors have met with Mayor David N. Dinkins, squared off against United States sailors in soccer and basketball games, and planned to see a Yankees game.
Mr. Borikov, who is not a man for chit-chat, summed up: "American hospitality has conquered the hearts of our sailors."
One teen-age sailor, Dmitri Vaneyev, who spoke with a visitor on the rear deck of the Bezuderzhny through an interpreter, said he found New York to be "a very impressive city."
 
Souvenirs and Cannons
 Dozens of other sailors, working in the shadow of the turret of the Bezuderzhny's 130-millimeter cannon, were selling bits of their uniforms to tourists.
"I walked on board and saw they were trading, so I joined in," said Alex Feldman, an Israeli tourist who bought a seaman's cotton shirt for $10. "Whatever they have -- their shoes, their shirts, their hats -- they'll sell you."
Mr. Feldman's nephew, Andy Feldman, drew out a brass belt buckle, stamped with hammer and sickle, newly purchased from a Russian sailor. "He wanted $5 but I got him down to $3," said Mr. Feldman, who lives in Brooklyn.
A Russian sailor approached and drew up his shirt to display a braided, mustard-colored service belt. Flashing five fingers into the air, twice, the sailor indicated he wanted $10 for the belt. Another sailor, pulling bits of uniforms and insignias from a shopping bag, sought to sell a Russian Navy watch, with a stem wind, for $30.
One likely reason the sailors were selling uniforms, a Navy spokesman said, was that Russian seamen, with their economy in crisis, earn as little as $25 a month. Base pay for an American sailor, in contrast, is $815 a month.
That differential gives American sailors more pocket money, which many, of course, have been spending on liquid spirits. Seaman Ira C. Gibbs, who works in the U.S.S. John F. Kennedy's print shop, bar-hopped his way through much of midtown during Fleet Week's first night. When he got up after just three hours sleep, he said he was eager to party some more.
But there were also new-age sailors, the fighting men and women who said they avoid not only strong drink but also high-cholesterol foods. For instance, Vernon L. Black of Pittsburgh, a third-class petty officer on the Kennedy, said he spent much of Thursday browsing through the New York City Public Library.
He said he was drawn in by a glimpse of the library's oil paintings. Once inside, he said, he got interested in the frieze work on the ceiling. "The way people do research in that library is unreal," he said.
