HEADLINE: USX Must Pay $630 Million in Price-Fixing

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
In one of the largest antitrust judgments, a Federal court has ruled that the USX Corporation must pay roughly $630 million to several steel companies that brought a price-fixing suit against a former USX subsidiary, the Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad Company.
The decision Thursday by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, in Philadelphia, upheld a 1991 ruling that found the railroad had conspired from the 1950's to the early 80's to monopolize the docks in lower Lake Erie ports and had fixed prices for transporting and unloading iron ore. 
 "It really redresses genuine economic harm that the steel companies suffered over a number of years," said William M. Wycoff, a Pittsburgh-based lawyer who represented National Steel and Sharon Steel in the case. Other plaintiffs in the case include the Wheeling Pittsburgh Corporation and the LTV Corporation of Cleveland.
LTV, the nation's third-largest steel company, will get the largest share of the award, $458 million plus 8 percent annual interest from July 1989.
USX, the nation's largest steelmaker, sold its transporation business, including the Bessemer & Lake Erie, in 1988, but remains liable for the judgment. The railroad is now a subsidiary of Transtar, in which USX holds a 44 percent equity stake.
The company said yesterday that it would appeal Thursday's ruling to either the United States Supreme Court or to a full panel of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.
USX said it expected that any award would be deductible for income tax purposes and that even though it expected to prevail on appeal it would reserve most of the award against the second-quarter results of its United States Steel Group. The stock of the United States Steel Group fell $2.625 yesterday, to $43, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The suits were filed in 1983 but the roots of the case date to the 1950's, when technology emerged to pelletize iron ore. That enabled the use of self-unloading vessels, which essentially operated their own conveyor belt systems to move iron ore off ships.
 
 
Plaintiffs' Contention
 This new technology would have represented a saving over the more traditional method of unloading ore with what were, in effect, large mechanized scoops. But the plaintiffs contended that the railroads, because of their near-monopoly position, did not lower their prices, which made investing in the new technology unwise.
Other railroads, including Conrail and Norfolk & Western settled their cases out of court earlier.
LTV, which plans to emerge from bankruptcy protection next month after seven years, said it would use the money from USX to help restore its pension plans. It has about $3 billion in unfunded pension liabilities.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Economic growth slowed to a near-standstill last winter while inflation sped up, revised figures showed. The gross domestic product expanded at only a 0.9 percent rate -- the slowest since the fourth quarter of 1991 -- and inflation, at a 4.2 percent annual rate, was at its highest since early 1991. [Page 1.]
Whether the higher taxes and reduced spending approved by the House will help the economy will depend a lot on what changes the Senate makes when it considers the plan next month. [6.]
 
 Companies
Former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was named by a Federal bankruptcy judge to mediate a struggle over control of the United States holdings of Olympia & York Developments. [33.]
Chevron's decision to dispose of hundreds of gas stations has angered wholesalers and retailers, who say the company did not give them sufficient notice. [33.]
USX must pay roughly $630 million to steel companies in a price-fixing suit against a former USX railroad subsidiary. The company said it would appeal, perhaps to the Supreme Court. [33.]
Bell companies can own information services, a court ruled in a defeat for newspapers and other information companies. [33.]
Shares of 3Com lost about 30 percent of their value after two analysts lowered their ratings on the company's stock. [35.]
Boxes of Marriott files pertinent in a bondholder suit fell off the back of a courier truck and have not been found. [35.]
A California home builder is wiring a 111-home development with fiber-optic communications cable. [35.]
Computer makers challenged an Administration plan to standardize coding for telephone and computer data transmissions. [35.]
New York Telephone will lay off 8 percent of its 7,700 managers in September as part of its efforts to cut costs. [23.]
Major league baseball owners overwhelmingly approved a six-year advertising joint-venture with ABC and NBC. [27.]
 
 International
With a surge in the yen's value that has shaken Japan for the last three months and driven the American dollar to historic lows, the outrageous has turned to the ridiculous in Tokyo. [1.]
Hoping tourism can aid their struggling economies, Libya, Croatia, Peru and other diverse destinations are struggling to repair their war-torn tourist infrastructures. [33.]
The Administration argued that Ross Perot's television commercial is wrong in contending that the Nafta will cost jobs. [45.]
U.S. telecommunications companies may be allowed to expand their service in Cuba. [8.]
 
 Markets
The stock market dropped sharply in reaction to lower economic growth figures and computerized sell programs. The Dow industrials lost 27.4 points, closing at 3,527.43. [34.]
Prices of long-term Treasury issues fell moderately in light trading ahead of the long holiday weekend. [42.]
The dollar tumbled to another low against the Japanese yen after a rescue attempt by the Federal Reserve failed. [44.] Gold prices fell sharply in late profit taking. [44.]
 
Your Money
Stock options can help increase investment returns, bring stability to an investment portfolio and maybe even result in a good night's sleep for investors who worry about their holdings. [31.]
A form of no-load mutual fund charges no up-front fee, no back-end fee, but a killer of an annual fee that continues forever. [31.]
Owners who rent their vacation homes should be aware of complex rules on the tax treatment of second homes. [32.]

HEADLINE: German Court Restricts Abortion, Angering Feminists and the East

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 28

 BODY:
Germany's highest court ruled today that the country's new liberal abortion law was unconstitutional. The court imposed interim restrictions that outraged feminists, especially those from eastern states, where abortion had been freely available for 20 years.
The Constitutional Court sent the issue back to Parliament, which passed the law last year making abortions legal in the first three months of pregnancy. But the court sought in the meantime to set compromise guidelines as it ruled on an issue that is as hotly debated here as in the United States. 
 It ruled that abortion was unconstitutional because it violates a constitutional provision requiring the state to protect human life. But at the same time, making use of its broad judicial prerogatives, the court said that women who undergo abortions in the first three months of pregnancy and their doctors should not be prosecuted even though the abortions are themselves illegal.
 
Insurance Won't Pay
 The legality issue is significant because as long as abortions are officially illegal, health insurance plans will not be allowed to pay for them and state-supported hospitals will stop performing them.
The court also ruled that a woman seeking an abortion must receive counseling that is not a "merely informational" recital of available options, but rather an active effort to dissuade her.
"The woman must be aware that the unborn child has its own right to life," the court said. "Abortion can only be considered in exceptional circumstances."
In practice, women who can afford to pay for abortions will continue to do so, and neither they nor their doctors will be punished if the abortion is performed in the first three months of pregnancy and if they have gone through the required counseling.
The court session was broadcast on national television. After the broadcast ended, protesters took to the streets in several German cities. Hundreds gathered in front of the historic Cologne Cathedral. At a spontaneous rally in Potsdam, one woman carried a sign reading, "This ruling is violence against women! I've had enough!"
Catholic bishops hailed the ruling and asserted in a statement, "The real winner is humanity."
Chancellor Helmut Kohl praised the court for having declared itself "clearly in favor of truly protecting unborn life." He said he expected all federal agencies to move swiftly toward full compliance.
Among the first attacks on the court ruling came from Regine Hildebrandt, minister for social affairs in the state of Brandenburg and one of the most popular politicians in eastern Germany. She denounced the ruling as "a return to the Middle Ages."
"This is a catastrophe," Mrs. Hildebrandt said as she and other angry female politicians left the courtroom in the western town of Karlsruhe. "This is just impossible at the end of the 20th century."
Many Catholic leaders endorsed the appeal to the Constitutional Court, and some lobbied behind the scenes for tighter restrictions. Only a few Protestant leaders, however, joined their call for a tighter restriction on abortion. Many oppose abortion but are not in favor of regulating it.
Almost half of western Germans are Catholics, while the percentage in the east is much smaller.
 
Law Must Fit Guidelines
 Rules announced by the court today are to take effect June 16. Parliament may pass a new abortion law thereafter, but it must fit within guidelines laid down by the court.
The ruling was likely not only to end a chapter in the German abortion debate, but also to intensify resentment felt by many easterners, who are seeing their social safety net weaken and the last remnants of East German life disappear.
From 1973 until its collapse in 1990, the East German state provided abortions without charge to all women who wanted them. Laws were stricter in West Germany, where abortion was allowed only if doctors certified that continued pregnancy would be harmful to the woman or her child, or if pregnancy was the result of a criminal assault.
The treaty of German unification signed in 1990 allowed existing abortion rules to remain in force until Parliament passed a new law for the whole country. Last year, after an emotional debate during which politicians from the east demanded that abortion rights not be curtailed, Parliament voted to legalize most abortions performed in the first three months of pregnancy. But 249 members of Parliament from Chancellor Kohl's ruling coalition, joined by the state government of largely Catholic Bavaria, challenged the law in court on the ground that it did not protect unborn life.
 
A 6-to-2 vote
 The court voted 6 to 2 for the new rules. Judges dressed in ceremonial red satin robes and pillbox hats listened as their chief, Ernst Gottfried Mahrenholz, read from the 183-page decision. Mr. Mahrenholz was one of the two dissenters, but the lone woman on the court, Karin Grasshof, voted with the majority. All the justices are from western Germany.
No easterners are on the court, nor is it expected that any will be appointed in the near future, because none have had careers in the west German system of law and members serve for 12 years. The Constitutional Court as an institution has generally been conservative.
The number of abortions performed in eastern and western Germany has been steadily declining. There were about 125,000 abortions here in 1991, the last year for which figures are available, in comparison with more than 180,000 in 1981.
Several influential feminists urged women to organize protests against the ruling.
Monica Wulf-Mathies, head of the German public employees' union and the country's most prominent female labor leader, encouraged members of her union to "show their indignation." She said the ruling showed that "men are not very sensitive to problems that face women."
 
Beyond Reach of Poor
 A senior member of Parliament, Heidemarie Wieczorek-Zeul, said the ruling effectively legalized abortion for women who could pay the costs, which range from about $200 to $650, but placed it beyond the reach of poorer women, especially the many who are unemployed in eastern states.
"If you have money you can have an abortion," Mrs. Weiczorek-Zeul said. "If you don't, then you have to find some quack."
While the decision announced today was a form of compromise, it imposes limitations on abortion that are among the tightest in Europe. Ireland maintains a complete ban, and Poland recently adopted a law that is almost as sweeping. Germany now joins Spain, Portugal and Italy as countries that impose some restrictions. Other European countries allow abortion virtually on request during the first three months of pregnancy.

HEADLINE: Once Off-Limits, Now Destinations With an Edge

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Declaring that tourism produces "a very big income," Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya proposed in a recent televised speech that his country encourage mass tourism. And Colonel Qaddafi is not alone in assuming that travel and tourism can aid struggling economies.
Destinations as diverse as Croatia and Peru are struggling to repair their war-torn tourist infrastructures. Egypt is cracking down on radical Islamic fundamentalists, and one reason officials give is that the terrorists' campaign is harming the country's $3 billion tourist industry, Egypt's largest source of foreign revenue. And the hope of luring tourists with hard currency is why China and Cuba are racing to build hotels, restaurants and other amenities of the travel trade. 
 Their view is supported in a recent report by the World Travel and Tourism Council, a Brussels-based coalition of chief executives from more than 50 travel-related corporations in many countries.
 
 
It's Not Always Easy
 "A buoyant travel and tourism sector will employ more people" and create new jobs and careers faster than any other industry, said the report, compiled by a group of international economists. It added, "Unlike many industries, there are no lengthy time lags before new jobs, foreign exchange and extra purchasing power filter into the economy."
But luring tourists to trouble spots, or what they perceive to be trouble spots, is no simple matter.
For example, officials in Croatia and Slovenia, in what was formerly Yugoslavia, are eager to restore what had been a thriving tourist trade, but find foreigners confuse their areas with war-wracked Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"Slovenia and Croatia are both perfectly safe," said Rose Pace-Bogdanic, the senior vice president of Sterling Cruises and Tours of Austin, Tex. "They just suffer from an identity crisis."
She and Damir-Dodo Bogdanic, her Croatian-born husband, used to promote tours to all of Yugoslavia, until age-old hatreds between Serbs and Croats fragmented the country in 1990 and plunged it into civil war. Last year, Sterling began offering tour packages to the castles, mountains and beaches of Slovenia, which declared its independence in 1991. And later this year it plans to offer tours to Croatia, which has suffered far less damage than some other parts of the former Yugoslavia.
Toward that end, Sterling opened a branch office last month in Ridgefield, N.J., staffed by a former executive of Yugotours International in Belgrade.
"Not everyone's going to rush out and go there on a tour," Mrs. Pace-Bogdanic said. "So we plan to start on a limited basis."
But some Americans are visiting Slovenia. "The view in North America may be that it's an unsafe place, but it's not as though you're traveling to Bosnia-Herzegovina," Scott Schnipper, an American traveler, said by telephone from London last week shortly before his departure. "It has a modern infrastructure and modern communications."
Cuba has an improving tourist climate, including hotels under construction, but is unlikely to rake in Americans' dollars so long as United States law bars most citizens from spending money there.
Nor have tourists been flocking to Libya so far, and Colonel Qaddafi sidestepped any mention of United Nations sanctions against Libya for harboring suspected terrorists -- sanctions that include a ban on travel to his country.
Another indication that Libya is unlikely to reap a tourist bonanza anytime soon, at least from English-speaking visitors, is the reluctance of Lonely Planet Publications to add a Libyan travel guide to its book list, which includes guides for such difficult or dangerous destinations as Iran, Myanmar, Yemen, Peru, Vietnam, Sri Lanka, Cambodia and Bangladesh.
"Nobody's knocking down our door for a book on Libya," said Carolyn Miller, promotions manager for Lonely Planet in Oakland, Calif. "In fact, I don't think I ever heard of any tourist wanting to go there."
Other countries eager for tourism also have a lot to learn about visitors' expectations. In "Falling Off the Map," a book published this month by Alfred A. Knopf, a travel writer, Pico Iyer, notes that North Korea is building the world's largest tourist hotel, 105 stories high -- although few tourists visit the country, which remains one of the world's most regimented and closed societies.
Similarly, Vietnam is not most Americans' idea of a vacation paradise, even though Hanoi designated 1990 as the "Year of Tourism." That same year, it began to remodel all of its hotels. It still offers few other amenities for tourists, and visitors say the Vietnamese appear to have unrealistic expectations of what the tourist traffic will bear.
"What would be, at most, a three-star hotel by our standards, costs around $200 a night," said Dianne Yamamoto of Los Angeles, who recently returned from a 10-day trip to Vietnam and Cambodia. "It was an incredible visit, but you have to be prepared to rough it, because there's very little tourist infrastructure."
 In contrast to Vietnam, Egypt has well-developed tourism operations, and intrepid travelers continue to visit the Pyramids and cruise the Nile despite attacks by Islamic extremists.
"Reports of problems in Egypt affected our business," conceded Aza Hussein, operations manager for Naggar Tours in San Francisco, a wholesale travel operator specializing in Egypt. "But groups are still traveling there."
John Yee, a tour leader with Asian Discoveries, a travel agency in Kensington, Calif., branched out to take about 20 people to Egypt last month for 12 days. "Only two people in our group canceled for safety reasons," he said. "And they missed out on a great visit. Besides, there were no lines at tourist sites."
Few tourist destinations have been as devastated as Peru, which in the 1980's attracted tens of thousands of visitors to Inca sites like Machu Picchu and Cuzco. But a terrorist war that broke out in Ayacucho in 1980 spread through much of the nation, claiming an estimated 25,000 lives, and a cholera epidemic two years ago claimed another several thousand. Tourists stayed away in droves.
Now, with the founder of the Shining Path terrorists, Abimael Guzman Reynoso, serving a life sentence, officials in Ayacucho and Lima are eager to revive tourism. And that prospect may not be as farfetched as it sounds.
"The last couple of years you could have called me two days before Christmas, and I could have booked a room for you at the Machu Picchu Hotel de Turistas,," said Luis Vasquez, owner of M.I.L.A./Peru Tours in Wadsworth, Ill. "But it's already sold out for Christmas this year, and tourism to the rest of Peru has been picking up for the last few months."
Tourism is also rebounding in China following sharp declines after Government troops killed protesters around Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1989. More than 300,000 Americans and 600,000 Japanese visit China each year, and Beijing hopes to raise those numbers significantly. Thus, it recently joined the Pacific Asia Travel Association, a San Francisco-based organization of airlines, cruise ships, hotels and tour operators from both the private and public sectors.
Michael Justice, a Los Angeles photographer who recently returned from China, said he had been uneasy about visiting the country after its suppression of protesters.
"But a visit isn't an endorsement," he said. "You go to see what's real in a country, before they put up lots of fast-food restaurants."
He added, "Besides, my mother was quite happy to see me leave Los Angeles for someplace safer."

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: The Outlook;
Will It Help or Harm? Economists Say Yes and Yes

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
Deficit reduction is a two-edged sword, and now that the House of Representatives has approved higher taxes and reduced spending, economists are assessing whether the budget plan will help the economy by cutting interest rates or harm it by cutting jobs.
Their answer: a little of each. 
 A lot will depend on how the Senate decides to change the tax increases and spending cuts when it considers the bill next month.
The biggest unknown is what will happen to the proposed energy tax. Several economists recommended trimming that tax and making more spending cuts instead, as Republicans tried unsuccessfully to do in the House and will try again, with some Democratic support, in the Senate.
 
Threat of Inflation
 If the energy tax is not altered, some economists said, it would add a bit to inflation over the next few years, heightening concerns about prices and perhaps leading the Federal Reserve Board to tighten interest rates.
These economists also warned of a brief but noticeable drag on the economy this winter if, as the House bill dictates, personal income tax increases are made retroactive to Jan. 1, 1993. That would force wealthier taxpayers to come up with a total of about $10 billion in 1993 taxes that would be due on April 15, just as their 1994 paychecks begin to shrink as the withholding of taxes takes effect.
"If it goes through this way, it is a double whammy on the economy at the end of this year and the beginning of next year," said Laurence Meyer, who owns a consulting company in St. Louis. "People are going to have to pay two years of taxes at once. And I suspect, given the weakness we are seeing in the economy right now, that the Congress and the Administration will be reluctant to do that."
While the economy would be held back by tax increases and spending cuts, the economists said, in the long run it would benefit from an end to the uncertainty that has clouded it and from a focused attack on the deficit.
"The deficit reduction is an important drag on the economy, and as it gets larger as years go by it becomes a heavier drag," said Donald H. Straszheim, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "Offsetting that is the benefit of lower interest rates associated with a more coherent fiscal policy and lower deficits."
 
Drag on Economy
 Mr. Meyer agreed. "Deficit reduction puts a drag on the economy in the near term; there is no way of escaping that," he said. "There never seems like a good time to do it."
The Administration, he said, forced by circumstance to take a disciplined approach to the deficit, has for the time being put the economy, and to some extent its own political fortunes, in the hands of the Federal Reserve Board.
John P. LaWare, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said in an interview that "on the face of it, huge tax increases and huge spending cuts spell contraction." The Fed, which has recently been hinting that its concerns about inflation are growing, will have to wait for the economic program to emerge in final form from the Senate before deciding what to do with monetary policy, he said. He said he was concerned about the prospect of "stagflation," in which inflation combines with economic stagnation.
But Robert F. Wescott, an economist at the WEFA Group in Philadelphia, said the mere presentation of the Clinton budget earlier this year drove down interest rates and that the Fed's role should not be exaggerated.
"The Fed controls short-term interest rates, and the markets control long-term interest rates," he said. "The action has been on the long end of the market since Clinton was elected."
His economic models suggest that the decline in interest rates earlier this year had the same effect as a $25 billion stimulus program.
Over all, he said, WEFA's models show "a slight plus" for the economy in 1993 and 1994, followed by a decline of perhaps half a percentage point in economic growth by 1996 and 1997, when military cuts are felt heavily and the energy tax is fully in place. By the end of the decade, the economy would be better off under the plan, he said.
For the short term, said Mr. Straszheim of Merrill Lynch, the uncertainties over the final shape of the budget program are holding back businesses from making investments. But even after a budget is approved, there will be continuing uncertainty as businesses await details of the health-care program with its additional costs.
Mr. Straszheim said Merrill Lynch was forecasting long-term interest rates of 6.5 to 7 percent for the rest of this year, with "a pretty good chance" of lower rates next year.
 
Importance of Taking Action
 Roger Brinner, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economics consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., said his company's studies showed that an energy tax would be more harmful than either a value added tax, which is not being seriously considered, or bigger spending cuts, which are.
"The energy tax was clearly the worst," he said, asserting that it adds to inflation, reduces American competitiveness and does less to reduce the Federal deficit than any of the others.
Nevertheless, he said, continuing progress on the budget plan would be helpful almost regardless of what action is taken. "A definitive set of tax and spending plans, even if you don't like them, is better than worrying about what might be," he said. "Even though I am no big fan of the energy tax, I think it will be fixed in the Senate. Within two months the public's mind will be taken off speculation about what the Congress will do, and consumers and businesses will be back to their daily occupations."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Seldom has a national figure stirred so much wonder and speculation in the news media by saying things that most of the American public consider unremarkable.
In an April 6 speech in Austin, Tex., and several interviews since then, Hillary Rodham Clinton talked about the Golden Rule and the Ten Commandments and "common-sense truth." She borrowed the Presidential bully pulpit from her husband, and here is what she declared: 
 *That the United States, despite its wealth, was feeling an "undercurrent of discontent" and a collapse of community, of which urban violence and teen-agers' self-destruction were only the most dramatic symptoms.
*That the dying Lee Atwater, the impresario of bare-knuckled Republican campaigns, was right to warn of a "spiritual vacuum at the heart of American society."
*That national renewal could not be found simply by shoring up Government programs or relying on the marketplace but would require "an ethos of individual responsibility and caring," a society that "makes us feel that we are a part of something bigger than ourselves" and the reinvigoration of "intermediary institutions" like families, local communities and voluntary groups.
*That "there is no -- or should be no -- debate that our family structure is in trouble" or that "our children need the stability, the predictability of a family."
Sometimes Mrs. Clinton sounded like Vaclav Havel, sometimes like Martin Luther King Jr., and sometimes, well, like George Bush with his "vision thing" and a thousand points of light.
The media have blinked with astonishment, if not consternation. "She sounded as if she's discovered spiritual truths that eluded Buddha and Jesus," sniffed one columnist. Incoherent and didactic, sniffed others.
In her Austin speech and in the interviews that followed, Mrs. Clinton praised her father's insistence that compassion for wrongdoers is not incompatible with firm standards of right and wrong. She talked of her inextinguishable conviction that people can be evil, not just socially conditioned. She suggested that the nation had become too tolerant of deviant behavior.
But she also rested her vision of social renewal on, yes, the Golden Rule and a personal change of heart. She imagined that lots of individual acts could add up to a big change, beginning with something as simple as not telling a racist or sexist joke and building to a larger awareness of economic hardships and inequities.
Children, cover your ears.
In 1976, Jimmy Carter rattled the press by explaining that he actually listened for God's guidance when facing important decisions. Apparently unfamiliar with the processes of prayer that most Americans take for granted, some pundits wondered whether the Baptist Mr. Carter was having apparitions.
Their successors are showing no more familiarity with the weekly exhortations from a million American pulpits, exhortations about caring, searching for meaning, applying old values to new problems, transforming society, etc., etc. Mrs. Clinton's talk of spirituality and moral values fits comfortably in this genre. It makes her neither incoherent nor an Orwellian Big Sister with New Age accessories.
Her actual words were far more Girl Scout than goddess worship, more concerned with strengthening non-governmental groups than expanding the state.
Michael Kelly may have been severe with Mrs. Clinton in parts of his revealing interview last Sunday in The New York Times Magazine, but he was on target when he wrote that Mrs. Clinton's liberalism is derived from her religious faith. Her politics combine, he wrote, "a generally 'progressive' social agenda with a strong dose of moralism, the admixture of the two driven by an abundant faith in the capacity of the human intellect and the redeeming power of love."
Admittedly Mrs. Clinton is a complex, political woman who zig-zags across stereotypes, both naturally and by calculation. But she has also become a kind of national Rorschach test where commentators project their own fears and weaknesses.
Her recent critics appear divided between conservatives who suspect she does not mean what she is saying and liberals who fear that she does. They include people who are wary of any political figures talking about values and spirituality and people who are just wary when Mrs. Clinton starts talking that way.
Convinced that the real meaning of her words must be couched below the surface, the commentators are poring over the ideas of Michael Lerner, the editor of the Jewish journal Tikkun, whose phrase, "the politics of meaning," Mrs. Clinton echoed in Texas. And they are trying hard to link Mrs. Clinton's remarks to her roots in the youthful movements for social change of the 1960's.
But Mrs. Clinton's remarks actually reflect almost nothing of Mr. Lerner's quite specific, highly psychological theory of "the politics of meaning" (which constitutes, by the way, a critique of 1960's liberal and radical politics). She seems to have borrowed no more from him than from any number of other thinkers whom the Clintons mine for ideas.
It is not whether the First Lady's outlook is some rare political departure but whether it will have any impact on the policies of her husband's Administration that ought to be the focus of attention. What is being called her moral crusade may be more compatible with the standard liberal agenda than either her conservative or liberal critics recognize.
But if she is enunciating a viewpoint that sees national renewal more in strengthening families and communities and less in claims of individual rights and entitlements, if she is trying to marry social conservatism with an economically interventionist government, sooner or later some policy difference should emerge.
Mrs. Clinton's soundest critics are not those who reflexively recoil at her talk about a spiritual vacuum and an ethos of individual responsibility and caring, but those who fear that it is only talk.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY SLOWED IN FIRST QUARTER

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Growth in the United States economy slowed to a near-standstill in the winter while inflation sped up, the Commerce Department reported yesterday in its second look at economic performance between January and March.
The report prompted investors to sell stocks, stirred fears of a tighter monetary policy and revived talk of that 1970's scourge, stagflation. 
 The gross domestic product expanded at a barely perceptible rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter -- the slowest pace since six-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1991 and a sharp slowdown from the 4 percent pace of last year's second half.
 
Surge in Imports
 The revised rate was just half the meager 1.8 percent first-quarter rate that the Commerce Department reported a month ago. A big surge in imports -- much of which apparently went unsold and ended up in inventories -- accounted for the downward revision in growth.
But first-quarter inflation was at its highest since a 4.9 percent rate in the first quarter of 1991. In the latest quarter, the fixed-weight G.D.P. deflator -- the broadest inflation measure -- rose at a 4.2 percent annual rate, the Commerce Department said, the same as estimated a month ago. That compared with 3.4 percent last fall and 2.2 percent in the summer.
Clinton Administration officials pointed to the revised G.D.P. data and the inflation figures as reasons for advancing their agenda of economic remedies.
"This shows why we needed the President's stimulus package to get the economy rolling for the short term," Jack F. DeVore Jr., the chief Treasury Department spokesman, said. "If we fail to enact his deficit reduction program, we're going to see the same kind of economic problems over the long term."
Last month, President Clinton's proposal to spend nearly $20 billion for jobs and public works projects was killed by a filibuster in the Senate. But his budget measure calling for tax increases and other measures to cut the deficit was approved by the House Thursday night.
Economists said fear of higher taxes and the uncertainty over the impact of the Administration's health-care proposals were the main reasons behind the slow growth.
Sizable revisions in G.D.P. figures like those announced yesterday are not unusual. Many of the components of gross domestic product -- the sum of all goods and services produced within United States -- are measured only indirectly and the estimates can change as fresh data are gathered.
For example, export and import figures for March were not available when the initial first-quarter G.D.P. report was issued in late April, so the quarterly trade figures had to be estimated based on the performance of January and February.
Most of the sources of slower growth in yesterday's revised report looked much as they did in the department's original report: consumers, who had been buying faster than their incomes were rising, barely raised their spending in the quarter; housing weakened, and a huge drop in military purchases took a big bite out of Federal outlays.
Consumer spending on goods and services accounts for two-thirds of the economy. With buying basically flat, inventories rose a hefty $36.8 billion, about what was originally estimated, much higher than the $9.8 billion inventory rise in the fourth quarter last year. The high inventories show that businesses have abundant stocks on their shelves that must be sold before more production is required.
The upward creep in inflation over the last few quarters, while not necessarily likely to continue, recently led the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee to authorize the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, to tighten monetary policy before the next meeting if conditions warrant.
"Things aren't going very well," said Joel Prakken an economist at Laurecne Meyer & Associates , a St. Louis economic forecasting firm.
Nonetheless, despite the looming uncertainties over taxes, health-care changes and Fed policy, most forecasters see signs that the economy is doing better now than in the winter. They expect growth to return to 3 percent or so in the year's second half and inflation to subside a bit.
Recent reports suggest that retail sales, car purchasing and home buying have picked up in April and May. Government spending, while on a gently downward path, is not apt to decline as sharply as it did in the winter, when military spending contracted at an abrupt annual rate of more than 25 percent. And foreign producers are likely to share some of the pain as orders are reduced to get inventories back into line with sales.
"In the second quarter, we should get a substantial reversal in imports," Gordon Richards, chief economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said.
But growth in the current quarter could easily remain shy of the 3 percent rate.
"A lot of businessmen were totally misled by strong consumption late last year," Mr. Richards said. "Those inventories have to be liquidated."
If growth does fall short of 3 percent, further gains on the job front could be slow in coming.
"Lack of momentum can beget lack of momentum," David Kelly, an economist at the Boston Company, said. Slow growth can "create pent-up demand, but it also cuts off income growth that would have been generated by stronger job growth," he added.
 
Some Bright Spots
 The Commerce Department report was not all gloom. Businesses have been spending even more heavily on new equipment than originally thought, and the report indicated that this trend might continue.
Equipment investment rose at a 16.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter, nearly twice as fast as the 8.6 percent annual rate initially reported. And profits were up at a 5.3 percent annual rate, to $253.8 billion, after climbing at an 8.5 percent rate in the previous quarter.
Data included in the first-quarter G.D.P. follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Dip in Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury issues fell moderately in light trading yesterday as traders wound up their investment strategies ahead of the holiday weekend.
But after an unusually volatile week dominated by bearish news, long-term Treasury prices ended the week slightly higher as traders shed some of their fears that the Federal Reserve might soon act to tighten monetary policy. 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 20/32 of a point, while its yield climbed to 6.98 percent, from 6.92 percent late Thursday. Still, that was down from its yield of 7.04 percent on the previous Friday.
Analysts said yesterday's selling was mostly a result of traders' getting out of risky positions before the three-day holiday.
 
 
Thin Trading Volume
 John Fechter, head government securities trader at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, said the bond sales had an exaggerated influence on price and yield movements because of the light trading.
Fears in the market about the central bank's interest-rate policy were eased somewhat by a report that the American economy's growth in the first quarter was much slower than first estimated. The Government said the gross domestic product -- the sum of all goods and services produced -- registered an anemic growth rate of nine-tenths of a percent, seasonally adjusted, in the first three months of the year.
The Fed would be hard-pressed to raise rates given the persistent economic weakness, Mr. Fechter said.
Yesterday's selloff, confined largely to longer-term maturities, was also tied to more fundamental factors, said William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
"What's disturbing the market is the continued weakness in the dollar and the upward bias in precious metals prices," Mr. Sullivan said.
The dollar's plunge against leading foreign currencies is making dollar-denominated investments like fixed-income securities less attractive.
In addition, a weak dollar means higher prices for imports. And when imports become more expensive, domestic producers may begin to increase prices in tandem, fueling inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
Also contributing to speculation that prices in the economy are headed higher is this year's powerful rally in gold, which is considered an investment hedge against inflation.
Short-term Treasuries ended unchanged to 1/32 point lower, and intermediate maturities were between 5/32 and 3/8 lower, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 2.29, to 1,285.29.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose 1 basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 3.05 percent. The discount rates on six-month bills slipped 1 basis point, to 3.21 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills gained 8 basis points, to 3.46 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10027/32 , down 1/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.89 percent.

HEADLINE: Bill Gingerly Urges Talks On Segregation Problems

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 28

 BODY:
In a first tentative step toward addressing the racial and economic segregation of schools in Connecticut's cities, the State House of Representatives voted early today for legislation that urges towns and cities to cooperate regionally to improve all public schools.
The bill, expected to win approval in the Senate next week, is much weaker than legislation submitted four months ago by the administration of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., which set goals for racially integrating schools across each of six regions of the state. 
 But it was supported by Governor Weicker and his commissioner of education, Vincent Ferrandino, because it would require, for the first time, towns and cities across entire metropolitan regions to discuss cooperating to improve their schools.
"What we're saying in this bill is that we believe that everyone ought to at least sit down and talk about this issue and try to develop a plan," Mr. Ferrandino said. "We also believe that once that process begins, people will be able to find some common ground. We're assuming the best of communities."
 
Concern Over Quality
 Governor Weicker urged the state to overcome the racial and economic divisions between its cities and towns in January, as testimony was being heard in a lawsuit that seeks a desegregation order linking schools in Hartford with those in 21 surrounding towns.
The state's poor black and Hispanic children, concentrated in a handful of cities, were not getting an adequate education, he said, and the entire state would eventually end up paying for that failure.
In months of lobbying for a bill that promoted integration as essential to improving the quality of schools, Mr. Ferrandino repeatedly warned that this year might be Connecticut's last to address the issue in the Legislature, rather than under a court order.
The bill approved today, in an 81-68 vote, will require towns and cities, divided into 11 regions, to consider how to raise the quality of education by such means as new schools or programs that serve children from more than one community.
 
Incentives for Participation
 It does not, however, require communities to take part in the plans that result. Instead, it provides incentives: grants to help pay for new regional schools, and reimbursement for transporting children from one town to another.
The bill's only power is that it allows the Department of Education to set the criteria by which each region's plan will be assessed in a competition for the school grants. The degree to which a plan improves the racial balance in a region's schools will be a critical factor, Mr. Ferrandino said.
But unlike Mr. Weicker's proposal, the bill does not use the words "integrate," "racial isolation" or "minority." Its only reference to race is to include, as the last of several goals in improving the quality of education, "enhancing student diversity."
The racial issue was minimized, both opponents and advocates of the bill said, because months of public debate found little support for desegregating schools across the town lines that have defined school districts in Connecticut for the last century.
Most suburban residents, legislative leaders said, recognize that schools in cities like Hartford, where 92 percent of the children are black and Hispanic and nearly two-thirds are poor, must be improved. But, the legislators said, they reject any argument that the inferior conditions are the result of racial barriers, and so they reject desegregation as a solution.
 
Skirting Racial Issue
 There is also broad sentiment, in both towns and cities, against the wide-scale reassignment and busing of students that people associate with desegregation plans.
"What I learned out of this whole experience is people's feelings, which are basically the same," said Representative Nancy Wyman, a Democrat from Tolland, who as co-chairwoman of the Education Committee played a large role in keeping the bill alive. "It's a fear on one side, and a realistic point of view on the other that we have to change to help our kids.
"You can walk into Hartford and people will say, just help us with our schools and make them better and leave our kids alone, and you can go down to Beacon Falls and they'll say the same thing," she continued. "Fix the schools where they need to be fixed."
The racial issue is so sensitive that in the seven hours of debate that began Thursday, even Representative Wyman would not directly acknowledge the bill's integration roots.
 
Parents Called 'Frightened'
 "Does student diversity mean racial diversity?" Representative Robert Farr, a Republican from West Hartford, asked her.
"It means all kinds of diversity," she replied, suggesting it could refer to children with physical handicaps. "If you want to talk about just racial diversity, that's your decision."
But Republicans, in proposing 10 amendments, including one to replace the bill with a statewide school-choice plan, repeatedly referred to the legislation as a desegregation plan.
"We're simply going to perpetuate the anxiety that parents now feel," Representative Paul J. Knierim of Simsbury, the ranking Republican on the Education Committee, said of the bill's planning process. "My constituents are absolutely frightened of what might happen to public schools."
Under the bill, local and regional planning groups made up of parents, elected officials, teachers and administrators will assess the needs of their public schools and draft regional plans. The planning phase would take place during 1994. State grants would be available for the 1995-96 school year.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: The Overview;
Clinton Takes His Fight For Budget on the Road

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
Facing an even more difficult task in the Senate than he had in the House of Representatives, President Clinton went back on the road today to generate political support for his budget.
At a rally in the courtyard of Philadelphia's City Hall, he implored the crowd to "stay with us, fight with us" to keep the plan on track in the Senate. 
 Mr. Clinton's goal was to build on the momentum from the cliffhanger vote for his program in the House of Representatives on Thursday night. The White House and the Democratic Congressional leadership were forced to pull out all stops to win the vote for the President's package, 219 to 213. Thirty-eight Democrats joined all 175 Republicans in opposition.
Many Democrats have complained that the Republicans and Ross Perot have dominated the public discourse on the budget so far. They say many of their constituents do not know, for instance, that the package includes spending cuts or that most of the tax increases would be borne by the wealthy.
About two-thirds of the higher taxes would be owed by the 1 percent of taxpayers with incomes above $200,000, and about three-quarters would be imposed on the 6 percent with incomes above $100,000.
As senators left the capital today for a 10-day recess, no one could confidently predict the eventual shape of the legislation. What is clear, however, is that the battle ahead will be bitter and partisan.
 
Counting Democratic Heads
 On the Senate Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over the bulk of the legislation and which has a history of operating in a bipartisan fashion, all nine Republicans are sworn to oppose the President's program. That means all 11 Democrats must vote for the measure to keep it alive, and one of them, David L. Boren of Oklahoma, has said he cannot support it in its current form.
Many lobbyists and staff assistants who are following every twist and turn of the legislation suggested that the whole plan might sink, either because Mr. Clinton was unwilling to make the compromises necessary to get it through the Senate or because concessions to the Senate would make it unpalatable to the House in its final form.
"Every time you try to do something in one area, it bulges out somewhere else," said Alan Kranowitz, a business lobbyist who once worked in the Reagan White House.
But others said they expected enactment of a bill, somewhat different from what the President proposed perhaps, but still recognizable. "There's a fundamental recognition up here that the Presidency is in profound need of support, and that's working to the advantage of passage," said a Democratic staff strategist in the Senate.
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a senior Republican on the Finance Committee, agreed with that analysis. In an interview, he said: "It'll have a contentious time -- no question about that -- in the Finance Committee. But I just would think when all is said and done, it will probably pass. They'll make enough adjustments to attract the required Democratic votes, and you'll still be able to recognize it as Clinton's."
 
Reciting the Predictable
 What other Senators said in public was more predictable.
Senator Boren reiterated that he could not support the package unless the ratio of spending cuts to tax increases was made larger and unless the proposed new fuel tax was dropped or significantly modified.
Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the Democratic chairman of the Budget Committee, said they expected the President's program to be approved basically intact.
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, disagreed completely. "I would say without fear of being wrong," he said on the "Morning News" program on CNN, "that this bill, this package, will not pass the Senate."
Mr. Domenici and all other Republicans in Congress, apparently, are opposing the President on both substantive and political grounds. Most of them say that the steep tax increases the President is proposing would be disastrous for an economy that seems to have little pep anyway. Further, they think that their reputation of favoring lower taxes, and the tax-and-spend charge they are leveling at Democrats, give them the best chance of picking up seats in Congress and regaining the White House in 1996.
Congressional Republicans have rarely been so united. Normally, some Republican Senators align themselves with Democrats on social and economic issues, just as some Democrats are often on the side of Republicans.
But Republican Senators got their backs up this spring after Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democratic chairman of the Appropriations Committee, tried to use parliamentary tricks to freeze them out of the debate on Mr. Clinton's program to stimulate the economy. The Republicans' filibuster forced the withdrawal of that legislation and the senators have been feeling their oats ever since.
 
Unusual Republican Unity
 The House tends to operate on more partisan terms than the Senate, but even in the House, it is very unusual for the entire Republican Party to hang together as happened Thursday night.
The President's political consultant, Paul Begala, who went with him to Philadelphia, said Mr. Clinton would make many more trips in the days ahead to sell his plan.
"We have to do a better job of communicating to the American people," Mr. Begala said. "They have not heard our side of the story."
In his speech, Mr. Clinton defended his proposed energy tax, which is under heavy fire in the Senate. Since all states, regardless of population, have two senators, those from oil producing states, who generally oppose the tax, have a disproportionate influence.
Mr. Clinton argued that the tax would cost typical families of four only $1 a month next year, $7 a month in 1995 and $17 a month in 1996.
If cutting the budget deficit results in lower interest rates, the President said, "You will save more in interest rates than you'll ever pay in the energy tax, and you'll have a healthier economy and lower deficit."

HEADLINE: New York Telephone Plans to Lay Off 600 Managers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The New York Telephone Company, the state's second-largest employer, said yesterday that it plans to lay off 600 low- to middle-level managers around the state next September. The cost-cutting move would pare $36 million, or 1.8 percent, from the company's $1.97 billion payroll.
The layoffs -- the third round of involuntary dismissals since March 1992 in cuts ordered by Nynex, the company's parent -- will affect 8 percent of New York Telephone's 7,700 managers in switching centers, installation and repair offices and technical support and operator service centers across the state. 
 John Bonomo, a company spokesman, said the layoffs were expected to have no impact on service. The installation of advanced equipment and changes in many operating procedures in recent years have streamlined the company's management, eliminating the need for hundreds of jobs, he said.
The layoffs were also expected to have little impact on the state economy. Bern Rotman, a spokesman for the state Department of Economic Development, said the total payroll in the state was $400 billion a year, and the loss of $36 million -- particularly spread around the state -- would not be significant.
But for managers losing jobs paying $37,000 to $68,000 a year, many of them long-time company employees, the layoffs will hit hard, coming in an economy still struggling to emerge from a multiyear recession that has eliminated thousands of job opportunities.
 
Two Months' Notice
 The nonunion workers to be laid off will be selected on various criteria, including performance, potential and management skills, Mr. Bonomo said, and will be notified on July 13, two months before the Sept. 10 layoffs. He said all would be eligible for two weeks' pay for each year of service and would be given counseling, retraining and other assistance.
New York Telephone, which has 40,200 workers and 6.5 million customers and as a major employer in the state is second only to the state government itself, laid off 800 management employees in March 1992 and 625 more last December.
Next September's layoffs will bring the three-round total, over 18 months, to slightly more than 2,000, and the company payroll will have been cut by more than $100 million. More layoffs are being borne by other Nynex subsidiaries, including New England Telephone and Nynex Mobile Communications.
The roots of cost-saving personnel cuts for telecommunications companies run deep. In the 1970's, New York Telephone and other phone companies hired bumper crops of young employees to handle an explosion in demand for telephones by Wall Street, the banking business and other sectors of a booming economy.
But two decades later, after a technological revolution in fiber optics and automated switching equipment that cut the need for white- and blue-collar workers, Nynex and its subsidiaries found themselves with thousands of managers in their mid-40's, too young to retire and too expensive to keep in an era of intense competition from smaller, more efficient telecommunications companies.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines by 27.40 On New Economic Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market dropped sharply yesterday, partly in reaction to a downward revision of first-quarter economic growth figures. But computerized sell programs amid surprisingly heavy trading before the long Memorial Day weekend probably exaggerated the declines, analysts said.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped as much as 44.56 points before closing at 3,527.43, down 27.40 points in a retreat from the record highs established earlier in the week. Still, the Dow managed a gain for the week of 34.60 points. The Standard & Poor's 500 dropped as much as 4.74 points yesterday before it closed down 2.22 points, to 450.19. 
 Investors were chilled by the Commerce Department's announcement in the morning of a downward revision of its first-quarter assessment of the economy. The gross domestic product, what the entire economy produces in goods and services, grew only at a nine-tenths of 1 percent annual rate, rather than the 1.8 percent initially reported a month ago.
 
Exodus From Securities
 But shortly before 1 P.M., the exodus of money from both stocks and bonds into, at least in part, gold reached its crest. Prices for the Dow component stocks firmed and so did yields on the long Treasury bond.
Gold prices then plummeted, but gold stocks, for the most part, did not follow. Contracts for the June delivery of gold on the Commodity Exchange in New York closed down $3.10, to $378.30 an ounce.
Yet Newmont Mining, which has typically tracked gold prices, closed up 1/8, to 52 3/8. Echo Bay Mines, as it has often been recently, was the most-active stock on the American Stock Exchange with 2.6 million shares changing hands. It closed up 1/4, to 12 1/4.
The Dow was dragged down mainly by seven stocks that dropped 1 point or more. The group was led by Aluminum Company of America, which dropped 1 1/2, to 67 1/2. The company's contract negotiations with its unions are expected to extend into the weekend.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped as well, down an especially sharp 4.06 points, to 700.53, and there was an even steeper decline in the Nasdaq 100 index, down 10.24 points, to 735.22. The American Stock Exchange market-value index declined 0.71 point, to 438.22.
Volume on the Big Board was 207.8 million shares, compared with Thursday's 300.8 million shares. The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index declined 0.83 point, to 248.60. Losing stocks outnumbered winners by 1,014 to 825.
 
The High-Technology Sector
 The high-technology sector posted especially deep declines. Computer-related stocks had been the hesitant leader in this very tentative market, but analysts are worried that a slow-growth economy will mean slow growth in technology sales as well. Hence the sharp drop in the Nasdaq composite index and the Nasdaq 100.
The 3Com Corporation was especially hard hit. With 13.8 million shares changing hands, it was by far the most-active stock on any exchange.
3Com dropped 11 1/2, to 27, after downgradings by analysts worried about the company's growth rate. 3Com makes computer networking products that would be useful to companies in a thriving economy but less so if the economy continues its lethargic growth.
Novell, also a computer-networking company, was the second most active at 6.7 million shares. Its shares declined 1 7/8, to 27 5/8 today, on no discernible news except for the pummeling of 3Com. It has seen its share price drop since last week as analysts expressed disappointment that Novell's strong earnings growth did not exceed their estimates.
Cisco Systems, the sixth-most-active stock in Nasdaq training and another computer-networking company, closed down 1, to 54.

HEADLINE: Administration Attacks Perot's Ad on Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration tried a preemptive strike against Ross Perot today as three top officials argued that his television commercial planned for Sunday was wrong in contending that the North American Free Trade Agreement would cost American jobs.
At a news conference today, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative; Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that Mr. Perot was using misleading and inaccurate information to attack the agreement. Mr. Kantor said he had discussed the agreement with Mr. Perot and believed the former Presidential candidate was being manipulated by the pact's opponents. 
 "I think their office has been victimized by some who are not exactly neutral on this subject, who have not looked at this in a serious way and are not dealing with the information in what I would call valid terms," Mr. Kantor said.
Mr. Perot has long criticized the free trade pact, which would eliminate import tariffs and other trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States.
 
Risk of Factory Shutdowns
 According to a partial text released by Mr. Perot's organization, United We Stand America, the commercial will emphasize the risk that American companies may move factories to Mexico if the pact is approved.
"The purpose of our program tonight is to alert millions of hard-working Americans that your job is being placed in jeopardy by this agreement," Mr. Perot says in the commercial. "Surely, you don't question the risk because you've already witnessed the collapse of entire communities when factories have been closed."
According to the partial text, Mr. Perot will cite Paterson, N.J., as a community that has experienced hardship because of the loss of a factory to Mexico. Mr. Perot has contended that 5.9 million American workers are employed by industries that may move to Mexico if the trade pact is approved.
At a rally last Sunday in Kansas City, Mo., Mr. Perot raised the possibility of protesting the trade pact by leading a march of his supporters down the Washington Mall to the Capitol. But Sharon L. Holman, the spokeswoman for Mr. Perot, said today that no planning was being done for such an event.
 
 
Poll: More Believe Perot
 In the latest sign of political trouble for the pact, the Cable News Network and Time magazine released a telephone poll this afternoon showing that only 25 percent of the 800 respondents believed the Clinton Administration's contention that the agreement would create jobs, while 63 percent believed Mr. Perot's claims that it would destroy jobs. The poll had a margin of error of 3.5 percentage points; it was conducted on Wednesday and Thursday.
"It's very, very clear to us that the American people relate to this and feel very strongly about jobs moving across the border," Ms. Holman said. "I don't think he is being manipulated by anybody."
Mr. Kantor closely duplicated Mr. Perot's folksy style during the news conference today. He used a series of simple black-and-white flip charts roughly the same size as those used by Mr. Perot in his commercials.
"I'm sorry, we don't have colored charts, we can't afford them in this Administration," Mr. Kantor joked.
Citing Commerce Department statistics, Mr. Kantor said today that 700,000 Americans worked last year on producing goods for the Mexican market, up from 275,000 in 1986.
With the pact, Mr. Kantor said, 900,000 Americans would be producing goods for Mexico by 1995. Without the pact, this export-related employment would drop to 500,000 by 1995, he warned.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops to a New Low Despite Fed's Rescue Effort

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar took another pounding yesterday, tumbling to a new low against the Japanese yen after a rescue attempt by the Federal Reserve failed.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 106.95 yen after recovering from a new low of 106.81 yen, which was reached in overseas markets. On Thursday, it fell to 107.10 yen in New York before edging higher to close at 107.20 yen. 
 The dollar also fell nearly 2 pfennigs against the German mark.
Dealers said the Federal Reserve was buying tens of millions of dollars, relatively little compared with the Bank of Japan's aggressive purchases of hundreds of millions of dollars. Although the Fed was more active than before, traders said they would not be convinced of its resolve to rescue the dollar unless the European central banks also joined in.
"There are absolutely no incentives visible to indicate dollar-buying at all," a European bank dealer in Tokyo said.
 
Interventions Expected
 The Federal Reserve's interventions were widely expected, said John Rothfield, international economist at the First Chicago Corporation, but the market was primed to meet the Fed head-on.
Japan's vice finance minister said Tokyo would take coordinated action with other Group of Seven industrial countries to counter the yen's rise. But the White House played down the idea of a special meeting of the group before its scheduled conference in early July, saying there was not enough time to organize it.
The dollar has been under pressure because of a widespread belief that the United States would prefer a stronger yen to help pare its huge trade deficit with Japan. Adding pressure was a Commerce Department report yesterday revising the first-quarter gross domestic product to show that total output had inched forward at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent, half the 1.8 percent rate estimated a month ago.
The German mark gained, helping to push the dollar below strong support at 1.60 marks. The dollar traded at 1.5850 marks at the New York close, down from Thursday's close of 1.6025 marks.
The British pound settled at $1.5630 in New York, up from $1.5587 Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Rises, Then Plunges, As Investors Cash In Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices fell sharply yesterday in a late round of profit taking after climbing early in the session to a 28-month high. Silver futures also retreated.
Gold for June delivery finished $3.10 lower at $378.30 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The volatile session featured prices as low as $375.50 and as high as $384.50, the highest gold price since Jan. 16, 1991. 
 Silver for July delivery fell 7.8 cents, to $4.622 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange.
The rally in precious metals, now in its third month, is encountering resistance as prices reach levels last seen just before the Persian Gulf war, said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., in Weehawken, N.J.
"It's understandable that we're going to get profit taking at these levels," he said. "It doesn't necessarily mean the bull move is over."
In fact, demand for gold continued to broaden yesterday, with many new investors entering the market before it turned lower, said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metals trading for Credit Suisse in New York.
The dollar's decline against the Japanese yen, which has potentially inflationary implications, continued to support gold prices, the analysts said.
Investors were also emboldened by a lack of action by the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates to fight inflation, Mr. Savaiko said.
"Some players in the gold market are calling the Fed's bluff," he said. "They don't think the Fed can afford to tighten and raise interest rates in light of the fragile state of the U.S. economy right now."
On other commodity markets, crude oil futures slipped; livestock and meat futures were mixed, and grains and soybeans were mixed. Trading volume was light on most markets just before the three-day Memorial Day weekend.
On the Mercantile Exchange in New York, light crude oil for July delivery slipped 4 cents, to $20.02 a barrel; June heating oil rose 0.30 cent, to 54.86 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline fell 0.29 cent, to 57.83 cents a gallon, and July natural gas rose 3.7 cents, to $2.141 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Most cattle futures rose and pork futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle for June delivery rose 0.07 cent, to 75.32 cents a pound; August feeder cattle rose 0.08 cent, to 85.35 cents a pound; June live hogs fell 0.53 cent, to 51.37 cents a pound, and July frozen pork bellies fell 1.05 cents, to 39.40 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Computer Code Plan Challenged

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The nation's largest computer makers have challenged a Clinton Administration plan to standardize a high-technology coding system that would let law-enforcement officials wiretap telephone calls and computer data transmissions.
The manufacturers say modern computer coding technology is essential for commerce and industry and cannot be restricted by the Government without hurting business. 
 The coding plan, developed secretly by the National Security Agency, was proposed last month by the National Institute for Standards and Technology, a Commerce Department agency. It calls for placing a special computer chip called the Clipper in a system that would encode telephone conversations.
Law-enforcement officials would be able to create a numeric "master key" that provides access to data and telephone transmissions by presenting a warrant to two separate agencies charged with protecting pieces of the key. The idea is that splitting the key would make it harder for Government officials or others to abuse the master key.
 
Plan Called Unworkable
 But the plan has drawn criticism from many computer researchers and civil libertarians who say that it would be unworkable and would have the potential to threaten privacy. On Thursday, 26 computer makers issued a statement criticizing the economic viability of the Clipper plan.
"We're going to work through our concerns with the Government," said Ollie Smoot, the executive vice president of the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association, a Washington trade organization. "The White House has made a commitment to listen."
The computer makers' statement was prepared for public testimony before the Computer System Security and Privacy Advisory Board, a Government review panel, which will begin three days of hearings on Wednesday on the Clipper plan and other public cryptography issues.
In their statement, the computer makers say that "encryption issues no longer can be treated as the province of only a small circle of national security, law-enforcement and technology experts."
Companies signing the statement included Apple Computer, A.T.& T., Compaq Computer, Digital Equipment, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., NCR, Tandem Computers and Xerox among others.
The association also raised questions about the viability of the coding plan, saying it would effectively handicap American computer and telecommunications equipment makers overseas. The group said that few foreign buyers would be willing to buy a coding device if the National Security Agency or law-enforcement agencies had access to a master key.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET;
Clinton's Poll Rating Sinks To a Historical Low Point

 BODY:
President Clinton's job performance rating is lower at this point in his term than that of any President since World War II, according to two national polls made public yesterday.
Most of the interviewing in the polls, both conducted Wednesday and Thursday, occurred before the House of Representatives narrowly passed Mr. Clinton's economic program on Thursday night. 
 A Time Magazine/CNN poll found 36 percent of Americans approving of the way the President was handling his job, while 50 percent disapproved, and 14 percent expressed no opinion. That poll was taken by Yankelovich Partners with 800 adults nationwide.
A Newsweek poll found identical results. That survey was conducted by Princeton Survey Research Associates with 750 adults nationwide.
Each telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Mr. Clinton's early-term ratings are the lowest of any President since modern poll taking began, in the second term of Presdent Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
Of the Presidents since then, Gerald Ford had the approval rating closest to Mr. Clinton's at an equivalent point in his term, with 42 percent approval in a Gallup Poll taken in December of 1974, three months after he had issued a pardon for former President Richard Nixon.
The other eight Presidents all had considerably higher ratings at this juncture. Just above Mr. Ford was Ronald Reagan, who had 59 percent approval in a Gallup Poll in June 1981. The highest was Harry Truman who had 92 percent approval in an August 1945 Gallup Poll, several months after the end of World War II.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 5, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Saturday comparing President Clinton's job aproval rating with that of his predecessors mischaracterized the timing of a Gallup poll taken in August 1945. That poll, in which 92 percent of those surveyed approved of the way Harry S. Truman was handling his job as President, was taken several months after the German surrender and two weeks after the Japanese surrender, not several months after the end of World War II.

HEADLINE: The Everything Solution

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Bendix; Jeffrey Bendix is a writer.

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
The Clintons and their brain trust think the solution to the health care crisis is managed competition. The idea is that health care consumers -- all of us -- will be organized into large purchasing cooperatives. The size of these cooperatives will enable them to bargain down the price of care they buy from hospitals and doctors. That's the theory, anyway.
I don't know if managed competition will work. But even if it doesn't, the idea behind it -- solving a problem by grouping more people into an existing process -- could be applied to lots of other areas of our national life. The National Hockey League is already experimenting with the idea. It has been trying to prop up sagging revenues by allowing almost every team into the playoffs. 
 How might this idea work in solving other problems? Let's start with violent crime. Using a concept we might call "managed security," the Government could easily take care of the problem by buying guns for everyone. (This is a variation of an idea suggested by the syndicated columnist Mike Royko at the height of the skyjacking craze. His solution: Arm all the passengers.)
We might reduce crime further by organizing everyone into "security cooperatives," encompassing blocks or entire neighborhoods. These cooperatives would be large and powerful enough to have round-the-clock patrols, armored vehicles or anything else members wanted to make themselves feel secure.
Just think of how managed security could improve our lives. First, we would all feel safer knowing we could blow away any hoodlum foolish enough to attack us. It would lower unemployment, as weapons makers (and undertakers) geared up to meet demand. Best of all, the National Rifle Association, having attained its nirvana of a gun in every household, would lose the reason for its existence.
Before trying managed security on a national scale, it would be a good idea to try a local experiment. Fortunately, one place already is doing just that. Nearly one million handguns have been sold in Los Angeles County in the past 10 years -- one for every nine residents -- and those are just the legal transactions.
A reporter for The New Republic, describing preparations for anticipated rioting after the second Rodney King verdict, wrote: "I know of at least one affluent neighborhood where residents have hired a full-time guard on each block. And so many neighborhoods have plans for barricading streets that L.A. will become a giant obstacle course if rioting breaks out." Sure, getting to the grocery store might be a little trickier, but at least you'd feel secure.
Another dilemma that Government-sponsored inclusion might address is voter apathy. Politics turns off ordinary people, the media tell us, because they feel their votes don't matter, that they have no chance of being heard over the money of the special interests and political-action committees.
Here, too, the answer is simple: The Government need only subsidize PAC membership for everyone. That way, we will each have someone looking out for our interests in Washington, we will all feel included in the process and voter turnout will swell.
Another advantage to universal PAC membership: With everyone part of a special interest, Congress will be in perpetual gridlock, no new legislation will get passed and we won't have to listen to Rush Limbaugh and other talk-radio ranters complaining about Government intervention in our lives.
To the objection that there aren't enough PAC's for all of us, I would point out that there are 4,100 registered PAC's lobbying Congress. That works out to about 610,000 Americans per PAC, considerably less than the current membership of such lobbying heavyweights as the American Medical Association and Common Cause.
